Dengue fever, RVF, and chikungunya are vector-borne diseases, while cholera is waterborne. The increase of these outbreaks can be linked to the recent floods in the country that have left large pools of stagnant water, which are breeding sites for various types of vectors such as mosquitoes and houseflies. Government authorities and humanitarian partners are actively responding to these outbreaks across the country, providing health assistance, vaccinations where appropriate, and vector control interventions.\n\nRift Valley fever\n---------------\nThere are 193 Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases -- including 4 deaths -- reported in Red Sea, River Nile, and Khartoum states since the onset of the disease on 28 Sept until 22 Oct 2019. The majority of cases (100) are in Red Sea. Of all cases reported, 94.8% have affected people over 5 years of age, and 83% are male.\n\nRift Valley fever response\n--------------------------\nSimilar to the dengue response, SMoH activated response taskforce meetings and developed state-level preparedness and response plans. There has been a joint investigation by the SMoH, WHO, and the Ministry of Animal Resources (MoAR) in locations where the outbreak has occurred. Case definition and management training has been provided to 131 medical staff, and an isolation center has been established in Tagadom hospital in Red Sea state. In addition, 2200 mosquito nets have been distributed, 1330 homes have been inspected for breeding sites, and 3542 homes have been fogged in the state. Health promotion activities have been carried out at the household and community levels.\n\nThe major gaps and challenges faced are the limited number of partners involved in response activities, the need for better coordination between humanitarian partners and MoAR [Ministry of Agriculture], and the need to scale up activities in affected states. In addition, a more comprehensive plan needs to be developed between the government authorities and partners; more training in surveillance and case management is required; and social mobilization and vector control activities need to be intensified.\n\nRVF is a viral disease that is spread either through the bite of an infected mosquito or by touching infected animal blood, breathing in the air around an infected animal being butchered, or drinking raw milk from an infected animal. The disease is spread between cows, sheep, goats, and camels by mosquitoes. Infection does not appear to be transmitted from person to person.\n\nVaccinating animals against the disease before the outbreak occurs can prevent it from being transmitted to humans. Other methods include eradicating mosquito breeding sites and avoiding their bites. If an outbreak occurs, limiting the movement of animals will reduce the spread of the disease. As a result, the declaration of RVF can have an impact on international and domestic livestock economies. Saudi Arabia has announced a ban on importing livestock from Sudan in response to the announcement of World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) concerning documented cases of RVF.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The acute need for a 'One Health' approach, encompassing all of Sudan's partners, is clearly indicated in the above report. - Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[2] Egypt bans Sudanese cattle imports after RVF outbreak\nDate: Thu 24 Oct 2019\nSource: Enterprise Press (Cairo) [edited]\nhttps://enterprise.press/stories/2019/10/24/egyptian-authorities-ban-sudanese-cattle-imports-after-rift-valley-outbreak/\n\n\nEgypt has banned the import of cattle from Sudan after an outbreak of Rift Valley fever in eastern Sudan announced by the World Organization for Animal Health, the local press reports.\n\nRift Valley fever is a virus that affects both animals and humans that can cause significant economic harm if allowed to spread. Sudan's health minister said this week that authorities have detected 135 cases in areas near the Red Sea and north Darfur.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A recent (2018) study addressed the risk of RVF introduction into and transmission within Egypt by camel imports from Sudan (Ref. 1). The results indicated that the main risk of RVFV introduction is posed by the continuous flow of a large number of camels coming from Sudan. Their numbers were steadily increasing. During 2015 (last analysed year), it was about 18 000 per month. No seasonal pattern was observed in the amount of camels imported (in difference with cattle, which make a significantly smaller import slice, mainly concentrated in the Eid-el-Adha festivities season). Most of the camels arrived from western Sudan (where the current event is located) to Abu Simbel quarantine in south-central Egypt. The risk of RVFV transmission by vectors (in Egypt being mainly _Culex pipiens_) is restricted to the areas surrounding the Nile River, and does not vary significantly throughout the year. Imported camels are taken to quarantines, where the risk of RVFV transmission by vectors is generally low. Then they are taken to animal markets or slaughterhouses, many located in populated areas, where the risk of RVFV transmission to animals or humans is much higher. The measures currently implemented (quarantines, vaccination, or testing) seem, according to the study, to have a limited effect in reducing the risk of RVFV introduction; the authors propose other (risk-based) surveillance strategies. - Mod.AS\n\nRef. 1: Napp S, Chevalier V, Busquets N, Calistri P, Casal J, Attia M, et al.: Understanding the legal trade of cattle and camels and the derived risk of Rift Valley fever introduction into and transmission within Egypt. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2018; 12(1): e0006143. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pntd.0006143.]\n\n******\n[3] Egypt's alert, preventive measures, and applied coordination\nDate: Thu 24 Oct 2019\nSource: MBS News [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.mbs.news/2019/10/after-a-decision-from-saudi-arabia-emergency-in-egypt-and-urgent-measures-to-protect-the-country.html\n\n\nEgypt and Saudi Arabia have raised their readiness to the maximum amid warnings of a threat from Sudan, amid pleas to protect the borders of the 2 countries significantly.\n\nThe Egyptian 'Portal News' published a statement from the Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation, and the General Authority for Veterinary Services, [proclaiming] a state of extreme emergency amid suspicion of the disease Rift Valley fever in northeastern Sudan.\n\nThe website quoted Abdul Hakim Mahmoud, head of the General Authority for Veterinary Services, as saying, 'The Authority is taking precautionary measures after the emergence of suspected cases of RVF.'\n\nThe agency promptly took action to protect the country from the deadly disease by vaccinating vulnerable animals in border areas in the south of the country.\n\nMahmoud said, 'Precautionary measures include restricting the movement of animals to and from the border provinces unless they [carry an ear tag with number] and [the consignment is] accompanied by a registration card where immunization against the disease [is testified].'\n\n'Coordination is also taking place with the Ministry of Local Development to direct governors in border governorates to spray cars coming from Sudan and their animals,' he added. 'Quarantines in border governorates also operate 24 hours a day, and animals from them are checked.'\n\nSaudi Arabia has also announced a moratorium on livestock imports from Sudan, fearing that the RVF could spill into the kingdom.\n\nThe Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture announced the suspension of the Kingdom's imports of live cattle from the Republic of Sudan, following the announcement of the World Organization for Animal Health [OIE] [about] the emergence of cases of RVF in Sudan, in addition to the suspension of imports of live cattle from Djibouti Kingdom, which has been denied access to the Kingdom. [The main Saudi imports from Sudan involve sheep, not cattle; is there a translational error here? Is sheep import being continued? - Mod.AS]\n\nIn addition, the ministry explained that it has started coordination directly to assess the current situation inside the Kingdom with the Ministry of Health and the National Center for Disease Prevention and Control and with neighboring countries and continued coordination with the OIE.\n\nFor its part, Sudan, in remarks quoted by the Sudanese newspaper 'Sayha,' [claims that] all cattle returned by Saudi Arabia [are free] of Rift Valley fever. The Port Sudan Port Administration said that it has conducted comprehensive tests for all cattle that Saudi Arabia recently returned and confirmed that they are all free of diseases, and there were no cases.\n\nThe director of the port 'Heydob,' Mohamed Hassan Mokhtar, said, 'Veterinary quarantines have done their part in the examination and review of livestock, and there was no case of animal disease. I declare that the veterinary quarantine is in the process of submitting the reports of doctors to the competent authorities.'\n\nMokhtar attributed the causes of livestock deaths to hunger and lack of water for long periods of detention during the period of return to Sudan and called for lifting of the ban on the export of cattle for lack of reasons for non-export.\n\nSource link: Sputnik News, in Arabic, at https://tinyurl.com/y3p38agk.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since early September 2019, there have been conflicting media reports from Sudan about the spatial dissemination of RVF, the date of the event's start, and the spectrum of the animal species involved. Earlier reports said that since early September 2019, undiagnosed fever disease cases in humans and cattle were reported from the states Red Sea and River Nile. According to the media, suspected cases in humans have been reported from additional states, namely the above-mentioned Khartoum as well as North Darfur and Kassala ( 20191006.6712623). No official confirmation of RVF, suspected in these locations, has become available.\n\nIn their immediate notification on RVF to the OIE, dated 13 Sep 2019, the Sudanese veterinary authorities claimed that 'there were few abortions in goat herds observed after heavy flooding in September 2019,' 'there is no cattle or sheep population in the area,' and the outbreak occurred 'in a dry area within the series of the Red Sea Hills.' No follow-up report has been submitted since, nor official information on the animal disease situation in other locations/states from where human haemorrhagic disease has been reported.\n\nOfficial information on RVF in Sudan is available on the website of WHO's Eastern Mediterranean Region, to which Sudan belongs (similarly to some other African countries such as Lybia, Egypt, and Somali). The table 'Current outbreaks in the WHO Eastern Mediterranean Region' (at http://www.emro.who.int/pandemic-epidemic-diseases/outbreaks/index.html) includes the following updated information on notifiable diseases in Sudan, of which 3 are vectorborne:\n\nCountry / Diseases / Cases / Deaths / CFR (%) / Date of event\nSudan / cholera / 309 / 8 / 2.6% / August 2019\nSudan / chikungunya / 10 / 0 / - / September 2019\nSudan / dengue / 135 / 1 / 0.7% / August 2019\nSudan / Rift Valley fever / 76 / 2 / 2.6% / September 2019\n\nSudan is a major exporter of live animals, mainly sheep and goats. In 2017, this export's value was more than USD 476 million; most of the export is destined for Saudi Arabia and the Gulf States. There is also export of camels, most of them going on hoof to Egypt. In the past, both Saudia and Egypt have experienced outbreaks of RVF. While in Saudia, east African countries, in particular around the Horn of Africa, were the suspected origin of infection; in Egypt, the suspicion involved mainly camels from Sudan. Enhanced transparency and adequate pre-export measures, in line with OIE's requirements, may be helpful in minimizing the losses. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The total number reported number of human cases since the outbreak began has been difficult to tally, since the cases have been widely scattered over 3 states. The above report does provide a total of 193 cases with 4 deaths. The ban of export of Sudanese livestock into Egypt will cause economic and social hardship for livestock owners in Sudan. In the absence of banks or similar institutions of financial support, livestock represent a kind of living bank account for their owners. Inability to export represents a loss of cash flow. It is likely that RVF virus will persist in this area in transovarially infected eggs of _Aedes_ mosquito vectors. These eggs can remain viable for long periods of time and hatch when flooded during future rain events, with subsequent emergence of infected females ready to transmit the virus. This risk provides justification for keeping livestock in the area well vaccinated into the future. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSudan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRVF is a viral disease that is spread either through the bite of an infected mosquito or by touching infected animal blood, breathing in the air around an infected animal being butchered, or drinking raw milk from an infected animal. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttps://lejournaldemayotte.yt/2019/05/27/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-apparition-de-nouveaux-cas-a-lest-et-au-sud/\n\n\nTo limit the spread of cases [of Rift Valley fever (RVF)], the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS Indian Ocean and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF) reminds all of the importance of prevention measures for protect from the disease [figure: Map of households as of 22 May 2019. New geographic areas affected.]\n\nEpidemiological situation as of 24 May 2019:\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November [2018]):\n- samples taken by veterinarians on sick animals or during abortions have identified 121 outbreaks of sick animals (including 97 cattle and 24 small ruminants);\n- the CHM laboratory reported 134 human cases of RVF at the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS) of Mayotte.\n\nAlthough the vast majority of human cases of RVF do not show signs of severity, 2 serious forms have been reported.\n\nThe Mahoran population is called to be vigilant at the end of Ramadan.\n\nThe rainy season, favoring the proliferation of mosquitoes, is coming to an end and should be accompanied by a reduction of animal cases. However, in the run-up to Eid el Fitr and the big wedding season, the health authorities remind the population to be vigilant in case of slaughter of animals, consumption of meat, and consumption of curdled milk. It is strongly recommended to follow the recommendations to protect yourself from the disease.\n\nRecommendations:\nIt is recommended to protect yourself when cutting zebu [cattle] carcasses.\n\nIn ruminants: Monitoring of Rift Valley fever includes monitoring of abortions. Thus, farmers are required to report promptly to veterinarians any abortions or stillbirths occurring in their animals or sick animals in order to take samples in search of the disease.\n\nAn order prohibiting the marketing of untreated milk has been in force since 27 Feb 2019. A decree prohibiting the export of live animals, raw meat, and milk produced by the ruminant farms of the country has been in force since 20 Mar 2019.\n\nIn humans: The disease is usually manifested by an influenza-like illness: high fever (39 C [102 F]), muscle and/or joint pain, severe headache, and tiredness. In the vast majority of cases, recovery occurs within a few days. It is recommended to consult a doctor as soon as the signs appear so that samples can be taken to see whether they are positive for the disease.\n\nRecommendations to protect yourself from the disease:\n\nFor farmers and people in contact with animals:\n- wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats);\n- do not handle sick or aborted animals without protection, or abortion products;\n- do not handle animal carcasses without protection;\n- wear gloves, goggles, and especially a mask for the slaughter of any animal. Indeed, infected animals may not present any signs, whereas they can transmit the virus.\n\nFor food:\n- boil the milk;\n- do not consume curd unless it has been boiled and then curdled with ferment of lactic acid;\n- wash hands after cutting meat;\n- cook the meat well;\n- never eat the meat of a sick animal.\n\nTo protect yourself from mosquito bites:\n- eliminate breeding sites; empty all containers that may contain water;\n- use mosquito nets and repellents.\n\nIn case of appearance of symptoms:\n- consult your doctor immediately.\n\n[byline: Anne Perzo]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the 12 May 2019 report, the number of animal cases has increased from 119 to 121 cases, and human cases currently number 134. Observation of the recommendations and requirements listed above should help to reduce the number of human and animal cases. As Mod.AS noted in an earlier post, a French delegation included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019: 'What about vaccination? To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.' Such authorization deserves early consideration. It would be of interest to know what role, if any, mosquito vectors are playing in transmission of RVF virus during the current outbreak. If aedes mosquitoes are involved, there is a risk of transovarial transmission of the virus that can persist for months in mosquito eggs with resumption of transmission when those eggs hatch and infected adult female mosquitoes emerge. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nR\u00e9gion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]", "summary": "\n\nRecommendations to protect yourself from the disease:\n\nFor farmers and people in contact with animals:\n- wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats);\n- do not handle sick or aborted animals without protection, or abortion products;\n- do not handle animal carcasses without protection;\n- wear gloves, goggles, and especially a mask for the slaughter of any animal. \n\n[byline: Anne Perzo]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the 12 May 2019 report, the number of animal cases has increased from 119 to 121 cases, and human cases currently number 134. by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Egypt's concerns\nDate: Wed 16 Oct 2019\nSource: MBS News/sputnik [abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.mbs.news/2019/10/rift-valley-fever-is-the-most-serious-disease-common-to-animals-and-humans.html\n\n\nSudan's announcement of outbreaks of 'Rift Valley fever' in some states of Sudan has raised serious concerns in neighboring countries that import live cattle from Sudan and raised alertness among quarantine and control agencies in Egypt for fear of transmission of the disease, which resulted in a disaster in 1977 [in Egypt].\n\nDr. Ibrahim El-Bendary, (formerly) director of preventive medicine at the Egyptian Veterinary Services Authority (formerly) told Sputnik that since Egypt started importing cattle from Sudan, the disease has spread to us in 1977. It was 1st reported in the southernmost province of Aswan and caused significant losses in livestock. At the time, it was equivalent to 82 million pounds, and there were cases of human deaths and injuries, where the injuries amounted to 18 000 cases, while the number of deaths was about 518. The disease is transmitted between humans and animals through mosquitoes and insects, and symptoms of the disease appear in the animal in 2 forms, namely abortions and, in the most severe form, the death of young animals.\n\nDr. Youssef Mamdouh, (formerly) head of the Central Reservation Department in the Veterinary Services, told Sputnik that when RVF emerges in any of the countries from which live livestock are imported, the animals should be quarantined, sampled, subsequently vaccinated, and kept for 3 weeks before being sent to their destination. He told Sputnik that in 2009 Egypt stopped importing livestock from Sudan because of the emergence of the disease. All quarantine procedures are to be applied in the territory of the exporting country, not in the importing country. It affects all types of livestock, including camels.\n\nThe Egyptian Ministry of Agriculture and Land Reclamation announced that all precautionary measures were taken after the media circulated on the suspicion of cases of Rift Valley cattle disease in the northeastern areas of Sudan, which caused the death and stress of some cattle.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Further information on the 1977 RVF event in Egypt:\nMeegan JM. Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg. 1979; 73(6): 618-23. doi: 10.1016/0035-9203(79)90004-x. https://doi.org/10.1016/0035-9203(79)90004-X.\n- Mod.AS]\n\n******\n[4] Sudan discontinues exports of livestock\nDate: Thu 17 Oct 2019\nSource: Khartoum Electronic Media Centre [edited]\nhttp://www.en.khartoumcenter.com/animal-resources-ministry-names-a-committee-to-probe-into-water-related-diseases/\n\n\nThe newly appointed minister of Animal Resources, Alam al-Din Abdalla, on Wednesday [16 Oct 2019] named an urgent committee to probe into emergence of water-related diseases on animals and man. 'We've banned export of livestock until newly emerged cases of Rift Valley fever are handled,' the minister said in statements.\n\nThe ministry's undersecretary, according to SUNA [Sudan News Agency], pointed to some Rift Valley cases in Red Sea and River Nile states estimated at 10-15 heads of goats, confirming that all these cases have been dealt with in collaboration with World Health Organization-Animal.\n\n[Byline: Khalid Mohamed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Sudan is a major exporter of live animals, mainly sheep and goats (Ref 1). In 2017, this export's value was more than USD 476 million; most of the export is destined for Saudi Arabia and the Gulf States. There is also export of camels, most of them going on the hoof to Egypt and Libya.\n\nThe transparency exercised during the current event by Sudan's Ministry of Health and the decision of the Agriculture Ministry to temporarily discontinue animal exports has, not surprisingly, met opposition, mainly by the economically involved parties (https://www.assayha.net/now/archives/18575/18575, in Arabic). The export-ban decision may, in the long run, positively contribute to the maintenance of uninterrupted exports, provided measures, in particular control upon intranational animal movements, and preventive mass vaccinations in hitherto not-infected regions, are undertaken at the earliest while consignments are certified in line with OIE's prescribed requirements.\n\nFAO has advised veterinary services and livestock farmers' communities in Sudan, South Sudan, Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Burundi, Rwanda, Somalia, Uganda, and United Republic of Tanzania to remain vigilant to the potential occurrence and spread of RVF in humans and/or animals. Egypt, Libya, Chad, Democratic Republic of Congo, Central African Republic, as well as Saudi Arabia and Yemen are also considered at risk of occurrence. The Egyptian 1977 disastrous RVF event should be kept in mind; it demonstrated how RVF-virgin regions may get infected when the virus is introduced, most probably by viraemic animals, into ecologically 'receptive' regions when suitable environmental conditions for the RVF vector amplification prevail.\n\nReference\nWilson RT. Mayotte (11): human, epidemiology, animal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6465247", "date": "2019-05-11 16:19:15", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (11): HUMAN, EPIDEMIOLOGY, ANIMAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 11 May 2019\nSource: Revue Francophone des Laboratoires May 2019, no. 512, p. 18 [in French, transl., abridged, edited]\nhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1773035X19302515?via%3Dihub (subscription)\n\n\nIn February 2019, 63 cases of Rift Valley fever were diagnosed by PCR at the Mayotte hospital laboratory. The first 5 cases were detected in November 2018 by the hospital laboratory and confirmed by the Reunion Reference Center. The vector control center and the health emergency unit of the ARS OI [The Indian Ocean Health Agency] were able to analyze the epidemiology of 36 cases: 21 subjects had been in direct contact with animals and 5 others lived nearby; the last 5 declared no direct or indirect contact with animals. In addition, in 15 cases, patients had consumed raw or curdled milk. Finally, it is interesting to note that 21 patients resided in the communes of west-central Mayotte. With regard to the 63 confirmed cases, the average age of the patients was 38 years (range, 10 to 74 years), of which 16% were under 20 years, with a male/female sex ratio of 4. In addition, 29 patients lived in rural or semi-urban dwellings, 9 of whom lived in traditional huts. In terms of symptoms, 24 patients had headache, 19 arthralgia, 17 myalgia, 14 asthenia, 6 retro-orbital pain, and 6 nausea and vomiting. An entomological survey found several mosquito species, especially _Culex_, _Aedes_, _Anopheles_ and _Mansonia_.\n\nAt the same time, samples taken from farms in which abortions were reported identified 33 outbreaks of 1 to 6 animals, including 25 cattle and 8 small ruminants [the figures have increased since; see in comments].\n\nRift Valley fever, which has been present in Mayotte for a long time, had disappeared in the past decade, with 10 patients detected in 2008 following an epidemic in Kenya. Then there was a steady regression of verified seroprevalence on ruminants. But this seroprevalence rose to 3.6% in 2017 and then to 10.1% in 2018, indicating a new circulation of the virus. This is probably due to illegal and continuous importation of contaminated livestock.\n\n[By: Dr. Patrice Bouree]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mayotte's health authorities published on Sat 11 May 2019 the following update.\n\n'Epidemiological situation as of May 10, 2019.\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018):\n1. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n2. Preventing illegal introduction of ruminants;\n2. Preventive vaccination of cattle, sheep and goats (preferably, with an inactivated RVF vaccine; see 20190422.6434655). - Mod.AS\n\nIt would be of interest to know what role, if any, mosquito vectors are playing in transmission of RVF virus during the current outbreak. The causative agent is a _Phlebovirus_ (Bunyaviridae), and the vector are mosquitos of different genera, especially _Aedes_. Infection in humans causes influenza-like illness complicated by hemorrhagic fever, encephalitis, ocular damage, and, in some cases, death. Wild ruminants, especially African buffalos, and some domestic ruminants may be involved in the maintenance of RVF virus. Natural and experimental infections by RVF virus have been documented in several mammalian orders, including Artiodactyla, Chiroptera, Rodentia, Primata (nonhuman), Perissodactyla, Carnivora, and others. Mosquitos are considered to be the maintenance hosts, and wild ruminants and other mammals may serve as amplifying hosts. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nChad: "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (08): INCREASE IN CASES, HUMAN, CATTLE\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 20 Apr 2019\nSource: Le Journal de Mayotte [in French trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttps://lejournaldemayotte.yt/2019/04/20/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-5-nouveaux-cas-humains-et-12-chez-les-animaux-dans-la-semaine/\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte. After a lull, the number of cases is increasing again. Preventive measures should be carefully followed.\n\nDuring the past week, 12 new animal foci and 5 new human cases have been reported, for a total of 104 animal foci and 122 human cases since the 1st cases occurred at the end of November 2018. In this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS [Regional Health Agency] Indian Ocean [OI] and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF) issues a reminder of the importance of prevention measures to protect against the disease.\n\nEpidemiological situation as of 18 Apr 2019\n-------------------------------------------\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November [2018]): Samples taken by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 104 foci of sick animals (including 82 bovines). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and north-west of the island. Additional outbreaks have appeared since the end of March [2019] in the communes of Dembeni, as well as on Petite Terre.\n\nThe CHM [Mayotte Hospital Center] laboratory reported 122 human cases of RVF from monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS/[Alert and Health Management Unit]) of Mayotte.\n\nAfter a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March [2019], a new increase has been observed since early April. Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and north-west of the island.\n\nRecommendations\n---------------\nIn ruminants:\nMonitoring of Rift Valley fever includes monitoring of abortions. Thus, farmers are required to report promptly to veterinarians any abortions or stillbirths occurring in their animals or sick animals in order to take samples in search of the disease.\n\nAn order prohibiting the marketing of untreated milk has been in force since 27 Feb 2019. A decree prohibiting the export of live animals, raw meat and milk produced by the ruminant farms of the country has been in force since 20 Mar 2019.\n\nIn humans:\nThe disease is usually manifested by an influenza-like illness: high fever (39 C [102 F]), muscle and/or joint pain, severe headache, tiredness. In the vast majority of cases, healing occurs within a few days. It is recommended to consult a doctor as soon as the signs appear so that the samples to diagnose the disease are taken.\n\nRecommendations to protect against disease\n------------------------------------------\nFor farmers and people in contact with animals:\n- wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats);\n- do not handle sick or aborted animals or abortion products without protection;\n- do not handle animal carcasses without protection;\n- must wear gloves, goggles, and especially a mask for the slaughter of any animal. Indeed, infected animals may not present any signs, whereas they can transmit the virus.\n\nFor food:\n- boil the milk;\n- do not consume curd unless it has been boiled and then curdled with fermentation of lactic acid;\n- wash hands after cutting meat;\n- cook the meat well;\n- never eat the meat of a sick animal.\n\nTo protect yourself from mosquito bites:\n- eliminate breeding sites, empty all containers that may contain water;\n- use mosquito nets and repellents.\n\nIn case of appearance of symptoms:\n- consult your doctor immediately.\n\n[Byline: Anne Perzo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[After a lull in transmission, cases of Rift Valley fever in humans and livestock continue to increase slowly on Mayotte Island.\n\nProMED-mail posted a summary of the EU-Health and Food Safety DG-Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCPAFF) 21 Mar 2019 committee meeting (see Rift Valley fever - Mayotte (06): animal, human, control, epidemiology 20190328.6391591) that lists the same precautions as above. In this post, Mod.AS commented that 'the introduction of RVF could have occurred either by traded animals or windborne infected vectors. The tropical ecological/climatic situation in Mayotte is not similar to the East African situation (and consequent RVF epidemiology), characterised by periodic exacerbations of latent endemic foci of infection or dormant mosquito larvae.'\n\nAs noted earlier, it would be of interest to know whether _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes are transmitting RVF virus on Mayotte and whether they are transovarially transmitting the virus to their eggs, as is the case in West Africa. These eggs can persist for long periods of time until flooded, when they hatch and develop into infected adults that can transmit the virus. This is not likely to occur if other genera of vector mosquitoes are transmitting the virus on Mayotte, in which case the outbreak can be expected to eventually die out. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nRegion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]", "summary": "For food:\n- boil the milk;\n- do not consume curd unless it has been boiled and then curdled with fermentation of lactic acid;\n- wash hands after cutting meat;\n- cook the meat well;\n- never eat the meat of a sick animal. In case of appearance of symptoms:\n- consult your doctor immediately.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": ["influenza-like illness"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2019-02-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-04-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Africa", "country": "Somalia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6434655", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Mayotte (09): animal, human, control, prevention", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6434655", "date": "2019-04-22 14:22:38", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAYOTTE (09): ANIMAL, HUMAN, CONTROL, PREVENTION\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 22 Apr 2019\nFrom: Arnon Shimshony <arnon@promedmail.org> [edited]\n\n\nCommencing end November 2018, an epidemic of Rift valley fever (RVF) has been ongoing in Mayotte, a French overseas archipelago department in the Indian Ocean, to present. After a steady decline in cases during the last 3 weeks of March 2019, a new increase has been observed since early April. During the past week, 12 new foci of sick animals and 5 new human cases have been reported, for a total of 104 animal foci (including 82 bovines) and 122 human cases since the start of the event ( 20190420.6433086).\n\nRVF had been circulating in Mayotte at least since early 2007, probably introduced there by the illegal importation of live infected ruminants from other Comoros islands (ref 2).\n\nThe economic activity of Mayotte (population, about 270 000), is based primarily on the agricultural sector, mainly fishing and livestock raising. Mayotte's livestock sector includes 4000 farms keeping 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants (2019 statistics, ref 1). The RVF losses to the livestock industry, caused by death, abortions, decreased production, veterinary treatment costs/medicines, movement restrictions, etc., are yet to be calculated.\n\nThe zoonotic impact of RVF is similarly deleterious. Infected humans suffer a serious sickness and complications. During the current event, their number is nearing 50 per 100 000 in Mayotte's general population, mainly in the rural section.\n\nGiven that domestic ruminants are involved in the epidemiological cycle and that humans mostly become infected after contact with viremic animals, the vaccination of ruminants, on top of protecting them, is the method of choice to prevent human disease.\n\nBoth live and inactivated vaccines are available for livestock. Live attenuated ('Smithburn') and inactivated vaccines are produced and commercially available in Egypt, South Africa, and Kenya. According to ref 2, 'There is no Community pharmaceutical legislation prohibiting companies from producing RVF vaccines on EU territory and there is no obligation to notify such production to the European Commission.' On the other hand, the French delegation, likely to be well aware of the need for animal vaccination in Mayotte, included the following comment in its presentation of 21 Mar 2019 (ref 1): 'What about vaccination? - To date, no vaccine has been authorized in the EU.'\n\nAccording to ECDC's risk assessment, published 6 Mar 2019 (ref 3), the current outbreak in Mayotte poses a very low risk for EU/EEA countries. The interests of Mayotte's economy and farming industry, and of those in contact with the animals, may have been rendered less consideration.\n\nAccording to the recent posting, Mayotte's farmers are being advised to 'monitor and report promptly to veterinarians any abortions or stillbirths occurring in their animals or sick animals in order to take samples in search of the disease'. No other measures are given for the protection of livestock.\n\nMonitoring will not prevent additional cases of RVF in cattle, sheep, and goats and, most probably, humans. In the absence of vaccination, monitoring farmers (and, indeed, the public), veterinarians and others in the rural areas of Mayotte, might due to be exposed, time and again, to a serious health hazard.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttps://lejournaldemayotte.yt/2019/03/29/point-fievre-vallee-rift-114-cas-humains-et-84-foyers-danimaux/\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte. There have been 114 human RVF cases and 84 animal outbreaks. This past week, 7 new human cases and 9 in animals were reported to the LRA. Human cases remain concentrated in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nAn animal disease of viral origin, Rift Valley fever mainly affects domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats), causing abortions and high mortality in young animals. It can be transmitted from the sick animal to humans.\n\nDuring the past week, 9 new animal foci and 7 new human cases have been reported, for a total of 84 animal foci and 114 human cases since the 1st cases occurred at the end of November 2018.\n\nIn this epidemic context, the prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS Indian Ocean and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF) reminds people of the importance of prevention measures to protect themselves from disease.\n\nEpidemiological situation as of 29 Mar 2019:\nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November):\n- Samples taken by veterinarians on sick animals or during abortions have identified 84 outbreaks of sick animals (including 69 cattle). The animal foci are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island, but some animal foci have been found in the commune of Mamoudzou.\n\n- 114 human cases of RVF have been reported to the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS) of Mayotte by the CHM laboratory.\n\n- Since the beginning of the health alert, human cases have remained mainly in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nRecommendations\nTransmission by ruminants\nIn ruminants:\n- Monitoring of Rift Valley fever includes monitoring of abortions. Thus, farmers are required to report promptly to veterinarians any abortions or stillbirths occurring in their animals or sick animals in order to take samples for diagnosis of the disease.\n- An order prohibiting the marketing of untreated milk has been in force since 27 Feb 2019.\n- A decree prohibiting the export of live animals, raw meat and milk produced by the ruminant farms of the country has been in force since 20 Mar 2019.\n\nIn humans:\n- The disease is usually manifested by an influenza-like illness: high fever (39 C [98.6 F]), muscle and/or joint pain, severe headache, tiredness. In the vast majority of cases, healing occurs within a few days.\n- It is recommended to consult a doctor as soon as the signs appear so that samples for diagnosis of the disease can be taken.\n\nRecommendations to protect against disease:\nFor farmers and people in contact with animals:\n- Wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats).\n- Do not handle unprotected or diseased animals or abortion products without protection.\n- Do not handle animal carcasses without protection.\n- Wear gloves, goggles and especially a mask for the slaughter of any animal. Infected animals may have no signs, although they can transmit the virus.\n\nFor food:\n- Boil the milk\n- Do not consume curd unless it has been boiled and curdled with lactic fermenters.\n- Wash hands after cutting meat.\n- Do not eat uncooked meat.\n- Do not consume the meat of a sick animal.\n\nTo protect yourself from mosquito bites:\n- Eliminate breeding sites, empty all containers that may contain water.\n- Use mosquito nets and repellents.\n\nIn case of appearance of symptoms:\n- Consult your doctor immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cases of Rift Valley fever in humans and livestock continue to increase slowly on Mayotte Island.\n\nProMED-mail posted a summary of the EU - Health and Food Safety DG - Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCPAFF) 21 Mar 2019 committee meeting (see Rift Valley fever - Mayotte (06): animal, human, control, epidemiology 20190328.6391591) that lists the same precautions as above. In this post, Mod.AS commented that 'the introduction of RVF could have occurred either by traded animals or windborne infected vectors. The tropical ecological/climatic situation in Mayotte is not similar to the East African situation (and consequent RVF epidemiology), characterised by periodic exacerbations of latent endemic foci of infection or dormant mosquito larvae.'\n\nIt would be of interest to know whether _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes are transmitting RVF virus on Mayotte and whether they are transovarially transmitting the virus to their eggs, as is the case in West Africa. These eggs can persist for long periods of time until flooded, when they hatch and develop into infected adults that can transmit the virus. This is not likely to occur if other genera of vector mosquitoes are transmitting the virus on Mayotte, in which case the outbreak can be expected to eventually die out. - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nR\u00e9gion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nIn total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November):\n- Samples taken by veterinarians on sick animals or during abortions have identified 84 outbreaks of sick animals (including 69 cattle). Modes of transmission:\n- vectors (many species of mosquitoes), mainly;\n- direct contact with biological fluid;\n- ingestion of contaminated products (milk or meat not sanitized).\n\n2. Background\nMayotte is at risk of exposure:\n- geographical proximity to many endemic countries (the Comoros, Madagascar);\n- illegal movements of animals;\n- tropical climate (vectors).\n\n3. Situation\nBetween 22 Nov 2018 and 14 Mar 2019, 101 human RVF cases and 60 [cases] in ruminants recorded [separate maps for animals and humans presented].\n\n4. Livestock monitoring\nSuspicion in farm - early detection of disease in livestock\nVeterinary visit triggered by a call from the farmer:\n- blood sampling;\n- confirmed case: animal with clinical signs and positive IgM test;\n- official confirmation by PCR (CIRAD);\n- epidemiological investigation.\nActive surveillance in ruminants:\n- 4000 farms, with 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants;\n- sampling of 1500 farms (blood sample).\n\n5. Control measures\na. Biosecurity measures:\n- burial stillborn;\n- isolating sick animals;\n- protect animal with insecticide treatment.\nb. No stamping-out of livestock because\n- period is too favourable to the development of vectors;\n- short duration of viraemia (7 days) vs delay of result;\n- risk of under-declaration [under-reporting] of outbreaks;\n- increasing the risk of illegal introduction of ruminants.\nc. What about vaccination?\n- to date, no vaccine authorized in the EU\n\n6. Joint action human and animal health\na. vector control: disinsectization around human and animal outbreaks.\nb. awareness messages for population and breeders:\n- boil the milk;\n- cook the meat;\n- keep out mosquitoes;\n- eliminate larval breeding habitat.\nc. for professionals:\n- use of individual protective equipment (masks, gloves, and goggles);\n- report abortions to the sanitary veterinarian.\n\n7. Conclusions:\na. French authorities remain vigilant to the epidemiological situation in Mayotte:\n- measures adapted to the local conditions;\n- human and animal epidemiological surveillance, biosecurity, information, vectors control.\nb. Risk of RVF spreading [from Mayotte, internationally] is negligible because\n- deficit in beef and sheep meat in Mayotte;\n- no live animals nor products exchanged from Mayotte to La Reunion or EU territory;\n- administrative decision to prohibit the export of live ruminants and products (meat and milk).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the above presentation by the French Ministry of Agriculture, the recent RVF event in Mayotte, which started in late November 2018, may have been caused by the introduction of the virus from endemic regional countries (the Comoros, Madagascar). This could have occurred either by traded animals or windborne infected vectors. The tropical ecological/climatic situation in Mayotte is not similar to the East African situation (and consequent RVF epidemiology), characterised by periodic exacerbations of latent endemic foci of infection or dormant mosquito larvae.\n\nAs apparent from the maps included in the presentation (RVF in animals and in man), the disease spread throughout the island. A recent paper addressing the RVF situation in Mayotte presented the following conclusion: 'Communes in the central region of Mayotte would play a major role in the spread of livestock diseases. A widespread epidemic is likely due to their high connectivity between themselves and to communes in the outer region. Surveillance efforts, therefore, need to be focused on central communes to achieve the timely detection of disease occurrence and minimise its consequences.' (See Kim Y, Dommergues L, Ben M'sa A, Merot Ph, Cardinale E et al.: Livestock trade network: potential for disease transmission and implications for risk-based surveillance on the island of Mayotte. (Nature) Scientific Reports. 2018; 8:11550. doi: 10.1038/s41598-018-29999-y.)\n\nPreventive vaccination could have significantly decreased the RVF epizootic, and consequently human infection; unfortunately, this seems to be, due to EU current legislation, excluded.\n\nAccording to a recent report by Le Journal de Mayotte (https://lejournaldemayotte.yt/2019/03/22/progression-de-la-fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-interdiction-dexporter-viande-ou-lait-cru/), since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018) and as of 22 Mar 2019, 75 outbreaks of disease in animals (including 59 cattle) have been established by samples taken by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions. Of those who could be interviewed, almost 80% reported contact with animals. Most human cases occurred in the center and northwest of the island. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nRegion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]", "summary": "No stamping-out of livestock because\n- period is too favourable to the development of vectors;\n- short duration of viraemia (7 days) vs delay of result;\n- risk of under-declaration [under-reporting] of outbreaks;\n- increasing the risk of illegal introduction of ruminants. Background\nMayotte is at risk of exposure:\n- geographical proximity to many endemic countries (the Comoros, Madagascar);\n- illegal movements of animals;\n- tropical climate (vectors). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Veterinary visit triggered by a call from the farmer:\n- blood sampling;\n- confirmed case: animal with clinical signs and positive IgM test;\n- official confirmation by PCR (CIRAD);\n- epidemiological investigation. b. Risk of RVF spreading [from Mayotte, internationally] is negligible because\n- deficit in beef and sheep meat in Mayotte;\n- no live animals nor products exchanged from Mayotte to La Reunion or EU territory;\n- administrative decision to prohibit the export of live ruminants and products (meat and milk). Modes of transmission:\n- vectors (many species of mosquitoes), mainly;\n- direct contact with biological fluid;\n- ingestion of contaminated products (milk or meat not sanitized). b. awareness messages for population and breeders:\n- boil the milk;\n- cook the meat;\n- keep out mosquitoes; a. French authorities remain vigilant to the epidemiological situation in Mayotte:\n- measures adapted to the local conditions;\n- human and animal epidemiological surveillance, biosecurity, information, vectors control. Active surveillance in ruminants:\n- 4000 farms, with 20 000 cattle and 15 000 small ruminants;\n- sampling of 1500 farms (blood sample). Source: EU - Health and Food Safety DG - Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (SCPAFF), 21 Mar 2019 committee meeting [summ., edited]\n Situation\nBetween 22 Nov 2018 and 14 Mar 2019", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "La Reunion", "country": "R\u00e9union"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}, {"location": "EU", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6387146", "headline": "PRO/AH> Foot & mouth disease, Rift Valley fever - Egypt: mass vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6387146", "date": "2019-03-26 20:32:38", "main_text": "FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE, RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EGYPT: MASS VACCINATION\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Mar 2019\nSource: Mobtada [in Arabic, trans. Mod.TSO, edited]\nhttps://www.mobtada.com/details/823857\n\n\nDr. Mona Mehrez, the deputy minister of agriculture, said that through the national campaign to vaccinate livestock against foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) and Rift Valley fever [RVF], which started on [Sat 2 Feb 2019] and ended on [Thu 14 Mar 2019], the campaign succeeded for the 1st time in reaching the target immunization proportion of 89% instead of the 81% [reached] the last year [2018].\n\nThe Deputy Minister of Agriculture for Animal, Poultry and Fishery Affairs confirmed that according to the latest report on the immunization of livestock, cattle, buffalo, and sheep against FMD and RVF, a total of 3.75 million head of livestock were vaccinated, of which 3.5 million were cattle and buffalo, and 250 000 were sheep and goats.\n\n[Byline: Ahmed Nassef]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[Egypt has been applying annual mass vaccinations of livestock as a preventive measure against FMD and RVF since 1993.\n\nFMD is endemic in Egypt; according to the most recent available EUFMD's monthly Global FMD Situation Report (January 2019), its incidence in Egypt is 'high,' the presumed FMD virus serotypes currently circulating being O (O/EA-3) and, to a lesser extent, SAT 2. (See table 16 'Conjectured circulating FMD viral lineages in each country of Pool 3 - North Africa' at https://tinyurl.com/y3ebeeh8). FMD has a very serious economic impact; it is not a zoonotic disease.\n\nRVFV causes a significant threat to both human and animal health. Human epidemics are generally preceded by epizootics in livestock, which serve as an amplification step in the spread of the virus. The disease is vector-borne in animals; humans get infected mainly by direct contact with infected animal tissues (e.g. blood) but also by the vectors (predominantly mosquitos). Prevention of disease in animals by vaccination is considered essential to protect humans from infection.\n\nUntil 1977, RVF was known to be limited to sub-Saharan Africa, mainly as an animal disease with zoonotic potential; in humans, it was mainly manifested as a self-limited febrile illness with the occasional complication of retinal lesions. During these years, the interest in the disease beyond Africa was practically limited to those engaged in potential biological warfare agents. In 1977, the disease was recorded, for the 1st time, in Egypt where it caused a major event with critical impact upon human health, continuing during 1978. The disease was associated with severe and fatal hemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. An official Egyptian report counted 598 deaths. Estimates of clinical cases from field workers exceeded 200 000 (Egypt's population at that time was 41 million). The animal industry suffered serious losses due to clinical disease, abortions, decreased production, and deaths. Mortality was high in sheep and cattle; it was intermediate or low in buffaloes, camels and goats. The disease spread throughout many of Egypt's governorates. During the early 1980's, some batches of an imported inactivated RVF animal vaccine were applied to terminate/prevent the circulation of the virus in the delta area and in Sinai.\n\nSince 1978, exacerbations of RVF have been reported from Egypt in 1993, 1994, 1997 and 2003. According to Egypt's OIE reports, the last RVF occurrence was in 2004. However, low-level circulation of the virus has been demonstrated there several times during the inter-epizootic periods, the disease regarded to have become endemic. New introductions, mainly by camels and cattle imported from Sudan and Ethiopia, are considered to occur.\n\nInitially, killed vaccines were applied for the general preventive annual vaccinations, while live attenuated Smithburn-strain vaccine was introduced during outbreaks. Since 2007, the GOVs have banned the use of the live attenuated vaccine, deciding to use only the inactivated ZH501 vaccine for regular immunization against RVFV in animals. This Binary ethylenamine inactivated and Alum adjuvanted vaccine, produced by VSVRI (Veterinary Serum & Vaccine Research Institute, Abbassia, Cairo) is based upon the 501 strain of RVFV, isolated during the 1977 epidemic from a patient with fatal hemorrhagic fever hospitalized in the Zagazig Fever Hospital, 83 km [51.6 mi] northeast of Cairo. The inactivated vaccine has overcome the disadvantages of the live attenuated vaccine, such as abortion in pregnant animals, and is applicable in all susceptible animal species. Both FMD and RVF vaccines, combined, are injected to cattle, water buffaloes, sheep and goats; camels are vaccinated only with the RVF vaccine.\n\nSome of the above, and additional data on RVF and its control in Egypt, as well as control, including vaccinations, in imported animals, is available in references 1 and 2.\n\nReferences\n1. Fawzy M & Helmy YA. The One Health Approach is Necessary for the Control of Rift Valley Fever Infections in Egypt: A Comprehensive Review. Viruses 2019, 11, 139; doi:10.3390/v11020139.\n2. Kamal SA. Observations on Rift Valley fever virus and vaccines in Egypt. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttps://lejournaldemayotte.yt/2019/03/01/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-39-cas-danimaux-et-82-cas-humain-au-1er-mars/\n\n\nThe circulation of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues in Mayotte as of 1 Mar 2019, the prefecture has reported. Raw milk should not be consumed if it is not treated. A viral animal disease, Rift Valley fever mainly affects domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats), causing abortions and high mortality in young animals. As we reported earlier, a quarter of Coconi high school is affected.\n\nThe virus can be transmitted from sick animals to humans. Since the 1st cases occurred in late November 2018, 39 animal outbreaks have been identified, and 82 human cases have been reported.\n\nThe prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS Indian Ocean and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF) stresses the importance of prevention measures to protect yourself from the disease.\n\nEpidemiological situation as of 1 Mar 2019\n------------------------------------------\nProtect yourself during handling. In total, since the beginning of the epidemic (end of November 2018):\n- Samples taken by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 39 outbreaks (30 bovine). Animal foci are mainly located in the center and north west of the island.\n- 82 human cases of RVF have been reported to the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the Agence r\u00e9gionale de sant\u00e9 Oc\u00e9an Indien (CVAGS) of R\u00e9union and Mayotte by the CHM laboratory. The weekly number of reported cases has remained stable for 3 weeks. Human cases are mainly located in the center and northwest of the island.\n\nIn ruminants, the monitoring of Rift Valley fever involves the monitoring of abortions:\n- breeders are required to report promptly to veterinarians any abortions occurring in their animals or sick animals in order to take samples from the animals;\n- an order prohibiting the marketing of untreated milk has been in force since 27 Feb 2019.\n\nIn humans, the disease usually manifests as an influenza-like illness: high fever (39 C [102 F]), muscle and/or joint pain, severe headache, and fatigue. In the vast majority of cases, healing occurs within a few days. Consult a doctor as soon as signs appear so that samples to detect the disease can be taken.\n\nFor breeders and people in contact with animals:\n- wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats);\n- do not handle unprotected or diseased animals or abortion products without protection;\n- do not handle animal carcasses without protection;\n- wear gloves, goggles and especially a mask for the slaughter of any animal. Infected animals may have no signs, although they can transmit the virus.\n\nFor food preparation:\n- boil the milk;\n- do not consume curd unless it has been boiled and curdled via lactic fermentation;\n- wash hands after cutting meat;\n- do not eat uncooked meat;\n- do not consume the meat of a sick animal.\n\nTo protect yourself from mosquito bites:\n- eliminate breeding sites, empty all containers that may contain water;\n- use mosquito nets and repellents.\n\nIn the event of symptoms appearing, immediately consult your doctor.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak has been going on since November 2018. The number of human cases of RVF has increased from 63 to 82 in about 2 weeks. The above report does not indicate whether the human infections are the result of contact with infected animals or their products or from virus transmission by mosquito vectors. The cattle cases certainly are the result of mosquito transmission.\n\nBecause RVF virus can be transovarially transmitted in populations of aedes mosquito vectors, and those resulting eggs can persist for a long period of time in nature, cases can occur periodically when the virus-containing eggs hatch, and infected adult females emerge from them.\n\nRecent studies have shown that RVF virus may severely injure human fetuses if contracted by mothers during pregnancy. There is no indication of whether any of the 63 RVF virus-infected people were pregnant. Abortions in infected livestock are common. There is no vaccine available for human use, but there is for livestock. There is no mention of whether the livestock populations in the area have been vaccinated.\n\nThe clinical findings related to the above human cases are not mentioned, but the symptoms associated with RVF infections in general are listed. In an earlier comment, Mod.CP noted that: 'The most common complication associated with RVF is inflammation of the retina. As a result, approximately 1-10% of affected patients may have some permanent vision loss. Approximately 1% of humans that become infected with RVF virus die of the disease.' - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nR\u00e9gion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]", "summary": "For breeders and people in contact with animals:\n- wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats);\n- do not handle unprotected or diseased animals or abortion products without protection;\n- do not handle animal carcasses without protection;\n- wear gloves, goggles and especially a mask for the slaughter of any animal. Corr. SB, edited]\nhttps://lejournaldemayotte.yt/2019/02/22/fievre-de-la-vallee-du-rift-63-cas-humains-depuis-le-debut-de-lepidemie/\n\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) continues to circulate in Mayotte among the herds of ruminants, and the number of human cases is increasing.\n\nThe prefecture of Mayotte, in collaboration with the ARS Indian Ocean and the Directorate of Food, Agriculture and Forestry of Mayotte (DAAF) reminds the population of the importance of implementing recommendations and preventive actions to avoid being ill.\n\nEpidemiological situation as of 22 Feb 2019:\n- Samples taken by veterinarians from sick animals or during abortions have identified 33 animal FVR outbreaks.\n- Since late November [2018], 63 human cases of RVF have been reported to the monitoring and health emergencies platform of the ARS OI (CVAGS) of Mayotte by the CHM laboratory.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a zoonosis (infectious disease that can be transmitted from animals to humans) of viral origin, which mainly affects domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats), causing abortions and high mortality in young animals.\n\nTransmission to humans can occur in different ways:\n- By contact with blood, body fluids, or tissues of a sick animal (during slaughter, cutting of meat, calving, care, etc.). The most exposed people are therefore professionals such as breeders, slaughterhouse employees, and veterinarians.\n- By mosquito bite, vectors of the disease near infected flocks, often in the rainy seasons.\n- When eating unboiled milk or unpasteurized curd from an infected animal.\n\nThere is no [direct] person-to-person transmission of RVF [virus].\n\nThe disease in humans is usually manifested by an influenza-like illness that clears in a few days and includes symptoms such as high fever (39 deg C [102 deg F]), muscle and / or joint pain, intense headaches, and fatigue. However, in 5% of cases, more serious forms may occur: ocular meningitis / meningoencephalitis, haemorrhagic fever.\n\nRecommendations for protection against the disease-causing virus:\n\nFor farmers and people in contact with animals:\n- Wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats).\n- Do not handle unprotected or diseased animals or abortion products without protection.\n- Do not handle animal carcasses without protection.\n- Wear gloves, goggles, and especially a mask for the slaughter of any animal. Infected animals may have no signs, although they can transmit the virus.\n\nFor food consumption:\nTransmission by ruminants\n- Boil the milk\n- Do not consume curd unless it has been boiled and curdled with lactic fermentation.\n- Wash hands after cutting meat.\n- Do not eat uncooked meat.\n- Do not consume the meat of a sick animal.\n\nTo protect yourself from mosquito bites:\n- Eliminate breeding sites; empty all containers that may contain water.\n- Use mosquito nets and repellents.\n\nIn case of appearance of symptoms, consult your doctor immediately.\n\nManagement measures:\n\nBy the Directorate of Food, Agriculture, and Forestry: The monitoring of Rift Valley fever involves the monitoring of abortions. Farmers are asked to report to veterinarians without delay any abortions occurring in their animals in order to take samples for the disease. The prevalence of RVF in the exchange zone with Mayotte being important, the risk of spread of the disease is not negligible in case of uncontrolled import of animals.\n\nBy the Indian Ocean Health Agency: Since the1st report, each ill person is interviewed by the ARS Indian Ocean to identify the risk factors for the disease.\n\nA treatment of larval breeding and a mosquito control are done by the service of the Anti-vector Fight [unit] to the homes of the sick persons and around the houses. Information to health professionals was made to strengthen surveillance and identification of human cases.\n\n[Byline: Anne]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak has been going on since November 2018. The numbers of human cases of RVF have increased from 31 to 63 in about 2 weeks. The above report does not indicate whether the human infections are the result of virus transmission by mosquito vectors, but the cattle cases certainly are. Because RVF virus can be transovarially transmitted in populations of _Aedes_ mosquito vectors, and those resulting eggs can persist for a long period of time in nature, cases can occur periodically when the virus-containing eggs hatch and infected adult females emerge from them. Recent studies have shown that RVF virus may severely injure human fetuses if contracted by mothers during pregnancy. There is no indication of whether any of the 63 RVF virus-infected people were pregnant. Abortions in infected livestock are common. There is no vaccine available for human use, but there is for livestock. There is no mention of whether the livestock populations in the area have been vaccinated.\n\nThe clinical findings related to the above human cases are not mentioned, but the symptoms associated with RVF infections in general are listed. In an earlier comment, Mod.CP noted that, 'The most common complication associated with RVF is inflammation of the retina. As a result, approximately 1-10% of affected patients may have some permanent vision loss. Approximately 1% of humans that become infected with RVF virus die of the disease.' - Mod.TY\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nRegion d'outre-mer de Mayotte, France: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/576]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRecommendations for protection against the disease-causing virus:\n\nFor farmers and people in contact with animals:\n- Wash hands with soap after contact with domestic ruminants (cattle, sheep, goats). Since the 1st human case was detected on [Tue 11 Dec 2018], health officials have reported 19 human cases. Most of the cases were located in the western part of the island.\n\nSamples made on ruminants present around human cases were analyzed at CIRAD in Reunion for the search for the RVF virus. The results identified several positive animals in different villages located in west and center of the island.\n\nIn addition, an IgM-positive cattle has been reported in Mamoudzou. This 2-year-old cattle belongs to a breeding herd of 8 cattle, including 4 adults and 4 2-month-old calves. Biological control and investigations are underway.\n\nECDC reports that the detection of autochthonous Rift Valley fever cases on Mayotte is not unexpected, but the occurrence of 19 cases within a short time period is of concern, as current weather conditions (rainy season from November to March) are favorable for the vectors.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is an illness that is primarily spread by direct contact with blood, fluids, or tissues of infected animals such as cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats, and camels. Less commonly, it can also be spread through mosquito bites.\n\nMost people with RVF do not feel sick or have only mild illness. Symptoms of RVF include fever, weakness, back pain, dizziness, and weight loss. However, a small percentage (8-10%) of people may have more serious illness, such as severe bleeding, swelling of the brain, or eye disease. Approximately 1% of people who get RVF die from the disease.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\nand\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 2 Feb 2019\nSource: ECDC Communicable Diseases Threats Report Week 5, 27 Jan - 2 Feb 2019 [edited]\nhttps://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/portal/files/documents/communicable-disease-threats-report-27-january-2-february-2019.pdf\n\n\nAccording to Institut de Veille Sanitaire (InVS), from 11 Dec 2018 - 28 Jan 2019, 19 Rift Valley fever cases were confirmed on Mayotte. All cases were locally acquired. Among these cases, 14 are male and 5 are female, with an age range of 27-64 years.\n\nMost of the cases were located in the western part of the island. Further investigations identified several positive ruminants in the western and central parts of the island.\n\nAccording to CIRAD, Rift Valley fever seroprevalence among ruminants has decreased from 2008 to 2017, but significantly increased in 2017 and 2018 (3.6%, CI 95% [2.3-5.6%]) and 2018 and 2019 (10.1% CI 95% [6.5-15.3%]). In addition, according to InVS, one case imported from Comoros was reported by authorities on Mayotte in 2011.\n\nThe detection of autochthonous Rift Valley fever cases on Mayotte is not unexpected, but the occurrence of 19 cases within a short time period is of concern, as current weather conditions (rainy season from November to March) are favourable for the vectors.\n\nECDC will continue monitoring this event through epidemic intelligence activities and report again if there is a relevant epidemiological update.\n\n[Map] Distribution of RVF human cases and ruminants, Mayotte, 11 Dec 2018 to 28 Jan 2019\n\n[Graph] Distribution of RVF confirmed human cases, Mayotte, 11 Dec 2018 to 28 Jan 2019\n\nYear-Week / Number of cases\n2018-50 / 1\n2018-51 / 0\n2018-52 / 2\n2019-01 / 2\n2019-02 / 0\n2019-03 / 2\n2019-04 / 8\n2019-05 / 4\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[It is not surprising to have both human and cattle Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases occur simultaneously. The above report does not indicate if the human infections are the result of virus transmission by mosquito vectors, but the cattle cases certainly are. Because RVF virus can be transovarially transmitted in populations of _Aedes_ mosquito vectors, and those resulting eggs can persist for a long period of time in nature, cases can occur periodically when the virus-containing eggs hatch and infected adult females emerge from them. Recent studies have shown that RVF virus may severely injure human fetuses if contracted by mothers during pregnancy. There is no indication if any of the 19 RVF virus-infected people were pregnant. Results showed that the virus may be even more damaging to fetuses than the Zika virus, which set off a global crisis in 2015 and left thousands of babies in Central America and South America with severe birth defects.\n\n'Zika caught everybody by surprise,' said Amy Hartman, an infectious disease specialist at the University of Pittsburgh, who led the research. 'If doctors had known about Zika's birth effects, they could have done a lot more to protect pregnant women and babies. With Rift Valley fever, we're trying to get ahead of the curve.'\n\nRift Valley fever primarily occurs in livestock in sub-Saharan Africa, where outbreaks cause 90 to 100 percent of pregnant cows in a herd to miscarry or deliver stillborn calves, often a significant economic loss.\n\nBut hundreds of cases also occur in humans each year, causing flulike symptoms and severe liver problems. The outbreaks have moved beyond Africa: In late 2000, an outbreak in Saudi Arabia infected more than 100 000 people and led to at least 700 deaths, according to Dr. Hartman. The mosquito that carries the disease is also found in Europe and the Americas.\n\n'Climate change can alter how emerging infectious diseases will spread,' Dr. Harman said. 'As mosquito populations move and change, we have a potential for this to spread far beyond its normal boundaries.'\n\nThere are no vaccines or treatments for Rift Valley fever. The World Health Organization has called the disease a potential public health emergency.\n\nThere are 2 documented cases of infected fetuses. One infant was born with an enlarged liver and spleen, among other symptoms; the other died within a week. Because the disease can be asymptomatic in pregnant women, many more cases of abnormalities and stillbirths may have been misidentified.\n\nAmong rats used in the study, 65 percent of the pups born to infected mothers died, compared to 25 percent of pups born from uninfected controls. Each infected mother lost at least one pup, and all of the infected mothers' offspring contracted the virus.\n\nPregnant rats were also more susceptible to death from Rift Valley fever than nonpregnant rats.\n\nMost surprising to researchers, the infected mothers' placentas harbored more virus than any other tissue in the body, more than even the liver, where the virus's damage is typically observed.\n\n'No one in the field recognized this before,' said Cynthia McMillen, a postdoctoral researcher in Dr. Hartman's lab, and one of the study's lead authors.\n\nTesting on human placental tissue revealed that, unlike the Zika virus, Rift Valley fever virus has a unique ability to infect a specialized layer of cells that supports the region of the placenta where nutrients flow in.\n\nZika must take the 'side roads' into the placenta to infect a fetus, while the Rift Valley fever virus can take the 'expressway,' Dr. Hartman said.\n\n'The fetus is protected from hundreds of thousands of dangers that could affect it,' she added. 'Only a few microbes can get past, and this is one of them.'\n\nLast week, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations launched a call for proposals to develop human vaccines against Rift Valley fever. About USD 48 million will finance up to 8 projects on Rift Valley fever and chikungunya viruses, according to an announcement.\n\n'We need more research into the epidemiology, how it causes disease, and how to prevent it,' Dr. McMillen said. 'This could spread beyond where it is found in the Middle East, so awareness is sorely needed.'\n\n[Byline: Emily Baumgaertner]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The above report provides more details and discussion than the abstract of the original article in Science Advances does (posted on 12 Dec 2018 as Rift Valley fever: vertical transmission 20181210.6203158).\n\nWe need to pay attention to the Harman statement, 'As mosquito populations move and change, we have a potential for this [virus] to spread far beyond its normal boundaries.'\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) virus transmission has been active in East Africa in 2018 and is endemic there. If West Nile virus made it across the Atlantic Ocean to the Americas, there is reason to assume that RVF virus would be able to make the same journey and with competent vectors present, initiate ongoing transmission. The World Health Organization's classification of RVF as a potential public health emergency is justification enough for development of a vaccine for human use. One hopes that the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations' call for proposals to develop human vaccines against RVF will elicit an ample response. An RVF vaccine exists for animals. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "\n\nTesting on human placental tissue revealed that, unlike the Zika virus, Rift Valley fever virus has a unique ability to infect a specialized layer of cells that supports the region of the placenta where nutrients flow in. \n\nMost surprising to researchers, the infected mothers' placentas harbored more virus than any other tissue in the body, more than even the liver, where the virus's damage is typically observed.
