The disease has also spread to the nearby Kirehe district [also in Eastern province], The New Times has learnt.\n\nRVF is an acute fever-causing viral disease that's commonly observed in domesticated animals such as cattle, sheep, goats, and camels. It can also attack wild animals such as buffaloes. The disease is caused by a virus transmitted by mosquitoes and blood feeding flies and mostly affects animals but it can also be transmitted to humans, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). In humans, the disease ranges from a mild flu-like illness to severe haemorrhagic fever that can be deadly.\n\nNgoma district vice mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Jean-Marie Vianney Rwiririza, told The New Times on [Tue 5 Jun 2018] that 102 cows had died from the fatal disease, while 103 others have aborted since the disease was first reported in the district on [18 May 2018].\n\nWHO says RVF can cause significant economic losses due to high mortality rate among young animals and waves of abortions. The virus was first identified in 1931 among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of Kenya.\n\nThe vice mayor for Finance and Economic Planning of Kirehe, Jean-Damasc\u00e8ne Nsengiyumva, said that about 16 cows in the district had been successfully treated of the infection while 22 were still undergoing treatment. 'We are vaccinating cows which have not yet been infected and treating those infected,' Nsengiyumva told The New Times.\n\nA dairy farmer from Kirehe sector in Kirehe district, lost a cow to the disease just a day after it got infected. The cow, which he bought for Rwf 600 000 [about USD 700] in August 2015, he said, was producing 20 litres of milk a day and was helping him fend for his family. He says the cow's value had since increased to about Rwf 2 million [about USD 2330].\n\nOfficials at Rwanda Agriculture Board [RAB] say that RVF was first recorded in Rwanda in 2011 and the government started vaccinating cows against the disease in 2015. The vaccines are provided free of charge.\n\nDr Isidore Gafarasi, the director of veterinary services at RAB, said some districts did not vaccinate their cows against the viral disease fast enough, adding that both Ngoma and Kirehe districts had a target to inoculate 7500 cattle each. Under the Veterinary Delivery Services/ Livestock Development project, the government set aside some Rwf 500 million [about USD 583 000] for the current financial year (2017/18) for RVF vaccines for 127 793 cows in all of the country's 30 districts.\n\nA restriction has been imposed on cattle movement in the affected region to help contain the viral disease. Consumption of the affected meat is prohibited because the disease can be transmitted to humans.\n\n[byline: Emmanuel Ntirenganya]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The reporting of RVF cases in cattle may have contributed to the high alert of the public health authorities. Unfortunately, in most RVF events, humans serve as sentinels. Having said that, one may consider the possibility of mild or subclinical human cases escaping reporting since the start of the event in cattle, reportedly on 18 May 2018.\n\nAccording to Rwanda's reports to the OIE, RVF -- a notifiable, endemic animal disease in Rwanda -- is (2017 data) 'limited to one or more zones'. FAO's [The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations] recent suitability maps for RVF vector amplification indicate risk areas in the eastern parts of Rwanda.\n\nAccording to Rwanda's semi-annual reports to the OIE for 2017, during the months January-June, 321 730 vaccinations 'in response to outbreaks' were applied in animals; during July-December 2017, the number was 32 650.\n\nA detailed vaccination report to OIE is available for 2016, indicating the number of vaccine doses used: cattle: 127 000, goats: 75 700, sheep & goats (likely, mixed flocks): 56 750. It may be assumed that the vaccine used for the animal vaccination is live-attenuated.\n\nSubscribers are referred to FAO's recent publication on RVF Surveillance (Ref 1). On top of the crucial surveillance issue, the richly-referenced document includes updated information and guidelines on the RVF control and prevention measures in affected and threatened countries. Vaccination regimes in different epidemiological situations, are revisited by the author. All involved with the surveillance, control, and prevention of RVF, a significant human and animal-health threat, will gain from this timely publication.\n\nThe population of RVF-susceptible animals in Rwanda (OIE's 2016 data) is:\n- cattle: 1 214 244 in 374 000 establishments;\n- goats: 2 486 334 in 103 500 establishments;\n- sheep: 637 068 in 15 000 establishments;\n- camels: 12 (a single establishment).\n\nRVF is known to be currently circulating in 2 other East African countries, affecting animals and humans: earlier, South Sudan and, more recently, Kenya, where human cases have been suspected ( 20180609.5847216) and a serious outbreak in camels, officially reported on Fri 8 Jun 2018. The situation in other regional countries, in particular Uganda and Tanzania, is to be followed with caution.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Mariner J. 2018. Rift Valley fever surveillance. So far, it is the only farm reported to be affected and further investigations are being carried out by the local veterinary services.\n\nRift Valley fever is caused by a virus carried by mosquitoes. It affects cattle, sheep, and goats and causes abortions and deaths in especially young animals. Humans can be infected with Rift Valley fever if they come into contact with the blood and other body fluids of an infected animal or an aborted foetus. Care should be taken when handling possibly infected animals or carcasses of animals that have died of the disease. Symptoms in humans are flu-like and some individuals can develop more serious complications. If a person suspects that they might have been infected with Rift Valley fever, they must consult a doctor.\n\nThe reoccurrence of Rift Valley fever is due to increased rainfall, which in turn causes an increase in mosquitoes. As this outbreak occurred in the beginning of the winter season, it will probably be an isolated incident as the cold weather will result in a decrease in the number of mosquitoes and therefore decrease the risk the disease spreading. It must be noted that the risk will increase at the start of the summer season. This outbreak provides us with a useful warning that all cattle, sheep, and goats have to be vaccinated to ensure that the level of immunity in the herds is high when the next summer season starts and the risk increases.\n\nFarmers are therefore advised to vaccinate their animals against Rift Valley fever. Live vaccines can only be used in non-pregnant animals as the live vaccine can cause abortions. Only dead (inactivated) vaccines must be used in pregnant animals. Please take care when vaccines are administered after outbreaks have been detected; use a clean needle for each animal as the virus can be spread between animals if the animals are in the incubation period. Animals in the incubation period will have a virus infection but will not show symptoms of the disease yet.\n\nRift Valley fever is a notifiable animal disease, but not a controlled animal disease, meaning that there are no prescribed control measures. The State Veterinary Services will give support and information to farmers in affected areas, but it is the responsibility of the animal owners to vaccinate their animals and prevent losses. Suspicion of disease must be immediately reported to the nearest State Veterinarian.\n\nAll livestock farmers in South Africa are advised to vaccinate all their cattle, sheep, and goats yearly or at least once during weaning.' - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nLetsemeng, Orange Free State, South Africa: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53679]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep / 41.67 / 41.67 / 100 / 41.67\n Date of previous occurrence: 30 Aug 2011\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\n Total animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 600 / 250 / 250 / 0 / 0\n 16 May 2018 from Dr Bothle Michael Modisane, Chief Director , Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Animal Production and Health, Pretoria, South Africa\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; The principal Secretary for livestock Mr. Harry Kimtai said that there is a looming danger of the disease following the heavy rainfall experienced countrywide noting that county governments should ensure that they roll out a massive vaccination of livestock.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[2] Kenya - Alerts, ministries of Agriculture and Health\nDate: Tue 22 May 2018, 9:05 AM\nSource: Standard Media [edited]\nhttps://www.standardmedia.co.ke/health/article/2001281290/alert-over-possible-rift-valley-fever-outbreak\n\n\nAn alert has been issued over the possible outbreak of RVF in parts of the country due to the ongoing rains. The alert from the ministries of Health and Agriculture named 15 counties as high-risk areas.\n\nThe notice was signed by Director of Veterinary Services Obadiah Njagi and his Health counterpart, Jackson Kioko. According to Dr. Njagi, there was increased risk of RVF due to increased cases of flooding. He noted that flooding not only caused displacement of people and animals but also increased the risk of diseases transmitted by mosquitoes such as RVF; 'a viral disease of livestock which also affects human beings if they get into contact with blood or tissues from infected animals,' he said.\n\nNjagi noted that certain groups, such as herders, slaughterhouse workers, farmers and veterinarians, were at higher risk of getting infected. 'The virus can be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during slaughtering, during births or while conducting veterinary procedures,' he said. He added that the last outbreak of the disease was recorded during the El Nino rains in 2006/2007, where around 160 people died and Sh4 billion [39 million USD] loss was recorded in the livestock sector.\n\nAnd Dr. Kioko called on the public to be cautious and stop slaughtering livestock at home without veterinary inspection. He advised the public to use protective gear while assisting livestock give birth or while removing stillbirths. He added that slaughtering or consuming food from sick or dead animals should be avoided and all suspicious deaths of livestock reported to relevant offices.\n\n'We are asking the public to use treated mosquito nets and repellants to keep away the insects that easily spread the virus mainly in flooded areas,' he said. Kioko further advised those who get a fever to report to the nearest health centre for treatment. 'To help in early detection and response in case of a disease outbreak, all reports of sudden deaths and abortions in livestock should be reported to the nearest veterinary offices for action,' he said.\n\n[Byline: Antony Gitonga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a per-acute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality and abortion occur and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\nHumans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures.\n\nRainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals, and may potentially vertically transmit the virus, so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\nLow level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and hemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\nThe current wet season in East Africa has been characterized by heavy rains and flooding, which enhance suitable ecological conditions for RVF vectors' amplification, increasing the risk of RVF occurrence. Recent suitability maps for RVF vector amplification, produced by FAO, showed a suitability pattern very similar to the one observed during the period September 2006-December 2007, a period that was characterized by abnormal, heavy rains and flooding which were followed by a major epizootic and epidemic in the region (Kenya, Tanzania and Somali covered in ProMED-mail's posts presented in 'See Also' section below).\n\nRVF has been reported during recent months from Uganda, South Sudan and South Africa.\n\nIn Jan 2018, a single case in a Korean man residing in Gambia was diagnosed while he visited Senegal. The site of his exposure was not definitely established; Gambia is not regarded an RVF-endemic country, in difference with Senegal. The case was reported to the WHO (see 20180124.5582417). No increase of abortions or compatible signs of RVF in livestock have been reported by the Senegalese veterinary service during the investigations regarding this case.\n\nEarlier (in mid Sep 2017), FAO had issued an alert to raise awareness about the risk of RVF vector amplification in Senegal, Mali, Mauritania and Niger. This was based on the observation of persistent heavy rains and floods during the wet season. Non-endemic regional countries, such as Nigeria, Chad, Cote D'Ivoire and Ghana, also showed wide areas at risk due to long, persistent heavy rains.\n\nKenya's authorities call to farmers to vaccinate their livestock, in particular cattle, goats and sheep, deserves to be listened to and be followed by immediate action, in all regional countries currently under similar climatic conditions. This will not only prevent serious financial losses, but is expected to protect the health of owners, their family members and others involved.\n\nParts of the above information and much more on RVF, its epidemiology, diagnosis and prevention is available in Chapter 2.1.18 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Manual, at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nKenya: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/174]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n He noted that flooding not only caused displacement of people and animals but also increased the risk of diseases transmitted by mosquitoes such as RVF; 'a viral disease of livestock which also affects human beings if they get into contact with blood or tissues from infected animals,' he said. \n\nKenya's authorities call to farmers to vaccinate their livestock, in particular cattle, goats and sheep, deserves to be listened to and be followed by immediate action, in all regional countries currently under similar climatic conditions. This follow-up report, created on 31 Mar 2018, notified continued absence of new animal cases since the initial, immediate notification to the OIE, dated 8 Mar 2018, when 8 cases in cattle were reported. The said notification included the following epidemiological comment: 'There were a few cases of abortion in cattle herds observed after heavy flooding in November 2017, when swampy areas formed and the number of mosquitoes increased. No mortalities in cattle have been reported. During the investigation clinical signs, consistent with Rift Valley fever, were observed' http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=26127. No more follow-up reports will be sent. Information about this disease will be included in the next 6-monthly reports'.\n\nUnfortunately, during the recent S. Sudan RVF event, as in most - if not all - previous RVF events in other African countries, humans served as sentinels. Improved surveillance in animals is desperately needed in Africa, to allow timely measures applied, predominantly preventive vaccination, before the development of a full-blown epizootic involving secondary infection in humans.\n\nThe initial WHO report on the S. Sudan RVF event ( 20180119.5568536) mentioned 'wild birds' among the affected animal species. It deserves to be noted that birds are known to be refractory to experimental infection with the RVF virus.. - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSouth Sudan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8402\n\nIt is fortunate that the RVF outbreak has ended, with no new reported cases in livestock. RVF-infected livestock can pose a significant risk to humans in contact with them, often livestock owners and veterinarians. Abortions in livestock with a loss in productivity present an economic problem for many ethnic groups that depend on them for livelihoods. In the absence of banks or similar institutions of financial support, livestock represent a kind of living bank account for their owners, in addition to a source of milk and meat. Apparently, this RVF outbreak did not result in an abortion storm that could have had serious economic, social and public health consequences. It is likely that RVF virus will persist in this area in transovarially infected eggs of _Aedes_ mosquito vectors. These eggs can remain viable for long period of time and hatch when flooded during future rain events, with subsequent emergence of infected females ready to transmit the virus. This risk provides justification for maintaining livestock of the area well vaccinated into the future. - Mod. He said that the situation is putting Marsabit County residents at risk.\n\n'Mass slaughter of livestock during the Idd celebration is likely to pose a greater risk to the people. Luckily, RVF does not affect poultry, so our people can use chicken as a substitute,' said Mr Bodha.\n\nLivestock are mainly from areas bordering Badanrero, Bute, Buna, Basir, Lakole, Rahmu, Daandu, Qofole and wider Wajir and Mandera counties.\n\nMr Bodha said that in the past 3 weeks, the county has experienced increased cases of abortion in both camels and small stock as well as increased vector populations.\n\nHe added that 5 camels were found dead in Funanyatta while a farmer in Bori lost 5 of his 12 camels that aborted.\n\n'Abortion in livestock, haemorrhage and fever characterise RVF in animals. We have received reports of increased cases in other areas like Badanrero, Amballo, Ittir, Kargi, Olturot, Loglogo, Korr and Laisamis,' said Mr Bodhi. North Horr, Balesa, Demo, Shuur and Maikona are also affected.\n\nFollowing the crisis, the veterinary department plans to enhance surveillance, institute ring vaccination to control disease spread, increase public awareness, institute quarantine of livestock, restrict home slaughter, and close livestock markets.\n\n'Due to stagnant waters around homesteads and night enclosures, there is marked increase in population of mosquitoes and other biting flies, which have been a menace to livestock in the county,' said Mr Bodha.\n\n[Byline: Irene Mwenda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Human cases, livestock movement\nDate: Fri 15 Jun 2018\nSource: Star [edited]\nhttps://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2018/06/15/wajir-officials-arrest-five-traders-in-fight-against-rift-valley-fever_c1772912\n\n\nThe Wajir Health department has arrested 5 people for violating a ban on sale of livestock products to control the spread of Rift Valley fever.\n\nHealth executive Abdihakim Billow said 6 people have died from the disease. The latest victim succumbed yesterday [14 Jun 2018] at Wajir County Referral Hospital. The woman from Basir in Eldas subcounty was among the 1st patients admitted to the hospital. Most victims are admitted to Wajir County Referral Hospital and Eldas Subcounty Hospital.\n\nWajir county hospital CEO Ahmed Abdinur said nurses and doctors have been working round the clock to treat patients diagnosed with the disease.\n\nHe said his worry is the outbreak might get out of control. 'We are doing everything humanly possible to save the lives of the victims. As you know, it is highly contagious, and it requires a high level of handling. It is our hope and prayer that the number of victims will not increase,' Abdinur said.\n\nOn Wednesday [13 Jun 2018], the government asked Kenyans to avoid eating uninspected meat. At least 10 cases have been confirmed within the area.\n\nThe 1st case was reported on 4 Jun [2018] after 2 relatives were referred to a local hospital with high fever and bleeding from the mouth.\n\nOne of the patients died the same day of their admission, a situation that has seen the government create a task force in order to reduce new incidences and prevent more deaths. The team comprises members from both the national and county government.\n\nObadiah Njagi, director of veterinary services, warned locals against handling meat that has not been inspected.\n\n'To aid in early detection and response in the event of an outbreak, all reports of sudden deaths and abortions of livestock should be reported to the nearest veterinary office or any other office,' Njagi said in a statement on Wednesday [13 Jun 2018].\n\nHe added: 'It is highly advised that all persons who experience fever of unknown origin should also report to the nearest health facility immediately.'\n\nRift Valley fever is a viral disease that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans.\n\nThe disease results in significant economic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected livestock, especially among camels and goats.\n\nSome of the symptoms [in humans] associated with the fever are high fever, bleeding gums, body weakness, among others.\n\nOn 13 Jun [2018], the government banned the consumption of meat that had not been inspected. Locals objected to the ban on grounds that they depend on their livestock to feed their family.\n\nAccording to WHO, the current outbreak has ecological and sub-regional geographical connotations. Livestock population movements are high in the sub-region, including cattle raiding activity between Uganda-Kenya-South Sudan.\n\n'The ongoing heavy rains and flooding in Kenya and other countries in East Africa have also resulted in increased vector density. Basir area in Eldas is worst hit with 17 cases reported from the area.\n\nMr Hassan said that a majority of the cases have reported contact with meat, and most of them involved individuals who slaughtered and distributed meat.\n\nHe added that they have set up 4 isolation centres in Wajir Referral Hospital, Basir, Arbajahan, and Eldas health centres in an effort to control the spread of the disease.\n\nAccording to Harry Kimtai, Principal Secretary Livestock, the 200 000 doses [of vaccine for animals] will help curb the spread of the disease that has so far claimed the lives of 5 people in Wajir county.\n\nAlthough no case of RVF has been reported in Tana River, Mandera, and Garissa counties, a team of livestock experts from the ministry have also been sent to the ground to help in the vaccination exercise.\n\nMr Kimtai said the ministry has already sent an alert to 20 counties; Uasin Gishu, Trans Nzoia, Nakuru, Laikipia, Kajiado, Baringo, Wajir, Garissa, Marsabit, Meru, Machakos, Taita Taveta, Tana River, Mombasa, Kwale, Kilifi, Nyeri, Tharaka Nithi, Murang'a, and Kiambu to immediately commence animal vaccination and vector control.\n\n'We are asking all the county governments to start animal vaccination and cooperate with our team so that we can contain the spread of this disease,' he said.\n\nHowever, an enhanced surveillance system has identified 4 counties as potential hotspots. These are, Marsabit, Wajir, Kajiado and Kitui.\n\nThe PS noted that already the director of veterinary services has informed the county directors and offered technical advice on disease detection and response.\n\nAt the same time, the directorate has set up an RVF alert centre using a toll-free line 0800 721 433 for immediate disease notification and response.\n\nMr Kimtai said a joint multiagency RVF outbreak technical committee comprising public health and animal health experts has been set up to assess the risk situation and advise the government on mitigation measures.\n\nTo contain the spread of the disease in Wajir, he said that, already, medical supplies including laboratory equipment and personal protective equipment have been supplied to departments of human and animal health technical support.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis, which periodically causes disease outbreaks in humans and livestock and is known to have been endemic in sub-Saharan Africa since 1912.\n\nPeople with RVF have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. Patients usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, and dizziness at the onset of the illness, and weight loss.\n\nIn animals, sheep and cattle may have nasal discharge, excess salivation, and loss of appetite, weakness, or diarrhoea.\n\n[Byline: Boniface Mwaniki and Bruhan Makong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak has both human and animal health consequences and reducing risk to both requires a One Health approach. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5682186", "date": "2018-03-12 21:06:50", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH SUDAN (07): (EASTERN LAKES)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Mar 2018\nSource: WHO Weekly Bulletin on Outbreaks and Other Emergencies [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/OEW10-39032018.pdf\n\n\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) continues to evolve in Eastern Lakes state, South Sudan, with another county affected. As of 9 Mar 2018, a total of 40 cases and 4 deaths have been reported from Yirol East (37 cases, 4 deaths) and Yirol West (3 cases, no deaths) counties. Of these, a total of 6 confirmed, 3 probable, and 12 suspect RVF cases (with pending laboratory results) have been reported. Of the suspected cases, 19 were considered as non-cases following negative laboratory results for RVF. The majority of suspected cases have been women (57.1 percent), and individuals aged 20-39 years make up the majority (72.2 percent) of cases.\n\n[Figure (map)] Geographical distribution of Rift Valley fever cases in South Sudan, 7 Dec 2017 - 9 Mar 2018\n\nIn week 10, 8 new suspected human cases were reported in Yirol East (5 cases) and Yirol West (3 cases). Samples have been collected from these cases, and 7 were shipped to the Uganda Virus Research Institute (UVRI) on 7 Mar 2018 for laboratory testing. As of 9 Mar 2018, there were no cases hospitalized. During the week, one human sample tested RVF IgG positive, bringing the cumulative number of confirmed RVF cases to 6 (one RVF IgM and IgG positive and 5 IgG-only positive).\n\nTest results from 21 animal samples (from livestock) that were shipped to South Africa were released during the week; 8 were RVF positive (3 IgM-positive and 5 IgG-positive), 6 samples were classified as suspect RVF cases based on IgG and IgM serological titres, and 7 samples were negative. Since the beginning of the outbreak, a total of 28 animal samples have been tested, with 9 classified as RVF positive (3 IgM and 6 IgG), 6 classified as suspected RVF (based on IgG and IgM serological titres), and 13 classified as RVF negative. Goats, sheep, and cattle in the area have shown evidence of zoonotic hemorrhagic illness, and abortions in livestock, disease in cattle, and wild bird die-offs have been reported.\n\nPublic Health Actions\n- In light of the confirmation of additional animal cases, a joint Ministry of Health and Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries press briefing is scheduled for 12 Mar 2018 to formally declare the outbreak in Yirol East county.\n- Investigation and response activities continue to be coordinated by a multi-sectoral task force that meets weekly at the national and sub-national (Yirol East) level.\n- On 6 Mar 2018, a high-level delegation led by the Minister of Health with participation of officials from the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries, WHO, and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) visited Yirol East. The delegation was briefed on the outbreak and status of prevention and response activities in Yirol East and other counties at risk.\n- State rapid response teams continue to investigate all new suspected RVF cases and are supporting the collection of samples to enable confirmatory laboratory testing.\n- Surveillance for human and animal cases by community health workers and community animal health workers is ongoing.\n- Community mobilization, engagement, and sensitization activities are ongoing in Yirol East, Yirol West, and Awerial counties with support from the Yirol East county health department, the Eastern Lakes State Ministry of Health, UNICEF, and Community Health and Development Organization (CHADO).\n- The development of a multi-sectoral RVF preparedness and response framework is ongoing.\n\nSituation Interpretation\nThe RVF outbreak in South Sudan continues to evolve, and the detection of suspected cases in a Yirol West county and confirmation of additional animal cases underscores the need to strengthen RVF preparedness, surveillance, and response capacity in human and animal populations at risk. Support from the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries, in collaboration with WHO, FAO, and partners will be needed to implement the necessary One Health interventions aimed at containing the disease in livestock and reducing the risk of animal to human RVF transmission. Extended human and animal health and entomological investigations into the event, and the nationalization of the multi-sectoral RVF preparedness and response framework are urgently needed to guide activities in this area. Technical support for the development of a long term RVF risk communication strategy is also needed, as such a strategy is a key component in reducing the risk of human RVF cases in this population.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is now clearly established that there is a Rift Valley fever outbreak in Eastern Lakes state involving both humans and livestock. The appearance of a new case in a different county (Yirol West) is unsettling. Addressing a new locality will complicate the surveillance and logistics of dealing with this outbreak. This outbreak now involves people and a variety of domestic animals. Fortunately, help is being provided to deal with this outbreak. A team of volunteers is working in close collaboration with the active case search team to engage the community and conduct risk communication. An understanding of the risks of handling infected animals is essential in avoiding more human cases, as is the avoidance of mosquito bites. The mission, comprised of representatives from the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries, the World Health Organization (WHO), and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), visited Yirol East on 6 Mar 2018 to consolidate response efforts and solicit more commitments by all stakeholders to contain the outbreak.\n\nThe RVF outbreak was 1st suspected in December 2017 [Information on the human cases and their tests were included in earlier posts. - Mod.AS].\n\nFollowing the reported cases and deaths, the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries, with support from WHO, FAO and other human and animal experts, launched a multi-sectoral response in the context of One Health for in-depth investigations to establish the exact cause of the reported deaths and illnesses in humans and animals.\n\nOne of the initial 7 animal samples tested at UVRI (Uganda Virus Research Institute) was positive for RVF. Furthermore, 8 out of 21 samples collected from animals tested positive for RVF at the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) reference laboratory in South Africa [Detailed test results of samples from animals, and a respective map, are available at https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/OEW10-39032018.pdf. - Mod.AS].\n\nA joint multi-sectoral contingency plan has been developed, which will be fully rolled out in Eastern Lakes to ensure RVF is contained. This will involve intensified surveillance in both humans and animals, risk communication, and case management.\n\nRVF is a viral zoonotic disease that primarily affects animals, but also has the capacity to infect humans. People are infected with RVF virus through contact with blood, body fluids, or tissues of RVF virus-infected animals, mainly livestock. This direct contact with infected animals can occur during slaughter or veterinary procedures, like assisting an animal giving birth. Less commonly, people can be infected with RVF virus from bites of infected mosquitoes and, rarely, from other biting insects that have the virus on their mouthparts. Spread from person to person has not been documented.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As indicated above, the main source of human RVF are animals, primarily sheep, goats, cattle, and camels. Early detection of the disease in animals is pre-conditional for the protection of human health. Unfortunately, as in many previous events, humans, instead of animals, have played the role of sentinels during the earlier stages of the current event.\n\nDisease surveillance is the main pillar of early detection and response, which may include preventive vaccination of the susceptible animal population, the potential source of human disease. Since January 2018, cases in both humans and livestock have been reported in this state. See map at http://iomsouthsudan.org/tracking/sites/default/publicfiles/documents/Lakes_YirolEast_Atlas.pdf.\n\n'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute, febrile, mosquito-borne, zoonotic disease caused by a virus of the family Bunyaviridae, genus Phlebovirus. It is usually present in epizootic form over large areas of a country following heavy rains and flooding and is characterised by high rates of abortion and neonatal mortality, primarily in sheep, goats, cattle and camels. The susceptibility of different species and breeds to RVF may vary considerably. Some animals may have inapparent infections, while others have severe clinical disease with mortality and abortion. Susceptible, older non-pregnant animals often do not show signs of disease.\n\nRVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas, favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\nRainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes mosquitoes_ acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals, and may potentially vertically transmit the virus, so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.' http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nEastern Lakes, South Sudan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63609]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\n Measures to be applied: movement control inside the country; quarantine; control of vectors; vector surveillance\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Onderstepoort Veterinary Institute, South Africa (OIE Reference Laboratory)\n Total outbreaks: 1\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Dec 2017\n Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 11 Dec 2017\n Total animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\n Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\n Outbreak 1: Wunthou, Lakes\nSummary of outbreaks\n Sheep/goats / - / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nAffected population: There were a few cases of abortion in cattle herds observed after heavy flooding in November 2017, when swampy areas formed, and the number of mosquitoes increased. South Sudan (04): (EL) human, livestock", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5675244", "date": "2018-03-09 12:23:47", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH SUDAN (04): (EASTERN LAKES) HUMAN LIVESTOCK\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Mar 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/south-sudan-additional-suspected-rift-valley-fever-death-reported-65702/\n\n\nThe Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak in Eastern Lakes state, South Sudan, has grown to 32 cases and 4 deaths, according to a World Health Organization (WHO) update published this week.\n\nDuring the past week, a 17-year-old male who presented to hospital on 19 Feb 2018 with a history of fever, headache, and joint pain that started the same day. On 21 Feb 2018, he vomited coffee grounds and frank blood, passed melena stools, lost consciousness, and died the same day. The case was positive for malaria by rapid diagnostic testing and a blood sample collected from the case was obtained for RVF testing. The deaths of goats and a cow have been reported in the neighborhood of the case.\n\nOverall, a total of 32 suspected RVF cases have been reported, including 5 confirmed cases (one of which was IgG and IgM positive and 4 which were IgG-only positive).\n\nOf 28 animal samples collected, one sample taken from a cow showed high RVF IgG titres indicative of previous RVF infection, 6 tested negative for RVF, and 21 samples are pending testing. Since the beginning of the outbreak, goats, sheep, and cattle in the area have shown evidence of zoonotic hemorrhagic illness and abortions in livestock, disease in cattle, and wild bird die-offs have been reported in the outbreak area.\n\nWHO says the suspected RVF outbreak in South Sudan continues to be closely monitored, and there is a continued need for support to strengthen national capacity for RVF preparedness, surveillance, and response.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne [viral disease] that is endemic in parts of Africa, including South Africa. It primarily infects animals like sheep, cattle, and goats and it can have an economic impact on a community due to the loss of livestock.\n\nHumans get infected through contact with infected animal blood or organs. Butchering and slaughtering of animals is a primary cause of transmission to humans. Certain occupations are at a higher risk of getting Rift Valley fever like farmers, herders, and veterinarians.\n\nIt can also be transmitted to humans through mosquito bites and the bites of blood-sucking flies.\n\nMost cases of Rift Valley fever are mild and symptoms include fever, headaches, and muscle pain. However, a small percentage of people can get serious disease, which includes retinitis, encephalitis, and a hemorrhagic fever. Fatalities happen in less than 1 percent of those infected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A recent release of information by the WHO also mentions the fatal human case and the seropositive cow. It also mentions that as of 24 Feb 2018, there were no cases hospitalized in Yirol East county (Eastern Lakes state). During the week, 8 human samples tested negative for Ebola, Marburg, Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever, RVF, and Sosuga viruses by PCR at the Uganda Viral Research Institute (UVRI). Serology testing of these samples for RVF is ongoing.\n\nOverall, a total of 32 suspected RVF cases have been reported, including 5 confirmed cases (one of which was IgG and IgM positive and 4 which were IgG-only positive), 3 probable cases who died, 12 suspected cases for whom complete laboratory results are pending (one of whom died), and 12 cases who were considered as non-cases following negative laboratory results for RVF. Excluding non-cases, the majority of suspected cases have been women (60 percent; 12/20), and individuals aged 20-39 years have comprised the majority (60 percent of cases (https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/OEW9-24022032018.pdf).\n\nThis outbreak now involves people and a variety of domestic animals. Fortunately, help is being provided to deal with this outbreak. A team of 27 volunteers is working in close collaboration with the active case search team to engage the community and conduct risk communication.\n\nCase searching and community mobilization have been activated in Awerial county following reports of cases and deaths of animals: between 16 and 26 Jan 2018, community mobilizers identified several cases in various locations. An understanding of the risks of handling infected animals is essential in avoiding more human cases. A vaccine is available for animals, although there is no mention of animal vaccination in this report.\n\nAs mentioned earlier, there have been undiagnosed cases of hemorrhagic disease in South Sudan several times before. In 2016, there was an outbreak of hemorrhagic disease. In that outbreak, several possible viruses were discarded by laboratory tests (see Undiagnosed hemorrhagic illness - South Sudan (02): addtl. information 20160625.4309572). It is difficult to know whether these earlier outbreaks were due to RVF or to something else.\n\nMaps of South Sudan: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/28_States_of_South_Sudan.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63609. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "Overall, a total of 32 suspected RVF cases have been reported, including 5 confirmed cases (one of which was IgG and IgM positive and 4 which were IgG-only positive), 3 probable cases who died, 12 suspected cases for whom complete laboratory results are pending (one of whom died), and 12 cases who were considered as non-cases following negative laboratory results for RVF. \n\nCase searching and community mobilization have been activated in Awerial county following reports of cases and deaths of animals: between 16 and 26 Jan 2018, community mobilizers identified several cases in various locations. Event\nOn Wed 7 Mar 2018, health officials warned of an ongoing outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Eastern Lakes state [South Sudan]. According to local sources, 32 suspected cases of RVF and 4 associated deaths were reported in recent weeks.\n\nHealth officials are reportedly taking active measures to prevent a larger outbreak of the disease.\n\n2. Context\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is an animal-borne virus (_Phlebovirus_) of the Bunyaviridae family. RVF is usually transmitted to people through contact with blood, secretions, organs, or other bodily fluids of infected domesticated and livestock animals (cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats, camels, etc.). Transmission can also occur via mosquitoes and other insects. Symptoms include high fever, back pain, and dizziness. When untreated, RVF can lead to severe ocular disease, vision loss, encephalitis, hemorrhagic fever, and even death. There is no vaccine available, and treatment is mostly limited to supportive care.\n\n3. Advice\nIndividuals in in Eastern Lakes state are advised to take measures against ticks, such as by wearing covering clothing and using insect repellent. Avoid close contact with livestock animals or with infected individuals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Earlier postings on the current RVF event in South Sudan addressed primarily the disease in humans, as noted since early 2018, before cases in animals became known. On 8 Mar 2018, South Sudan's national Veterinary Services reported to the OIE about 8 cases in cattle out of 2000 susceptible animals; the start of the event was given as 11 Dec 2017. Information on the affected population included the following details: 'There were a few cases of abortion in cattle herds observed after heavy flooding in November 2017, when swampy areas formed, and the number of mosquitoes increased. No mortalities in cattle have been reported. During the investigation, clinical signs consistent with Rift Valley fever were observed'. Please see the complete OIE report and commentary by Mod.CRD in archive no. 20180309.5675819.\n\nAccording to South Sudan's Ministry of Health's most recent RVF situation report (no. 8, published 16 Feb 2018; ref 1), human samples were submitted to Uganda's Virus Research Institute (UVRI) in Entebbe, where several were diagnosed positive for RVF. In addition, 21 samples collected from livestock were shipped to South Africa for laboratory testing. At the mentioned time of publication, their results were 'pending'. We will appreciate obtaining these results, in case available.\n\nFrom a reliable source we have noted that RVF virus is currently suspected to be circulating in the endemic area of Senegal, causing clinical cases in small ruminants. Confirmation and additional details will be appreciated. The last confirmed RVF outbreaks in animals in Senegal occurred in October 2013 in Dakar region; cases were recorded in goats, cattle, and Dorcas gazelles (see 20140318.2341029, 20131018.2008030, and 20130924.1964250).\n\nIn East Africa, particularly in Kenya, the epidemiological patterns of RVF are different from those described in West Africa, particularly in Senegal. In Kenya, several RVF outbreaks have been linked to prolonged heavy rainfall, whereas in Senegal, outbreaks usually occur during years of normal or poor rainfall. The main East African RVFV vectors are regarded to be _Aedes ochraceus_ and _Ae. mcintoshi_, while in West Africa the main vectors are _Ae. vexans arabiensis_, _Ae. ochraceus_, and _Culex poicilipes_. (For the said and additional entomological information from Senegal, see a recent paper -- ref 2).\n\nFAO issued an alert in mid-September 2017 to raise awareness about the risk of RVF vector amplification in Senegal, Mali, Mauritania, and Niger. Non-endemic countries, such as Nigeria, Chad, C\u00f4te d'Ivoire, and Ghana, also showed wide areas at risk due to long, persistent heavy rains.\n\nAccording to FAO's 'Food Chain Crisis Early Warning Bulletin' no. 26, 2 zoonotic animal diseases were 'representing a high or moderate risk to the food chain for the period January to March 2018': avian influenza and Rift Valley fever.\n\nIn several African and particularly in Middle Eastern countries (Egypt, Saudi Arabia) prevention of RVF is applied by animal vaccination.\n\nSubscribers are referred to FAO's new manual on RVF surveillance (ref 3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Farm animals are the main reservoirs and amplifiers of RVF virus.\n\nRVF outbreaks very often involve significant numbers of ill and dead small ruminant animals and abortions. It is odd that no small ruminant animal cases are mentioned, unless the animals had been vaccinated previously and are immune.\n\nRVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. Eradicating the virus from these areas is not possible with current technology.\n\nAs Mod. Disease in cattle / 1\n7 / Wild bird deaths / 1\n8 / Specimens collected:\n- Human since last update / 1\n- Human cumulative / 18\n- Animal sheep cumulative / 2\n- Animal goats cumulative / 2\n- Animal cattle cumulative / 3\n9 / Total samples shipped to WHO/FAO collaborating laboratories:\n- Human / 18\n- Animal / 7\n10 / Cumulative specimens (blood) collected:\n- Human / 18\n- Animal / 7\n11 / Number of cases with laboratory confirmation:\n- Human samples - PCR negative for Ebola, Marburg, CCHF, RVF, Sosuga / 13\n- Human samples - RVF serology - IgM and IgG positive (high titres) / 1\n- Human samples - RVF serology - IgG positive (high titres) / 2\n- Animal samples - RVF serology - IgG positive (high titres) / 1\n\nSituation update\n- Since the last update (of 26 Jan 2018), 6 new suspect RVF cases have been reported in Yirol East. These include 2 males and 4 females aged 7-60 years, and clustered in Wonthow payam, Yirol East county. There are currently no suspect cases on admission.\n- The number of alerts have continued to decline in the week with the last alert that met case definition being reported on 25 Jan 2018; 3 alerts were reported from 26 - 27 Jan 2018, but they all did not meet the case definition. From 28 Jan 2018 to date, there have been no new alerts from all the areas under surveillance.\n- However, reports of illness and death in Livestock are still rampant in the outbreak area where for example on 31 Jan 2018, the rapid response team witnessed 4 sick goats, one aborted and 2 had nose bleeding in Acigoor village close to the Thonabutkok village. The MLF/FAO team is conducting follow up investigations. Additional reports of animal deaths after short illness of 3-4 days in Pem cattle camp, Awerial county are also being investigated.\n- As of 2 Feb 2018, a total of 26 suspect RVF human cases have been reported in Eastern Lakes State. Out of the 26 suspect human cases reported since 7 Dec 2017, 3 human cases have been confirmed, 3 died and were classified as probable cases with epidemiological linkage to the 3 confirmed cases, 4 were classified as non-cases following negative laboratory results for RVF, and 16 are still classified suspect cases due to pending or partial laboratory sample testing.\n- During the week, 5 new samples were sent to Uganda Virus Research Institute (UVRI) for testing on 31 Jan 2018 and the test results are still pending.\n\nInitial reports on the event\n- On 28 Dec 2017, the Eastern Lakes Ministry of Health reported a suspect viral hemorrhagic fever cluster to the National Ministry of Health and WHO. The initial cluster involved 3 deaths in Thonabutkok village, Yali Payam, Yirol East county with 7 Dec 2017 as the earliest date of onset.\n- Preliminary investigations conducted by the County Health Department, State and National MoH, CUAMM, and WHO show that the 3 deaths had a severe hemorrhagic illness and were epidemiologically linked by place (Thonabutkok village) and time (with 49 and 51 as the respective epidemiological weeks of illness onset). However, there was no history of close physical contact between the cases and travel history was not significant. In addition, the symptoms were not reported in the respective close case contacts during the clinical illness or even after death.\n- There is significant history suggesting a zoonotic hemorrhagic illness as abortions in goats and sheep; deaths/disease in goats and cows; wild bird die-offs have been reported in association with this event cluster.\n\nBrief Case Clinical and Epidemiological Findings\n- The putative initial case was a 30-year-old female housewife from Thonabutkok village in Yirol East county. Her illness started on 7 Dec 2017 with fever, headache, neck pain and sudden nose, gum, and injection site bleeding. She reported to a health facility the same day where she was admitted in the maternity ward since she was pregnant. After 8 days of treatment with no improvement, she moved to a private clinic for 4 days where she was treated for malaria and typhoid fever. The illness worsened on 19 Dec 2017 and requested to return home. She died at home the same day. No supervised burial was done, and no symptomatic cases have been reported among the close contacts during the clinical illness and after death.\n- The 2nd case was a 13-year-old female from Thonabutkok village (approximately 150 meters from the putative initial case). Her illness started on 20 Dec 2017 with headache, joint pain, neck pain, fever, generalized swelling at the joints which were painful (ecchymosis), bleeding from the nose and gums. She died at home on 26 Dec 2017 after the she developed bleeding from the skin blisters. Goat and sheep abortions were reported in association with this case. No supervised burial was done, and no symptomatic cases have been reported among the close contacts during the clinical illness and after death.\n- The 3rd case was a 15-year-old male from Thonabutkok village. His illness started on 24 Dec 2017 with headache, fever, sweating, and neck pain, nose bleeding, vomiting of blood and gum bleeding, convulsions and loss of consciousness. He died at home on 27 Dec 2017 after failing to improve on treatment in a private clinic. in the case neighborhood, 8 goat deaths with extensive hemorrhage were reported (the goats were skinned, cooked and eaten). No supervised burial was done, and no symptomatic cases have been reported among the close contacts during the clinical illness and after death.\n- As of 2 Feb 2018, the cumulative number of suspect RVF cases had risen to a total of 26 suspect RVF cases including 3 deaths, all reported in Eastern Lakes State. Active surveillance is ongoing to detect, investigate, and initiate supportive care for new suspect cases.\n- The case fatality rate among suspect, probable and confirmed cases (excluding non-cases) is 13.64 percent (3/22). More cases have been reported among females 15 (68.1 percent) than males 7 (32.82 percent) (Figure 1).\n- Most of the cases have been reported in the 20-19-year age-group with most cases occurring the 10-19-year age-group in the males, while in the females, most cases are reported in the 0-9-year, 20-29-year, and 30-39-year age-groups (Figure 2). The deaths occurred in the 10-19-year and 30-39-year age-groups (Figure 3).\n- Figures 4 and 5 show the distribution of cases by time and outcome/epi-classification. The initial probable cases occurred between week 49-52, 2017. During weeks 3 and 4, an increase in suspect cases has been registered, though none have been confirmed.\n- Figure 6 shows the distribution of clinical symptoms among suspect, probable, and confirmed cases (excluding non-cases). The most frequent symptoms are non-specific and include fever, headache, neck pains, and joint pains. Bleeding has been reported in 82 percent of suspect cases but none of the confirmed cases had bleeding.\n- All the 22 probable, confirmed, and suspect cases (excluding the non-cases) have been reported from Yirol East county in Eastern Lakes state (Figure 7). In Yirol East county, cases have been reported from 5 payams with most 9 (40.90 percent) cases and all the 3 deaths reported from Yali payam.\n- All the probable and confirmed cases are clustered in Yali Payam, Thonabutkok village (Figures 8 and 9).\n\nResponse updates\nOverall coordination of investigation and response activities:\n- The overall coordination of investigation and response activities is currently coordinated by a multi-sectoral taskforce that is meeting weekly at the national level and sub-national (Yirol East) level.\n- The RVF taskforce meetings at the national and state level were held on 31 Jan 2018 and 1 Feb 2018, respectively. The Yirol East taskforce meeting was chaired by the Director General with the following partners in attendance WHO, UNICEF, FAO, CUAMM, LiveWell, HELP, CCOSS, and CHADO. The highlights of the meeting included:\n- The need to intensify animal health investigation and response interventions.\n- The arrival of the Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries/FAO team that will be in Yirol East for one week to conduct animal health investigations, train community animal health workers, and enhance community awareness to facilitate reporting animal cases and promote hygienic animal handling.\n- The Ministry of Health, WHO, and CUAMM are currently implementing active case surveillance and alert response.\n- There is need for logistical support (fuel) for the 3 vehicles donated by MOH to continue supporting activities. WHO and CUAMM have stepped in to provide fuel in the last weeks.\n- The draft contingency plan will be discussed in detail in the meeting next week once the animal health components are incorporated.\n\nSurveillance and case management\n- The surveillance, laboratory, entomology, and case management sub-committee meeting convened on 26 Jan 2018 in Juba to review the terms or reference, action, plan and surveillance guidelines including the case definition.\n- The WHO/MoH rapid response team is on the group to support the overall coordination, investigation, and response activities in Eastern Lakes state.\n- With support from WHO, The MoH has drafted health workers guidelines on RVF case surveillance, investigation, case management, and control. The draft guidelines have been disseminated for input by committee members and subject matter experts at the international level.\n- WHO supported 6 teams with a total of 25 community health workers that are conducting active case in the Yirol East. These community health workers have detected and reported alerts from Yali, Pagarua, Tinagau, Khap, Nyanga and Lekakudu payams in the last one week. In Yirol West, the team of 15 community health workers conducted active case search in Anuol and Aruau payams in the last one week. The team also conducted active case search in Aruau PHCU, Acigoor PHCU and Pagarau PHCU.\n- The Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries/FAO animal health team arrived in Yirol West on 31 Jan 2018 and participated in the Yirol East taskforce meeting of 1 Feb 2018. The team is expected to lead the animal health investigation and response interventions including sample collection and mobilisation of communities to report sick animals and promote sanitary animal handling.\n\nWeekly update on UNICEF support to the ongoing RVF outbreak (25 Jan- 1 Feb 2018)\n- CHADO (UNICEF implementing partner) continued with community engagement, case search and reporting of suspected cases and death of animals. The CHADO team of 27 volunteers is working in close collaboration with the active case search team to engage the community and conduct risk communication.\n- Case searching and community mobilization have been activated in Awerial county following reports of cases and deaths of animals: between 16-26 Jan [2018], community mobilizers identified several cases in various locations (97 goats died; one goat had a abortion; 12 cows had sign and symptoms of RVF, and 4 cows died). However, these are pending verification by the MLF/FAO animal health team.\n- 82 705 people in Yirol East and 5619 people in Awerial county have been reached through house-to-house visits, community meetings; radio continues to air key messages on RVF.\n- Orientation of 8 CHADO Mobilizers on key preventive messages and IPC skills were conducted by UNICEF technical officers in Thonabutkok area.\n- 40 flyers with key preventive messages on RVF were distributed to CHADO mobilizers today in Thonabutkok area for community sensitization and an additional 2500 IEC materials are being produced for distribution.\n- 200 LLINs have been delivered to Thonabutkok area and will be distributed to 60 households.\n- A taskforce coordination meeting was attended by UNICEF C4D & Health officers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of new suspected cases continues to increase. Charles Olaro, acting director general of health services at the ministry of health, said in a statement that blood samples taken from 2 dead patients in Mityana and Kiboga tested positive for RVF.\n\nThe 2 were a 26 year old male forest ranger, who died on 16 Nov [2017], and a 69 year old male farmer and fisherman, who died on 21 Nov [2017]. Olaro said the National Rapid Response Team has been sent to support the district response structures to contain the outbreak.\n\nRVF is a viral zoonosis that can also infect humans. Most human infections result from contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The disease can result in significant economic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected livestock.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As mentioned in previous posts, Rift Valley fever virus is endemic in Uganda, and human cases occur there sporadically. The above report makes no mention of cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in domestic animals in the area where the human cases occurred. Farm animals are the main reservoirs and amplifiers of RVF virus.\n\nRVF outbreaks very often involve significant numbers of ill and dead small ruminant animals. It is odd that no small ruminant animal cases are mentioned, unless the animals had been vaccinated previously and are immune.\n\nRVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in aedes vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. Eradicating the virus from these areas is not possible with current technology.\n\nAs Mod.AB noted: 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a major zoonotic disease caused by a virus of the genus _Phlebovirus_ of the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by mosquitoes of the genus _Aedes_.' - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Uganda showing the districts mentioned above can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11507.]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As mentioned in previous posts, Rift Valley fever virus is endemic in Uganda, and human cases occur there sporadically. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in aedes vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. \n\nThe 2 were a 26 year old male forest ranger, who died on 16 Nov [2017], and a 69 year old male farmer and fisherman, who died on 21 Nov [2017]. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by mosquitoes of the genus _Aedes_.' Charles Olaro, acting director general of health services at the ministry of health, said in a statement that blood samples taken from 2 dead patients in Mityana and Kiboga tested positive for RVF. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. \n\nRVF outbreaks very often involve significant numbers of ill and dead small ruminant animals.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Mityana", "country": "Uganda"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5582524", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Gambia: (BJ) WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5582524", "date": "2018-01-24 23:34:22", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - THE GAMBIA: (BANJUL) WHO\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 Jan 2018\nSource: WHO [edited]\nhttp://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/259885/1/OEW03-1319012018.pdf\n\n\nOn [3 Jan 2018], the Ministry of Health of Senegal notified WHO of a case of Rift Valley fever (RVF) reported from a hospital in Dakar. On [29 Dec 2017], a blood sample taken from a 52-year-old Korean man, resident in the Gambia, done at the Institute Pasteur Dakar, was positive for RVF on IgM testing. Previous PCR testing had been negative for RVF and other arboviruses.\n\nThe case patient worked for a fishing company in the Gambia and had no known history of handling raw meat. On [5 Dec 2017], the case patient travelled with his brother and 2 colleagues from Banjul, the Gambia, to Ziguinchor, Senegal. On [8 Dec 2017], the case patient continued travelling with his brother, a colleague, and a driver, from Ziguinchor to Bissau, Guinea-Bissau, and continued to Buba the following day. On [10 Dec 2017], the case patient returned from Buba to Bissau, and presented with a dry cough, fever, headache, and joint pain. His brother and the driver also developed a dry cough on [10 Dec 2017], which improved the following day. The group returned to the Gambia (via Ziguinchor) on [12 Dec 2017]. The case patient, however, continued to suffer a persistent cough during this time. On his return to Banjul, he additionally developed fever, headache, and vertigo. He was hospitalized on [20 Dec 2017] and diagnosed with severe malaria. On [23 Dec 2017], he became delirious and developed psychomotor agitation, profuse mucousy diarrhoea, bile-stained vomiting, and haemorrhage. On [25 Dec 2017], he became comatose and was evacuated by ambulance to Dakar. His symptoms improved, and blood samples were taken on 26, 28, and 30 Dec 2017. However, he experienced a recurrence of haemorrhagic symptoms on 31 Dec 2017 and died the same day.\n\nPublic health actions\n\nA case investigation was conducted by a multidisciplinary team from the Centre of Health Emergency Operations of the Ministry of Health of Senegal. As part of this investigation, blood samples were collected from the brother of the case and the colleague and driver who accompanied him to Guinea-Bissau. These samples were all negative for RVFV by PCR. The results of the investigation and recommendations for action from the Ministry of Health of Senegal are pending. A case investigation was conducted by a multidisciplinary team from the Epidemic and Disease Control Unit of the Ministry Health of the Gambia. Enhanced RVF surveillance in the animal population and community RVF sensitization have been implemented in the country.\n\nSituation interpretation\n\nOutbreaks of RVF are uncommon in the Gambia and its neighbouring countries. The last documented human case of RVF in the Gambia was reported in 2002. There is currently no indication of risk of a major RVF outbreak in the Gambia, Senegal, or Guinea-Bissau. Heavy rainfall, causing flooding and mass emergence RVF vectors, _Aedes_ and _Culex spp._ mosquitoes, is closely associated with RVF outbreaks. Uncontrolled movement of livestock can increase the risk of spread of the disease to new areas. RVF can cause trade reductions and important economic losses due to high mortality and abortion rates among infected livestock. Integrated control measures that address both human and animal health are therefore necessary (e.g. preventive animal vaccination, vector control, control of animal movements, educational campaigns for populations at risk).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[The case, who travelled in 3 different countries (The Gambia, Senegal, and Bissau) was diagnosed as being affected by malaria. Later, this person and people accompanying him exhibited symptoms that can be attributed to RVF. However, all of the other 3 tested negative, while the case was diagnosed RVF positive on IgM testing and negative on PCR. The situation needs some clarification, especially since it is not the flooding season in the region, which favors the multiplication of disease vector insects and thereby precipitates the appearance of RVF in animals with possible contamination of humans. - Mod.AB]\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. Eradicating the virus from these areas is not possible with current technology.\n\nAlthough ProMED-mail has not previously posted cases of RVF in the Gambia, there is a report from neighboring Senegal. - Mod.TY\n\nMauritania, a country in close proximity (neighboring with Senegal to its north) has also experience recurrent outbreaks of RVF (see prior ProMED-mail posts below). - Mod.MPP\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nGambia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/481]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[The case, who travelled in 3 different countries (The Gambia, Senegal, and Bissau) was diagnosed as being affected by malaria.
