She is from Arwa Village in Yirol West (not Yirol East like the suspect cases reported previously) and has no linkage with the cases reported previously. Sample was collected and shipped for testing.\n- During the week, one of the contacts, an 18-year-old; 7-month pregnant female in Thonabutkok village (village of initial case) and contact to the initial case developed symptoms on [9 Jan 2018]. The symptoms included chills, joint pains, headache, neck pains and 2 episodes of epistaxis. Updates on her status and sample collection to follow.\n- There have been no other alerts from the village or other neighbouring communities; surveillance has been heightened, and facilities have been urged to report any suspected cases.\n- During the week, a total of 7 human samples were collected and shipped to Uganda Virus Research Institute (UVRI) for testing: 6 samples were from close contacts (asymptomatic) and the 7th sample was obtained from the new suspect case in Yirol West (see above).\n- The 7 human samples initially tested negative on [10 Jan 2018] (by PCR) for Ebola, Marburg, CCHF, RVF and Sosuga viruses.\n- Follow up serological testing showed one sample had high RVF IgM and IgG and another 2 samples had high RVF IgG titres.\n- A total of 7 animal (2 sheep; 2 goat; and 3 cattle) samples have also been shipped to UVRI for testing but the test results are pending.\n\nInitial reports on the event\n- On [28 Dec 2017], the Eastern Lakes Ministry of Health reported a suspect viral hemorrhagic fever cluster to the National Ministry of Health and WHO. The initial cluster involved 3 deaths in Thonabutkok village, Yali Payam, Yirol East county with [7 Dec 2017] as the earliest date of onset.\n- Preliminary investigations conducted by the County Health Department, State and National MoH, CUAMM, and WHO show that the 3 deaths had a severe hemorrhagic illness and were epidemiologically linked by place (Thonabutkok village) and time (with 49 and 51 as the respective epidemiological weeks of illness onset). However, there was no history of close physical contact between the cases and travel history was not significant. In addition, the symptoms were not reported in the respective close case contacts during the clinical illness or even after death.\n- There is significant history suggesting a zoonotic hemorrhagic illness as abortions in goats and sheep; deaths/disease in goats and cows; wild bird die-offs have been reported in association with this event cluster.\n\nBrief clinical and epidemiological findings\n-------------------------------------------\n- The putative initial case was a 30-year-old female housewife from Thonabutkok village in Yirol East county. Her illness started on [7 Dec 2017] with fever, headache, neck pain and sudden nose, gum, and injection site bleeding. She reported to a health facility the same day where she was admitted in maternity ward since she was pregnant. After 8 days of treatment with no improvement, she moved to a private clinic for 4 days where she was treated for malaria and typhoid fever. The illness worsened on [19 Dec 2017] and requested to return home. She died at home the same day. No supervised burial was done and no symptomatic cases have been reported among the close contacts during the clinical illness and after death.\n- The 2nd case was a 13-year-old female from Thonabutkok village (approximately 150 meters from the putative initial case). Her illness started on [20 Dec 2017] with headache, joint pain, neck pain, fever, generalized swelling at the joints which were painful (ecchymosis), bleeding from the nose and gums. She died at home on [26 Dec 2017] after the she developed bleeding from the skin blisters. Goat and sheep abortions were reported in association with this case. No supervised burial was done and no symptomatic cases have been reported among the close contacts during the clinical illness and after death.\n- The 3rd case was a 15-year-old male from Thonabutkok village. His illness started on [24 Dec 2017] with headache, fever, sweating, and neck pain, nose bleeding, vomiting of blood and gum bleeding, convulsions and loss of consciousness. He died at home on [27 Dec 2017] after failing to improve on treatment in a private clinic. In the case neighborhood 8 goat deaths with extensive hemorrhage were reported (the goats were skinned, cooked and eaten). No supervised burial was done and no symptomatic cases have been reported among the close contacts during the clinical illness and after death.\n- The most recent suspect case involves a 14-year-old girl from Arwa Village in Yirol West. She presented on [9 Jan 2017] with fever and conjunctival injection. She had no epidemiological linkage to the 3 suspect cases reported previously. Sample was collected and shipped for testing.\n- At least 60 contacts have been listed for follow up.\n\nResponse updates\n----------------\nOverall coordination of investigation and response activities\n- A multi-disciplinary national rapid response team headed by the Director General Preventive Health Services from the National Ministry of Health and a Technical Officer from the Ministry of Livestock are supporting investigation and response activities in Yirol East.\n- At the national level, the MoH is collaboration with the Ministry of Animal Health Resources and Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) are working alongside the national taskforce to conduct animal health investigations and containment measures.\n- The state level outbreak taskforce is activated in Yirol East and is meeting daily with full technical support from the National Ministry of Health, Ministry of Livestock, WHO, and partners.\n- During the week, the National EPR meeting was held and stakeholders are working to enhance multi-sectoral coordination, update stock levels, preposition supplies, and update the VHF response plan.\n- CDC has also shared generic IEC materials on RVF for adaptation to the South Sudan context.\n- There are ample supplies of personal protective equipment and sample collection kits in the country to support the current outbreak response needs.\n- 2 laboratories have been identified to conduct any further laboratory testing required: Uganda Virus Research Institute (UVRI) in Uganda and IPD in Senegal.\n- Mentor Initiative has offered to lead the entomological investigations into this event on the basis of an official request from the taskforce, Government, or health cluster. A protocol for the entomological investigations has been drafted.\n- Unicef has drafted key messages on Rift Valley fever to enhance awareness and mitigate the risk of the disease at community level.\n\nPlanned activities and way forward\n----------------------------------\n- Ministry of Health to convene regular multisectoral and multi-agency meetings to coordinate investigation and response activities.\n- Update the Viral Hemorrhagic Fever response plan to conform to the standard RVF recommended interventions that are tailored to the South Sudan context.\n- Re-orient the national and sub-national multi-sectoral outbreak response coordination towards enhancing national capacities for RVF surveillance and outbreak prevention and control.\n- Enhance social mobilization and public health education on RVF prevention and control by finalizing the communication strategy and disseminating the messages.\n- Conduct extended public health, animal health, and entomological investigations into the event by - Ministry of Health; Ministry of Animal Health Resources and Fisheries, WHO, FAO, Health Cluster, and partners.\n- Strengthen animal and public health surveillance to ensure that new human/animal events are promptly detected.\n- Disseminate regular updates by way of situation reports and/or press statements/releases as the situation evolves.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[At least some of these human cases point to Rift Valley fever (RVF) as the etiological agent. The ruminant cases (sheep, goats and cattle) are also compatible with RVF. However, until the laboratory results are available, the RVF diagnosis should be made with some caution. There is always the possibility that more than one pathogen is circulating in this locality. However, the main hemorrhagic fever agents have been excluded in the 10 Jan 2018 laboratory tests. Source: WHO Situation Report (SitRep 3) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/hac/crises/ssd/sitreps/south-sudan-rift-valley-fever-14january2018.pdf?ua=1", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-01-09 00:00:00", "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "2017-12-25 00:00:00", "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2051-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Thonabutkok", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "South Sudan"}, {"location": "Arwa Village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Thonabutkok village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marburg", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5243601", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Europe: vector competence", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5243601", "date": "2017-08-11 14:10:19", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EUROPE: VECTOR COMPETENCE\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2015\nSource: Medical and Veterinary Entomology journal [edited]\nhttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/mve.12254/full\n\n\nRef: Brustolin M, Talavera S, Nunez A, et al. Rift Valley fever virus and European mosquitoes: vector competence of _Culex pipiens_ and _Stegomyia albopicta_ (_Aedes albopictus_). Med Vet Entomol. 2017 Aug 7. doi: 10.1111/mve.12254. [Epub ahead of print]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a mosquito-borne disease caused by the Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV). Rift Valley fever affects a large number of species, including human, and has severe impact on public health and the economy, especially in African countries. The present study examined the vector competence of 3 different European mosquito species, _Culex pipiens_ (Linnaeus, 1758) form _molestus_ (Diptera: Culicidae), _Cx. pipiens_ hybrid form, and _Stegomyia albopicta_ (_Aedes albopictus_) (Skuse, 1894) (Diptera: Culicidae). Mosquitoes were artificially fed with blood containing RVFV. Infection, disseminated infection and transmission efficiency were evaluated. This is the 1st study to assess the transmission efficiency of European mosquito species using a virulent RVFV strain. The virus disseminated in _Cx. pipiens_ hybrid form and in _S. albopicta_. Moreover, infectious viral particles were isolated from saliva of both species, showing their RVFV transmission capacity. The presence of competent _Cx. pipiens_ and _S. albopicta_ in Spain indicates that an autochthonous outbreak of RVF may occur if the virus is introduced. These findings provide information that will help health authorities to set up efficient entomological surveillance and RVFV vector control programmes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[RVFV can move outside the traditionally endemic sub-Saharan region and into other regions, as demonstrated in the past in Comoros Islands, Madagascar, Egypt, and the Arabian Peninsula. In addition to these regions, which are geographically adjacent to RVFV-endemic countries, in other more distant areas of the world the ecological infrastructure exists to allow RVFV to potentially thrive in vector, wildlife, livestock, and human hosts. The virus could be purposefully introduced into new areas as a tactic of bioterrorism, or moved accidentally via viremic mosquitoes (including infected mosquito eggs), humans, wildlife, or livestock along the extensive networks of global transportation, expanding the range of the virus to other continents. Humans, for instance, may develop RVFV viremia sufficient to infect naive mosquitoes. Laboratory studies have demonstrated that European as well as North American mosquito species of medical or veterinary importance can become infected with and transmit RVFV (see also Table 2 in ref 1 below).\n\nPrevention might best be exercised through vigilance and monitoring of RVF activity in endemic settings and increased vigilance for RVFV at high-risk locations in other continents that are connected to these endemic areas.\n\nAn extensive discussion of the issue can be found in a recent US-government sponsored review (1).\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Linthicum, KJ, Britch, SC, Anyamba, A. Rift Valley fever: an emerging mosquito-borne disease. Annu Rev Entomol. 2016; 61: 395-415. doi:10.1146/annurev-ento-010715-023819; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26982443.\n- Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[RVFV can move outside the traditionally endemic sub-Saharan region and into other regions, as demonstrated in the past in Comoros Islands, Madagascar, Egypt, and the Arabian Peninsula. All 3 samples tested negative for all arboviruses included on the molecular panel, namely: dengue, West Nile, RVF, chikungunya, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and Ebola. However, one sample was anti-RVF virus IgM positive on serology testing by ELISA.\n\nEarlier this month [July 2017], the district rapid response team was deployed to the affected village to conduct outbreak investigation. The team observed that the affected village is served by a large diameter well, with shepherds in seasonal movement with their livestock living nearby and regularly visiting the village.\n\nScore of samples were taken from villagers and domestic animals. Test results are pending.\n\nThe World Health Organization says the occurrence of a sporadic case of RVF in a village in Mali is not surprising.\n\nDuring August-November 2016, communities in the Tahoua Region, Niger (on the border with Mali) experienced an outbreak of RVF. And in January this year [2017], OIE confirmed RVF virus as the cause of abortions in sheep and goats across the border in Menaka, Mali (some 1700 km [1056 mi] from the abovementioned outbreaks).\n\nNevertheless, the detection of even a single case warrants an immediate emergency response, as such cases are often an early indication of widespread infection in livestock populations, associated with abortions with devastating economic impacts. Though the disease in humans is often subclinical or mild, 8 to 10 percent of cases develop severe symptoms, including ocular disease, encephalitis and/or haemorrhagic fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is endemic in may sub-Saharan countries, including Mali. Cases occur sporadically in livestock and in humans. Mod.AS provided an excellent comment on RVF previously; 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised [in some domestic animals] by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older, non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur, and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\n'Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\n'RVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\n'Rainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus [transovarily] so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\n'Low level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\n'During an outbreak, preventive measures to protect workers from infection should be employed when there are suspicions that RVFV-infected animals or animal products are to be handled.\n\n'The above and much more information is available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf.'\n\nAlthough ProMED-mail has received relatively few reports of RVF in Mali, there have been cases reported this year (2017) in neighboring Mauritania and Niger.\n\nOulessebougou is located 80 km (50 mi) south of Bamako in southwestern Mali. A political map of Mali can be accessed at http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/mali_map.htm and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Mali can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29544. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus [transovarily] so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. Its occurrence in the neighbouring countries of Benin, Burkina Faso and Nigeria is considered less probable, between unlikely (a 10-30% chance) and as likely as not (a 33-66 percent chance).\n\nThe experts are of the opinion that RVF is unlikely to spread into Algeria, Libya or Morocco in the next 3 to 5 years.\n\nAnimal movements, trade and changes in weather conditions are the main risk factors in RVF (re)occurring in West Africa and spreading to unaffected areas.\n\nImproving human health and the capacities of veterinary services to recognize the clinical signs of RVF in humans and animals are crucial for rapid RVF detection and response.\n\nFinally, to prevent human infection, the most feasible measure is to put in place communication campaigns for farmers and the general public.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the Bunyaviridae family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older, non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur, and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\nHumans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\nRVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\nRainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. Aedes mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\nLow level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\nDuring an outbreak, preventive measures to protect workers from infection should be employed when there are suspicions that RVFV-infected animals or animal products are to be handled.\n\nThe above and much more information is available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf.\n\nSubscribers are encouraged to read the full FAO risk analysis document at the source URL. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In the view of the experts participating in this risk assessment, Rift Valley fever (RVF) in Niger currently poses a medium risk (a mean score of 5.75 on a scale of 0 to 10) to human health and a medium-high risk (a mean score of 6.5) to animal health. \n\nHumans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. Source: FAO Animal Health Risk Analysis RVF in Niger [edited]\nhttp://www.fao.org/3/a-i7055e.pdf\n\n\nSummary\n \n\nAnimal movements, trade and changes in weather conditions are the main risk factors in RVF (re)occurring in West Africa and spreading to unaffected areas. Mod AS provided an excellent comment on RVF previously; 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older, non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur, and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\n'Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\n'RVFV is endemic in many African countries and may involve several countries in the region at the same time or progressively expand geographically over the course of a few years. In addition to Africa, large outbreaks have been observed in the Arabian Peninsula and some Indian Ocean Islands. These generally, but not exclusively, follow the periodic cycles of unusually heavy rainfall, which may occur at intervals of several years, or the flooding of wide areas favouring the proliferation of mosquitoes.\n\n'Rainfall facilitates mosquito eggs to hatch. _Aedes_ mosquitoes acquire the virus from feeding on infected animals and may potentially vertically transmit the virus so that new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch from their eggs. This provides a potential mechanism for maintaining the virus in nature, as the eggs of these mosquitoes may survive for periods of up to several years in dry conditions. Once livestock is infected, a wide variety of mosquito species may act as the vector for transmission of RVFV and can spread the disease.\n\n'Low level RVF activity may take place during inter-epizootic periods. RVF should be suspected when exceptional flooding and subsequent abundant mosquito populations are followed by the occurrence of abortions, together with fatal disease marked by necrosis and haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs, kids and calves, potentially concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like illness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\n'During an outbreak, preventive measures to protect workers from infection should be employed when there are suspicions that RVFV-infected animals or animal products are to be handled.\n\n'The above and much more information is available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_RVF.pdf.'\n\nProMED would appreciate receiving additional information including laboratory results about this case and any new ones that might appear as they become available, in addition to information on presumed location of infection as the diagnosis was made in the capital city, but no mention of where the individual came from. - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/51.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/26556.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[If this case were to be definitively confirmed in the laboratory, it would have occurred almost 18 months after the series of cases, including 4 fatal cases, which Mauritania had experienced over various provinces in October 2015. The outbreak started in August [2016] in the Tahoua region.\n\nThe fear from UN health officials is that the viral disease my spread in West Africa. 'Herders migrating with infected livestock pose the biggest risk of the epidemic crossing borders,' Oumarou Maidadji, medical coordinator for The Alliance for International Medical Action (ALIMA), told the Thomson Reuters Foundation by phone.\n\nNomadic stockbreeders from Niger and neighboring countries have just participated in the Cure Sal\u00e9e festival, a major annual mass gathering event from 23-25 Sep [2016]. During this festival, herds are brought to graze on the salty pastures ahead of the dry season. Around 2 million cattle and even more small ruminants were expected to be part of the event.\n\nRift Valley fever is a mosquitoborne virus that is endemic in parts of Africa including South Africa. It primarily infects animals like sheep, cattle and goats and it can have an economic impact on a community due to the loss of livestock. Humans get infected through contact with infected animal blood or organs. Butchering and slaughtering of animals is a primary cause of transmission to humans. Certain occupations are at a higher risk of getting Rift Valley fever like farmers, herders and veterinarians. It can also be transmitted to humans through mosquito bites and the bites of blood-sucking flies.\n\nMost cases of Rift Valley fever are mild and symptoms include fever, headaches and muscle pain. However, a small percentage of people can get serious disease which includes retinitis, encephalitis and a hemorrhagic fever. Fatalities happen in less than 1 per cent of those infected.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of human Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases has increased over those given in the 29 Sep 2016 ProMED-mail post (archive no. 20160929.4525684). [edited]\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28861841\n\n\nCitation\n--------\nGur S, Kale M, Erol N, Yapici O, Mamak N and Yavru S. The first serological evidence for Rift Valley fever infection in the camel, goitered gazelle and Anatolian water buffaloes in Turkey. Trop Anim Health Prod. 2017 Aug 31. doi: 10.1007/s11250-017-1359-8. [Epub ahead of print]\n\nAbstract\n--------\nRift valley fever (RVF), a vector-borne zoonotic disease, is caused by a _phlebovirus_ (family _Bunyaviridae_). The virus was initially characterized approximately 80 years ago in Kenya and disseminated to many countries in the continental Africa, Saudi Arabia, and Yemen. The infection has not been reported in Turkey. In this study, blood serum samples collected from camel (_Camelus dromedairus_), goitered gazelle (_Gazella subgutturosa subgutturosa_), and buffaloes (_Bubalus bubalis linneaus_) from 2000 to 2006 were investigated for RVF using C-ELISA. Camel samples (n of 72) were obtained from private small enterprises in Ayd\u0131n province in the Aegean region. Gazella samples (82) were taken from the biggest captive gazelle herd in \u015eanl\u0131urfa province in the southeast Anatolia. Buffalo samples were collected mostly from small private family type farms in Afyon (168), Amasya (80), Samsun (69), Ankara (35), Sivas (21), Tokat (19), Konya (10), and Elaz\u0131g (8) provinces in the central, north, west, and east Anatolia. All of the gazella samples were negative; whereas, one of the 71 camel samples (1.3 percent) was positive for RVF-specific antibodies. Buffalos from Sivas, Tokat, Konya, and Elaz\u0131g provinces were negative. However, 35 of the 410 samples (8.5 percent) from rural areas in the following 4 provinces were positive: Amasya (12/80, 15 percent), Ankara (5/35, 14.2 percent), Samsun (8/69, 11.5 percent), and Afyon (10/168, 5.9 percent). To our knowledge, this is the first report of presence of RVF infection in Turkey.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favoring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterized, in the susceptible animal species, by abortion, neonatal mortality and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an unapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality and abortion occurs and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle.\n\nHumans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes. RVFV has also caused serious infections in laboratory workers and must be handled with biosafety and biocontainment measures. It is recommended that laboratory workers be vaccinated if possible.\n\nUntil 1977, RVF was known to be limited to sub-Saharan Africa, mainly as an animal disease with zoonotic potential; in humans, it was mainly manifested as a self-limited febrile illness with the occasional complication of retinal lesions. During these years, the interest in the disease beyond Africa was practically limited to those engaged in potential biological warfare agents. In 1977, the disease was recorded, for the 1st time, in Egypt where it caused a major event with critical impact upon human health, continuing during 1978. The disease was associated with severe and fatal hemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. An official Egyptian report counted 598 deaths. Estimates of clinical cases from field workers exceeded 200 000 (Egypt's population at that time was 41 million). The animal industry suffered serious losses due to clinical disease, abortions, decreased production and deaths. Mortality was high in sheep and cattle; it was intermediate or low in buffaloes, camels and goats. The disease spread throughout many of Egypt's governorates, one of the heaviest affected being Sharqia, bordering the Suez canal.\n\nThe Egyptian event, which was signified by an unprecedented severity of the disease in humans combined with the spread of the virus into the Mediterranean basin, caused alarm elsewhere and attracted the attention of the international community and to its potential to spread further into receptive ecosystems. During the event, one seropositive goat was recorded in northern Sinai, some 60 km [approx. 36 mi] east of the Suez canal which divides Africa from Asia (Bir el-'Abd, map at http://tinyurl.com/y7j2v7xd). This animal was found not to be an endemic case since it had been transported from Sharqia. In 1979, 7 Swedish UN Emergency Forces soldiers serving in Egypt and the Sinai peninsula tested serologically positive to RVF virus. It was considered that they had contracted RVF while on duty in their posts in western Sinai, or while visiting Egypt. On the other hand, in 1979 RVF was diagnosed in Canada, in a 41-year-old Canadian woman who likely contracted the infection in Kenya; this case was cited as a potential exposure to Canadian livestock had she returned directly to her rural Canadian home.\n\nSince 1978, exacerbations of RVF have been reported several times from Egypt, Mass vaccination of ruminants have been applied there annually to the present day. In 2000, Yemen and Saudi Arabia became the first Asian countries infected by RVF, which most probably originated in East Africa. This was preceded by a major outbreak in East Africa which started in late 1997 and sickened some 90 000 people, of which almost 500 people died; animal herds were seriously affected. In March 2001, the accumulated number of human cases in Saudi Arabia was reported to be 882, of which 124 died. The disease re-emerged in Saudi Arabia in 2004 and 2010. No other countries outside Africa are known to have been infected so far; a reported suspicion of the disease in Iraq, 2001, remained unconfirmed.\n\nIn the discussion chapter of the current paper, which deals with samples collected in northern Turkey between 2000 and 2006, the authors suggest that RVF infection was introduced into Anatolia at the time of outbreaks in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, probably through Syria and Iraq via uncontrolled movement of animals and vectors. No clinical or suspected RVF cases, in humans or animals, have been reported from Turkey. The authors conclude that large scale serological and virological studies are necessary to determine the status of the infection to prevent possible dangers to Turkey and Europe.\n\nThis conclusion is compatible with several scientific assessments of RVF potential and epidemiological studies; some of them are presented in the following reference list.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Arsevska E, Hellal J, Mejri S, et al. Identifying Areas Suitable for the Occurrence of Rift Valley Fever in North Africa: Implications for Surveillance. Transbound Emerg Dis. 2016;63(6):658-674. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Arsevska+E%2C+Hellal+J%2C+Mejri+S.\n\n2. A. Bosworth A, Ghabbari T, Dowall S, et al. Serologic evidence of exposure to Rift Valley fever virus detected in Tunisia. New Microbes New Infect. 2015;9:1-7. Available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4678919/.\n\n3. Rolin, A., Berrang-Ford, L. and Kulkami, M. The risk of Rift Valley fever virus introduction and establishment in the United States and European Union. Emerg Microbes Infect. 2013; 2(12): e81. Available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3880870/pdf/emi201381a.pdf.\n\n4. Fischer EA, Boender GJ, Nodelijk G, de Koeijer AA and van Roermund HJ. The transmission potential of Rift Valley fever virus among livestock in the Netherlands: a modelling study. Vet Res. 2013, 22;44:58. Available at:\nhttp://www.veterinaryresearch.org/content/44/1/58.\n\n5. Hartley DM1, Rinderknecht JL, Nipp TL, et al. Potential effects of Rift Valley fever in the United States. Emerg Infect Dis. 2011;17(8):e1. Available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3381545/.\n\n6. Kasari TR, Carr DA, Lynn TV and Weaver JT. Evaluation of pathways for release of Rift Valley fever virus into domestic ruminant livestock, ruminant wildlife, and human populations in the continental United States. Niger (06): (TH) WHO, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4666462", "date": "2016-11-30 17:37:06", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - NIGER (06): (TAHOUA) WHO, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Nov 2016\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/24-november-2016-rift-valley-fever-niger/en/\n\n\nRift Valley Fever in Niger\n--------------------------\n\nOn 30 Aug [2016], the Ministry of Health in Niger notified WHO of unexplained deaths among humans, along with deaths in livestock in the Tahoua region of Niger. On 23 Sep [2016], human and animal specimens were tested at the Institut Pasteur de Dakar (IPD) and were reported positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus by PCR and for specific IgM antibodies confirming the 1st outbreak of RVF in Niger. Initially the outbreak was centered in the north west of the country in areas bordering Mali, in particular around Tassara and Tchintabaraden in the Tahoua Region, however suspected cases of RVF have recently been identified in new areas to the north and south of Tchintabaraden.\n\nThe outbreak also coincided with the annual Cure Sal\u00e9e gathering in Ingall (close to Agadez), Tahoua region, where nomadic stockbreeders from Niger and surrounding countries gather with their animals. It is estimated that around 2 million cattle and smaller ruminants were in the affected area during the beginning of the outbreak. Furthermore, there were reports of waves of abortions and deaths among livestock in Boni-Bangou in Niger while human RVF suspected cases and animals were confirmed with specific IgM in the neighbouring region of Menaka in Mali.\n\nFrom 8 Aug to 21 Nov [2016], 266 suspected human cases including 32 deaths have been reported from Abalak, Keita, Madaoua, Tilia, Tassara, Tahoua department and Tchintabaraden in the Tahoua Region. From 8 Aug to 18 Nov [2016], 196 specimens were tested and 17 patients were confirmed positive by RVF PCR and/or serological identification of IgM antibodies. Further testing of RVF negative specimens is being performed at IPD.\n\nGiven that more than 90 per cent of the samples tested negative for a recent RVF infection (IgG, PCR negative) and the increasing proportion of housewives and children affected there is a need to broaden the investigation to identify possible other underlying cause(s). In this regard an adapted investigation protocol is currently being developed which includes infectious and non-infectious diseases as well as chemicals and toxins.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\n- Support has been provided by WHO to the Ministry of Health (MoH) in Niger for carrying out the initial investigation for confirmation of the outbreak and notification in accordance with the provision of the International Health Regulations.\n\n- A joint field mission of the MoH and Ministry of Livestock (MoL) was conducted to the affected areas during the 1st week of October [2016] to participate in the ongoing outbreak investigations, ensure prevention and control measures are being implemented and to begin community engagement regarding RVF.\n\n- Laboratory testing and training of personnel at Centre de Recherche M\u00e9dicale et Sanitaire (CERMES) was initiated by experts from IPD.\n\n- The Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN), with the support of partners has deployed laboratory experts from Institute Pasteur Dakar to enhance laboratory capacity in Niamey, Niger. Specifically, they tested specimens and trained 6 local experts on lab testing (serology).\n\n- Personnel have been deployed by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Crisis Management Centre to participate in a joint field outbreak investigation, supporting the MoH and MoL, and in response activities.\n\n- Engagement of the regional AFR-EDPLN (WHO African Region-Emerging and Dangerous Pathogens Laboratory Network) has been initiated to support the enhancement of laboratory capacity in neighbouring countries.\n\n- Reinforcement and replenishing of laboratory reagents and supplies has been facilitated by WHO African region.\n\n- Provision of triple packaging for specimen transport has been facilitated by WHO African region.\n\n- A comprehensive outbreak investigation protocol is being developed by WHO country office with support from WHO headquarters and African region.\n\n- Funds are being mobilized to implement critical response activities in the areas of surveillance, laboratory, and risk communication entomology.\n\n- Engagement with nongovernmental organizations in the field (Alima/ l'ONG BEFEN/ Red Cross) who are assisting with case management and sensitization of communities is continuing also supported by UNICEF.\n\n- Deployed entomological experts from IPD in conjunction with MoH National entomologist conducted a comprehensive field investigation. Field specimens collected were all negative for RVF virus.\n\n- The deployment of additional personnel, by WHO African region and GOARN to support the MoH in implementing outbreak and response activities, specifically in the areas of epidemiological investigation surveillance and response, case management, risk communication and social mobilisation activities in the country is in process.\n\n- Considering the generalized signs and symptoms of RVF in the human population, suspected cases presenting to health facilities should also be tested for malaria by rapid diagnostic tests.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nSince October 2016, the epidemiological situation has evolved. Since August 2016, out of 196 specimens tested, only 17 patients have been confirmed with RVF, including 2 confirmed in November 2016 and 2 in October 2016. The epidemiological data are showing that the RVF outbreak amplitude is modest.\n\nThe spread of the RVF outbreak to previously unaffected areas should still be monitored as the health infrastructure is limited and the areas and populations dispersed along the stock routes.\n\nThe stockbreeder population is highly mobile and moves along stock routes to find pasture for their herds in the Sahel region that incorporates a number of neighbouring countries. The RVF outbreak caused concern and posed a serious public health threat in Niger as the health infrastructure is limited and populations are dispersed along the stock routes. Surrounding countries previously considered at risk including Mali, Burkina Faso, Nigeria, Chad, Benin, Togo and Cameroon have not reported any RVF cases.\n\nAlthough there is no indication at this point in time for an infectious disease which is easily spreading between humans there is a need to broaden the investigation to identify additional causing aetiologies as this would have an influence on the necessary response and control activities.\n\nWHO advice\n----------\nAny trade measures with regards to imports and exports of live animals from affected areas, or their products (meat or milk) should follow the 'Terrestrial Animal Health Code 2016' of the OIE.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak continues in the Tahoua region. The case count has increased from 98 cases with 28 deaths on 10 Oct 2016 to 230 cases with 32 deaths in the 17 Nov 2016 report, and now there are 266 suspected cases with 32 deaths. Although no RVF cases in livestock are mentioned in previous posts, both abortions and confirmed livestock RVF cases are reported above, as one would expect in a RVF outbreak.\n\nGiven that 90 per cent of the samples tested were negative for RVF, there must be another cause of the human cases. ProMED-mail would appreciate receiving additional information as it becomes available.\n\nAs mentioned earlier, Mod.CRD's excellent comment stated, 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquitoborne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality, and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats, and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an unapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle. Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes.'\n\nMaps of Niger can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32064. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak continues in the Tahoua region. \n\n- The deployment of additional personnel, by WHO African region and GOARN to support the MoH in implementing outbreak and response activities, specifically in the areas of epidemiological investigation surveillance and response, case management, risk communication and social mobilisation activities in the country is in process. The undersecretary also recalled the continuation of the immunization campaigns of domestic poultry against avian influenza and the education of housewives on the disease, adding that 900 000 family owned birds have been vaccinated while 7 outbreaks were detected in bird markets.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kalyoubia", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "EGYPT", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4525684", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Niger (03): (TH) livestock, human", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4525684", "date": "2016-09-29 17:41:35", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - NIGER (03): (TAHOUA) LIVESTOCK, HUMAN\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Sep 2016\nSource: WHO Emergencies Preparedness, Response [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/29-september-2016-rift-valley-fever-niger/en/\n\n\nOn 30 Aug 2016, WHO received reports about unexplained deaths among humans, along with death and abortion in livestock in the North Western parts of Niger, and the areas bordering Mali.\n\nFrom 2 Aug to 22 Sep 2016, 64 human cases including 23 deaths have been reported in Tchintabaraden health district in Tahoua region. The area is mainly populated by nomadic stockbreeders.\n\nMost of the cases are male (62.5 percent), and work as farmers or animal breeders. In the affected area, an epizootic outbreak is also reported among livestock during the same time duration, including deaths and abortions among cattle and small ruminants.\n\nAs of 16 Sep 2016, 6 of the 13 human specimens tested at Institute Pasteur (IP), Dakar were positive for Rift Valley fever (RVF). Among the 6 animal specimens tested, 3 were positive for RVF. Sequencing and further laboratory testing is ongoing. Genetic sequence data is required to confirm or refute the endogenous origin of the outbreak. Moreover, laboratory support for Niger is being considered.\n\nPublic Health Response\nOn 31 Aug [2016], a multisectoral national rapid response team, including members from the Ministry of Health, veterinary services and Centre de Recherche M\u00e9dicale et Sanitaire (CERMES), and World Health Organization, was deployed for field investigation. Ministries of Health and Agriculture/Livestock have developed a national response plan.\n\nThe WHO Country Office continues to provide technical and financial support for surveillance, outbreak investigation, technical guidelines regarding case definition, case management, shipment of samples and risk communication.\n\nFAO, OIE, and WHO are coordinating on animal and human health and providing additional support to Niger for the outbreak response WHO is working with partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) to coordinate international support for the response. IFRC and Unicef are supporting outbreak response.\n\nThe NGO ALIMA and the Nigerian NGO BEFEN are providing support for case management and social mobilisation on the ground.\n\nCurrently, in conjunction with the Ministry of Public Health, an entomological survey is being prepared for urgent implementation with WHO technical and financial support. This is to identify potential vectors for RVF in the region and it is considered to be in the definition of vector control activities.\n\nCurrently, some of the main challenges include under-detection of human cases. The risk that only severe cases are being detected and reported cannot be ruled out. There is no national local capacity to test the specimens. For laboratory confirmation for RVF, the samples are being shipped to WHO regional collaborating centres. Moreover, to ascertain the extent of this outbreak, the involvement of the national livestock department is required.\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\nBased on the available information, the event risk assessment is ongoing. The risk of further spread of outbreak within Niger and internationally (especially to neighbouring countries and those on the transhumance and migration routes) cannot be ruled out.\n\nNomadic stockbreeders from Niger and neighbouring countries have just participated in the Cure Sal\u00e9e festival, a major annual mass gathering event from 23-25 Sep [2016]. During this festival, herds are brought to graze on the salty pastures ahead of the dry season. Around 2 million cattle and even more small ruminants were expected to be part of the event.\n\nAt the end of the rainy season, as per known migration patterns, the nomadic human population along with their herds will progressively move to other Southern Sub Saharan countries and irrigation systems along the Niger river where pastures may still be available. In conjunction with the ongoing outbreak, the high density of animals in the area and the transhumance pattern significantly increases the risk of international spread. The security situation in the Sahel is unstable and also needs to be taken into consideration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous reports of this Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak have made the number of human cases uncertain. The above report clarifies the case number and provides valuable social and economic elements important in this outbreak. Prompt response to contain this outbreak is essential, given the impending move of the nomadic population and their herds to southern Sub Saharan areas. No mention is made about plans to vaccinate animals before they move south. It would seem that a vaccination campaign in the region for RVF would not only address the livestock problem, but would reduce human risk of infection as well.\n\nMod.CRD's excellent earlier comment stated, 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a peracute or acute zoonotic disease of domestic ruminants. The virus is confined to the African continent and Arabian Peninsula. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne virus of the _Bunyaviridae_ family (genus _Phlebovirus_). The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by abortion, neonatal mortality and liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats, and cattle. Older non-pregnant animals, although susceptible to infection, are more resistant to clinical disease. There is considerable variation in the susceptibility to RVF of animals of different species. Camels usually have an inapparent infection with RVF virus (RVFV), but sudden mortality, neonatal mortality, and abortion occur and abortion rates can be as high as in cattle. Humans are susceptible to RVFV and are infected through contact with infected animal material (body fluids or tissues) or through bites from infected mosquitoes.'\n\nMaps of Niger can be accessed at http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/africa/political-map-of-Niger.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32064. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "\n\nFAO, OIE, and WHO are coordinating on animal and human health and providing additional support to Niger for the outbreak response WHO is working with partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) to coordinate international support for the response. with contaminated animals, has infected 52 people in Niger's western region of Tahoua since late August, the country's health ministry said.\n\nThe Alliance for International Medical Action (ALIMA) and Niger's health authorities have opened an emergency treatment center, in the region's hardest-hit district of Tchintabaraden, to look after the infected and stop the disease from spreading.\n\n'Unfortunately, the 52 severe cases officially registered at present only represent the tip of the iceberg,' ALIMA's medical coordinator Oumarou Maidadji said in a statement.\n\nWith no specific treatment or effective human vaccine, Rift Valley fever can cause blindness and severe haemorrhaging, leading the victim to vomit blood or even bleed to death.\n\nHerders and farmers [and veterinarians] are deemed at higher risk of infection from the disease, which can devastate livestock.\n\nNiger's health ministry said people in the Tahoua region, especially pastoralists, should avoid handling meat from infected animals, boil raw milk before consumption, and ensure that the corpses of dead animals are buried carefully.\n\nALIMA is also working with local partners and doctors to provide a mobile clinic which travels the region to inform the public about the disease and how to prevent it from spreading.\n\n[Byline: Kieran Guilbert, Edited by: Jo Griffin]\n\n--\nCommunicated 'The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected domestic animals. The virus can be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting veterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses,' he said.\n\n'There is no doubt the threat is real, we need to see how to put our hands together so that we can fight this epidemic,' Said Dr Andama.\n\nThis is the 2nd outbreak of the Rift Valley fever in Uganda in less than 2 months. The disease was first recorded in Kenya in 1931 and later in the 1990s in Somalia, Kenya, and Tanzania.\n\nOutside Africa, the disease has been reported in Saudi Arabia and Yemen.\n\n[Byline: Godfrey Tugume]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever virus is endemic in Uganda and human cases occur there sporadically. Over the past 3 months, no mention is made of cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in domestic animals in the area where the human cases occurred. Farm animals are the main reservoirs and amplifiers of RVF virus. RVF outbreaks very often involve significant numbers of ill and dead small ruminant animals. It is odd that no small ruminant animal cases are mentioned, unless the animals had been vaccinated previously and are immune. RVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. Eradicating the virus from these areas is not possible with current technology.\n\nAs Mod.AB noted: 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a major zoonotic disease caused by a virus of the genus _Phlebovirus_ of the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by mosquitoes of the genus _Aedes_.' - Mod.TY\n\nMaps of Uganda can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11507. In that era, South African workers documented fatal clinical RVF in a patient originating from Angola (1). The Chinese must be commended for rapidly considering RVF as a differential diagnosis.\n\nIt is not impossible that local transmission and infection, especially in humans, are missed in Angola if focus is on infections like dengue and yellow fever that have similar presentation with RVF. Furthermore, a possible lack of local diagnostic expertise used in the South African report may be contributory. Of note, evidence of local RVF endemicity in Nigeria has existed for years with extensive work having been carried out in the past at the virology lab in the University of Ibadan (2), but clinical cases remain unrecognized. An additional challenge in Nigeria may be malaria over-diagnosis. As regards animal reservoirs, though the issue of reservoir status of RVFV remains debatable, farm animals are more likely to play an amplifying rather than maintenance role. Ecologic and climatic factors influencing inter-epidemic maintenance should also be considered.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Gear JH: Clinical aspects of African viral hemorrhagic fevers. Rev Infect Dis. 1989; 11 Suppl 4: S777-82; [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2665013].\n2. Tomori O, Fabiyi A, Sorungbe A, et al: Viral hemorrhagic fever antibodies in Nigerian populations. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 1988; 38(2): 407-10; [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3128130].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nShamsudeen Fagbo, DVM, MSc\nDept. Of note, evidence of local RVF endemicity in Nigeria has existed for years with extensive work having been carried out in the past at the virology lab in the University of Ibadan (2), but clinical cases remain unrecognized.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "malaria", "rift valley fever", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Angola", "country": "Angola"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/165", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4207036", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - France ex Mali, 2015", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4207036", "date": "2016-05-06 21:47:31", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - FRANCE ex MALI, 2015\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 May 2016\nSource: Eurosurveillance 21 (18) DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.18.30222 [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22470\n\n\nHaneche F, Leparc-Goffart I, Simon F, Hentzien M, Martinez-Pourcher V, Caumes E, Maquart M. Rift Valley fever in kidney transplant recipient returning from Mali with viral RNA detected in semen up to 4 months from symptom onset, France, autumn 2015.\n\nAbstract\nA 29-year-old kidney transplant recipient returning from Mali was diagnosed with Rift Valley fever (RVF) in France in autumn 2015. The patient was immunosuppressed due to his renal transplant. IgM and IgG specific to RVF virus (RVFV) were detected in cerebrospinal fluid and blood up to 2 months after symptom onset, whereas in urine, RVFV genomic RNA was detected by RT-PCR up to 3 months, and in semen up to 4 months post symptom onset.\n\nConclusion\nWe report the 1st RVF viral RNA detection in urine and in human semen that did not have gross blood contamination. No information about infectivity could be determined as viral isolation failed. The RVFV was previously detected in cattle semen but not in humans. Infectious Ebola virus can be present in semen more than 3 months after recovery and is transmitted to other persons by sexual route. Similarly, Zika virus has been isolated from the semen of a patient 24 days post onset of symptoms. Ebola virus RNA was detected more than 9 months post-exposure. Duration of virus persistence in semen may be linked to the immunosuppressive status of a patient or a viral characteristic as for Ebola and Zika virus. As a precaution, we recommend to abstain or engage only in protected intercourse when RVFV is detected in semen, until complete clearance of the virus [occurs].\n\nRVFV genomic RNA was detected in semen 4 months after the onset of symptoms in an immunocompromised patient. Testing semen could be a new method for diagnosing RVF retrospectively and presence of RVFV genomic RNA raises the possibility that RVF could be transmitted sexually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is an unusual case, in that the patient was immunosuppressed. It will be interesting to see if virus is present in urine and semen of infected individuals who are not immunocompromised. ProMED-mail subscribers interested in the clinical details of this case are urged to read the complete report.\n\nProMED-mail has posted only one previous instance of RVF in Mali, and that in livestock, and apparently the cases were not laboratory confirmed. The individual's source of exposure to the virus is not clear. The patient was reported to have taken care of his father's livestock in Mali. He did not report contact with ill or dead animals, nor mention spontaneous abortions in the small ruminants, which is common among RVF virus-infected animals. He did mention consumption of raw milk. That could have been the source of his exposure to the virus, or perhaps via mosquitoes.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Mali can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "IgM and IgG specific to RVF virus (RVFV) were detected in cerebrospinal fluid and blood up to 2 months after symptom onset, whereas in urine, RVFV genomic RNA was detected by RT-PCR up to 3 months, and in semen up to 4 months post symptom onset. On Saturday evening [23 Jul 2016], he was tested positive for RVF.\n\nThe patient is currently in critical condition and is receiving treatment, NHFPC said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n[Although ProMED-mail has not posted cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in humans or in animals in Angola, it is not surprising that the virus is found there. RVF is endemic across wide areas of sub-Sahara Africa from Mauritania and Sudan to South Africa. There have been outbreaks in Egypt and Saudi Arabia as well.\n\nThere is no indication of the circumstances under which the man acquired his infection.\n\nFarm animals are the main reservoirs and amplifiers of RVF virus. RVF outbreaks very often involve significant numbers of ill and dead small ruminant animals. Animal handlers and veterinarians are at particular risk for RVF virus infections. RVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. Eradicating the virus from these areas is not possible with current technology.\n\nAs Mod.AB noted: 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a major zoonotic disease caused by a virus of the genus _Phlebovirus_ of the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by mosquitoes of the genus _Aedes_.' - Mod.TY\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/165.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n RVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by mosquitoes of the genus _Aedes_.' \n\nThe 45-year-old man from Henan Province got fever and headache and suffered pains of his joints and muscles on 14 Jul [2016] in Angola, the National Health and Family Planning Commission (NHFPC) said Sunday [Although ProMED-mail has not posted cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in humans or in animals in Angola, it is not surprising that the virus is found there. There is significant movement of livestock including goats within the district. Interdistrict movement of livestock is also common. In addition, there is movement of livestock including goats across the international borders. Livestock movement is mainly for trade, gifts, dowry, search for water and pasture among others. A goat on a farm in Kashenyi village, Kicumbi parish, Kamuganguzi subcounty, showed clinical signs of Rift Valley Fever (RVF) and PCR confirmed presence of RVF virus.\n\nOutbreak statistics (rates apparent, expressed in percentages)\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nGoats / 0.00 / 0.00 / 0.00 / 0.00\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Human cases were reported and confirmed in the same area.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestation; traceability; dipping/spraying; quarantine; control of vectors; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Uganda Virus Research Institute Laboratory (national laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nGoats / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 24 Mar 2016 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Several cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF) have been recently diagnosed in humans in Uganda's south-western province Kabale, bordering Rwanda. Traditionally, RVF is known to cause a severe disease in ruminants, with mortality rates in juvenile ruminants, particularly lambs and kids, known to exceed 50 percent and in newborn animals even significantly higher. The main symptom in adult animals is abortion. Human disease follows the disease in animals by exposure to infected animal tissues such as aborted foeti, placentae, organs and blood, as well as by arthropod vectors transmitting the virus from the viraemic animals to human victims.\n\nAntibodies in humans were reported in Uganda in 1936. During the period 1944-1967, RVF virus was isolated from mosquitoes and humans. In 1968, a limited epidemic was reported in humans. A cross-sectional study published in 2013 reported serological evidence in goats in Sembabule, Mpigi, Masaka and Mubende districts of Uganda.\n\nSubscribers are referred to the commentary by Mod.MPP in posting 20160317.4099896. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3948.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail {"archive_id": "3694282", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Mauritania: (TG)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3694282", "date": "2015-10-07 12:55:59", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MAURITANIA: (TAGANT)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 4 Oct 2015\nSource: Rapideinfo, Mauritanian News Agency (AMI) report [in French, trans. Mod.AB, edited]\nhttp://rapideinfo.net/node/7838\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health published on Sunday night [4 Oct 2015] a press release, a copy of which was received by the Mauritanian News Agency (AMI), stating that the health situation is under control and well attended. The full text of this press release follows:\n\n'The Ministry of Health has been informed by its local services on [14 Sep 2015] of the death of a suspected case of hemorrhagic fever in Magtaa Lahjar Health Center in Tourguelil Town, Moudjeria district [Tagant region].\n\nA multidisciplinary team from the Ministry of Health went immediately to the area and conducted investigations on cases and contact tracing. The patient was admitted at the Magtaa Lahjar health center, and samples were collected from him and sent to the Pasteur Institute in Dakar for biological analysis, which confirmed a recent infection with Rift Valley fever [RVF] virus. The same day, a joint team of the health and livestock ministries crisscrossed the localities of Moudjeria district and carried out education sessions to sensitize people about the risks of viral haemorrhagic fevers and ways to protect themselves, while searching for potential cases and following the contacts.\n\nThe detection of current suspected cases led to hospitalization, isolation and case management at the hospitals. Their condition is evolving favorably, and monitoring of contacts in Nouakchott and in the interior of the country is underway. Note that all these cases have never been in contact or made trips to countries affected by Ebola virus disease. Samples for analysis were immediately made and sent to the Pasteur Institute in Dakar.\n\nGiven this situation, the Ministry of Health has promptly taken the following measures:\n- Meeting of the monitoring committee\n- Monitoring and strengthening of epidemiological surveillance with daily reporting and count of weekly cases\n- Sending field missions for awareness\n- Extension of operational guidelines for case management at health structures\n- Development and dissemination of audiovisual spots in the 4 main languages.\n\nRemember that usually during the winter periods, sporadic cases of hemorrhagic fever occur and are well supported by our health facilities with a favorable evolution.\n\nThe Ministry of Health brings to the attention of the people that all necessary measures have been taken and that the situation is under control and well attended.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a major zoonotic disease caused by a virus of the genus _Phlebovirus_ of the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by arthropods of the genus _Aedes_.\n\nThe disease was confirmed in Mauritania in the early 2000s and, since then, it has reappeared recurrently; the most recent epidemic dates back to 2012-2013.\n\nThe case raised by the Mauritanian Information Agency (AMI) announced a new episode of the disease that has already caused one death and led to several suspected cases, the numbers of which are not mentioned in the communique of the Health Minister. It is not clear whether epidemiological investigations have been conducted in farm animals, which are the main reservoirs of the RVF virus.\n\nMaps of Mauritania can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/mauritania/maps/map-of-mauritania.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14540. Moudjeria is a town and a district in south-central Mauritania, located in Tagant region. The region is divided into 3 districts: Moudjeria, Tichit, and Tidjikja (https://goo.gl/6uCOZk). - Mod.AB\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) outbreaks very often involve significant numbers of ill and dead small ruminant animals. It is odd that no small ruminant animal cases are mentioned, unless the animals had been vaccinated previously and are immune. RVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. Eradicating the virus from these areas is not possible with current technology. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "\n\nGiven this situation, the Ministry of Health has promptly taken the following measures:\n- Meeting of the monitoring committee\n- Monitoring and strengthening of epidemiological surveillance with daily reporting and count of weekly cases\n- Sending field missions for awareness\n- Extension of operational guidelines for case management at health structures\n- Development and dissemination of audiovisual spots in the 4 main languages. The Ministry of Health brings to the attention of the people that all necessary measures have been taken and that the situation is under control and well attended.'\n\n--\n RVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. The same day, a joint team of the health and livestock ministries crisscrossed the localities of Moudjeria district and carried out education sessions to sensitize people about the risks of viral haemorrhagic fevers and ways to protect themselves, while searching for potential cases and following the contacts. \n\nRemember that usually during the winter periods, sporadic cases of hemorrhagic fever occur and are well supported by our health facilities with a favorable evolution. \n\nA multidisciplinary team from the Ministry of Health went immediately to the area and conducted investigations on cases and contact tracing. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by arthropods of the genus _Aedes_. The case raised by the Mauritanian Information Agency (AMI) announced a new episode of the disease that has already caused one death and led to several suspected cases, the numbers of which are not mentioned in the communique of the Health Minister.
