CopyEd.LMI, edited]\nhttp://rapideinfo.net/node/8105\n\n\nAn official document confirms the deaths of 8 people from Rift Valley fever.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF), a disease that primarily affects animals but can also infect humans, has killed 8 people in Mauritania since September [2015], according to a new report released on Saturday [10 Oct 2015] by the World Health Organization (WHO).\n\n'From the beginning, the assessment made by the government (of Mauritania), which ensures transparency, confirmed 8 deaths out of 25 suspected cases,' WHO representative in Nouakchott Jean-Pierre Baptiste, explained to the AFP.\n\nThe Mauritanian government sent the report to WHO on Friday [9 Oct 2015]. The Mauritanian authorities in charge of this case could not be reached for further information on Saturday [10 Oct 2015].\n\nMr. Baptiste praised 'the strong mobilization of the government for the management of patients suspected of having Rift Valley fever in all affected regions.'\n\nThe Mauritanian government said that the central and southeast regions were mainly affected by the disease.\n\nDuring an interview on Friday [9 Oct 2015], the Mauritanian Health Minister, Ahmed Ould Jelvoune, reassured people, declaring that 'his government had full control of the situation in the country.'\n\nRift Valley fever, named after the Kenyan region where it was identified in 1931, killed 17 people in Mauritania in 2012.\n\nThis disease is transmitted by mosquitoes, and, according to WHO, in the vast majority of cases, the infection occurs in humans as a result of direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals.\n\nWHO said that there was no treatment, but potential vaccines are in development.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The report above adds additional information that was not included in the previous RFV report from Mauritania (ProMED-mail archive no. 20151007.3694282), including human case numbers.\n\nAs Mod.AB noted: 'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a major zoonotic disease caused by a virus of the genus _Phlebovirus_ of the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus affects different animal species (buffaloes, camels, cattle, goats, and sheep) and can pass to humans either by direct contact through blood or body fluids during slaughter or ingestion of contaminated meat or indirectly through arthropod biting, especially by arthropods of the genus _Aedes_.\n\n'The disease was confirmed in Mauritania in the early 2000s, and, since then, it has reappeared recurrently; the most recent epidemic dates back to 2012-2013.'\n\nIt is still not clear whether epidemiological investigations have been conducted in farm animals, which are the main reservoirs and amplifiers of RVF virus.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) outbreaks very often involve significant numbers of ill and dead small ruminant animals. It is odd that no small ruminant animal cases are mentioned, unless the animals had been vaccinated previously and are immune. RVF virus can persist for a long time in some areas, maintained in _Aedes_ vector mosquitoes that deposit eggs in seasonally-flooded areas, where those eggs are transovarially infected with the virus. Adult female mosquitoes coming from infected eggs can transmit the virus during their 1st blood meals. Eradicating the virus from these areas is not possible with current technology.\n\nMaps of Mauritania can be accessed at http://www.mapsofworld.com/mauritania/maps/map-of-mauritania.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/51. - Mod.TY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRift Valley fever (RVF), a disease that primarily affects animals but can also infect humans, has killed 8 people in Mauritania since September [2015], according to a new report released on Saturday [10 Oct 2015] by the World Health Organization (WHO). The 4 reported outbreaks are, reportedly, located in 4 different provinces in the southern regions of Mauritania -- 1 outbreak per province (see map). Such information is requested.\n\nRVF was initially reported from West Africa (Senegal and Mauritania) in 1987, following the opening of Diama Dam at the mouth of the Senegal River, in an area where the virus was, most probably, present earlier but not generally recognized. The dam project created additional breeding grounds for mosquitoes carrying the disease and resulted in more than 200 human deaths from RVF. It is regarded as endemic with flare-ups every several years.\n\nAccording to the most recent available annual report (2013) from Mauritania, RVF (in animals) is not officially notifiable in this country. It is 'present, limited to 1 or more zones'. No vaccination is applied. During 2013, 5 outbreaks were reported, affecting sheep and goats (mixed flocks; 190 cases out of 750 susceptible, no mortalities), sheep (90/300, no mortalities) and camels (11/100, 3 mortalities). Such mortality rates are rather low; in 2012, the figures were higher, accompanied by human infections including fatalities.\n\nThe disease's lethality rate is traditionally known to be particularly high in offspring (for example, in southern and east Africa, with death rates nearing 100 per cent in lambs and kids under the age of 4 weeks). It will be interesting to note if the affected flocks in Mauritania included young lambs/kids during the outbreaks. - Mods. ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 15 Mar 2016\nSource: Uganda Radio Network [edited]\nhttp://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/rift-valley-fever-government-sets-up-national-task-force\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health has set up a multi-sectorial national taskforce to coordinate all efforts to control and manage the outbreak of Rift Valley fever in Kabale district.\n\nThe task force is comprised of officials from the Ministry of Health, Agriculture, Water and Environment and Uganda Wildlife Authority-UWA. It is supported by the World Health Organization (WHO) and Centre for Disease Control (CDC).\n\nThe development follows the confirmation of an outbreak of Rift Valley fever, a viral infection that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Up to 5 cases have so far been confirmed in Kabale district over the last 3 days.\n\nThe virus, characterized by fever, severe illness and abortions, is transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during slaughtering, conducting veterinary procedures or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses, according to the WHO. The majority of human infections result from contact with blood or organs of infected animals and persons.\n\nDr Ruth Aceng, the Director General Health Services, says the task force will conduct research, surveillance training of health workers in case management and conduct social mobilization on mechanism to contain the virus.\n\nAceng adds that 3 more people have been reported to have signs of the disease, bringing the number to 5 since it was reported 4 days ago.\n\nDr Nicholas Kawuta, the Director of Animal Resources at the Ministry of Agriculture, says the Rift Valley fever outbreak had been expected at the onset of El Ni\u00f1o rains. He however adds that the government has started working with the World Bank to vaccinate animals in Kabale and surrounding districts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is good to see that a multi-sectorial task force involving public health, animal health and wildlife has been assembled and has begun to investigate this outbreak. It would be helpful to know if the domestic animals in the area, especially small ruminants, have been vaccinated against Rift Valley fever. - Mod.TY]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 15 Mar 2016\nSource: New Vision [edited]\nhttp://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1419671/diagnosed-rift-valley-fever-kabale\n\n\nTwo diagnosed with Rift Valley fever in Kabale\n----------------------------------------------\nThe Ministry of Health has instituted a task force to combat an outbreak of Rift Valley fever in Kabale district.\n\nThis comes after 2 people in Kabale town council were diagnosed with the disease and referred to Kabale Regional Referral Hospital for treatment while 3 other cases have so far been identified in the same area.\n\nDr. Ruth Aceng, the director general of health services in the ministry, said the task force is comprised of experts from the ministries of health, agriculture and animal husbandry in addition to the Uganda Wildlife authority.\n\n'The multi-sectorial task force has boosted surveillance programs in Kabale, Rwanda and DRC [Democratic Republic of the Congo] borders. So far a total of 59 animal and 11 human samples have been collected for testing at the Uganda Virus Research Institute,' Aceng said.\n\nAceng noted that the disease is an acute fever that is transmitted by mosquitoes during the rainy season and affects animals such as cattle, sheep, goats, and buffaloes.\n\nThe disease presents symptoms of fever, general weakness, back pain, dizziness and weight loss at the onset of the illness.\n\n'We urge the general public to report any suspected patient or sick animal to a nearby health facility or veterinary clinic respectively,' Aceng added.\n\nDr. Kawuta Nicholas, who is in charge of animal resources in the ministry of agriculture, noted that the ministry will not consider the quarantine of animals in the district until they find enough evidence to show that the outbreak is linked to animals.\n\n[Byline: Joyce Nyakato]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 15 Mar 2016\nSource: Uganda Radio Network [edited]\nhttp://ugandaradionetwork.com/story/another-rift-valley-fever-suspect-isolated-at-kabale-hospital-\n\n\nAnother Rift Valley Fever Suspect Isolated at Kabale Hospital\n-------------------------------------------------------------\nAnother suspected victim of the Rift Valley fever has been admitted at Kabale Regional Referral Hospital, barely few days it was confirmed in Kabale District. Dr. Patrick Tusiime, the Kabale District Medical Officer, says the suspect is a long distance truck driver.\n\nAccording to Dr. Tusiime, the suspect was admitted in the isolation unit at Kabale Referral Hospital when he presented with signs of Rift Valley fever. He says samples from the suspected Rift Valley fever victim have been dispatched to Uganda Virus Research institute Entebbe for verification.\n\nOnce the tests turn out positive, this will be the 3rd case that has been recorded in Kabale district. Dr. Tusiime says in an attempt to contain the spread of the fever, they have called off all blood donation drives by Uganda Red Cross Society in the district until further notice.\n\nHe says information gathered by the surveillance team shows that a number of people succumbed to the fever over the last 2 weeks before the outbreak was confirmed on [11 Mar 2016].\n\nRift Valley fever is a viral infection that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. It presents with fever, severe illness and abortions in animals.\n\nAccording to World Health Organization, the fever is transmitted to humans through poor handling of animal tissue during slaughtering, veterinary procedures or disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\n\nMajority of human infections result from contact with blood or organs of infected animals and persons.\n\n[Byline: Anthony Kushaba]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: Wed 16 Mar 2016\nSource: New Vision [edited]\nhttp://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1419798/rift-valley-fever-suspect-dies-kabale\n\n\nSuspected Rift Valley fever patient dies in Kabale\n--------------------------------------------------\nA truck driver from Burundi died at the hospital after being admitted on Monday morning [14 Mar 2016].\n\nA patient admitted at Kabale Regional Referral Hospital suspected of contracting Rift Valley fever has passed away.\n\n[The patient], a truck driver from Burundi, died at the hospital after being admitted on Monday morning [14 Mar 2016] bearing symptoms of Rift Valley fever.\n\nBernard Lubwama, an epidemiologist at the Ministry of Health, on Tuesday evening [15 Mar 2016] made the revelation while addressing the media at Kabale district Rukiiko Hall.\n\n'This evening at around 7pm, the long truck driver who reported to us and was admitted at the regional referral hospital succumbed and died of a disease suspected to be RVI. He was vomiting a lot of blood,' Lubwama said.\n\n'The health workers there did all they could but unfortunately, they were not able to save his life. We had not yet received his lab results. Our burial team shall conduct his burial after clearance from his family and other structures in the Ministry of Health,' Lubwama added.\n\nThe deceased was married to 3 women; one in Burundi and the others in Katuna and Entebbe.\n\nAccording to health officials, there are 3 more suspects still admitted in Kabale with 2 of them at Kabale Regional Referral Hospital and the other at Rugarama Hospital. The 2 confirmed cases of the disease are said to be improving.\n\nEfforts to control the spread of the virus continues to be implemented in the district.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has sent items to the medics in Kabale to help in controlling the spreading of the virus. These included jackets, aprons, gloves, gumboots among other items.\n\nOfficials have also continued medical education sessions at Kabale Regional Referral Hospital amongst staff there to sensitize them on the outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Job Namanya]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a zoonotic disease, primarily of domesticated animals such as cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats and camels, caused by the RVF virus, a Phlebovirus from the _Bunyaviridae_ family.\n\nRVF has been reported from most of the countries in the eastern portion of Africa, extending from Egypt at the north down through South Africa in the south, with the exception of Uganda. It has also been reported from Senegal and Mauritania in the western part of the African continent, as well as in the Arabian peninsula (see Nanyingi, M., Munyua, P., Kiama, S., Muchemi, G., Thumbi, S., Bitek, A., Bett, B., Muriithi, R., & Njenga, M. (2015). A systematic review of Rift Valley Fever epidemiology 1931-2014. Infection Ecology & Epidemiology, 5. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.3402/iee.v5.28024, with an excellent map showing the distribution of reported outbreaks of available at: http://www.infectionecologyandepidemiology.net/index.php/iee/article/viewFile/28024/html_15/167731).\n\nAddressing that void in reported cases, Magona et al. did a serosurvey of goats and mosquito vectors in Uganda demonstrating the seroprevalence of RVF in domestic goats in Uganda.\n\nAbstract\n'Increasing occurrence of outbreaks of Rift Valley fever (RVF) has been reported in Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania, Sudan, Madagascar and South Africa during heavy and prolonged, often unseasonal, rainfall from 1997 to 2009. Given Uganda's location in the endemic zone of RVF, surveys were conducted on goat farms with a view to establishing presence of RVF virus and existence of its mosquito vectors. A total of 1470 sera were tested using the IgG ELISA and subsequently 700 sera tested using the Virus Neutralization Test (VNT) and a species identification survey for mosquitoes undertaken. The findings revealed an overall seroprevalence of anti-RVF virus IgG of 9.8 percent (95 percent CI, 8.5-11.1 percent). VNT revealed a seroprevalence of 24.3 percent (95 percent CI, 21.1-27.5 percent). The following specific farms had a higher likelihood to have seropositive goats: Lubega (OR 3.5 (1.1-11.3)), Katabarwa (OR 6.4 (2.0-20.5)) and Maduwa (OR 5.3 (1.6-16.7)). Mubende goats were 4 times (OR 4.2 (1.3-13.5)) more likely to be seropositive to RVF virus than Boer goats, and adult goats were 2 times (OR 2.2 (1.5-3.3)) more likely to be seropositive to RVF virus than young ones. Mosquito species found, included, _Anopheles gambiae_ (71.2 percent), _Culex_ sp. (21.5 percent), _Anopheles funestus_ (6.5 percent), _Aedes_ sp. (0.7 percent) and _Mansonia_ sp. (0.2 percent). High prevalence of anti-RVFV IgG in goats in some locations together with presence of RVF virus neutralizing antibodies (up to 1:80) suggested that the RVF virus is endemic in goats in Uganda. Presence of RVF virus coupled with existence of Aedes sp. and Culex sp. mosquito vectors are likely to lead to RVF outbreaks once the mosquito population flares-up due to flooding and increased RVF virus amplification occurs.' (Magona JW, Galiwango T, Walubengo J, Mukiibi G. Rift Valley fever in Uganda: seroprevalence and risk factor surveillance vis-\u00e0-vis mosquito vectors, anti-RVF virus IgG and RVF virus neutralizing antibodies in goats. It is characterized by high mortality rates in young animals and abortions in pregnant ruminants. RVF is endemic in sub-Saharan Africa. Epidemics occur in this region when heavy rainfalls cause infected mosquito eggs to hatch, and large numbers of susceptible animals are present.\n\nRVF epizootics are often accompanied by human disease. Many human cases are caused by occupational exposure to blood and tissues from infected animals, but mosquito-borne transmission can cause epidemics. The most common form of the disease is a self-limiting, flu-like illness; however, ocular disease and rare cases of fatal hemorrhagic fever also occur.\n\nThe media report above is based upon Senegal's follow-up report no. 2 addressing this epizootic, dated 14 Mar 2014, available, with an interactive map, at http://tinyurl.com/oqcf5uc. According to this OIE report, the outbreak in cattle had started 10 Oct 2013; thus, this is a belated reporting of an event which had taken place about 5 months ago. It involved 7 cases of RVF recorded within a herd of 190 susceptible cattle; no deaths reported. For the diagnosis, reportedly performed on 10 Oct 2013 by Senegal's National Livestock and Veterinary Research Laboratory, real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) was applied. The report included the following epidemiological comment: 'The rainy winter season is the period at risk favourable to the proliferation of vectors transmitting Rift Valley fever.'\n\nThe same epizootic included 3 earlier RVF outbreaks, as follows:\n\n1. The 1st outbreak, which started 10 Sep 2013, involved Dorcas gazelles (_Gazella dorcas_) in north-west Senegal. The immediate notification, with a map, is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=14138. It included the following epidemiological comment: 'Rift Valley fever is a vector-borne disease. The winter season, rainy, hot and humid is the period at risk, favourable to the proliferation of vectors. The date of last detection of the disease in wild species was 2004' (see 20130924.1964250).\n\n2. Outbreaks no. 2 and 3, involving 2 goat flocks in north Senegal on the border with Mauritania, reported on 10 Oct 2013 in follow-up report no. 1, available with map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=14211. The outbreaks had started on 16 and 19 Sep 2013 respectively, affecting a total of 37 cases out of 208 susceptible goats, of which 8 died.\n\nIt will be of interest to note if human RVF cases have been recorded in Senegal during the (now, apparently terminated) disease season.\n\nFor additional information on RVF in Senegal, see the commentary in 20131018.2008030. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2892.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Outbreaks no. 2 and 3, involving 2 goat flocks in north Senegal on the border with Mauritania, reported on 10 Oct 2013 in follow-up report no. 1, available with map at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=14211. \n\nThe same epizootic included 3 earlier RVF outbreaks, as follows:\n\n1. \n\nDr Mbargou Lo, Director of Veterinary Services, confirmed measures are in place to control the spread of the condition previously reported in Senegal last year [2013], killing 8 goats. This disease is characterized by high mortality rates in young animals and abortions in pregnant ruminants. Rift Valley fever is endemic in sub-Saharan Africa. Epidemics occur in this region when heavy rainfalls cause infected mosquito eggs to hatch, and large numbers of susceptible animals are present. Rift Valley fever first appeared outside Africa in 2000, when outbreaks were reported in Saudi Arabia and Yemen.\n\nRift Valley fever epizootics are often accompanied by human disease. Many human cases are caused by occupational exposure to blood and tissues from infected animals, but mosquitoborne transmission can cause epidemics. The most common form of the disease is a self-limiting, flu-like illness; however, ocular disease and rare cases of fatal hemorrhagic fever also occur.'\n\nFor the above and additional background information, please refer to the fact sheet 'Rift Valley fever', prepared by The Center for Food Security and Public Health, Iowa State University available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/rift_valley_fever.pdf.\n\nIn May 2010, Botswana reported its 1st case of Rift Valley fever (RVF). It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus Phlebovirus. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 'Rift Valley Fever' at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf\n\nHumans usually get RVF through bites from infected mosquitoes and possibly other biting insects that have virus-contaminated mouthparts. Humans can also get the disease if they are exposed to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of infected animals. Direct exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through veterinary and obstetric procedures. Infection through aerosol transmission of RVF virus has occurred in the laboratory.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with RVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within two days to one week after onset of illness. http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvf_qa.htm\n\nCommunication regarding disease risk and awareness campaigns on risk mitigation is essential in protecting humans from RVF infections by limiting exposure to the RVF virus for populations at risk, such as farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers. A communication strategy, jointly prepared by the animal and human health authorities, will increase the chances of decreasing the population's risk of exposure to the RVF virus and subsequent disease, as well as increasing consumer confidence and avoiding miscommunication on food safety concerns. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn 2010 Mauritania sent an immediate notification to the OIE reporting 3 outbreaks on RFV which occurred in the northern desert region of Adrar. This event was resolved on 28 Feb 2011. Details on these outbreaks and the interactive map are available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=10054\n\nPictures of RVF clinical signs in camels affected in a 2010 outbreak can be seen at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/10/11-0397-f2.htm\n\nThe most current official information from Mauritania can be found in its 2nd OIE 6-monthly report for 2012. In October 2012, 3 outbreaks of RVF were reported. These were located in the Magta-Lahjar region and the affected species were camelidae (640 susceptible, 78 cases), and sheep and goats (540000 susceptible, 1120 cases, 56 deaths). http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail\n(Note: to view the information on RVF, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease, country and time period).\n\nIn early September 2012, a human case of RVF was reported in Mauritania. By 30 October 2012, a total of 6 regions were affected with 34 human cases of RVF, including 17 deaths. Only the southern regions of Mauritania, those closest to the usual enzootic areas along the Senegal River, seem to have been involved in this event. See http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf and ProMed archive number: 20121102.1387490.\n\nThe distribution in animals and humans from 2002 to 2012 can be found in the article on Rift Valley Fever- Vol 27, December 2012 - published by Emergency prevention systems (EMPRES WATCH), FAO. http://www.fao.org/docrep/017/ap392e/ap392e.pdf\n\nIn this latest immediate notification, the reported absence of [livestock] mortality is surprising. This phenomenon may be seen provided the flocks include young animals. In other seasons, older animals may suffer waves of abortions.\n\nIn the most current 'Outbreak Bulletin' provided from WHO African region (January to July 2013), no outbreaks of RVF were reported. http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news.html - This is inaccurate. There is no outbreak of Rift Valley fever in South Sudan that we know of.\n\nThose quoted in the news release were participants of a workshop being held in Juba 15-16 Oct 2013, entitled 'Developing a risk map and decision-support tools for managing Rift Valley fever in South Sudan'. The workshop was organized by the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) and the South Sudan Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, Tourism, Animal Resources, Fisheries, Cooperative and Rural Development. ILRI veterinary epidemiologist Bernard Bett, BVM, MVEE, PhD, of ILRI's Food Safety and Zoonosis Program, took part in that workshop. He reports that all conversations of the participants dealt with historical, not contemporary, information.\n\nIn the news release, Bett is misquoted and misnamed. He is a veterinary epidemiologist whose research focus is Rift Valley fever and other arboviruses. He is one of those working on developing the risk map for Rift Valley fever.\n\nThe misinformation was further circulated online in several places. ILRI has asked the relevant agencies to issue a statement correcting this misinformation.\n\nFor further information, please contact Bernard Bett: b.bett AT CGIAR.org\n\nFor more on the Rift Valley fever risk map, see this slide presentation by Bernard Bett and colleagues [available from the URL above].\n\n*****\n[3]\nDate: 18 Oct 2013\nSource: Statement from Director of Vector and Disease Control, South Sudan, Aluma Araba Ameri [edited]\n\n\nDear colleagues,\nI am responding to the international alert issued in regards to an outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in South Sudan as misquoted in the GOSS website by a journalist.\n\nQuote 'In the website reads JUBA, 16 October 2012 NASS - An outbreak of Rift Valley Fever Disease has been reported in South Sudan's Eastern Equatoria and Upper Nile states, a government official has announced' - 'Rift Valley fever is a viral disease spread primarily by mosquitoes, which can affect both humans and animals. This was revealed by Dr. Aluma Araba the Director of Vector and Disease Control in the national Ministry of Agriculture Forestry and Tourism'. end of quote\n\nThere is no rumor or suspected outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in the whole of South Sudan up to date. It is caused by a single serotype of a mosquito-borne bunyavirus of the genus _Phlebovirus_. The disease occurs in climatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is characterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats and cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high mortality rate in the newborn.\n\nFor additional background information, including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Terrestrial Manual 2013, Chapter 2.1.14 'Rift Valley fever' at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.14_RVF.pdf.\n\nAccording to Chapter 8.12 on Rift Valley fever of the OIE's Terrestrial Code, countries or zones within the historic distribution of RVF or adjacent to those that are historically infected should be subjected to surveillance.\n\nEpidemics of RVF may occur in infected areas after flooding. They are separated by inter-epidemic periods that may last for several decades in arid areas, and, during these periods, the prevalence of infection in humans, animals, and mosquitoes can be difficult to detect. In the absence of clinical disease, the RVF status of a country or zone within the historically infected regions of the world should be determined by a surveillance programme focusing on mosquitoes and serology of susceptible mammals. The programme should concentrate on parts of the country or zone at high risk because of historical, geographic and climatic factors, ruminant and mosquito population distribution, and proximity to areas where epidemics have recently occurred http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.12.htm.\n\nRVF is a zoonosis (a disease which primarily affects animals but causes disease in humans). Humans are highly susceptible to the RVF virus and may become infected with RVF by being bitten by infected mosquitoes, through contact with blood, other body fluids, or tissues during killing, skinning and cutting of infected animals, or by consumption of raw milk or uncooked meat from infected animals. Humans working in slaughter facilities, laboratories or hospitals are at risk of acquiring infections.\n\nPeople with RVF will either show no symptoms or develop a mild illness. Signs of illness include fever, weakness, myalgia (muscle pain), back ache, dizziness, liver abnormalities, and weight loss. In some patients, the illness can progress to haemorrhagic fever, encephalitis (inflammation of the brain), or ocular disease (inflammation of the eye, blindness). Severe complications develop in 1-4 percent of cases, though most people recover within 4-7 days. Approximately one per cent of humans infected with Rift Valley fever die of the disease http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/RVF-EN.pdf.\n\nInformation on the RVF situation in OIE Member countries found in the last 6-monthly report is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist. Such information shows that during July-December 2012: Clinical disease was reported by 2 countries; Disease was reported as present but 'restricted to certain zone(s)/region(s)' in 2 countries; Reported present as 'Infection/Infestation in one or more zones' from one country; Reported as 'infection was present (with no clinical disease)' in one country, and; Reported as 'suspected' in 3 countries.\n\nIn the countries where the disease was reported for the period as 'absent' (21 countries), most indicate that they have 'general surveillance' and maintain 'targeted surveillance' in domestic animals. However, for wild animals, only 10 countries maintain 'general surveillance,' and only 4 of them have 'target surveillance. One of these countries was Senegal, where the disease has been indicated as absent in domestic animals since December 2012 and absent in wild animals since 2004; see HANDISTATUS http://web.oie.int/hs2/sit_mald_freq_pl.asp?c_cont=1&c_mald=9.\n\nInformation obtained from OIE's WAHID database indicates that since 2011 to date (September 2013), 141 outbreaks were reported officially in the area: Mauritania (3), Namibia (3), South Africa (134) and Senegal (1), the most recent case.\n\nThis information and additional data on these events can also be found in the WAHID database at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Diseasetimeseries. Rift Valley fever is a viral disease spread primarily by mosquitoes, which can affect both humans and animals. This was revealed by Dr. Aluma Araba, the Director of Vector and Disease Control in the national Ministry of Agriculture Forestry and Tourism.\n\nDr. Araba said the disease can also be transmitted by taking unpasteurized milk or by eating not-well-cooked meat of an infected animal. 'This is the 1st time we are reporting an outbreak of Rift Valley fever disease. We are preparing with emergency response but it would require decision makers to allocate more resources to fight this serious disease', said Dr. Araba.\n\nSouth Sudan reportedly has the biggest animal resources in Africa, and such an outbreak could have serious consequences for the country's livestock if no quick measures are taken to mitigate the outbreak. Rift Valley fever disease was 1st discovered in Kenya in 1931. It's largely believed to have made its way into the new country through the movement and trade of livestock across the borders.\n\nA workshop [has been established] to develop a contingency plan to map and identify the high-risk areas so that emergency responses can be directed [there], explained Dr. Bernard Betty, the head of ILRI [International Livestock Research Institute] team. She said it would take the collective efforts of government, stakeholders, and NGOs, among others, to bring the outbreak under control. The director for research and development in the Ministry of Agriculture, Professor Erneo B.Och, described the workshop as 'tangible' [?] and said the taskforce will be formulated together with [relevant] Ministries and other key stakeholders to stop 'losing this important sector and human life'. He said South Sudan will stop at nothing less than food security and human protection.\n\n[Byline: Abdulrazig Juma Abdalla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This government press release conveys no more information than the notification of an outbreak of Rift Valley fever [presumably in livestock] in the Eastern Equatoria and Upper Nile states of South Sudan. Further precise information is requested.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a mosquito-borne viral disease that typically occurs in various areas of sub-Saharan Africa, where virus activity varies from a low-level enzootic cycle to explosive outbreaks covering large areas. Periodically, Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) spreads to other areas, including northward into Egypt in 1977 and eastward across the Red Sea into Saudi Arabia and Yemen in 2000. How RVFV travels is unclear but probably involves movement of infected livestock or mosquitoes.\n\nThe 1st reported outbreak of RVF in Sudan occurred in 1973 in sheep and cattle in White Nile state; shortly thereafter, RVFV was isolated from a herd of cattle in northern Khartoum. Serologic surveys have detected RVFV antibodies in domestic livestock and in humans from different Sudanese states, including Nile, Khartoum, Kassala, El Gezira, Sennar, and White Nile. A recent seroepidemiologic survey reported a high prevalence of RVFV IgG (immunoglobulin G) among febrile patients admitted to New Halfa Hospital in Kassala state. New Halfa is an extensively irrigated agricultural area about 500 km (310 miles) east of Khartoum. Although the presence of IgG does not indicate recent infection, it does suggest considerable circulation of RVFV in the area at some time in the past. [For further information see: Imadeldin E. Aradaib et al., Rift Vally fever, Sudan, 2007 and 2010, in Emerging Infectious Diseases, Volume 19, Number 2 -- February 2013 http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/19/2/12-0834_article.htm.]\n\n[N.B. with respect to the above, South Sudan became an independent state on 9 Jul 2011, following a referendum that passed with 98.83 percent of the vote. It is a United Nations member state and a member state of the African Union.]\n\nA map of the Republic of South Sudan showing the location of the states mentioned in the above report can be accessed at: https://docs.unocha.org/sites/dms/SouthSudan/map_2684.pdf. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3q1_.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a mosquito-borne viral disease that typically occurs in various areas of sub-Saharan Africa, where virus activity varies from a low-level enzootic cycle to explosive outbreaks covering large areas. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This government press release conveys no more information than the notification of an outbreak of Rift Valley fever [presumably in livestock] in the Eastern Equatoria and Upper Nile states of South Sudan. \n\nSouth Sudan reportedly has the biggest animal resources in Africa, and such an outbreak could have serious consequences for the country's livestock if no quick measures are taken to mitigate the outbreak. \n\nA workshop [has been established] to develop a contingency plan to map and identify the high-risk areas so that emergency responses can be directed [there], explained Dr. Bernard Betty, the head of ILRI [International Livestock Research Institute] team. \n\nDr. Araba said the disease can also be transmitted by taking unpasteurized milk or by eating not-well-cooked meat of an infected animal. He added that meat should be cooked thoroughly before consumption, and milk should always be boiled before use, especially in areas where animal disease had been observed.\n\nHe stated that no new cases of Rift Valley fever virus infection had been reported for 5 days over the whole country, including Nouakchott. Infection can cause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected livestock. The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting veterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. Certain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of infection. There is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\n\nOn 4 Oct 2012, the Mauritanian Ministry of Health reported that 7 human cases of Rift Valley fever had been recorded in the country, resulting in 4 deaths; 2 of the survivors were recovering, and one was still under treatment. The extent of the outbreak in livestock has not been reported. Although the number of human cases has risen to 30 with 13 deaths, it is considered that the outbreak is declining because of the prevailing weather conditions.\n\nHowever, this coming weekend marks the festival of Eid Al Adha, also known as Eid El Kebir. Many sheep will be slaughtered as part of the festival rituals around the country. Past experience has shown (e.g. in Egypt in 1977 and 1978) that during the slaughtering procedures, blood aerosols may expose attending humans to RVF infection.\n\nNouakchott is the capital and the largest city of Mauritania. The city is the administrative and economic centre of Mauritania. Our best guess is that certain floodwater _Aedes_ species are responsible for inter-epidemic transmission between non-human hosts and that these species ignite the epidemic phase of transmission.\n\nPlease note that the term, 'the _Aedes_ mosquito' is too generic. It would seem more likely that competent _Culex_ species such as _Culex poicilipes_ in East and West Africa, _Culex pipiens_ var. _molestus_ in Egypt, _Culex tritaeniorhynchus_ in the Arabian Peninsula, and _Culex theileri_ in southern Africa are responsible for introducing RVF virus into the human population. These species are far more numerous and widespread than the floodwater _Aedes_ species during periods of recovering and extensive rainfall and constitute important pest species for humans. Whereas the _Aedes_ vectors will most certainly feed on humans, their ecology does not normally bring them into contact with humans. The one possible exception to this rule is the species implicated in the Saudi Arabian and Mauritanian outbreaks, _Aedes vexans_ subspecies _arabiensis_.\n\n--\nAlan Kemp MSc(Med)\nCentre for Emerging and Zoonotic Diseases\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases\nNational Health Laboratory Service\nSouth Africa\n<alank@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Alan Kemp for providing this information on the mosquito vector species that might be responsible for transmitting Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus to humans in Mauritania and elsewhere. Alan also pointed out that, strictly speaking, mosquitoes should be included among the hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies referred to in the moderator's comment.\n\nThe interactive ProMED/HealthMap of Mauritania can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "National Institute for Communicable Diseases\nNational Health Laboratory Service\nSouth Africa\n<alank@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Alan Kemp for providing this information on the mosquito vector species that might be responsible for transmitting Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus to humans in Mauritania and elsewhere. From 16 Sep 2012 (the date of detection of the index case) to 30 Oct 2012, a total of 34 cases, including 17 deaths have been reported from 6 [of the 12 regions of Mauritania]. The last case was notified on 27 Oct 2012 from Magta Lahjar in the Brakna region. The 6 regions include Assaba, Brakna, Hodh Chargui, Hodh Gharbi, Tagant, and Trarza. All the cases had history of contact with animals.\n\nIn humans, 25 samples tested positive by ELISA and PCR at the National Reference Laboratory of the National Institute of Public Health Research (INRS) in Nouakchott [the capital city of Mauritania] and at the Institut Pasteur in Dakar. In the animal population, analysis conducted by the National Veterinary Research Laboratory shows virus circulation in several regions of the country.\n\nA multi-sector task force has been jointly established by the MOH and the Ministry of Rural Development to respond to this outbreak. WHO and partners, including the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), are working within the task force to strengthen epidemiological surveillance in both human and animal health, strengthen capacity in case management at health care facilities, strengthen health measures in slaughterhouses, and raise awareness among farmers.\n\nA multi-sector investigation team has been deployed to conduct a detailed outbreak investigation among humans and animals in the affected areas. An international team of experts will be deployed to provide technical assistance from 3 to 10 Nov 2012.\n\nMauritania experienced an outbreak of RVF in 2010. With regard to this outbreak, WHO does not recommend any travel or trade restrictions be applied.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects livestock but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected livestock. The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting veterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. Certain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of infection. There is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals. Human infections can also result occasionally from the bites of infected _Aedes_ spp. mosquitoes. Human-to-human transmission of RVF has been not been documented.\n\nOn 24 Oct 212 the Mauritanian Ministry of Health reported 30 human cases of Rift Valley fever infection, 13 of whom died. As of 1 Nov 2012 the number of confirmed cases has risen to 34, and the number of deaths to 17. It was suggested in the previous report that the outbreak was in decline now because the rainy season, which is one of the factors favouring the spread of the disease, has ended. However, no information has been provided, then or now, concerning the progress and extent of the outbreak in the animal population.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt and a map of the regions of Mauritania at http://www.unicef.org/har2010/images/HAR10_Map_Mauritania.jpg. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n WHO and partners, including the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), are working within the task force to strengthen epidemiological surveillance in both human and animal health, strengthen capacity in case management at health care facilities, strengthen health measures in slaughterhouses, and raise awareness among farmers. From 16 Sep 2012 (the date of detection of the index case) to 30 Oct 2012, a total of 34 cases, including 17 deaths have been reported from 6 [of the 12 regions of Mauritania]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects livestock but also has the capacity to infect humans. A multi-sector investigation team has been deployed to conduct a detailed outbreak investigation among humans and animals in the affected areas. The virus can be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting veterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. There is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals. As of 1 Nov 2012 the number of confirmed cases has risen to 34, and the number of deaths to 17. On 24 Oct 212 the Mauritanian Ministry of Health reported 30 human cases of Rift Valley fever infection, 13 of whom died. The Minister of Health, Mr. Hamady Ba Housseynou, presented to Cabinet a paper on an outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RFV) in Mauritania. The Minister reported that 7 cases of fever had been recorded in the country causing 4 deaths. 2 of the survivors were recovering and one was still under treatment.\n\nThis is not the 1st time that Rift Valley fever has occurred in Mauritania. Cases were recorded in Adrar in 2010. Among the causes of Rift valley fever are high rainfall and lack of ability to cook meat thoroughly. Mr. Hamady Ba Housseynou called on citizens to look out for signs of the disease and to take appropriate action immediately to contain the infection.\n\nThe Department of Health says it is ready to intervene at any time. But the situation is much more difficult for cases that occur away from urban areas on account of the difficult in provision the supply of blood that is vital to save the patients' lives.\n\nThe current disease situation situation is not unusual and there is no cause for panic. The cases are sporadic and there is no focal epidemic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCorrespondent Gert van der Hoek\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected livestock. The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting veterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. Certain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection. There is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\n\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected mosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF virus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\nTo date, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and no transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when standard infection control precautions have been put in place. There has been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nThe incubation period for RVF varies from 2 to 6 days. The symptoms of RVF usually last from 4 to 7 days, after which time the immune response becomes detectable with the appearance of antibodies and the virus gradually disappears from the blood. While most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of patients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually appears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 percent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). The total case fatality rate has varied widely between different epidemics but, overall, has been less than 1 percent in those documented cases. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the haemorrhagic icterus form. For further information, see: http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html).\n\nThe interactive ProMED/HealthMap of Mauritania can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3AVt. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n This usually appears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 percent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). She acknowledged that the next\nday after return she experienced fever that resolved within a week.\n\nLaboratory investigations for malaria, Lyme disease, rickettsiosis,\ndengue, chikungunya, and West Nile fever viruses were all negative\nwhereas Rift Valley fever virus serology using Elisa testing was\npositive for IgM.\n\nOn 17 Oct 2011 she is still complaining of headache although no\nrelapse in fever was noted. To the best of our knowledge, this is the\n1st report of human Rift Valley fever from Zimbabwe.\n\n--\nGuillaume Vesin\n<guillaume.vesin@chu-bordeaux.fr>\nDr Receveur, Pr Malvy\nService de medecine tropicale\nCHU de Bordeaux\nFrance\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Guillaume Vesin for forwarding this interesting\naccount of the detection of the 1st known human case of Rift Valley\nfever virus (RVFV) infection in Zimbabwe.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF), a mosquitoborne zoonotic disease among humans\nand ruminants, is caused by Rift Valley fever virus, a virus belonging\nto the family _Bunyaviridae_, genus _Phlebovirus_. RVF is endemic to\nsub-Saharan African countries and has caused major outbreaks in\nseveral countries including Kenya, Tanzania, Somalia, South Africa,\nMadagascar, Egypt, Sudan, Mauritania, Senegal, Saudi Arabia, and\nYemen. Pregnant ruminants infected with RVFV typically are subject to\nhigh-rate abortions, fetal malformation, and subclinical-to-fatal\nfebrile illness, while newborn lambs usually die by acute hepatitis.\nRVFV infection in humans primarily causes a self-limiting febrile\nillness; however, some patients develop haemorrhagic fever,\nneurological disorders, or blindness after the febrile period. In\nendemic areas, _Aedes_ mosquitoes, such as _Ae. mcintoshi_ or _Ae.\nvexans_ serve as vectors, and the virus can be transmitted into\noffspring transovarially. Heavy rainfall or flooding of river banks\ndue to construction of dams increases the number of permanent fresh\nwater species of mosquitoes such as _Culex pipiens_, which play a role\nin amplifying RVFV among mosquitoes, ruminants, and humans (see\nIkegami T, Makino S. The pathogenesis of Rift Valley fever. Viruses.\n2011; 3(5): 493-5;\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3111045/).\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be\ntransmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nThe aerosol mode of transmission has also led to infection in\nlaboratory workers. There is some evidence that humans may also become\ninfected with RVFV by ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of\ninfected animals. To date, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has\nbeen documented, and no transmission of RVF to health care workers has\nbeen reported when standard infection control precautions have been\nput in place (see\nhttp://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html).\n\nAlthough the human case described above may be the 1st record of human\ninfection in Zimbabwe, phylogenetic analyses of RVF viruses isolated\nin Zimbabwe has revealed the presence of multiple virus lineages\nindicating that the spread of distinct RVF virus genotypes is an\nongoing process and can occur over large geographic distances (see\nBird, et al. J Virol. 2007 March; 81(6): 2805-16;\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1865992).\n\nMarondera is a town and district in Mashonaland East, Zimbabwe,\nsituated about 72 km (45 mi) east of the capital Harare. It can be\nlocated in the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Zimbabwe at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1m1w. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Although the human case described above may be the 1st record of human\ninfection in Zimbabwe, phylogenetic analyses of RVF viruses isolated\nin Zimbabwe has revealed the presence of multiple virus lineages\nindicating that the spread of distinct RVF virus genotypes is an\nongoing process and can occur over large geographic distances (see\nBird, et al. France: ex Zimbabwe (ME) 1st Archive Number: 20111020.3132).\nAs reporting of RVF is mandatory in France, the patient's samples were\nsent to the National Reference Laboratory for Arboviruses for\nconfirmation.\n\nThe 1st serum, obtained at day 25 after symptom onset was\nreinvestigated for the presence of anti-arbovirus antibodies (i.e.,\nDengue; Chikungunya; West Nile; Rift Valley fever). Only a borderline\nIgM reactivity against RVF virus antigen was detected. A 2nd sample\nobtained at day 67 after onset was found negative for both IgM and IgG\nfor all antigens tested. The lack of enhancement of IgM response and\nno IgG seroconversion led us to conclude that the transient IgM\nresponse in the initial sample was a non-specific reaction.\nConsequently RVF infection has been classifies as 'not confirmed.'\n\nDiagnosis of imported cases has proven to be valuable for the global\nsurveillance of arboviruses. Thus, clinicians should be aware that\npathologies (case definition; diagnostic procedures including\ninterpretation criteria), especially where mandatory reporting at the\nnational or the international levels, is required.\n\n--\nDr Marc Grandadam\nNational Reference Centre for Arboviruses\nInstitut Pasteur\nParis\nFrance\n<marc.grandadam@pasteur.fr>\nand\nDr Deny Malvy\nService de Medicine Tropicale\nCHU de Bordeaux\nFrance\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Grandadam and Malvy for providing this\ninformation and correcting the record. - Mod.CP\n]", "summary": "Dr Marc Grandadam\nNational Reference Centre for Arboviruses\nInstitut Pasteur\nParis\nFrance\n<marc.grandadam@pasteur.fr>\nand\nDr Deny Malvy\nService de Medicine Tropicale\nCHU de Bordeaux\nFrance\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Drs Grandadam and Malvy for providing this\ninformation and correcting the record. - Mod. [See abstract below].\n\nPreliminary investigations of the most recent outbreak (2011) seem to\nbe affecting more mature male animals. To my knowledge, RVF has not\nbeen reported in alpacas before and there is also no registered\nvaccine for use in camelids.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Sophette Gers\nState Veterinarian\nProvincial Veterinary Laboratory\nDepartment of Agriculture: Western Cape\nPrivate Bag X5020, Stellenbosch, 7599, South Africa\nemail: <sophetteg@elsenburg.com>\nDepartmental website: <http://www.elsenburg.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail post 20110129.0350 included the following comment: 'It\nwould be interesting to obtain more information on the disease in\nalpacas: age, clinical observations. Are alpacas included in the\napplied vaccination regime?'\n\nDr Gers is gratefully acknowledged for responding with the above\nfirsthand information. The abstract follows:\n\nRift Valley fever infection in alpacas.\nBy S Gers (Western Cape Provincial Veterinary Laboratory,\nStellen-bosch, South Africa) and J Grewar (Veterinary Services Western\nCape, Epidemiology Section, Elsenburg, South Africa).\n\nVeterinary Pathology Online\n<http://vet.sagepub.com/content/47/6_suppl/3S> (subscription):\nAbstract 165 2010 47: 3S Vet Pathol.\n\n'Rift Valley fever (RVF) is an acute to peracute zoonotic disease of\ndomestic ruminants occurring predominantly in Africa. It is caused by\na single serotype of a vector-borne RNA virus (Bunyavirus) of the\ngenus Phlebovirus. Floodwater-breeding mosquitoes of Aedes species\nplay a major role in outbreak initiation following periods of above\naverage rainfall, while Culex and Anopheles species, and less\nimportantly biting flies, are considered epidemic vectors. In South\nAfrica (SA), RVF occurs at irregular intervals; the first known\noutbreak reported in the 1950s, a major outbreak in 1974-76 and small,\nlocalized outbreaks in 1981 and 1999. In 2008, RVF reoccurred, with\nisolated outbreaks reported in 2009 followed by an extensive epidemic\nin 2010 affecting most parts of SA.\n\nIn April 2010, RVF was diagnosed in 4 sub-adult alpacas that died on\na farm in the Western Cape Province of SA. The disease had an abrupt\nonset and short course lasting from 4 to 6 hours. Affected animals\nwere anorexic, depressed, pyrexic, showed signs of abdominal\ndiscomfort, developed respiratory distress and despite supportive\ntherapy, died. At necropsy, widespread petechiae and ecchymoses were\nobserved in the buccal mucosa, subcutis, serosal surfaces, endo- and\nepicardium, liver, thymus, lungs, and lymph nodes. Small intestinal\nintraluminal hemorrhage was present in 2 animals. Histologically the\nliver showed multifocal to coalescent, extensive areas of coagulative\nto lytic necrosis. Characteristic intranuclear inclusions were present\nin two animals. Both immunohistochemical staining and rtPCR confirmed\nRVF.\n\nVarious epidemiological aspects of the outbreak were investigated,\nincluding vector trapping and identification. Interestingly, although\nthis is a multi-age alpaca enterprise, only the yearling group was\naffected. To the authors' knowledge, this is the 1st reported case of\nRVF virus infection in alpacas'.\n\nDuring the 2010 major epizootic, which reportedly started on 19 Jan\n2010 and resolved on 18 Sep 2010, a total of 489 outbreaks were\nreported to the OIE; a summary of the epizootic,including a map, is\navailable at\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=8967>.\n\n\nThe initial report on RVF cases in 'camelidae' was included in\nfollow-up report No 6, submitted 21 Apr 2010, addressing 2 cases (and\ndeaths) in Bains Game Lodge, Mangaung, Free State, on 12 Apr 2010.\n\nThe affected population was described as follows: 'A few llamas were\nkept in a camp, together with springboks, blesboks and giraffes. Signs\nof disease were only observed in the llamas'. Later (follow-up report\nno 8, submitted 7 May 2010; see archived 20100512.1548) the disease\nwas reported to have affected, on 18 Apr 2010, 3 alpacas (out of 223)\nwhich died in Landskroon, Drakenstein, Western Cape Province.\n\nThe (78) sheep on the same holding remained, reportedly, unaffected.\n\nInterestingly, according to available literature, RVF has been\nregarded hitherto to be clinically inapparent in camels (dromedaries),\nthough abortions may occur. See 2004 review at\n<http://web.oie.int/boutique/extrait/613-624gerdes.pdf>. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon, 31 Jan 2011\nFrom: Sophette Gers <sophetteg@elsenburg.com>\n\nRift Valley fever in alpacas in South Africa\n During the 2010 major epizootic, which reportedly started on 19 Jan\n2010 and resolved on 18 Sep 2010, a total of 489 outbreaks were\nreported to the OIE; a summary of the epizootic,including a map, is\navailable at\n<http://web.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=8967>. Later (follow-up report\nno 8, submitted 7 May 2010; see archived 20100512.1548) the disease\nwas reported to have affected, on 18 Apr 2010, 3 alpacas (out of 223)\nwhich died in Landskroon, Drakenstein, Western Cape Province. In the 2010 outbreak, it was mostly yearling animals that were\naffected(I have presented the macroscopic and histopathology findings\nat the American College of Veterinary Pathologists' - ACVP meeting in\nBaltimore, in October/November 2010). In South\nAfrica (SA), RVF occurs at irregular intervals; the first known\noutbreak reported in the 1950s, a major outbreak in 1974-76 and small,\nlocalized outbreaks in 1981 and 1999. Floodwater-breeding mosquitoes of Aedes species\nplay a major role in outbreak initiation following periods of above\naverage rainfall, while Culex and Anopheles species, and less\nimportantly biting flies, are considered epidemic vectors. Affected animals\nwere anorexic, depressed, pyrexic, showed signs of abdominal\ndiscomfort, developed respiratory distress and despite supportive\ntherapy, died. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Sophette Gers\n Provincial Veterinary Laboratory\nDepartment of Agriculture: Western Cape\nPrivate Bag X5020, Stellenbosch, 7599, South Africa\nemail: <sophetteg@elsenburg.com> Departmental website: <http://www.elsenburg.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail post 20110129.0350 included the following comment: 'It\nwould be interesting to obtain more information on the disease in\nalpacas: age, clinical observations. \n\n\nThe initial report on RVF cases in 'camelidae' was included in\nfollow-up report No 6, submitted 21 Apr 2010, addressing 2 cases (and\ndeaths) in Bains Game Lodge, Mangaung, Free State, on 12 Apr 2010. 20110129.0350]:\n\nI am a diagnostic veterinary pathologist and was involved in the\ndiagnosis of the initial RVF outbreak in Alpacas in the Western Cape\nlast year and on a different property this year. \n\nVeterinary Pathology Online\n<http://vet.sagepub.com/content/47/6_suppl/3S> (subscription):\nAbstract 165 2010 47: 3S Vet Pathol. This means that the State Veterinary\nServices are not solely responsible for the control of the disease.\nThe government assists farmers with the supply of vaccine and promotes\nthe vaccination of South African livestock, but the responsibility\nlies with the farmer. Vaccine is cheap and readily available to\nfarmers. The result is that when reporting an outbreak, the State\nVeterinary Services do not have any statistics with regard to the\nnumber of animals vaccinated, as the numbers vaccinated by farmers and\nprivate veterinarians far exceed the numbers vaccinated by the state.\nThe OIE's WAHID disease reporting system does not allow for this\nscenario and if vaccination is recorded on the system as a control\nmeasure, details must be given which the state does not have.\n\nSouth African Veterinary Services, by means of the Provincial\nVeterinary Services do vaccinate in response to outbreaks, but the\neffect of media campaigns like the one mentioned in the ProMED-mail\nRFI [referenced above] has a much greater effect on the numbers of\nanimals vaccinated. There is no 'no vaccination' policy in South\nAfrica with regards to the control of Rift Valley fever, this was a\nmiscommunication caused by the OIE WAHIS [World Animal Health\nInformation System]. South Africa cannot officially report vaccination\nnumbers as it is not a legal requirement to report RVF vaccinations to\nthe State.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Boitshoko Ntshabele\nChief Director, Food and Veterinary Services\nDepartment of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries\nPretoria, South Africa\n<CDFVS@nda.agric.za>\n\n[The response above, for which ProMED-mail is very grateful to Dr\nNtshabele, sets the matter clear: there is no 'no vaccination' policy\nin South Africa with regard to the control of RVF.\n\nThe following information on RVF control in South Africa is currently\nlisted in WAHID interface (South Africa 2009 annual report, submitted\n4 May 2010), referring to the relevant domestic animals, namely\ncattle, buffaloes, sheep, goats, and camelids:\n1. The\nIndependent press, quoting from official sources, speaks of 17 deaths.\n\n'Cases of fever Rift Valley [fever] have caused losses of (human)\nlives and of livestock,' stated the Mauritanian News Agency (l'Agence\nmauritanienne d'information, AMI), without specifying the total.\nAccording to local independent media, the epidemic has already killed\n17 people, and the sick were sent to hospitals including those in Nouakchott.\n\nThe Minister of Health and Interior visiting the region has given\nstrict instructions to the population of the Adrar (the region where\nAoujeft is situated) that they must refrain, in response to these\n[Rift Valley] fever cases, from consuming locally produced meat and\nmilk, says AMI. These restrictions on meat and milk, 2 essential\ncommodities in the diet of the people, must last at least until the\ninvestigation is finished and the results of laboratory tests\nconducted since Thursday [2 Dec 2010] by veterinary specialists on\ninfected animals are confirmed says AMI.\n\nRift Valley fever is a disease that primarily affects animals but can\nalso infect humans. The infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans. The deaths and abortions in cattle infected with\nthe disease also result in substantial economic losses.\n\nThere is no specific treatment, and no human vaccine is available\nagainst the disease, which is transmitted by mosquitoes and affects\nmainly young men in contact with infected cattle.\n\nRift Valley fever bears the name of the region of Kenya where it was\nidentified in 1931. The disease has hit Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania\nin the years 1967/68, and the last major outbreak was reported in\n2000 in Yemen and Saudi Arabia [and Mauritania in 2003; see\nProMED-mail archive references below].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mortality on this scale is unusual for local outbreaks of Rift\nValley fever. The text of this press report suggests that a precise\ndiagnosis has still to be confirmed. Further information is awaited.\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans. The disease also\nresults in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock.\n\nRVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera\nin the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931\nduring an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the\nRift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa [Mauritania]. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are, therefore, at higher risk of\ninfection. The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals.\n\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented, and\nno transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported when\nstandard infection control precautions have been put in place. There\nhas been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent).\n\nThe total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than one percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nMore detailed information can be obtained from the WHO website at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Dec 2010\n The virus infects humans through inoculation, for example\nvia a wound from an infected knife or through contact with broken\nskin, or through inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter\nof infected animals. In 1997-98, a major\noutbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania, and in September\n2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the\n1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent.\n\n This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than one\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than one percent). When you examine the history of Rift Valley Fever in West\nAfrica through our archives, it is apparent that there is a cyclic\nnature to the outbreaks in the western-most countries of West Africa\nlike Mauritania and Senegal -- just as RVF has a cyclic nature in East\nAfrica.\n\nThere were outbreaks in Mauritania in 2009 and 2010. This was preceded\nby outbreaks in 2002 and 2003. Prior to that we have a series in\noutbreaks in 1998 and 1999. But what is absolutely fascinating is one\nof the earliest ProMED-mail posts in 1994 was concerning the emergence\nof Rift Valley Fever in southern Mauritania and northern Senegal.\nScientist from The Pasteur Institute reported the following: 13\nstrains of Rift Valley Fever virus were isolated from _Aedes vexans_\nand _Aedes ochraceus_ collected in October and November 1993 around\ntemporary ground pools in Northern Senegal. See the reference below\nfor details.\n\nAnother notable feature is that this cycle of outbreaks begs\nverification that RVF occurrence can be predicted by climatic models.\nRVF seems to be associated with above average rainfall and RVF\nforecasting and climatic models can be useful in predicting outbreaks\nas indicated on WHO fact sheet on RVF - see\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>. The question\nthen arises as how well do climatic models predict this particular\nseries of outbreaks in Senegal and Mauritania and can they be useful\nfor further outbreaks? Another important question is how well\nestablished is RVF in this region and when can we expect more outbreaks.\n\nA summary of WHO information on climate models and RVF is given below:\n\nForecasting can predict climatic conditions that are frequently\nassociated with an increased risk of outbreaks, and may improve\ndisease control. In Africa, Saudi Arabia and Yemen RVF outbreaks are\nclosely associated with periods of above-average rainfall. The\nresponse of vegetation to increased levels of rainfall can be easily\nmeasured and monitored by Remote Sensing Satellite Imagery. In\naddition RVF outbreaks in East Africa are closely associated with the\nheavy rainfall that occurs during the warm phase of the El\nNino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon.\n\nThese findings have enabled the successful development of forecasting\nmodels and early warning systems for RVF using satellite images and\nweather/climate forecasting data. Early warning systems, such as\nthese, could be used to detect animal cases at an early stage of an\noutbreak enabling authorities to implement measures to avert impending\nepidemics.\n\nWithin the framework of the new International Health Regulations\n(2005), the forecasting and early detection of RVF outbreaks, together\nwith a comprehensive assessment of the risk of diffusion to new areas,\nare essential to enable effective and timely control measures\n[livestock vaccination] to be implemented. - Mod.PC]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Mauritania can be\naccessed at: <http://healthmap.org/r/0hQ0>. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 16 Dec 2010\n Within the framework of the new International Health Regulations\n(2005), the forecasting and early detection of RVF outbreaks, together\nwith a comprehensive assessment of the risk of diffusion to new areas,\nare essential to enable effective and timely control measures\n The question\nthen arises as how well do climatic models predict this particular\nseries of outbreaks in Senegal and Mauritania and can they be useful\nfor further outbreaks? This comes close to 5 months after tens of\nNamibian animals were infected with RVF [virus] in the 1st outbreak of the\ndisease in the country since 1985.\n\nA notice about the 3 affected farmers was published in the weekly\nnewsletter of the Namibia Agricultural Union (NAU) last Friday [27 Aug\n2010]. Until yesterday [2 Sep 2010], however, Dr Jack Vries, chairperson of\nthe Ministry of Health and Social Service's National Health Emergency\nManagement Committee, had not been officially informed about the cases.\nVries told The Namibian that none of the country's 2 laboratories had made\nany positive diagnoses. This, he said, could be as a result of patients\nbeing tested in South Africa or not being tested at all.\n\nA Dorper sheep farmer, in the south of the country, yesterday [2 Sep 2010]\nsaid that he accidentally injected himself whilst he was busy immunising\nhis sheep about 3 weeks ago. 'I accidentally injected myself that Friday\nafternoon. By 1900 [that evening], I realised there was big trouble.'\nAccording to him, he could by then not even talk anymore. Apart from this,\nhe experienced a high fever, an increased heart beat and painful urination.\n'I also had terrible headaches. My urine was golden yellow, and it was\npainful when I urinated. And the heartbeats, it feels like your heart wants\nto run away.' It was only by Saturday afternoon that he could talk again,\nhe said. The farmer said that he decided not to go to a doctor. Instead, he\nspent a week in bed. A veterinarian he spoke to told him that it 'must be'\nRVF, he said.\n\nIn its newsletter, the NAU urged farmers 'to be very cautious when animals\nare vaccinated against RVF. If one gets pricked by the needle, the disease\ncan be contracted through the vaccine.' The union issued this warning\n'following the confirmation of 3 farmers in the south of Namibia who were\nidentified with the dreaded RVF.'\n\nDr Cleopas Bamhare, acting chief veterinary officer in the Ministry of\nAgriculture, Water and Forestry, earlier warned people to wear rubber\ngloves and face masks when they come into close contact with sick animals,\naborted foetuses, blood and other body fluids, especially during handling,\nslaughtering, butchering and milking, to avoid human infections. Meat\nintended for human consumption needs to be chilled and matured at 2 C for\nat least 24 hours. This, he said, will inactivate the virus if it is\npresent. The past week, Bamhare said no new animal infections have been\nreported to his office.\n\nEarlier this year [2010], it was reported that close to a 100 animals were\naffected in Namibia. Half of these died. Namibian farmers lost millions of\ndollars as a result of export bans that were in place when the outbreak was\nrife. More than 20 humans and hundreds of animals died in neighbouring\nSouth Africa during a recent RVF outbreak there.\n\nBamhare also earlier warned Namibians that RVF could cause a widespread\nepidemic in the next rainy season.\n\nAccording to Vries, the man would have landed in the intensive care unit\n(ICU) had it been RVF. However, another doctor The Namibian spoke to said\nit is 'definitely possible' for the farmer to have contracted the virus\nthrough the live vaccine. The farmer confirmed that it was the live vaccine.\n\n[byline: Denver Kisting]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The statement of the Namibia Agricultural Union that RVF virus infection\nin the 3 farmers was confirmed is not supported by other information, nor\nby the statement that samples were not tested by either of the country's 2\nlaboratories.
