Presumably, it might\ninfect a human following needlestick injury.\n\nPossible exposures of the other 2 farmers is not given. Conceivably, the\nfarmers may have been bitten by transovarially infected mosquitoes carrying\nthe virus that remained in the area following the last outbreak earlier\nthis year (2010). Several bunyaviruses, including RVF virus, can be\ntransovarially transmitted in _Aedes_ mosquitoes, and the virus-containing\neggs may remain viable for long periods of time in low-lying areas\n('dambos' in East Africa). However, in the absence of cases in livestock,\nthis possibility seems unlikely. 'Their alertness and prompt reaction prevented outbreaks of\nRVF in May 2010 from spreading, with potentially devastating\nconsequences on lives, livelihoods and food security,' Diouf said.\n\nDiouf singled out the Meat Board of Namibia, the abattoirs where the\ndisease was detected, the Directorate of Veterinary Services and the\nlivestock farmers concerned.\n\nThe vigilance and response of the veterinary services was all the more\nremarkable, Diouf said, when considering that RVF emerged in Namibia\nafter an absence of 25 years; almost all the staff involved had never\nhad to fight the disease before.\n\nRVF is a disease carried by mosquitoes after heavy rains and flooding\nand is characterised by high rates of abortion and neonatal mortality,\nprimarily in sheep, goats and also cattle. Humans are at risk -- and\ncan die -- when in close contact with the blood or organs of infected\nanimals or when bitten by infected mosquitoes.\n\nAn FAO team comprising members of the Animal Production and Health\nDivision and the Emergency Centre for Transboundary Animal Diseases\ndeployed at the request of the government returned from Namibia full\nof praise for the professional performance of the veterinary services\nin handling the outbreaks. Dr Juan Lubroth, FAO's Chief Veterinary\nOfficer said: 'The swift response is exemplary and very likely\nprevented worse from happening.'\n\nRVF was 1st suspected by veterinary services in sheep from 2 farms in\nthe Hardap/Karas regions on 9 May 2010. The disease was detected\nduring inspection at the Farmers' Meat Market Abattoir in Mariental,\nwhen lesions of RVF were recognised during examination.\n\n'The positive contribution of Namibia in the fight against RVF has\ninternational significance,' Diouf said. 'For this reason, FAO would\nlike to formally recognise the preparedness and readiness in place in\nNamibia and the alertness of veterinary services.\n\n'This is an inspiring example for other countries to follow to protect\ntheir animals, livelihoods, trade and indeed people, together with\nneighbouring countries from serious animal diseases.'\n\nHowever, RVF will continue to pose threats, including to Namibia, as\nthe next rainy season -- expected in October/November 2010 -- brings\nthe risks back. FAO looks forward to providing support in defining the\ndifferent options for control and prevention as part of Namibia's\nfuture strategy.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia has reported to the OIE, since 10 May 2010 (Immediate\nNotification), 12 outbreaks of RVF in animals. The reports and a map\nshowing the affected locations, spread throughout the country, are\navailable at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=9258>.\n\nIn contrast to several RVF-affected countries during recent years,\nwhere humans acted as sentinels of the virus circulation, in Namibia,\nthe disease was detected in animals, while no human infections have\nbeen -- to the best of our knowledge -- reported so far. This\nachievement is indeed commendable.\n\nThe most recent OIE follow-up report (No 2), submitted 7 Jul 2010,\nprovided data on 5 new outbreaks in sheep and goats. It included the\nfollowing epidemiological commentary:\n\n'Foci detected during general surveillance. Temperatures are low with\nthe onset of winter, and there is little vector activity. Movement\nrestrictions imposed within a 5-km-radius of the infected properties.\nVaccination encouraged.' A new follow-up report is anticipated.\n\nRVF virus has been, reportedly, circulating lately in 3 southern\nAfrica countries: South Africa, where animal and human infections have\nbeen recorded since the end of 2009, Namibia and Botswana. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Humans are at risk -- and\ncan die -- when in close contact with the blood or organs of infected\nanimals or when bitten by infected mosquitoes.\n\nAn FAO team comprising members of the Animal Production and Health\nDivision and the Emergency Centre for Transboundary Animal Diseases\ndeployed at the request of the government returned from Namibia full\nof praise for the professional performance of the veterinary services\nin handling the outbreaks. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed, 28 Jul 2010\n Dr Juan Lubroth, FAO's Chief Veterinary\nOfficer said: 'The swift response is exemplary and very likely\nprevented worse from happening.'\n\nRVF was 1st suspected by veterinary services in sheep from 2 farms in\nthe Hardap/Karas regions on 9 May 2010. The Directorate of Veterinary Services'\nsurveillance activities have led to the diagnosis on 6 other farms,\nbringing the total number of farms to 14.\n\nOne of the newly identified farms is in the Erongo Region, 2 are in\nthe Karas Region, and 3 in the Hardap Region. Hardap has the highest\nnumber of animals affected by the outbreak, where 11 farms are\naffected. The outbreak in Erongo is the 1st of its kind.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry said measures to\ncontain the outbreaks are being implemented with the co-operation of\naffected farmers. The total number of reported clinical cases so far\nidentified is 67 and 46 deaths from a total population of 9700 small\nstock on the affected farms.\n\nClinical signs of infection include abortion, stillbirths, weakness,\nbloody diarrhoea and difficulty in breathing. All cases (except on 2\nfarms where goats were affected) involve sheep.\n\n'These findings indicate that the disease is not widespread and can\nbe described as sporadic at this stage. This situation can be\nexplained by the prevailing winter conditions that do not favour the\nsurvival of the vectors (mosquitoes and biting flies),' a statement\nby the Directorate of Veterinary Services read. The directorate,\nhowever, warns farmers that the disease is likely to cause a\nwidespread epidemic during the next rainy season when vector activity\nis expected to increase if animals are not vaccinated.\n\nFarmers are therefore urged to vaccinate their livestock -- cattle,\nsheep and goats -- during this time. Control measures that were\npreviously announced remain in place.\n\nThe importation of live ruminants, such as cattle, sheep, goats and\ngame into South Africa under a RSA veterinary import permit and\nhealth certificate processed by a the Directorate of Veterinary\nServices of Namibia will be allowed, provided the animals did not\npass through an RVF-infected zone during transportation.\n\nMovement of livestock within the country is now permitted subject to\na movement permit issued by the Directorate of Veterinary Services,\nexcept from farms that are under restriction for Rift Valley fever or\nother reasons.\n\nFarms under movement restriction due to RVF will be allowed to move\nlivestock 21 days after vaccination, while no live game animal will\nbe allowed to move from the restricted farms. The directorate\npredicts that there is an increased risk of the epidemic during the\ncoming rainy season. All livestock in the Hardap and Karas regions\nmust be vaccinated before the onset of the rains.\n\nTransporters intending to move animals through Botswana are expected\nto vaccinate their livestock with an attenuated live vaccine at least\n21 days prior to movement. Prior arrangements with the local State\nveterinary office must be made to avoid problems.\n\nIn the meantime, farmers who have vaccinated or would like to\nvaccinate their livestock, must inform their State veterinarian 3\nworking days prior to vaccination, provide proof of purchase of\nvaccine and empty vaccine containers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Namibia reported to the OIE about the above outbreaks, in 3\nprovinces, in follow-up report No 2, submitted 7 Jul 2010. She had been 'scared' of contracting\nRift Valley fever, which can be passed on to humans who come into\ncontact with the tissue of infected animals. He said she had\ncomplained of flu symptoms, but tests had repeatedly come back\nnegative for the disease [Rift Valley fever], which is spread among\nanimals by mosquitoes. He recalled that 'she would wear a protective\nsuit and 3 sets of gloves when she was doing autopsies on animals\nsuspected of dying of Rift Valley fever.' But when he called her on\nSat 15 May 2010, she sounded incoherent and slurred. Subsequently,\nshe was taken to hospital when she was already in a coma. She was\ndeclared brain dead, and her life support switched off on Fri 11 Jun\n2010. A colleague said that 'it was so hard to see her in the coma,\nbecause only about 2 percent of humans who contract this disease die of it.'\n\nThe Eastern Cape now has 17 confirmed human cases of Rift Valley\nfever. South Africa has 221 human cases of the disease, which has\nclaimed 23 lives nationally.\n\n[Byline: Barbara Hollands]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whereas most human cases of Rift Valley fever are relatively mild, a\nsmall percentage of patients develop a much more severe form of the\ndisease. This usually appears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes:\nocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis\n(less than 1 percent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent).\n\nIn the ocular form of the disease, the usual symptoms associated with\nthe mild form of the disease are accompanied by retinal lesions. The\nonset of the lesions in the eyes is usually one to 3 weeks after\nappearance of the 1st symptoms. Patients usually report blurred or\ndecreased vision. The disease may resolve itself with no lasting\neffects within 10 to 12 weeks. However, when the lesions occur in the\nmacula, 50 percent of patients will experience a permanent loss of\nvision. Death in patients with only the ocular form of the disease is uncommon.\n\nThe symptoms of the haemorrhagic form of the disease appear 2-4 days\nafter the onset of illness, and begin with evidence of severe liver\nimpairment, such as jaundice. Subsequently, signs of haemorrhage then\nappear such as vomiting blood, passing blood in the faeces, a\npurpuric rash or ecchymoses (caused by bleeding in the skin),\nbleeding from the nose or gums, menorrhagia and bleeding from\nvenepuncture sites. The case-fatality ratio for patients developing\nthe haemorrhagic form of the disease is high at approximately 50\npercent. Death usually occurs 3-6 days after the onset of symptoms.\nThe virus may be detectable in the blood for up to 10 days, in\npatients with the hemorrhagic icterus form of RVF.\n\nThe onset of the meningoencephalitis form of the disease usually\noccurs one to 4 weeks after the 1st symptoms of RVF appear. Clinical\nfeatures include intense headache, loss of memory, hallucinations,\nconfusion, disorientation, vertigo, convulsions, lethargy and coma.\nNeurological complications can appear later (over 60 days). The death\nrate in patients who experience only this form of the disease is low,\nalthough residual neurological deficit, which may be severe, is\ncommon. It is evident that the young Eastern Cape vet experienced\nthis form of the disease, and the fatal outcome was unexpected. It is\nsurprising that according to this account, diagnostic tests were\nnegative during the course of her illness.\n\nA set of maps of Eastern Cape Province showing the location of\nCradock can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/eastcape_atlas.htm>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]\n\n[RVF is extremely contagious and doesn't pick and chose. You don't\nwant to be anywhere nearby when an RVF animal is being necropsied; in\nan incident in Somalia in the early 1980s everyone within 25 paces of\na field necropsy came down with it. This case is a tragedy but it\nwill be bring home that RFV is a threat to all, not just indigenous\nvillagers. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jun 2010\n Source: The Herald online [abbreviated & edited]\n<http://www.theherald.co.za/article.aspx?id=576036>\n\n\nA 27-year-old veterinarian died at Port Elizabeth's St George's\nHospital last week after a 24-day coma, dashing hopes she would\nrecover from the disease she fought so hard to combat [in her role\nas] Cradock's state veterinarian. Subsequently, signs of haemorrhage then\nappear such as vomiting blood, passing blood in the faeces, a\npurpuric rash or ecchymoses (caused by bleeding in the skin),\nbleeding from the nose or gums, menorrhagia and bleeding from\nvenepuncture sites. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whereas most human cases of Rift Valley fever are relatively mild, a\nsmall percentage of patients develop a much more severe form of the\ndisease. He said she had\ncomplained of flu symptoms, but tests had repeatedly come back\nnegative for the disease [Rift Valley fever], which is spread among\nanimals by mosquitoes. The death\nrate in patients who experience only this form of the disease is low,\nalthough residual neurological deficit, which may be severe, is\ncommon. You don't\nwant to be anywhere nearby when an RVF animal is being necropsied; in\nan incident in Somalia in the early 1980s everyone within 25 paces of\na field necropsy came down with it. This usually appears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes:\nocular (eye) disease (0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis\n(less than 1 percent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). The symptoms of the haemorrhagic form of the disease appear 2-4 days\nafter the onset of illness, and begin with evidence of severe liver\nimpairment, such as jaundice. The case-fatality ratio for patients developing\nthe haemorrhagic form of the disease is high at approximately 50\npercent. The deceased vet's father said his daughter had taken the utmost\nprecaution when carrying out autopsies on farm animals suspected of\nbeing infected with the disease. The\nonset of the lesions in the eyes is usually one to 3 weeks after\nappearance of the 1st symptoms. However, when the lesions occur in the\nmacula, 50 percent of patients will experience a permanent loss of\nvision. He recalled that 'she would wear a protective\nsuit and 3 sets of gloves when she was doing autopsies on animals\nsuspected of dying of Rift Valley fever.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever", "encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "441775", "headline": "PRO/AH> Rift Valley fever, animal - South Africa (02): control strategy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=441775", "date": "2010-06-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, ANIMAL - SOUTH AFRICA (2): CONTROL STRATEGY\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 5 Jun 2010\nFrom: Willie Ungerer <WillieU@nda.agric.za>\n\n\nObservations during the present outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF)\nin South Africa confirm that the vast majority of human infections\noccur in persons involved in the livestock industry and result from\ncontact with the infected tissues of diseased animals. Only a small\nproportion of infections can be presumed to result from mosquito\nbite, and the local vectors of the virus generally bite outdoors at\nnight in fields close to their breeding sites, and not in towns.\n\nAt the time of release of the interim report on the current outbreak\non 3 May 2010, there had been 172 laboratory confirmed human cases of\nthe disease with 15 deaths. Many diagnostic specimens arrive at the\nlaboratory with scant information, and the histories of potential\nexposure to infection have to be obtained retrospectively. By 3 May\n2010, it had been established that 113/139 (81 percent) of the 172\npatients were employed in the livestock industry and that 124/128 (97\npercent) had direct contact with infected animals or tissues prior to\nthe onset of disease. Of the remaining 4 patients investigated, one\nhad ingested unpasteurized milk and 3 (2 percent) reported exposure\nto mosquito bite in the absence of exposure to sick animals or animal\ntissues. By 20 May 2010, 202 cases of the disease had been confirmed\n(out of 1400 specimens examined), and investigation of the patient\nhistories continues, but laboratory confirmations have declined to\n5-10 per week in line with a marke!\nd reduction in veterinary diagnoses. From past experience, it can be\nsurmised that there will be a sharp decline in transmission of the\ndisease when the onset of frosts at the end of May 2010 suppresses\nmosquito activity.\n\nThere is no evidence that RVF infection has ever occurred in urban\nconsumers of meat subjected to inspection at abattoirs, as opposed to\nmeat derived form informal slaughter of sick animals in rural\ncommunities, and pasteurized milk and other dairy products sold in\ntowns likewise appear to be safe. Since RVF did not pose a threat to\nthe population at large at the height of the present outbreak, it is\nunlikely to present a hazard to tourists during the winter months of\nJune and July.\n\nVeterinary control and prevention of the disease is compounded by the\nirregular occurrence of outbreaks and the feasibility of mass\nimmunization of livestock. Methods for predicting outbreaks of RVF\nare as yet imprecise. Nevertheless, national and provincial\nveterinary services in South Africa repeatedly warned farmers to\nvaccinate livestock during the past 3 years. Unfortunately, many of\nthe farmers are unfamiliar with the disease and were slow to respond.\nMoreover, if livestock are vaccinated during an outbreak, there is a\ndanger of spreading the outbreak. Furthermore, it is not cost\neffective to produce and stockpile vaccine when demand is low, so\nsupply problems are often encountered during outbreaks. The most\nreadily produced veterinary vaccine, a modified live virus vaccine,\ncauses abortion in a small proportion of pregnant animals with a\nresultant reluctance to use it in breeding stock. An inactivated\n(killed) virus vaccine is also available, but is more laborious and e!\nxpensive to produce, and since at least 2 initial doses and annual\nboosters are required to induce solid immunity, it is less effective\nfor use in the face of an imminent outbreak.\n\nThe institution of compulsory livestock vaccination and veterinary\ncontrol would be prohibitively expensive and impossible to sustain\nfor a disease which disappears for decades at a time. The situation\nmay change with the advent of improved vaccines, which are already in\nan advanced stage of development. A killed vaccine for use in humans\nwas produced in limited quantities decades ago, but it is no longer\navailable, and the small and irregular potential demand inhibits the\ndevelopment of a new human vaccine.\n\n--\nDr. Willie Ungerer\nActing Director\nDirectorate: Animal Health\nDepartment of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries\nRepublic of South Africa\n<WillieU@nda.agric.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail very much appreciates the information provided by Dr.\nWillie Ungerer, which details some factual information about Rift\nValley fever transmission to humans, control strategies in animal\npopulations and factors determining the disease control choices made\nduring the current outbreak of RVF in South Africa. Clearly, it is\nimportant to emphasize the fact that the vast majority of cases in\nhumans are associated with animal contact on farms and that foodborne\ntransmission of well cooked items, with the exception of\nunpasteurized milk, has clearly never been associated with human RVF\ncases. Again, Dr. Ungerer points out that Rift Valley fever has not\nbeen a transmission threat to urban consumers of meats, and so\ntourists who stay in town to watch the upcoming FIFA World Cup are\nnot at any increased risk of disease. This is emphatically the case\nas evidenced by the fact that there are no international travel\nwarnings for South Africa concerning RVF.\n\nWhat is of greatest interest in this South Africa RVF outbreak is the\nassessment and management of risk and the integration of animal and\nhuman health concerns. Risk is not limited to only the probability of\ndisease spread in the animal population and its potential for\ninfecting humans. A proper risk assessment requires consideration of\nmagnitude of the consequences if the disease were to not only infect\nfarmers, veterinarians, slaughterhouse workers etc. but also somehow\ninfect a tourist traveling outside the FIFA World Cup game sites\nwhile on their visit to South Africa. The FIFA world cup will last\nfor about a month, and any case of RVF in tourists would have severe\nramifications.\n\nClearly, the disease has a history of disappearing for decades in\nSouth Africa, but it has also appeared for the last 2 years in South\nAfrica affecting cattle, sheep, goats and African buffalo, with 28\noutbreaks and 501 cases in 2008 and 56 outbreaks and 401 cases in\n2009 (see Disease Database Query on Animal Diseases in the RSA at\n<http://www.daff.gov.za/>).\n\nDoes the fact that the disease appeared in South Africa during the\nlast 2 years change the disease control calculus in any way? Another\nissue, which really is the proverbial elephant in the room, is how\nmuch risk is being accepted by letting the disease run its course,\nwhen so many tourists are flocking to the country. It is stated by\nDr. Ungerer that the disease would be prohibitively expensive to\ncontrol in livestock, but what would be the consequences and cost of\neven a single tourist being diagnosed with a true case of RVF?\nAdditionally, given that farmers are only encouraged but not mandated\nto vaccinate, are not provided vaccine by the government and have\napparently chosen not to vaccinate, it appears that the only RVF\ndisease control strategy has been to allow the disease to run its\ncourse. This has resulted in a situation where the control strategy\nfor both animals and, by extension, humans depends on reducing the\ndisease in animals passively as the vector population d!\nies out with the approaching winter. Given recent experiences with\nclimate variation associated with global climate change and the\nextension of vector ranges such as bluetongue in Europe, is such a\npassive strategy justified given the stakes this year (2010) in South\nAfrica?\n\nThe disease outbreaks are still being updated at OIE, so can we\nreally depend this year (2010) on the traditional onset of winter to\nend the epidemic in animals? Would a formal cost benefit and risk\nanalysis provide help in making any or all of these risk management\ndecisions?\n\nA final issue which may shed light on optimal disease control\napproaches to use in the future is how well have the human and animal\ndisease control sectors integrated their responses. This is\nparticularly important because the nature of Rift Valley fever is\nsuch that animals are the source of the disease and the source of its\nultimate control. Control efforts in people appeared to be a high\npriority as the South African Field Epidemiology and Laboratory\nTraining Program (SAFELTP) was involved early, but it would be\nfascinating to know the public health perspective on letting the\nSouth African winter end the epidemic in animals as the chief disease\ncontrol tactic for the source of ongoing disease spread. It would\nalso be important to know how decision making in the South African\npublic health establishment integrated veterinary inputs for\ncontrolling the disease in animals, their assessment of risk after\nthe last 2 years of outbreaks, and how much emphasis is placed on\nzoonotic!\ndisease control in various public health decision making centers\nsuch as the FELTP program. In the end, it is a question of how much\nand at what levels integrated veterinary and human health inputs in\ndisease control decision making occur, how integrated the process is\nin the day to day disease management sense, and how much of a One\nMedicine, One Health perspective is taken when being faced with an\noutbreak situation involving a major zoonotic disease during a time\nof high visibility, greatly increased worldwide travel to South\nAfrica and when major economic stakes are involved.\n\nIn summary, we are beginning to understand that disease emerges when\njust the 'perfect storm' of events come together to foster the\nemergence of a new disease or a major change in disease epidemiology.\nIs the failure of vaccination in animals, the passivity of the\ncontrol program in animals, the lack of emphasis on monitoring and\ncontrol at the human animal interface, the population and\ndemographics changes which are occurring with the influx of tourists\nfor FIFA World Cup games just such a 'perfect storm'? Probably not,\nas the emergence of new disease is rare indeed and some new\ntransmission dynamics would have to be elaborated by the virus\nbecause current prospects for any human transmission to tourists are\nreally highly unlikely. However, I do hope such precautionary\nthinking is a part of an integrated prevention perspective where such\nunusual circumstances occur from time to time around the world. -\nMod.PC]", "summary": "In the end, it is a question of how much\nand at what levels integrated veterinary and human health inputs in\ndisease control decision making occur, how integrated the process is\nin the day to day disease management sense, and how much of a One\nMedicine, One Health perspective is taken when being faced with an\noutbreak situation involving a major zoonotic disease during a time\nof high visibility, greatly increased worldwide travel to South\nAfrica and when major economic stakes are involved. It is a viral\ndisease of domestic and wildlife animals, but it can also affect\npeople.\n\nIn animals, it is mainly transmitted through mosquito bites. It is\ncharacterized by abortion at all stages of pregnancy and high\nmortality in young animals.\n\nPeople can contract the disease through handling or consuming\ncontaminated materials such as meat, milk, body fluids and sick\nanimals. The disease may present itself with fever, muscle or joint\npains and bleeding from the nose, mouth and skin. The disease can\nlead to death, hence the public is advised to be careful.\n\nIn order to reduce the risk of spread of the disease and determine\nthe extent of the outbreak, the following measures have been put in\nplace with immediate effect:\n\n- Movement of cattle, goats and sheep within, out and into Ramotswa\nextension area is not allowed.\n- Movement of cattle, goats and sheep within, out and into Kgatleng\nDistrict, Good-hope Sub-district and Lobatse, Otse, Tlokweng,\nGaborone and Mogobane extension areas except for direct slaughter at\nslaughter facilities licensed by the Department of Veterinary\nServices is not allowed.\n- Transiting cattle, sheep and goats for rearing through Kgatleng and\nSoutheast Districts and Goodhope Sub-district from other parts of the\ncountry is allowed under permit after dipping with a mosquito\nrepellent dip or pour-ons.\n- Transiting of imported vaccinated cattle, sheep and goats is\nallowed through Kgatleng and Southeast Districts and Goodhope\nsub-district after dipping with a mosquito repellent dip or pours-ons.\n- However, movement of cattle, sheep and goats in the rest of the\ncountry is not affected by these movement restrictions.\n\nAs part of surveillance, farmers are urged to report any cases of\nabortion in cattle, sheep and goats or mortality in young animals to\nthe nearest veterinary office. Farmers and the general public are\nstrongly advised to avoid handling or consuming any suspect or\npossibly contaminated material.\n\nThe general public is further advised to thoroughly cook animal\nproducts before eating such products.\n\n[Byline: Oaitse Mathala]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Botswana's immediate notification to the OIE with map, submitted 28\nJun 2010, was included in archived post 20100630.2176. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "\n- Movement of cattle, goats and sheep within, out and into Kgatleng\nDistrict, Good-hope Sub-district and Lobatse, Otse, Tlokweng,\nGaborone and Mogobane extension areas except for direct slaughter at\nslaughter facilities licensed by the Department of Veterinary\nServices is not allowed. However, should farmers not take precautionary measures by\nvaccinating their animals, they might be in for a rough ride next summer\n[2010-11]. So says Dr Cleopas Bamhare, acting chief veterinary officer in\nthe Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry.\n\nAccording to Bamhare, no new RVF infections have been reported since the\nones reported on 6 farms in the Hardap Region and one in the Karas Region.\nThe onset of winter played a significant role in bringing the [zoonotic]\ndisease under control for the time being, he said.\n\nA total of 17 animals died in the 2 affected regions in what was regarded\nas the 1st RVF outbreak in Namibia since 1985. Hundreds of animals and\nclose to 20 people died of RVF in neighbouring South Africa (SA) recently.\n\nIf Namibia does not prepare adequately against a follow-up outbreak, the\ncountry might be worse off than it was during last month's [May 2010]\noutbreak. 'It is the next season that we are worried about. For now, it is\nunder control,' Bamhare said.\n\nNo human infections have been reported in Namibia.\n\nBamhare said the department of veterinary services dealt with the outbreak\n'textbook-style', which helped convince trade partners to lift restrictions\non imports of Namibian animals and meat products within weeks. 'And a\nsituation like that [trade restrictions] could take months to bring under\ncontrol, crippling the industry,' he said.\n\nHe said there are still no proper statistics available of the number of\nanimals that have been vaccinated against RVF. In terms of an agreement\nwith SA, live animals must have been vaccinated at least 21 days before\nbeing allowed into that country.\n\nBamhare spoke to The Namibian at an aquatic animal health training seminar\nthat started in Swakopmund on Tuesday evening [15 Jun 2010]. Kuti said on Thursday [20 May\n2010] that his ministry is awaiting response from Treasury for\nadditional funding to enable it embark on round 2 of the vaccination exercise.\n\nThe Minister said already animals in the pastoralist regions are\ninfected but no deaths have been reported as they had been\nvaccinated. 'There is high activity of the disease in the animals in\npastoralist areas, but we are on high alert and intend to embark on\nthe 2nd round of the vaccination exercise so that we do not reach\nepidemic levels,' said Kuti who addressed a meeting at Kilimo house.\n\nThe Minister said already the government undertook a vaccination\nexercise for one million heads of cattle to curb any outbreak this\nrainy season.\n\nLast year [2009] the government invested some 500 million shillings\n[6.41 million USD] to undertake the off-take exercise during the drought.\n\nRVF is a viral hemorrhagic fever which primarily affects animals but\ncan also infect humans. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among animals infected.\n\nA probable case occurs when a person or animal has acute fever with\nunexplained bleeding in stool, vomit, sputum, gums, nose, skin and\neyes. The vision deteriorates, [mental status becomes] altered [and]\nthen loses consciousness.\n\nThe virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an investigation into an\nepidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of Kenya.\n\nA major outbreak occurred in the country In 1997-98, during the El-Nino rains.\n\nIn December 2006, several deaths were reported in Garissa District.\nOther hemorrhagic fevers that occur in sub-Saharan Africa are yellow\nfever, Ebola, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and dengue viruses.\n\n[Byline: Judith Akolo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It will be interesting to note if the vaccine used in Kenya is the\nlive attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine, expected to confer lifelong\nimmunity after a single vaccination but contraindicated for\napplication in pregnant animals, or the inactivated vaccine, which\ncan be used in susceptible animals irrespective of the stage of\npregnancy and lactation but requires a booster vaccination and is\nmore costly. update 2\n--------------------------------------------\nOn Tue 11 May 2010 the Bernhard-Nocht-Institute for Tropical Medicine\nin Germany reported that additional laboratory analyses conducted both\nin Germany and South Africa on the German tourist who was\npreliminarily diagnosed with Rift Valley fever (RVF) following her\nreturn from South Africa, was in-fact infected with _Rickettsia_ and\nnot with RVF virus [see ProMED-mail Rift Valley fever - South Africa\n(17): tourist, NOT 20100511.1537].\n\n_Rickettsia_, commonly known as [a cause of] tick fever is a bacterium\nwhich can cause many diseases that are transmitted by blood-sucking\nparasitic arthropods such as fleas, lice, and ticks. Symptoms of\nrickettsial infections include rash, fever, and flu like symptoms.\nAfrican tick bite fever is caused by _Rickettsia africae_ and tends to\nbe a milder illness, with less prominent rash and little tendency to\nprogress to complicated disease. All rickettsial diseases respond to\ntreatment with antibiotics such as doxycycline and tetracycline.\n\nAs of 10 May [2010], the Government of South Africa has reported 186\nconfirmed cases of RVF in humans, including 18 deaths, in Free State\nProvince, Eastern Cape Province, Northern Cape Province, Western Cape,\nand North West Province. RVF is a viral disease that primarily affects\nanimals (such as cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats, and camels). The\ndisease can also affect humans. The main mode of transmission of RVF\nis via direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected\nanimals. Human infections have also resulted from the bites of\ninfected mosquitoes. There is evidence that humans may become infected\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\n\nWHO advises no international travel restriction to or from South\nAfrica. However, WHO recommends that visitors to South Africa,\nespecially those intending to visit farms and/or game reserves, avoid\ncoming into contact with animal tissues or blood, avoid drinking\nunpasteurized or uncooked milk or eating raw meat.\n\nAll travelers should take appropriate precautions against bites from\nmosquitoes and other blood-sucking insects (including the use of\ninsect repellents, wearing long-sleeved shirts and trousers, and\nsleeping under mosquito nets). Travel medicine professionals and\ntravel medicine services should be aware of the current RVF situation\nin South Africa in order to provide advice and care accordingly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Further information can be obtained from the following sources:\nDepartment of Health, South Africa (<http://www.doh.gov.za/>),\nThe National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD), South Africa\n(<http://www.nicd.ac.za/>),\nRift Valley fever: WHO fact sheet\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>).\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "On Tue 11 May 2010 the Bernhard-Nocht-Institute for Tropical Medicine\nin Germany reported that additional laboratory analyses conducted both\nin Germany and South Africa on the German tourist who was\npreliminarily diagnosed with Rift Valley fever (RVF) following her\nreturn from South Africa, was in-fact infected with _Rickettsia_ and\nnot with RVF virus [see ProMED-mail Rift Valley fever - South Africa\n(17): tourist, NOT 20100511.1537]. Additional laboratory\nanalyses, conducted both in Germany and in South Africa, however,\ncould not confirm this preliminary diagnosis.\n\nTesting of a 2nd, convalescent serum sample at BNI did not reveal an\nincrease in anti-RVF virus antibody titres indicating that the\nantibodies are not related to the illness following the travel to\nSouth Africa. The serum samples, which were sent to and investigated\nat the Special Pathogens Unit, National Institute for Communicable\nDiseases of the National Health Laboratory Service (SPU NICD-NHLS),\nSandringham, South Africa, tested negative for RVF virus-specific\nantibodies in different tests, including ELISA and virus neutralizing assays.\n\nWhile the reason for the discrepant findings remains unclear, in 3\nlaboratories, including BNI and SPU NICD-NHLS, seroconversion to\nRickettsia-specific IgM and IgG was detected, indicating recent\ninfection with _Rickettsia_ sp. We conclude from these new findings\nthat the acute illness in the case-patient after returning from South\nAfrica was caused by infection with _Rickettsia_ and not with RVF virus.\n\n--\nProf. Stephan Gunther\nDepartment of Virology\nBernhard-Nocht-Institute for Tropical Medicine\nBernhard-Nocht-Str. 74, 20359 Hamburg, Germany\n<guenther@bni.uni-hamburg.de>\n\nProf. Janusz T. The State Veterinary Services\ngive support by giving information and advice to farmers. The State\nVeterinary Services will supply some vaccines to upcoming farmers and\nsupport vaccination campaigns in non commercial domestic animals.\nPrivate owners are responsible for the vaccination of commercial\ndomestic animals. Farmers are advised not to move their animals while\nthe event is ongoing and to adhere to good biosecurity practices.\n\nControl measures: Measures applied No vaccination\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied No other measures\n\nFuture Reporting- The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports\nwill be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This reports summarizes 53 outbreaks in the week after our previous\nreport posted on our East African Regional list - ProMED-EAFR Rift\nValley fever, animal - South Africa: OIE 20100504.207118 . The\noutbreaks cover a wide geographic range of the country including the\nFree State, Northern Cape Province, Eastern Cape Province, Western\nCape Province and now the North West Province, which means there are\nreports from 5 of the 9 provinces in the country.\n\nTo summarize the current status of the outbreaks this week: Sheep\nhave been mainly infected with 1190 cases and 895 deaths. Other\nspecies including cattle, goats, buffaloes, camilidaes, and wild\nanimals have been affected to a much lesser degree. The latest\nfigures from the human side of the zoonotic bridge include 186 human\ncases with 18 deaths, an approximate 10 percent case fatality rate.\nAlthough an effective vaccine for animals is available, there appears\nto be only very passive efforts to control the disease in the animal\npopulation.\n\nGiven the influx of visitors for the upcoming FIFA World Cup set to\nbegin in just under a month, the strategy of allowing a zoonotic\ndisease to run its course in animals seems very risky indeed. The\ndisease can be transmitted by mosquitoes although it usually is not,\nbeing most commonly transmitted by exposure to infected animal\ntissues. Of the 186 human cases to date, how many are veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers and/or farmers, and how many fall outside the\ntraditional high risk groups? It would seem, given the stakes, that\nan extra insurance, really the best and most reliable insurance\nwhenever a zoonotic disease is involved, should be taken out by\neradicating this zoonotic disease in animals.\n\nFor further information on RVF in animals and the current South\nAfrican attempts to control it, we are repeating the moderator\ncomments from the previous ProMED-EAFR posting Rift Valley fever,\nanimal - South Africa: OIE 20100504.207118. - Mods.PC/FE]\n\n[Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is an arthropod borne viral disease that\noccurs throughout sub-Saharan Africa, Egypt and Arabic Peninsula. The\ndisease is caused by a RNA virus that has been classified in the\nfamily of Bunyaviridae and genus Phlebovirus. RVF outbreak normally\noccurs following exceptionally heavy rainfall preceded by a drought.\nThe disease was reported in Free State Province in February 2010 and\nsince then, two other Provinces (Northern and Eastern Cape) have\nreported the disease. This area is different from the previous\noutbreaks in the country.\n\nIn 2008, the outbreaks were much smaller in scale and in a different\nlocation. There were 31 total outbreaks between January and June,\n2008 with 14 in Mpumalanga, 5 in Limpopo, 6 in Guateng and 6 in North\nWest Province. These areas are adjacent to Swaziland, which also had\ntwo outbreaks around the same time. In 1999, the outbreaks occurred\nin near the Kruger National Park, not terribly far away from some of\nthe outbreaks in Limpopo and Mpumalanga in 2008. The current\noutbreaks are to the South and West previous outbreaks in the Free\nState, Northern Cape and Western Cape Provinces.\n\nThe following is extracted from an excellent, firsthand account of\nthe outbreak in 1999 kindly sent in to ProMED-mail by the\ndistinguished South African virologist, Bob Swanepol. I also\nrecommend the second posting in the series, with particular attention\nto the moderator comments by Charlie Calisher. What follows is a\nSwanepol's summary of outbreaks going back to the 1970s:\n\nRVF occurs in the country at irregular intervals of many years when\nparticularly heavy rains favour the occurrence of population\nexplosions of the floodwater-breeding aedine mosquito vectors of the\nvirus. The last big outbreaks occurred on the inland plateau during\nthe heavy rains of 1974-76, and a small outbreak on the coast of\nnorthern KwaZulu-Natal Province in 1981 -- since when the disease has\nnot been diagnosed in South Africa.\n\nWe provide you this historical background to make a point. The\ncurrent outbreak is unprecedented in its impact in animals, with 79\nnew outbreaks in the first report and 93 in the second update in this\nreport . It appears as if the disease is running rampant in South\nAfrica and is totally uncontrolled. RVF took its 12 human victim\nrecently and yet there is apparently no effective efforts to control\nthe disease in animals.\n\nRift Valley Fever classically starts in animals and spreads to\npeople. Most human cases arise through exposure to infected animal\ntissues at slaughter or through veterinary activities. However,\ninfection through mosquito bites cannot be completely ruled out. So\nfar in these outbreaks it appears high risk individuals working with\nanimals are those getting the infection.\n\nNot only does the disease start in animals, it also must be\ncontrolled there to keep people safe. By the magnitude of the\noutbreaks reported here, it would seem South Africa is in an\nunprecedented situation. Even though RVF is not a 'controlled\ndisease' in South Africa, only being notifiable and only meriting\ninformation and advice from the State Veterinary Services, it is\nbecoming increasingly obvious that such tactics are not getting the\njob done. It is understandable that standing, effective animal\ndisease control programs might not be in place when there can be gaps\nof a decade or more in between outbreaks. This is the nature of\nemerging disease but this is exactly why Joshua Lederberg, a true\nleader in the EID field indicated that 'against the adaptability of\nmicrobes, all we have is our wits.'\n\nEven though both attenuated and inactivated vaccines have been shown\nto work, it appears as if the disease is not being controlled by the\ncurrent animal disease control paradigm of information, support and\nadvice to farmers. Furthermore the number of human cases keeps\nrising, having increased by 23 in the six day period between our last\ntwo ProMED-mail reports to a total of 143 human cases with 9 deaths.\nAgain, the best method of control is for the disease to be nipped in\nthe bud at its animal source and if current measures don't allow for\neffective control then innovation should be seriously considered.\nParticularly given that the eyes of world will soon be squarely\nfocused on South Africa with the upcoming FIFA World Cup soccer\nfinals to begin in mid June, just some 40 days from now. - Mods.PC/FE]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 12 May 2010\n What follows is a\nSwanepol's summary of outbreaks going back to the 1970s:\n\nRVF occurs in the country at irregular intervals of many years when\nparticularly heavy rains favour the occurrence of population\nexplosions of the floodwater-breeding aedine mosquito vectors of the\nvirus. No. 20 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=weekly_report_index&admin=0>\n\n\nRift Valley fever, Namibia\n---------------------------\nInformation received on 14 May 2010 from Dr Albertina Shilongo, Chief\nVeterinarian Epidemiology, Import and Export Control and Training,\nDirectorate of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture, Water &\nForestry, Windhoek, Namibia\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nStart date: 10 May 2010\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 12 May 2010\nReport date: 14 May 2010\nDate submitted to OIE: 14 May 2010\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: May 1985\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nLocation: HARDAP (Hebron No 493, Mariental)\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies/ Susceptible/ Cases/ Deaths/ Destroyed/ Slaughtered\nSheep/ 3300/ 10/ 7/ 3/ 0\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Vectors\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: Quarantine, Movement control inside the country, No\nvaccination [Why? - Mod.AS], No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: Control of arthropods, Vaccination in\nresponse to the outbreak.\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Laboratory, Windhoek\n(National laboratory)\nTests and results:\nSpecies/ Test/ Test date/ Result\nSheep/ real-time PCR/ 12 May 2010/ Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 14 May 2010\nSource: Southern Times [edited]\n<http://www.southerntimesafrica.com/article.php?title=Rift%20Valley%20Fever%20(RVF)%20outbreak%20spreads%20to%20Namibia%20%20&id=4131&sid=6a193300470e8429f482eb655544f2ac>\n\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) outbreak spreads to Namibia\n---------------------------------------------------\nRift Valley fever (RVF), detected in South Africa 3 months ago, has\nspread into southern Namibia with cases reported in the Karas and\nHardap regions, the Ministry of Agriculture, Water and Forestry said\non Friday [14 May 2010].\n\nNamibia banned the import of South Africa meat and live animals from\nthat country following the outbreak of the viral disease which\naffects wild animals and domestic animals such as cattle and sheep.\n\nNamibia's acting chief veterinary officer Cleopas Bamhare said RVF\ncases had been detected and confirmed at 2 farms in the Hardap\nregion. There is also a suspicious outbreak under investigation in\nthe Karas region. The Government said it had banned movement of\ncattle, sheep and goats in the 2 regions.\n\n'The ministry imposes with immediate effect, the suspension of all\nmovement of cattle, sheep and goats from, into, within, and through\nthe 2 regions of Karas and Hardap for one week,' Bamhare said in a\nstatement. RVF is prevalent in east and north Africa [The United\nNations definition of Northern Africa includes Algeria, Egypt, Libya,\nMorocco, Sudan, Tunisia, and Western Sahara. RVF has been reported,\nonly from Sudan and Egypt. The disease is present also in West\nAfrica. - Mod.AS] In South Africa the outbreak was detected earlier this year.\n\nThe South African government has confirmed 186 cases of the viral\nfever in humans by 10 May 2010, including 18 deaths in the Free\nState, Eastern, Western and Northern Cape as well as the North West Provinces.\n\nRVF is a viral disease in livestock such as cattle, sheep and camels\nbut can also infect humans through indirect or direct contact with\ninfected animal blood or organs.\n\n'Therefore all permits that were issued involving the 2 regions have\nbeen suspended. The slaughter of cattle, sheep and goats at export\nabattoirs and the sale of animals at auctions have also been\nsuspended,' Bamhare said.\n\nThe Government also said it had closed movement of livestock and meat\nproducts at 2 border posts linking Namibia to South Africa,\nNoordoewer and Ariamsvlei.\n\n'Noordoewer and Ariamsvlei border posts are now closed to livestock,\nincluding fresh or frozen meat for own consumption. The measures have\nbeen imposed in order to allow time to ascertain the extent of the\noutbreak and to open negotiations with trading partners,' Bamhare said.\n\nThe Government [increased] its surveillance and urged people who have\nrecently been in contact with sick animals, organs or their body\nfluids and are showing signs of RVF sickness to seek medical attention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nGut Laach 52385 Nideggen, Germany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[Similarly to South Africa, where reporting RVF in animals (19 Feb\n2010) preceded reports on human disease [4 Mar 2010], the Namibian\nVeterinary Services seems to have managed detecting and reporting the\nstart of the epidemic before the appearance of human cases.\n\nThe application of the term 'no vaccination' in the OIE report may be\nmisleading; vaccination is not forbidden in Namibia, but has not been\napplied by animal breeders, prior to the appearance of the cases,\nmost probably due to the absence of disease for an extended period.\n\nSee Mods. Manifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: Rift Valley fever virus\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-02-19 00:00:00", "1985-05-25 00:00:00", "3300-10-07 00:00:00", "2010-05-14 00:00:00", "2010-05-12 00:00:00", "2010-05-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Namibia", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "Libya"}, {"location": "Windhoek", "country": "Namibia"}, {"location": "Morocco", "country": "Morocco"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "Tunisia"}, {"location": "Northern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "423316", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: (NJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=423316", "date": "2010-05-07 16:00:03", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA: (NAJRAN)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 May 2010\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com> [edited]\n\n\nRift Valley fever virus infection of a resident of Najran\n---------------------------------------------------------\nA 40 year old Saudi man, a fire fighter by profession and resident in\nNajran, was diagnosed with Rift Valley fever on 28 Apr 2010. He first\nreported signs of illness on 23 Apr 2010. The same day he presented at a\nMinistry of Health facility in Najran, where he was hospitalised and\nsuspected to be a case of viral haemorrhagic fever. Signs observed included\nnausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and epistaxis.\n\nThe patient's blood was sent to the Central Laboratory (Riyadh) and tested\nfor various viral haemorrhagic fevers (Rift Valley fever, Alkhurma\nhaemorrhagic fever, and dengue fever). All were negative except for Rift\nValley fever, which was detected using real time RT-PCR. Tests for Rift\nValley fever virus IgM and IgG were negative.\n\nAt the present time, the exact source and locale of Rift Valley fever virus\ninfection is not clear and is still being investigated. The patient\ntravelled extensively in the south western areas of the kingdom of Saudi\nArabia known to be endemic for Rift Valley fever (Tihama, Aseer, and Gizan)\nsome 45 days before the onset of his present illness. However, this\nextended time frame does not seem compatible with the known incubation\nperiod of Rift Valley fever virus (around 2 to 6 days). In addition, the\nlack of antibodies (IgM or IgG) adds further doubt to the patient being\ninfected during that visit. The patient is also known to have visited a\nlivestock farm where he purchased an animal. It was then slaughtered and\ncooked for him at a commercial outlet. He reported not taking part in the\nslaughtering or cutting up process.\n\nThe Ministry of Health, in coordination with the Ministry of Agriculture\nand local municipalities of Gizan, Najran, and Aseer, is conducting\nextensive epidemiological and entomological investigations and results are\npending. Active surveillance for human and animal disease is ongoing.\nVaccination of animals with the live attenuated Rift Valley fever virus\nvaccine is continuing in the said locales.\n\n--\nZiad A Memish MD, FRCPC, FACP\nAssistant Deputy Minister for Preventive Medicine\nand\nShamsudeen F Fagbo DVM\nZoonotic Diseases Unit\nDirectorate of Communicable Diseases\nMinistry of Health\nRiyadh 11176\nKingdom of Saudi Arabia\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[Rift Valley fever is a viral zoonosis that can cause severe disease in a\nlow proportion of infected humans. The virus is classified in the genus\n_Phlebovirus_ of the family _Bunyaviridae_ and causes outbreaks of\nabortions and deaths of young livestock (predominantly sheep, goats, and\ncattle). Humans become infected from contact with infected tissues of\nlivestock, and less frequently from mosquito bites. The mosquitoes (and\nbiting flies) which transmit the virus generally prefer to feed on\nlivestock outdoors at night.\n\nThe virus was first identified in 1931 during an investigation into an\nepidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of Kenya, hence its name.\nSince then, extensive outbreaks have been reported in sub-Saharan and North\nAfrica. In 1997-98, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia, and\nTanzania and subsequently in September 2000 Rift Valley fever was confirmed\nin Saudi Arabia and Yemen (the 1st and only reported occurrence of the\ndisease out-with the African continent). Currently there is an ongoing\noutbreak of Rift Valley fever in South Africa, which has been responsible\nfor several human deaths.\n\nThe source of the Saudi patient's exposure is unclear. Although he had\ntravelled in virus endemic areas of Saudi Arabia, his infection appears to\nhave been more recent. The majority of human infections result from direct\nor indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals, during\nthe handling of animals, slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal\nbirths, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. Certain occupational\ngroups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians\nare therefore at higher risk of infection. Other routes of transmission\ninclude inhalation of aerosols produced during the handling and slaughter\nof infected animals, by consumption of unpasteurized milk, and by insect\nbites. No human-to-human transmission of Rift Valley fever virus infection\nhas been documented, and transmission to health care workers is not a\nhazard provided standard infection control precautions are in place.\nFurther information on the source of the Saudi patient's infection is awaited.\n\nA map of Saudi Arabia showing the location of Najran in the south, near the\nborder with Yemen is available at <http://www.saudinf.com/main/map.htm>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Saudi Arabia can be accessed\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/01gJ>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 May 2010\n The majority of human infections result from direct\nor indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals, during\nthe handling of animals, slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal\nbirths, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. On 7\nApr 2010, the case developed symptoms including fever, headache, and a rash\n(exanthema). Almost concurrently a similar illness was reported in her\ntravel companions. German health authorities are currently investigating\nthe circumstances around infection in the confirmed case.\n\nAs of 3 May 2010, the Department of Health of South Africa has reported 172\ncases, including 15 deaths since the beginning of the outbreak in Free\nState Province, Eastern Cape Province, Northern Cape Province, Western\nCape, and North West Province. While it is reported that most of these\ncases have had direct contact with RVF-infected livestock and/or are\nepidemiologically linked to farms with confirmed animal cases of RVF, there\nare a number of cases in which the route of transmission is currently\nunknown. Exposure to infected mosquitoes in these cases cannot be currently\nruled out.\n\nThe Government of South Africa has implemented public health control\nmeasures, which include development of key risk reduction messages for the\npopulation at risk and guidelines to assist health workers in case\nidentification and reporting, laboratory investigations, clinical case\nmanagement, hospital infection control, and the public health measures for\nprevention and control and animal vaccination in non-affected areas.\n\nWHO advises no international travel restriction to or from South Africa.\nHowever, WHO recommends that visitors to South Africa, especially those\nintending to visit farms and/or game reserves, avoid coming into contact\nwith animal tissues or blood, avoid drinking unpasteurized or uncooked\nmilk, or eating raw meat. All travellers should take appropriate\nprecautions against mosquito bites (use of mosquito nets, insect\nrepellents). Travel medicine professionals and travel medicine services\nshould be aware of the current RVF situation in South Africa in order to\nprovide advice and care accordingly.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[In the 5 days since the previous ProMED-mail report from South Africa the\nnumber of confirmed human cases has increased from 150 to 172, and the\nnumber of fatalities from 12 to 15.\n\nFurther information can be obtained from the following sources:\n- Department of Health, South Africa (<http://www.doh.gov.za/>)\n- The National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD), South Africa\n(<http://www.nicd.ac.za/>)\n- Rift Valley fever: WHO fact sheet\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>)\n- Protection against vectors -- International Travel and Health\n(<http://www.who.int/ith/ITH2010chapter3.pdf>)\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. The patient travelled (as part\nof a group) from Port Elizabeth through rural areas along the southern\ncoast of South Africa (Eastern and Western Cape provinces). She visited\nsafari parks and mountain areas. Nights were spent in hotels or lodges.\nTowards the end of the trip, the group visited Cape Town for a few days.\nShe fell ill on 7 Apr 2010, the day before returning to Germany. Symptoms\nincluded fever up to 39 deg C [102.2 deg F], slight thrombocytopenia,\nheadache, conjunctivitis, swollen inguinal lymph nodes, a slight\nmacula-papulous exanthema on both legs, and a discrete hemorrhagic\nexanthema of the abdominal skin, as well as vesicular efflorescences on the\nfeet. Hospital [admission] was not required. Blood samples tested positive\nfor Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus-specific IgM and IgG; RT-PCR was\nnegative. Based on the currently available data, it is likely that the case\npatient acquired a RVF infection in South Africa. Further laboratory\nanalyses, both in Germany and in South Africa, are in progress.\n\nThe German public health authorities still consider the risk of RVF virus\ninfection for tourists visiting South Africa to be small. Tourists are\nrecommended to observe mosquito protection measures (repellents, nets, long\nclothing) even outside of endemic areas and during the day. Close contact\nwith wild and domestic animals (especially raw meat, blood, faeces, urine,\nplacenta tissue) should be avoided. Uncooked meat and raw milk should not\nbe consumed (heated meats and pasteurized milk are fine). If fever develops\nwithin a month after leaving South Africa, a physician should be visited\nand made aware of the travel history.\n\n[authors: Christina Frank, Robert Koch Institute, Berlin, Germany\nJonas Schmidt-Chanasit, Bernhard Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine,\nHamburg, Germany)\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr. med. Certain occupational groups such as herders, farmers,\nslaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of\ninfection.\n\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected mosquitoes,\nmost commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito, and by hematophagous flies. It may be\nthat this tourist acquired infection by this route.\n\nHuman-to-human transmission of Rift Valley fever virus infection has not\nbeen documented, and no transmission to health care workers has been\nreported when standard infection control precautions have been put in\nplace. Most human cases of Rift Valley fever are relatively mild and of\nshort duration, and no specific treatment is required for these patients.\nFor the more severe cases, the predominant treatment is general supportive\ntherapy (see <http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>).\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. 'There has been an inter-governmental approach adopted\nand an outbreak response team activated,' provincial Department of\nHealth spokesperson Siyanda Manana said yesterday [Tue 13 Apr 2010].\n\nThe 7 are among 111 people confirmed to have been infected\ncountrywide since the disease broke out in February 2010. Those\nconfirmed to have died from the fever include 5 from the Free State\nand 4 from the Northern Cape,' National Health spokesperson Charity\nBengu said.\n\nShe said that 81 people from the Free Sate had been infected, 7 from\nthe Eastern Cape, 22 cases from the Northern Cape and one from the\nNorth West. Bengu said that direct contact with RVF-infected\nlivestock and/or links to farms with confirmed animal cases remained\nthe main risk factor for infection.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and occurs throughout Africa\nand Madagascar when exceptionally heavy rain favours the breeding of\nthe mosquitoes.\n\nMeanwhile, the test results for a patient who died at East London's\nSt Dominic's Hospital last week have come back negative for a\nsuspected viral haemorrhagic fever (VHF). VHF is not related to Rift\nValley Fever. The patient, whose details have not been released,\narrived at the hospital on Thursday [8 Apr 2010] evening exhibiting\nsigns of a VHF. The hospital immediately isolated him as a\nprecautionary measure.\n\n[Byline: Ntando Makhubu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the previous report from South Africa, dated 9 Apr 2010, the\nnumber of confirmed human cases has increased from 100 to 120 and the\nnumber of deaths from 7 to 9. Zucca,\nwho has been with the hospital for 7 years, said she had never\nwitnessed a case of cross contamination while working at the\nhospital. 'That only happens when a place is dirty,' she said adding\nthat the hospital was sanitised thoroughly.\n\nThe risk of exposure to members of the public is further lowered by\nthe fact that animals infected in outbreaks such as this one are\nusually not treated by private vets, said Dr Gary Buhrmann, Boland\nchief state veterinarian. 'State veterinarians are usually\nresponsible for a large bulk of the cases,' he told News24. He urged\nmembers of the public to remain calm, as they were 'not really at risk.'\n\nIn the Western Cape -- the latest province to report infections after\nthe outbreak started in the Free State, spread to the Eastern Cape\nand the Northern Cape -- 3 farms in Beaufort West have reported Rift\nValley fever infections, Buhrmann said. Infected animals there were\ndying at a rate of 5 - 10 percent, he said.\n\nBeaufort West state veterinarian Dr Jaco Pienaar, who is recovering\nfrom what he believes to be Rift Valley fever (he is waiting for\nlaboratory confirmation), reiterated Buhrmann's assertions. He said\nalthough the risk remained high for people who come into contact with\nthe bodily fluids of infected animals, he had never heard of a human\nto human infection case and infection through mosquito bites was yet\nto be proven. Pienaar was infected while performing a post mortem on\nan infected cow.\n\n'I'm feeling a lot better now,' Pienaar said although his eyes were\nstill hurting. Sensitivity to light is one of the symptoms of Rift\nValley fever in humans. According to the National Institute for\nCommunicable Diseases other symptoms include flu-like symptoms, neck\nstiffness, vomiting and loss of appetite.\n\nAs of Thursday [8 Apr 2010], there were 100 confirmed cases of human\nRift Valley fever infections in the country, 77 of them in the Free\nState. Rift Valley fever, sheep - South Africa: (FS) OIE 20100225.0622\n2009\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "the Free State", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Free State", "country": "South Africa"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "405055", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - South Africa (08): (multi-province)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=405055", "date": "2010-04-03 23:00:13", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA (08) MULTI-PROVINCE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 31 Mar 2010\nSource: South African Government Information, Department of Health\nreport [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2010/10033113551001.htm>\n\n\n3 more people have been infected with Rift Valley fever (RVF) this\nmorning [31 mar 2010], bringing the total to 69 laboratory confirmed\nhuman cases since the 1st incident on 13 Feb 2010; 2 deaths have been\nreported, both from the Free State. [Now 82 cases/5 deaths -- see [2]\nbelow].\n\nThe National Institute of Communicable Disease (NICD) reported this\nmorning [31 Mar 2010] that of the 69 cases of infected people, 58\ncases and 2 deaths are from Free State, 4 in Eastern Cape, and 7 in\nNorthern Cape.\nDirect contact with RVF-infected livestock and/or linked to farms with\nconfirmed animal cases of RVF, remain the main risk factor for the\ninfection. The human cases are farmers, veterinarians, and farm\nworkers. Additional suspect cases are currently being tested.\n\nOutbreak investigations by the Department of Health and the Department\nof Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries are ongoing, supported by the\nSouth African Field Epidemiology and Training Programme (SA-FELTP) and\nthe NICD.\n\nAffected farms are primarily clustered within Free State (initially in\nLejweleputswa District, Bultfontein area); however animal cases of RVF\nhave been confirmed in all districts with spill over into Eastern\nCape, Northern Cape, and Gauteng. The Department of Agriculture in\nFree State has started the vaccination of animals, to contain the\nspread of the virus. RVF is a viral disease that can cause severe\nillness in a small proportion of infected humans. The virus is\ntransmitted by mosquitoes and causes outbreaks of abortion and deaths\nof young livestock (sheep, goats and cattle). It is important to note\nthat humans become infected from contact with infected tissues of\nlivestock and less frequently from mosquito bites. The disease occurs\nthroughout Africa and Madagascar when exceptionally heavy rains favour\nthe breeding of the mosquito vectors.\n\nClinical features in humans\n---------------------------\nTypically illness is asymptomatic or mild in the vast majority of\ninfected persons, and severe disease would be expected to occur in\nless than 1 percent of infected persons.\n\nKey symptoms\n------------\n- The incubation period (interval from infection to onset of symptoms)\nfor RVF varies from two to six days\n- Sudden onset of flu-like fever and/or muscle pain\n- Some patients develop neck stiffness, sensitivity to light, loss of\nappetite and vomiting\n- Symptoms of RVF usually last from 4-7 days, after which time the\nimmune response becomes detectable with the appearance of antibodies\nand the virus gradually disappears from the blood.\n\nSevere form of RVF in humans includes\n- Vision disturbances\n- Intense headache, loss of memory, hallucinations, confusion,\ndisorientation, vertigo, convulsions, lethargy and coma\n- Haemorrhagic fever.\n\nThe public living in the affected areas is encouraged to seek medical\nattention at their nearest Health facilities, should they have any of\nthe symptoms above.\n\nPreventive measures\n------------------\n- While there is no specific treatment, the majority of persons\naffected will recover completely. People should avoid contact with the\ntissues of infected animals, refrain from drinking unpasteurised milk\nand prevent mosquito bites to avoid becoming infected\n- Farmers and veterinarians should wear protective clothing when\nhandling sick animals or their tissues. There is no routine vaccine\navailable for humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 3 Apr 2010\nSource: Saturday Star, South African Press Association (SAPA) report [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=5415554>\n\n\nSo far 5 people have died and 82 others countrywide are infected with\nRift Valley fever, the Ministry of Health said yesterday [Fri 2 Apr\n2010]. Nine [sic] new infections have been detected since the virus\n[disease] broke out on 13 Feb 2010.\n\nFree State was the worst hit [province] with 4 deaths and 66\ninfections, followed by the Northern Cape with 1 death and 10 people\ninfected.\n\nRift Valley fever virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes\nabortion in and deaths of young livestock. Farmers, veterinarians, and\nfarm workers are mostly affected. Direct contact with infected animals\nremains the main risk factor for the infection, the department stated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 1st report indicates the number of human cases increased from 63\nto 69 between 27 and 31 Mar 2010. The 2nd report indicates that by 2\nApr 2010 the number of human cases had risen to 82 and the number of\nfatalities had increased from 2 to 5 during this period.\n\nThese figures indicate that the outbreak first detected in\nmid-February 2010 is now spreading rapidly although still restricted\nmanly to Free State province.\n\nThe last major outbreak of RVF on the interior plateau of South Africa\noccurred in 1974-76 during prolonged heavy rains, causing 10 000 to 20\n000 human cases. Since then, sporadic outbreaks and human infections\nhave been documented within KwaZulu-Natal, the Kruger National Park,\nLimpopo, Gauteng, North West, and Northern Cape Provinces.\n\nFor detailed information go to the South African National Institute\nfor Communicable Diseases website at\n<http://www.nicd.ac.za/outbreaks/rvf/rvf_outbreak.htm>\nor refer to the commentaries in the preceding ProMED-mail posts listed below.\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa is available\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n People should avoid contact with the\ntissues of infected animals, refrain from drinking unpasteurised milk\nand prevent mosquito bites to avoid becoming infected\n- Farmers and veterinarians should wear protective clothing when\nhandling sick animals or their tissues. \n\nSevere form of RVF in humans includes\n- Vision disturbances\n- Intense headache, loss of memory, hallucinations, confusion,\ndisorientation, vertigo, convulsions, lethargy and coma\n- Haemorrhagic fever. Most of these cases reported direct contact with RVF virus\ninfected livestock and/or linked to farms with confirmed animal cases\nof RVF. The human cases are: farmers, veterinarians and farm workers.\nAll cases were confirmed as RVF by tests conducted at the National\nInstitute of Communicable Diseases (NICD) in Johannesburg, South\nAfrica (see <http://www.nicd.ac.za/>).\n\nThere is an ongoing outbreak of RVF virus infection affecting sheep,\ngoats, cattle and wildlife on farms within Free State, Eastern Cape,\nNorthern Cape, Western Cape, Mpumalanga, North West, and Gauteng\nprovinces. As of Mon 29 Mar 2010, approximately 78 farms reported\nlaboratory-confirmed animal cases, with extensive livestock deaths.\n\nOutbreak investigations by the Department of Health and the Department\nof Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries are ongoing, and are being\nsupported by the South African Field Epidemiology and Training\nProgramme (SA-FELTP) and NICD. The 2 departments are taking measures\nto enhance disease surveillance among cattle and in managing the\ncontrol of the outbreak.\n\nSporadic cases of RVF infection in animals have been documented in\nSouth Africa in recent years. The last major outbreak of the disease\nin humans occurred between 1974-76, where an estimated 10 000 to 20\n000 people were affected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high rates\nof disease and death. Most infections in humans are mild. The disease\nalso results in significant economic losses due to death and abortion\namong RVF-infected livestock. RVF virus is a member of the genus\n_Phlebovirus_, one of the five genera in the family _Bunyaviridae_.\nThe virus was first identified in 1931 during an investigation into an\nepidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of Kenya. Since\nthen, outbreaks have been reported in sub-Saharan and North Africa. In\n1997-98, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania and\nin September 2000, RVF cases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen,\nmarking the 1st reported occurrence of the disease outside the African\ncontinent. (For more detailed information see\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>).\n\nThe WHO report above restores Mpumalanga to the list of affected\nprovinces. This pushes\nup the number of confirmed cases to 47. Of the 47 confirmed cases on\nWednesday [24 Mar 2010], 41 cases with 2 deaths were reported in the\nFree State, 3 in the Eastern Cape [province] and 3 in the Northern\nCape [province].\n\n'Outbreak investigations by the Departments of Health and\nAgriculture, Forestry and Fisheries are ongoing, supported by the\nSouth African Field Epidemiology and Training Programme,' said the\nDepartment of Health.\n\nThe NICD have also confirmed the spread of RVF in animals in the\nNorth West Province. No\nfurther fatalities have been reported. The outbreak in livestock\nremains centered in the Free State province, but has now spread also\ninto North West province.\n\nAs most human cases of Rift Valley fever are relatively mild and of\nshort duration, no specific treatment is required for these patients.\nFor the more severe cases, the predominant treatment is general\nsupportive therapy. Outbreaks of Rift valley fever in animals can be\nprevented by a sustained programme of animal vaccination. Both\nmodified live attenuated virus and inactivated virus vaccines have\nbeen developed for veterinary use. An inactivated vaccine has been\ndeveloped for human use. However, this vaccine is not licensed and is\nnot commercially available.\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed at:\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>.
