South Africa (03): (FS, EC, NC, GT, MP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=398856", "date": "2010-03-21 18:00:03", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SOUTH AFRICA (03): (FREE STATE, EASTERN CAPE,\nNORTHERN CAPE, GAUTENG, MPUMALANGA)\n*****************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 21 Mar 2010\nFrom: Jacqueline Weyer\n<jacquelinew@nicd.ac.za>\n\n\nRift Valley fever outbreak in South Africa\n------------------------------------------\nCurrently there is an extensive outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF)\naffecting livestock in South Africa with animal cases reported on\nfarms predominantly in the Free State Province but also in the\nEastern Cape, Northern Cape, Gauteng and Mpumalanga Provinces.\nConsiderable rainfall has created conditions favourable for breeding\nof the mosquito vectors over much of the country, and preliminary\nmolecular epidemiological findings suggest that the outbreak involves\nspread of one of 2 genotypes of the virus which have emerged locally\nover the past few years.\n\nAs of 15 Mar 2010, there have been 42 human laboratory-confirmed\ncases including 2 deaths, with 37 cases from the Free State Province,\n2 cases from the Northern Cape and 3 cases from the Eastern Cape. It\nis likely that there are more human cases, given that the typical\ninfection is mild and persons may not present to health centres or be\ntested. Contact with infected animal tissues has been identified as\nthe likely route of transmission with farmers, farm workers,\nveterinarians and assistants, and slaughter men being affected.\n\nAll patients, with the exception of the 2 fatal cases have had mild\ndisease with self-limiting febrile illness and myalgia. The 2 fatal\ncases presented with multi-organ failure, notably with severe hepatic\ndysfunction and markedly raised hepatic enzymes, and profound\nthrombocytopenia and bleeding. Investigations are ongoing to identify\nany co-morbidity.\n\nThe RVF outbreak has occurred in areas where Crimean-Congo\nhaemorrhagic fever (CCHF) [a tick-transmitted disease - Mod.CP] is\nwell documented and considering the overlapping clinical and\nclinico-pathological features it is clearly critical to consider this\nin the differential diagnosis and management of patients, especially\nregarding infection control issues.\n\nCCHF was confirmed in 2 patients in the past week. The 1st case, a\nfarmer from the Free State Province, was confirmed by RT-PCR and\nserology. He presented with an acute febrile illness, myalgia,\nhaemorrhage with profound thrombocytopenia and transaminitis, and had\na good response to ribavirin treatment. The 2nd patient was from the\nNorthern Cape with a reported tick bite exposure. CCHF was confirmed\nby RT-PCR. This patient passed away.\n\nIntensive health promotion and active case finding is ongoing in the\naffected areas as well as areas with the potential for spread of the RVF.\n\n--\nLucille Blumberg\nJuno Thomas\nJacqueline Weyer\nPetrus Jansen van Vuuren\nPatricia Leman\nAntoinette Grobbelaar\nAlan Kemp\nRobert Swanepoel\nJanusz Paweska\n\nSpecial Pathogens and Outbreak Units,\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases,\nNational Health Laboratory Service,\n1 Modderfontein road,\nSandringham,\nJohannesburg,\nSouth Africa\nJacqueline Weyer\n<jacquelinew@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[ProMED-mail is indebted to Jacqueline Weyer and colleagues for\nproviding this update on the progress of the current outbreak of Rift\nValley fever in South Africa. Previous reports indicated that the\noutbreak was confined to the Free State, but human cases have been\nrecorded now in Eastern Cape and Northern Cape provinces. In addition\nanimal cases have been recorded in Gauteng and Mpumalanga provinces\nand human cases may follow.\n\nOutbreaks of Rift Valley fever are associated characteristically with\npersistent heavy rainfall with sustained flooding and the appearance\nof large numbers of mosquitoes, the main vector. Localised heavy\nrainfall is seldom sufficient to create conditions for an outbreak;\nthe simultaneous emergence of large numbers of 1st generation\ntransovarially infected mosquitoes is also required. After virus\namplification in vertebrates, mosquitoes act as secondary vectors to\nsustain the epidemic.\n\nGenome analysis has confirmed that this outbreak is associated with\none of the 2 strains of Rift valley fever virus that have emerged\nlocally in South Africa in recent years. According to Bird et al.\n(Journal of Virology, 2007 Mar;81(6):2805-16) Rift Valley fever virus\nstrains isolated within an epidemic have exhibited little diversity,\nwhereas those in enzootic settings can be highly diverse. Currently there is an extensive outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF)\naffecting livestock in South Africa with animal cases reported on\nfarms predominantly in the Free State Province but also in the\nEastern Cape, Northern Cape, Gauteng and Mpumalanga Provinces. The 2 fatal\ncases presented with multi-organ failure, notably with severe hepatic\ndysfunction and markedly raised hepatic enzymes, and profound\nthrombocytopenia and bleeding. Localised heavy\nrainfall is seldom sufficient to create conditions for an outbreak;\nthe simultaneous emergence of large numbers of 1st generation\ntransovarially infected mosquitoes is also required. It\nis likely that there are more human cases, given that the typical\ninfection is mild and persons may not present to health centres or be\ntested. 'The 6 others, who had mild disease, continue to be\nunder observation and treatment.' Sefularo, who was on an inspection\ntour of the Pelonomi hospital in the Free State to inspect the level\nof readiness of health facilities for the FIFA World Cup, said the\ndisease posed no threat to the event. 'I would like to place it on\nrecord that this occurrence does not constitute a crisis. The\noutbreak is being contained,' he said.\n\nRVF is a communicable virus, endemic in South Africa and other\nAfrican countries. In animals, the virus is transmitted by mosquitoes\nand causes outbreaks of abortion and deaths of young sheep, cattle\nand goats. It [can be] transmitted to humans through contact with\ninfected livestock through direct or indirect contact with blood or\norgans of infected animals; the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering of animals or assisting with animal\nbirths; conducting veterinary services or through being cut by\ninfected knives or needles among other things.\n\nSefularo said 15 farms had reported laboratory confirmed animal cases\nwith extensive livestock deaths. The affected farms were primarily\nclustered around the Lejweleputswa District in the Bultfontein area.\nHe said no human-to-human transmission had occurred. Symptoms of the\nvirus were mild fever, headaches and muscle pain.\n\nSefularo appealed to farming communities in the Free State and\nNorthern Cape to avoid high risk husbandry procedures and\nslaughtering practices by using gloves and protective clothing and to\navoid the consumption of fresh blood, raw milk or animal tissue.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high\nrates of disease and death. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected\nlivestock. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported elsewhere\nin Africa.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, abbatoir\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito, and transmission of\nRVF virus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular disease (0.5-2\npercent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1 percent) or\nhaemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent). The total case fatality\nrate has varied widely between different epidemics but, overall, has\nbeen less than 1 percent in those documented. Most fatalities occur\nin patients who develop the haemorrhagic icterus form.\n\nAs outbreaks of RVF in animals precede human cases, the establishment\nof an active animal health surveillance system to detect new cases is\nessential in providing early warning for veterinary and human public\nhealth authorities. 'Direct contact with\nRVF-infected livestock and/or linked to farms with confirmed animal\ncases of RVF, remain the main risk factors for the infection. Additional\nsuspect cases are currently being tested.'\n\nRift Valley fever is a viral disease that can cause severe illness in\na low proportion of infected humans. The virus is transmitted by\nmosquitoes and causes outbreaks of abortion and deaths of young\nlivestock such as sheep, goats and cattle. 'It is important to note\nthat humans become infected by contact with infected tissues of\nlivestock and less frequently from mosquito bites,' said Bhengu.\n\nSo far, 70 000 animals have been vaccinated in the Free State to\ncontain the spread of the virus, according to the Department of\nAgriculture. We warn riverside residents to stay away from the shores,'\nVenance Bouda, the official in charge of hydroelectric power, told the\nAssociated Press news agency.\n\nIn Ghana, at least 25 people have already died in flooding-related\nincidents, officials say.\n\nThe torrential rains have also hit other countries in the region. In\nSenegal, 30 000 homes were flooded, while in Guinea, 20 000 people are\naffected.\n\nOur reporter says similar floods in 2007 killed 300 people.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nShamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[We are grateful to Shamsudeen Fagbo, who forwarded the above item to\nProMED-mail with his accompanying comment: 'This may be post worthy;\nit may warn of potential Rift Valley fever (RVF) outbreaks in the\nnearest future in these areas.' His comment seems to be fully justified.\n\nIndeed, floods in this region are cause for alertness by both animal\nhealth and public health authorities, since RVF is known to have\nbecome endemic in the region, particularly in Senegal and in the\nadjacent parts of Mauritania. The most striking effect of RVF in\nanimals are mass abortions, affecting sheep, goats and cattle. In\n2003, the awareness of the Senegalese veterinary authorities led to\nthe detection of RVF in animals prior to the reporting of human cases.\n\nRVF usually occurs in epizootics in Africa, which may involve several\ncountries in a region at one and the same time. These follow the\nperiodic cycles of exceptionally heavy rain, which may occur very\nrarely in semi-arid zones (25-35 year cycles), or more frequently\n(5-15 year cycles) in higher rainfall savannah grasslands. Low level\nundetectable RVF activity may take place in inter-epizootic periods.\nRVF should be suspected when unusually heavy rains are followed by the\noccurrence of abortions together with fatal disease marked by necrosis\nand haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs,\nkids and calves, concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like\nillness in farm workers and people handling raw meat.\n\nRVF virus may be isolated from serum and blood collected in an\nanticoagulant during the febrile stage of the disease, from liver,\nspleen and brain of animals that have died, or from aborted fetuses.\n\nPreventative measures to protect workers from infection should be\nemployed when there are suspicions that RVF virus-infected meat and\ntissue samples are to be handled.\n\nRVF was initially recorded in southwest Mauritania and bordering north\nSenegal in 1987, following the opening of Diama Dam at the mouth of\nthe Senegal River. The dam project created additional breeding grounds\nfor mosquitoes carrying the disease and initially resulted in more\nthan 200 human deaths from RVF. Senegal suffered outbreaks, though on\na more limited scale, in 1994, 1999, 2002 and 2003. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat, 5 Sep 2009\n RVF should be suspected when unusually heavy rains are followed by the\noccurrence of abortions together with fatal disease marked by necrosis\nand haemorrhages in the liver that particularly affect newborn lambs,\nkids and calves, concurrent with the occurrence of an influenza-like\nillness in farm workers and people handling raw meat. Paweska\n<januszp@nicd.ac.za>\n\n\nA novel Rift Valley fever virus genotype strikes in Northern Cape, South Africa\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn mid October 2009, 4 suspected human cases of Rift Valley fever\n(RVF) from the Northern Cape Province of South Africa were\ninvestigated at the Special Pathogens Unit, National Institute for\nCommunicable Disease of the National Health Laboratory Service. Of\nthose, 2 were confirmed by serology, virus isolation and nucleic acid\ndetection as being recently infected with RVF virus. Analysis of\npartial sequencing data of the M segment of a virus isolate recovered\nfrom the index case revealed that the patient was infected with a RVF\nvirus genotype closest related to a 2004 Namibian isolate from the\nCaprivi Strip, and clustering with a 1981 South African isolate from\nthe East Coast, and isolates from Senegal (1993), Central African\nRepublic (1969) and Guinea (1981, 1984), but not with other South\nAfrican isolates recovered from Kwazulu-Natal in March this year\n[2009] and from other 4 provinces (Mpumalanga, Limpopo, North West\nand Gauteng) during 2008.\n\nRVF outbreaks are associated either with spread of a single genotype\nor with simultaneous emergence of multiple genotypes in endemic foci.\nRVF virus isolates recovered during the last decade in southern and\neastern Africa, the Arabian Peninsula, Mauritania, and Madagascar\nexhibit little genetic diversity, which indicates recent widespread\ndistribution of very closely related genotypes of the virus over a\nvast area. Various isolates recovered from humans, cattle and buffalo\nin Mpumalanga, Limpopo, North West and Gauteng in 2008 and in\nKwazulu-Natal in February/March 2009 are genetically almost identical\nand very similar to isolates from eastern Africa, the Arabian\nPeninsula, Mauritania, and Madagascar, but the recent isolate from\nNorthern Cape is genetically different. All laboratory confirmed\nhuman cases (n = 25) in 2008-2009 in South Africa had very close\ncontact with infected animals and/or their tissues, including the 2\nmost recent cases in Northern Cape. There have been no!\nmortalities.\n\nRVF virus was 1st isolated in 1930 following an epizootic on a sheep\nfarm in the Rift Valley in Kenya and historically was endemic to\nsub-Saharan Africa, but in the last 4 decades spread to Egypt, West\nAfrica and most recently to the Arabian Peninsula and the Archipelago\nof Comoros, including the French Department of Mayotte. Humans become\ninfected from contact with tissues of infected animals or from\nmosquito bite, and usually develop asymptomatic, mild or moderate\nfebrile illness. Severe complications that may be life-threatening\ndevelop only in a small proportion of infected patients, but\nsubstantial numbers of people may succumb to infection during large\noutbreaks of the disease in livestock. Large outbreaks of RVF in\ndomestic ruminants occur at irregular intervals when exceptionally\nheavy rains favour the breeding and high abundance of competent\nmosquito vectors, and are associated with high mortality among\nnewborn animals and abortion in pregnant animals.\n\nA major epizootic, which caused an estimated 500 000 abortions and\n100 000 deaths of sheep, occurred in 1950-1951 in South Africa. The\n2nd major and more widespread outbreak in South Africa caused\nextensive losses of ruminants in 1974-1976. Small outbreaks of RVF or\nsporadic virus isolations of the virus were recorded in South Africa\nin 1981 and 1999 and most recently in 2008-2009. Compared to\nhistorical outbreaks of RVF in South Africa, the recent outbreaks\nappear to be very localized and affected relatively small numbers of\nanimals and humans. This might be due to the low level of endemicity\nof RVF in the country, where prolonged dry spells since the 1974-76\nhave limited virus activity. However, the present cases diagnosed\nearly in the wet season this year might indicate increasing activity\nof the virus in the country.\n\n[Byline: JT Paweska, A Grobbelaar, J Weyer, P Leman, L Blumberg and B\nSwanepoel]\n\n--\nProf. Janusz T. Paweska,DVSc, Dr hab.\nHead Special Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases\nof the National Health Laboratory Service\nPrivate Bag X4, Sandringham-Johannesburg, 2131\nModderfontein Road 1, Gauteng, South Africa\n<januszp@nicd.ac.za>j\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professor Paweska and colleagues for providing\nProMED-mail and the wider community with this report describing the\nidentification of a novel genotype of Rift Valley Fever virus\nrecently isolated and characterised in South Africa. Although at\npresent still localised and affecting few animals and humans it needs\nto be kept under surveillance lest it herald an imminent resurgence\nof Rift Valley fever in southern Africa.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of South Africa can be accessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00vd>, and a map of the provinces of South Africa at:\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Analysis of\npartial sequencing data of the M segment of a virus isolate recovered\nfrom the index case revealed that the patient was infected with a RVF\nvirus genotype closest related to a 2004 Namibian isolate from the\nCaprivi Strip, and clustering with a 1981 South African isolate from\nthe East Coast, and isolates from Senegal (1993), Central African\nRepublic (1969) and Guinea (1981, 1984), but not with other South\nAfrican isolates recovered from Kwazulu-Natal in March this year\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDat: Fri 20 Nov 2009\n RVF virus isolates recovered during the last decade in southern and\neastern Africa, the Arabian Peninsula, Mauritania, and Madagascar\nexhibit little genetic diversity, which indicates recent widespread\ndistribution of very closely related genotypes of the virus over a\nvast area. Quoting government medical sources, the official\nSaudi press agency SPA had at the time announced 33 cases of RVF\nillness in Jeddah and 103 in Mecca since the beginning of the month.\n\nThe daily Okaz had, on 12 Apr 2009, reported that a Saudi man and\nwoman, aged respectively 20 and 22 years old, afflicted by the virus,\nhad finally succumbed the previous day at King Faisal hospital in\nMecca. The following day, other newspapers had reported the\nhospitalisation in Mecca of more than 100 people affected by the\ndisease. Most of them were discharged from hospitals after receiving\nemergency treatment.\n\nAn American company has been called in to eradicate the RVF virus\n[vector?] by using biological processes, instead of chemical means,\nstated the website Anaween on Thu 28 May 2009.\n\n[Translated by: Naima Bouteldja]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Shamsudeen Fagbo\n\n[Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high\nrates of disease and death. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected\nlivestock. Outbreaks of rift Valley fever in the human population are\nusually preceded by extensive outbreaks of disease in livestock,\ntherefore the current report from Saudi Arabia should be treated with caution.\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation Fact Sheet\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>) The\nvast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nThe virus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound\nfrom an infected knife or through contact with broken skin, or\nthrough inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter of\ninfected animals. There is some evidence that humans may also become\ninfected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of\ninfected animals.\n\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ spp., and transmission of\nRVF virus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\nTo date, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented,\nand no transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported\nwhen standard infection control precautions have been put in place.\nThere has been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas. - Mod.CP]\n\n[A map of Saudi Arabia is available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/cia08/saudi_arabia_sm_2008.gif>. - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 31 May 2009\n \nSeveral newspapers and websites have rung alarm bells and warned\nagainst a new epidemic of Rift Valley fever [RVF] virus, a virus\nmainly transmitted by mosquitoes, that decimates mainly the animal\nbut also [affects] the human population. \n\nThe daily Okaz had, on 12 Apr 2009, reported that a Saudi man and\nwoman, aged respectively 20 and 22 years old, afflicted by the virus,\nhad finally succumbed the previous day at King Faisal hospital in\nMecca. 'We sent people to\nCreighton to put the disease under control. We are also working\ntowards getting a vaccine to ensure that it does not spread.'\n\nAccording to the World Health Organisation, Rift Valley Fever (RVF)\nis a viral zoonosis that primarily affects animals but also has the\ncapacity to infect humans. Infection can cause severe disease in both\nanimals and humans, leading to high rates of death.\n\nUnconfirmed reports on Tuesday stated that more than 50 animals had\ndied in Creighton since the outbreak was picked up. Mthimkhulu said\nthere was no need to start pressing alarm bells, saying that there\nwere no signs the disease was spreading.\n\nThe majority of human RVF infections resulted from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering.\n\n'When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,' said Mthimkhulu. He said a joint task team\ncomprising government, organised agricultural unions (KwaNalu and\nNafu) and community based organisations had been put in place to\ndevelop a comprehensive plan of action.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Information on the species of the affected animals, their ages and\ntheir vaccination history will be helpful.\n\nSubscribers are referred to Mod.CP's commentary in posting\n20080701.2012. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 3 Mar 2009\n He said a joint task team\ncomprising government, organised agricultural unions (KwaNalu and\nNafu) and community based organisations had been put in place to\ndevelop a comprehensive plan of action. \n\n'When we heard about the disease, I urgently summoned our Veterinary\nServices Unit (VSU) to put together an urgent plan of action to\nhandle this matter,' said Mthimkhulu. Cellule interregionale d'epidemiologie (Cire) Reunion - Mayotte,\nInstitut de veille sanitaire, Saint-Denis de La Reunion, France\n2. Laboratoire de biologie, Centre hospitalier de Mayotte, France\n3. Cellule de veille epidemiologique, Centre hospitalier de Mayotte, France\n4. Institut de veille sanitaire, Saint-Maurice, France\n\nEnglish language Abstract of the publication entitled Emergence of\nRift Valley fever in Mayotte, 2007-2008\n---------------------------------------\nBackground\n----------\nEpidemic resurgence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in 2006-2007 in Kenya\nled to the implementation of an active laboratory-based animal\nsurveillance, and to the assessment of possible spread in the\npopulation.\n\nMethods\n-------\nRVF was investigated retrospectively and prospectively in serum\nspecimen collected from patients with dengue-like illness (DLI) who\nconsulted between 1 Sep 2007 and 31 May 2008 in any health centre in\nMayotte and tested negative for chikungunya, dengue, and malaria. A\nconfirmed recent case-patient was defined by the presence in the\nserum of anti-RVF virus-IgM (MAC-ELISA [IgM antibody capture\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay]) or RVF virus-RNA (RT-PCR [reverse\ntranscriptase polymerase chain reaction]).\n\nResults\n-------\nA total of 10/220 (4.5 percent) patients were diagnosed with recent\nRVF: RT-PCR (6), MAC-ELISA (2), or both (2). The earliest recorded\nonset of DLI was 27 Sep 2007 while the latest was 14 May 2008. Seven\ncases (70 percent) occurred between January and April 2008. Ages\nranged 16-53 years, and 9/10 (88 percent) were male. Neither severe\ncases nor fatalities were observed. In patients (9/10), exposures to\nanimal products represented 5 out of 9 cases, consumption of raw milk\nalone (1/9), breeding sites in the housing environment (3/9).\nPhylogenic studies demonstrated that these strains are similar to\nthose circulated in Kenya in 1997.\n\nConclusion and discussion\n-------------------------\nThis 1st recorded autochthonous transmission of the RVF in Mayotte\nillustrates the risk of introduction or circulation in Mayotte of\narboviruses involved in outbreaks in neighboring Eastern-African\ncostal countries or islands. Efforts should be intensified and\nmaintained routinely in order to detect promptly any renewed\nintroduction or resurgence of RVFV in Mayotte.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Comoro Islands are an archipelago lying between Madagascar and\nthe African continent. The main islands are Grande Comore, Anjouan,\nMoheli, and Mayotte. The islands are volcanic in origin. Politically,\nthe islands are divided into 2 entities: Comoros, a sovereign state,\nand Mayotte, an overseas collective of France.\n\nMayotte can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=921810&v=-12.833,45.167,5>.\nA map of the Comoro Islands can be accessed at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comoro_Islands>.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with\nRVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated\nwith fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients, the\nillness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (affecting the\neye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset\nof the illness. Typically, patients recover within 2 days to one week\nafter onset of illness.\n\nThe most common complication associated with RVF is inflammation of\nthe retina (a structure connecting the nerves of the eye to the\nbrain). As a result, approximately 1-10 percent of affected patients\nmay have some permanent vision loss. Approximately one percent of\nhumans that become infected with RVF die of the disease.\n\nCase-fatality proportions are significantly higher for infected\nanimals. The most severe impact is observed in pregnant livestock\ninfected with RVF, which results in abortion of virtually 100 percent\nof fetuses.\n\nThe source of these infections in Mayotte has not been determined but\nit is likely that infection occurred by transmission from an infected\nanimal on the Comoros. The occurrence of RVF in animals in the Comoros\nis possible because the islands lie in the Indian Ocean between the\nRVF-endemic territories of Tanzania/Mozambique and northern Madagascar.\n\nTanzania suffered an RVF outbreak earlier in 2007; Madagascar is also\nknown to be endemically infected, as in 1982 a virus designated Zinga\nvirus, isolated in Madagascar, was identified subsequently by the WHO\nReference laboratory for Arboviruses in Yale to be RVF virus. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Jan 2009\n However, in some patients, the\nillness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (affecting the\neye). A\nconfirmed recent case-patient was defined by the presence in the\nserum of anti-RVF virus-IgM (MAC-ELISA [IgM antibody capture\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay]) or RVF virus-RNA (RT-PCR [reverse\ntranscriptase polymerase chain reaction]). \nEpidemic resurgence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in 2006-2007 in Kenya\nled to the implementation of an active laboratory-based animal\nsurveillance, and to the assessment of possible spread in the\npopulation. \n\nTanzania suffered an RVF outbreak earlier in 2007; Madagascar is also\nknown to be endemically infected, as in 1982 a virus designated Zinga\nvirus, isolated in Madagascar, was identified subsequently by the WHO\nReference laboratory for Arboviruses in Yale to be RVF virus. In the alert issued\nThursday [13 Nov 2008] from Garissa, the North Eastern Provincial\ncapital, 374 kilometres (232.4 mi) from Nairobi, a senior veterinary\nofficer, Dr Wycliffe Wangwe, said the on-going heavy rains and\nwarm/humid weather provide the optimal breeding conditions for\nmosquitoes, which spread the deadly disease.\n\nWangwe therefore warned pastoralists in the region to move to high\ngrounds with their animals and avoid areas with stagnant floodwater\nthat may host mosquitoes, which are carriers of the viral disease.\n\nHe also advised livestock keepers in the region to liaise with the\npublic health department to acquire [animal] vaccines that may prove\nvital in the fight against the disease, which is fatal to both\nanimals and humans.\n\nWangwe at the same time asked pastoralists to immediately report\ncases of animals displaying symptoms such as hemorrhagic diarrhea,\nshivering, abortions, or sudden deaths in both small and large animals.\n\nThe official possible.\n\nMovement of animals from areas where the disease has been reported\nshould also be avoided as it will spread the disease to other areas.\n\nHe said the RVF vaccine was available free and welcomed all those who\ndid not present their animals for vaccination to do so as soon as\ntheir local veterinary office announces the immunization programme.\n\nThe viral disease last hit the region in 2006, claiming the lives of\nmore than 40 people and thousands of animals.\n\nMeanwhile the Ministry of Livestock Development has announced plans\nto carry out a mop-up campaign in central rift were also vaccinated against the\nRift Valley fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The application of the (live attenuated) RVF vaccine ahead A useful summary of the current situation and basic information\nof RVF is presented by FAO's (UN Food and Agriculture Organisation)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-04-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nasandratrony", "country": "Madagascar"}, {"location": "destroy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Egypt"}, {"location": "Antady", "country": "Madagascar"}, {"location": "Herinaina Rakotosamimanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Imandry", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "132442", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: (AS) susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=132442", "date": "2008-12-03 11:00:38", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA: (ASIR), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 3 Dec 2008\nSource: Saudi Gazette [edited]\n<http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2008120323652>\n\n\nRVF [Rift Valley fever] disease back in Asir?\n---------------------------------------------\nA case of a 40-year-old Bangladeshi worker who has been admitted into\nthe ICU [intensive care unit] in a private hospital in Asir region\nwith suspected laboratory characteristics of the Rift Valley fever\n(RVF) has brought back harsh memories of the early reports of the\noutbreak of the disease in Jizan, border city with Yemen, in\nSeptember 2000. The man was initially diagnosed with an unknown type\nof fever and elevated liver enzyme levels, both indicators of the RVF.\n\nThe Asir Agriculture Department has recently acted on media reports\nof suspected cattle infected with the disease in different villages\nin the region by sending specimens from there for lab analysis in\nRiyadh for immunoglobulin M (IgM). The lab tests were positive for\nIgM, antibody to Rift Valley fever virus in domestic ruminants.\n\n'There are strong suspicions of the RVF outbreak again in the region,\nbut they are still not confirmed,' said Mubark Al-Mutalqah, director\nof the Asir Agriculture Department. The symptoms could be either a\nreal viral infection or a side effect of the antibody injection\npreviously used on the animals to ward off the virus, he said. 'We\nare still waiting for the final lab reports from the Ministry of\nHealth and the Ministry of Agriculture to confirm the source of the\nIgM as we are closely monitoring the area,' he said.\n\nIf the disease were confirmed, the government agencies would work\nhard to combat it through sending planes to spray insecticide to kill\nthe mosquitoes, which are thought to be spreading the disease. RVF is\na mosquito-borne zoonotic disease affecting domestic ungulates\n(especially goats and sheep) characterized by large epizootics during\nperiods of heavy rainfall with associated outbreaks in humans. Most\nhuman infection is associated with an uncomplicated febrile illness\nor is unapparent.\n\nMore severe complications include retinitis, hepatitis, renal\nfailure, hemorrhagic fever, encephalitis, and death. According to\nrecent research, if the disease breaks out, it may be transmitted in\nan approximately 600 km (373 mi) area, including the flood plains of\nthe wadis [valleys] extending from the Sarawat mountains to the Red\nSea coastal plains. The duration from disease onset to\nhospitalization is 3.3 days and the average time from disease onset\nto death is 6.3 days. [References to the said data -- probably\nderived from previous Saudi observations -- will be appreciated. In\nany event, the generally acceptable data on case fatality rate of RVF\nin humans does not exceed 1-2 percent. - Mod.AS]\n\nA Health Ministry report said Rift Valley fever killed 124 people in\nthe Kingdom between September 2000 and May 2001, while 760 of the 884\ninfected people recovered.\n\nThe Kingdom has since either banned or carefully examined the import\nof livestock from several African countries as well as from Yemen.\n\nAlthough Rift Valley Fever was first identified in 1930, after an\nepidemic among sheep in Kenya, it has also affected Egypt,\nMadagascar, Mauritania, and Somalia, according to the World Health\nOrganization.\n\n[Byline: Fahd Al-Rubai, Al-Hassan Al-Sayyid]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For the Asir province in southwest Saudi Arabia, bordering Yemen, see map at\n<http://www.maplandia.com/saudi-arabia/asir/>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Saudi Arabia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=108180&v=21,42,5>.\n\nIn case the described suspected human RVF case is confirmed, this is\nbad news since it may be indicative of RVF virus circulation in Saudi\nArabia, provided the patient was not infected elsewhere (East\nAfrica?). If confirmed, RVF must already have involved (undetected or\nunreported) infections in ruminants, particularly sheep and goats.\nThe virus can spread by vectors (mosquitoes) and by exposure of\nhumans or susceptible animals to infected tissues.\n\nThe most striking features, expected in (unvaccinated) ruminants, are\nmass abortions and mortality of offspring (which -- in the most\nsusceptible animals, namely lambs younger than 4 weeks -- may reach\nalmost 100 percent). The timing of the current event is most\nunfortunate: the Hajj (annual pilgrimage to Mecca) is due to start in\njust 3 days, on 6 Dec 2008. The Eid-ul-Adha (Festival of the\nSacrifice), when millions of ruminants will be slaughtered, is due on\n8 Dec 2008. The expected influx of over 2 million pilgrims for the\nHajj, as well as the presence of a large migrant population, generate\nhigh human and animal traffic that present a challenging agenda for\npublic health. Returning pilgrims may, if infected, transfer the\nvirus to other regions.\n\nThe Saudi authorities are expected to take the appropriate measures\navoiding the introduction into Mecca of animals from the south and\nprescribing intensive veterinary inspection of the slaughtering\nprocess, particularly antemortem inspections. Infection of humans\nwith the RVF virus may occur by their exposure to organs,\nparticularly blood, of viraemic animals. Reportedly, the exposure of\nhumans to aerosols in slaughtering facilities and home slaughtering,\nduring the major 1977-78 epizootic in Egypt, was a main contributor\nto the very high morbidity and mortality observed.\n\nThe potential risks within this period as well as other peculiar\necological factors have been discussed in the paper, 'The evolving\ntransmission pattern of Rift Valley fever in the Arabian peninsula'\nby Shamsudeen F Fagbo, Ann N Y Acad Sci 969: 201-4 (2002) (abstract\navailable at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12381591?dopt=Abstract>).\n\nSaudi Arabia initially reported the presence of RVF during 2000 and\nthe 1st quarter of 2001. Saudi investigators raised later the\nspeculation that the RVF virus had been introduced into the Arabian\npeninsula earlier, namely in 1997/1998 during the RVF epidemic in\nEast Africa, via introduction of infected imported livestock or via\nwindborne infected mosquitoes, and that climatic conditions have\npromoted sufficient vector populations to support transmission in\nSaudi Arabia and Yemen. (See A Madani et al: 'Rift Valley Fever\nEpidemic in Saudi Arabia: Epidemiological, Clinical and Laboratory\nCharacteristics'. J. Virol. 2008; 0: JVI.01519-08v1. Epub ahead\nof print 10 Sep 2008]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAuthors: Bird BH, Githinji JW, Macharia JM, Kasiiti JL, Muriithi RM,\nGacheru SG, Musaa JO, Towner JS, Reeder SA, Oliver JB, Stevens TL,\nErickson BR, Morgan LT, Khristova ML, Hartman AL, Comer JA, Rollin\nPE, Ksiazek TG, Nichol ST.\nAt: Special Pathogens Branch, Division of Viral and Rickettsial\nDiseases, Coordinating Center for Infectious Diseases, and\nBiotechnology Core Facility Branch, Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, 1600 Clifton Road MS G-14 Atlanta, GA 30329, USA;\nMinistry of Livestock and Fisheries Development, Department of\nVeterinary Services, Kabete, Kenya; University of California, Davis,\nSchool of Veterinary Medicine, Davis, CA 95616.\n\nAbstract: Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus has historically caused\nwidespread and extensive outbreaks of severe human and livestock\ndisease throughout Africa, Madagascar, and the Arabian Peninsula.\nFollowing unusually heavy rainfall during the late autumn of 2006,\nreports of human and animal illness consistent with RVF virus\ninfection emerged across semi-arid regions of Garissa District of\nnortheastern Kenya and southern Somalia. Following initial RVF virus\nlaboratory confirmation, a high throughput RVF diagnostic facility\nwas established at the Kenyan Central Veterinary Laboratories in\nKabete, Kenya, to support real-time identification of infected\nlivestock and to facilitate outbreak response and control activities.\n\nA total of 3250 specimens from a variety of animal species including\ndomesticated livestock (cattle, sheep, goats, and camels) and\nwildlife collected from a total of 55 of 71 Kenyan administrative\ndistricts were tested by molecular and serologic assays. Evidence of\nRVF infection was found in 9.2 percent of animals tested, and across\n23 districts of Kenya, reflecting the large number of affected\nlivestock and geographic extent of the outbreak.\n\nThe complete S, M, and/or L genome segment sequence [Rift Valley\nfever virus is a tripartite genome negative strand RNA virus,\nbelonging to the genus _Phlebovirus_ in the family _Bunyaviridae_. -\nMod.CP] was obtained from a total of 31 RVF virus specimens spanning\nthe entire known outbreak period (December 2006-May 2007) and\ngeographic areas affected by RVF virus activity. Extensive genomic\nanalyses demonstrated the concurrent circulation of multiple virus\nlineages, gene segment reassortment, and common ancestry of the\n2006-2007 outbreak viruses with those from the 1997-1998 east-African\nRVF outbreak.\n\nEvidence of recent increases in genomic diversity and effective\npopulation size 2 to 4 years prior to the 2006-2007 outbreak was also\nfound, indicating ongoing RVF virus activity and evolution during the\ninter-epizootic/epidemic period. These findings have implications for\nfurther studies of basic RVF virus ecology, the design of future\nsurveillance/diagnostic activities and highlight the critical need\nfor safe and effective vaccines and antiviral compounds to combat\nthis significant veterinary and public health threat.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high\nrates of disease and death. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected\nlivestock. The virus was first identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa. In 1997-1998, a major outbreak occurred\nin Kenya, Somalia, and Tanzania and in September 2000, RVF cases were\nconfirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nThere is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To\ndate, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented.\n\nFor a comprehensive account of Rift Valley fever disease in animals\nand humans, the World Health Organisation (WHO) overview of the\ndisease can be accessed at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>.\n\nPreviously Bird et al. published an analysis of the complete genome\nsequences of 33 ecologically and biologically diverse Rift Valley\nfever virus strains isolated from humans and animals in Africa (J\nVirol. 2007; 81(6): 2805-16; <http://jvi.asm.org/cgi/content/full/81/6/2805>).\n\nSeveral distinct virus genetic lineages were determined, which\napproximately correlated with geographic origin, but several\nexceptions indicative of long-distance virus movement were found.\nVirus genetic diversity was low and primarily involved accumulation\nof mutations at an average of 2.9 x 10(-4) substitutions/site/year,\nalthough some evidence of genome subunit reassortment was found.\n\nThe current publication describes an in-depth analysis of viruses\nisolated during the course of the extensive outbreak that occurred in\nthe Garissa district of Kenya and Somalia in 2006-2007. Continuity\nwith earlier outbreaks and with viruses isolated during the\ninter-epidemic period was observed. Several distinct virus lineages\nwere circulating during the 2006-2007 outbreak and diversity was\nincreased by genetic reassortment during the course of the outbreak.\nIt is evident from this analysis that the genomic diversity of Rift\nValley fever virus is increasing and that the virus is continuing to\nevolve both within and between epidemic periods.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Kenya is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=0.5,37.9,6>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "At: Special Pathogens Branch, Division of Viral and Rickettsial\nDiseases, Coordinating Center for Infectious Diseases, and\nBiotechnology Core Facility Branch, Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, 1600 Clifton Road MS G-14 Atlanta, GA 30329, USA;\nMinistry of Livestock and Fisheries Development, Department of\nVeterinary Services, Kabete, Kenya; University of California, Davis,\nSchool of Veterinary Medicine, Davis, CA 95616. Communicated by:\nShamsudeen Fagbo\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[Rift Valley fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. For a comprehensive account of Rift Valley fever disease in animals\nand humans, the World Health Organisation (WHO) overview of the\ndisease can be accessed at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>. CP] was obtained from a total of 31 RVF virus specimens spanning\nthe entire known outbreak period (December 2006-May 2007) and\ngeographic areas affected by RVF virus activity. \n\nSeveral distinct virus genetic lineages were determined, which\napproximately correlated with geographic origin, but several\nexceptions indicative of long-distance virus movement were found.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1931-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1600-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Somalia", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "Yemen"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Kabete", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "135504", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (02): (AS), susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=135504", "date": "2008-12-11 16:00:39", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA (02): (ASIR), SUSPECTED\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 10 Dec 2008\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n\n1. In response to the moderator's request for information in the posting\n'Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia: (Asir) suspected, RFI 20081203.3798:'\nFirstly, please note that RVF vaccination in Saudi Arabia is applied in\nyoung animals using the live attenuated RVF Smithburn strain vaccine (Ref\n1). More details can be found in the said paper and in Ref 2.\n\n2. As to the moderator's hint at a possible East African source, the\npossibility of other RVFV-like viruses being involved arises. I would like\nto remind the reader that during the 1997/98 outbreak in East Africa,\nclinical pictures similar to RVF eventually turned out to be caused by\nanother member of the _Bunyaviridae_, named Garissa virus (Ref 3). Possible\ninvolvement of other Bunyaviruses deserves consideration also in view of\nthe lack of observed disease symptoms characteristic of RVF in reportedly\ninfected animals.\n\n3. The suggested endemicity of RVFV in Saudi Arabia is supported by\nevidence from a government lab in the RVF-prone area. In 2004, the Ministry\nof Agric workers detected local natural infection in sentinel animals used\nin surveillance programs (Ref 1). There were no camels amongst the sentinel\nanimals.\n\n4. The role of camels in the emergence and spread of RVF in the region\nseems not to be given much attention, as shown in local surveys (Ref 2). A\npublished sero-surveillance report on camels detected one single RVF\nIgG-positive camel among 496 animals tested (0.2 per cent) (Ref 4). Details\non exactly where and when the positive sample was taken as well as\ninformation on confirmation of the Indirect ELISA used by other means or\nfurther investigations are not given. These authors again acknowledge the\npresent lack of camel sentinels. Camels are known to move through extensive\nareas that again present exposure determination challenges. Sadly, little\nis still known of RVF pathogenicity in camels. In addition, most of the\nvaluable ELISA protocols are not validated for this species. However,\ncamels are susceptible, and their movements between the Gulf States (Ref 5)\nmay constitute a risk pathway that needs to be evaluated. This is of\nparticular importance to neighbouring countries like UAE where efforts are\nbeing made to export camel products to Europe. The need to increase\ncamel-related RVF monitoring/research cannot be overemphasized.\n\n5. Even though enzootic, possible routes of RVFV reintroduction still\nexist. The government is well aware of this potential problem, and strict\nrequirements are said to have been applied for newly permitted livestock\nimports from Sudan and Eritrea. However, the potential for entry via\nnontraditional routes remains. Private zoos and individuals in the region\ndo import susceptible wildlife from RVF endemic regions of Africa; these\nmay not be adequately covered by local RVF surveillance and thus may\ncontribute to undetected local transmission. While efforts to better\nunderstand the role of wildlife in RVF inter-epizootic maintenance are\nstill ongoing, there is evidence that wildlife is actively infected by RVF.\nAs reported in postings 20080210.0541 and 20080701.2012, RVF-affected\nbuffaloes have passed infection to humans in South Africa earlier this year\n[2008]; such animals are found in private zoos.\n\n6. The report on the Asir suspected human case says: 'The man was initially\ndiagnosed with an unknown type of fever and elevated liver enzyme levels,\nboth indicators of RVF.' With the RVFV specific IgM unconfirmed,\ndifferential diagnoses such as dengue and Alkhurmah haemorrhagic fever\nviruses come to mind; they should receive more consideration if the initial\nIgM turns out to be false positive. The latter virus is thought to be\nunder-diagnosed.\n\n7. Statements such as 'the symptoms could be either a real viral infection\nor a side effect of the antibody injection previously used on the animals\nto ward off the virus' are really confusing and may be due to translation\nerrors from an Arabic original as well as inaccuracy in reporting\ninfectious diseases by the media. This was experienced in the 1st RVF\noutbreak in 2000. In the same light, the use of the term 'cattle' should be\ninterpreted cautiously, since the word 'mawaashi' (which means livestock)\nin Arabic has in past reports been mistranslated to 'cattle,' erroneously\nexcluding other livestock, particularly small ruminants. Susceptible sheep\nand goats are, generally, more ubiquitous than cattle in these regions.\n\n8. The above quoted statement further indicates lack of clarity regarding\nthe RVF vaccination status of the animals in the affected area. The risk of\nreversion to virulence does exist with live attenuated vaccines; these\nvaccines also do not allow for the differential identification between\ninfected and vaccinated animals [DIVA] (Ref 6); it would be interesting to\nsee the local adoption/trial of the new DIVA recombinant RVF vaccine\ndeveloped by these authors. Without more evidence, especially evidence\ngenerated using molecular tools to sequence and characterize any virus\nisolated, it would be difficult to trace the source of the virus. Using\nsuch protocols, it might have been possible to judge the possibility of\nvaccine reversion.\n\n9. If and when RVF is confirmed (which is not the case so far), the\npotential risks for pilgrims in Makkah is not one that can be easily\nextrapolated. A general analysis of such potential risks was given by Glyn\nDavies in his paper 2 years ago (Ref 7). However, since he probably did not\nhave the opportunity to be present on location during the pilgrimage\nitself, may I add several other dynamic variables for consideration. One's\nfamiliarity with the Haj rites, abattoirs and fellow veterinarians there\nmay enable suggesting that risk exposure pathways vary greatly amongst the\npilgrims, who come from virtually all over the world. A generalized risk\nanalysis may not be possible: Potential exposure pathways can only be\ndeveloped by factoring in these various dynamic variables. These variables\ndepend on the pilgrims' nationalities and the attendant cultural\ndiversities expressed by the country of origin, purchasing power, etc. Even\nintra-national variations in potential risk exposure patterns will and do\nexist. For example, not all pilgrims are required to slaughter an animal.\nHow many pilgrims opt for this and why? How many of them carry out the\nslaughter and subsequently consume the slaughtered meat? Going into such\ndetails is far beyond the scope of a comment here. It should be noted that\nseveral official sanitary, risk reducing measures have been operational for\nmany years. For example, there is a system of coupon-mediated proxy\nslaughter that limits access of pilgrims to live animals and coordinates\nanimal movement. It is, however, not known how many of the pilgrims make\nuse of this facility and at what level. The government has also limited\noutward movement of animals from the Makkah area [see item 2]. However, it\nis not clear whether the mentioned measures will cover other routes of\ntransmission, namely mosquitoes and nontraditional hosts. Stray cats are\npotential nontraditional alternative hosts. They are present in enormous\nnumbers in the Makkah region; they can easily access abattoirs, carcasses,\nas well as provide meals for abundant tiger mosquitoes, _Aedes (Stegomyia)\nalbopictus_, which feed on animals and humans.\n\n10. What further abates any fear of a massive RVF epizootic is the fact\nthat, though there were heavy rains in the RVF-endemic areas in early\nNovember 2008, the expected interval for trans-ovarially infected\nmosquitoes to erupt and infect susceptible animals/humans, followed by a\nshort incubation period, can be said to have elapsed. However, this does\nnot obviate the need to confirm post rain fall vector dynamics and confirm\nwhether local RVF epizootics will not be always similar to the rainfall\nassociated patterns in East Africa.\n\nIn summary, while a risk does exist for RVF transmission, its full\nevaluation requires detailed information on local conditions and on ground\nrisk parameters. Until confirmed, there is no need to stoke up fears.\nProactive preventive measures can be heightened. Whenever confirmed,\nanalytical risk deductions are best done on a nationality to nationality\nbasis. It is also hoped that the new risk levels will increase commitment\nto research on this and other arboviral zoonoses.\n\nReferences\n1. Elfadil AA, Hasab-Allah KA, Dafa-Allah OM, Elmanea AA. The persistence\nof rift valley fever in the Jazan region of Saudi Arabia. Rev Sci Tech\n2006; 25(3): 1131-6.\n2. Elfadil AA, Hasab-Allah KA, Dafa-Allah OM. Factors associated with Rift\nValley fever in south-west Saudi Arabia. Rev Sci Tech 2006; 25(3): 1137-45.\n3. Gerrard SR, Li Li, Barrett AD, Nichol ST. Ngari Virus is a Bunyamwera\nvirus reassortant that can be associated with large outbreaks of\nhemorrhagic fever in Africa. J Virol 2004; 78(16): 8922-6.\n4. Al-Afaleq AI, Abu-Elzein EE, Hegazy AA, Al-Naeem A. Serosurveillance of\ncamels (Camelus dromedarius) to detect antibodies against viral diseases in\nSaudi Arabia. J Camel Practice Research 2007; 14(2): 91-6.\n5. Wernery U, Thomas R, Syriac, G. Raghavan, R. J Virol\n2008; 82(6): 2681-91.\n7. Davies FG. Risk of a rift valley fever epidemic at the haj in Mecca,\nSaudi Arabia. Rev Sci Tech 2006; 25(1): 137-47.\n\n--\nShamsudeen Fagbo\nDept of Tropical Veterinary Diseases\nUniversity of Pretoria South Africa\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 7 Dec 2008\nSource: Saudi Gazette [edited]\n<http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2008120723849>\n\n\nAuthorities have imposed a ban on removing livestock from Makkah during\nHaj, Dr Fahd Balghunaim, minister of agriculture, said here on Saturday [6\nDec 2008].\n\nHe said his ministry has adopted a number of preventive measures to avoid a\nrecurrence of Rift Valley fever (RVF) and bird flu, pointing out that the\nban on importing live birds was still in place. The government is taking\nextra precautions since there was a suspected case of RVF in Asir Region\nrecently after a Bangladeshi national was hospitalized there with symptoms\nof the disease. The minister said importing livestock from Sudan and Syria\nhas been resumed to meet the increasing demand during this season after\nconfirming implementation of health specifications by the 2 countries [See\nadditional media sources on the Saudi animal import policy in the\ncommentary at the bottom of this posting. - Mod.AS].\n\n'The ministry has provided additional staff for Makkah Region's land and\nsea entry points in order to deal with the increasing number of livestock\narriving in Jeddah. Madagascar (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=95644", "date": "2008-07-16 19:00:26", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - MADAGASCAR (02)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 15 Jul 2008\nSource: afrol News [edited]\n<http://www.afrol.com/articles/29834>\n\n\nMadagascar needs more help to combat deadly Rift Valley fever outbreak\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nUnited Nations agencies helping to support Madagascar's emergency plan have\nappealed to international donors to step in, to extend coverage of all\npopulations at risk of the deadly outbreak of Rift Valley fever (RVF) in\nthe country. RVF in Madagascar has already caused 20 human deaths as well\nas affecting livestock, according to reports by UN agencies. Since January\n[2008], RVF has been reported in both animals and humans in more than 20\nout of 119 districts of Madagascar, primarily in the north, south, and\ncentral highlands. By the end of June [2008], Madagascar's Ministry of\nHealth had reported a total of 520 human-suspected cases related to RVF,\nincluding 20 deaths. Laboratory tests have confirmed 84 human cases so far.\n\nThe UN's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and World Health\nOrganization (WHO) have helped Malagasy authorities develop an Emergency\nResponse Plan, which includes providing disease management for affected\nlivestock herds and human populations at risk, reinforcing livestock\ndisease surveillance and improving reporting systems and laboratory\ndiagnostics.\n\nTransmitted by mosquitoes, RVF is a dangerous disease that affects both\nlivestock -- including sheep, goats, cattle, and camels -- and humans, but\nis usually well established in animal populations by the time the 1st human\ncases are observed.\n\nHumans become infected through mosquito bites or direct contact with\ninfected material and liquids such as animal blood during slaughtering,\nwhile the uncooked milk of infected animals can also pose a risk. No cases\nof human-to-human transmission have ever been reported.\n\nWhile some infected people experience no detectable symptoms, others\ndevelop flu-like fever, muscle pain, headaches, joint pain, vomiting, loss\nof appetite, and sensitivity to light. In more severe cases patients can\nalso experience lesions in their eyes, neurological problems, liver\nimpairment, and haemorrhagic fever symptoms including widespread bleeding.\n\nFAO and WHO have received a total of USD 376 000 from the UN Central\nEmergency Response Fund (CERF) to support the emergency plan, but the 2\nagencies are appealing to international donors to help extend the programme\nto areas not yet covered, aiming to cover all populations at risk.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The outbreak of RVF in Madagascar was reported by the Agriculture Ministry\non 9 Apr 2008, following positive results of tests on 2 of nine 9 that were\ntaken ill with symptoms associated with the disease 2 months previously.\nThe RVF situation in Madagascar has become serious because the 2 month\ndelay in disease reporting facilitated the spread of the disease and the\nconsequent occurrence of several human cases and deaths.\n\nBy 18 Apr 2008 a total of 418 human cases and 17 deaths had been recorded.\nBy the end of June 2008 the human case number had become 520 with 20\nfatalities, suggesting a degree of containment of the outbreak. However, as\nyet only 84 cases have been confirmed by laboratory testing.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Madagascar can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-19.4,46.7,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nThe UN's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and World Health\nOrganization (WHO) have helped Malagasy authorities develop an Emergency\nResponse Plan, which includes providing disease management for affected\nlivestock herds and human populations at risk, reinforcing livestock\ndisease surveillance and improving reporting systems and laboratory\ndiagnostics. The following communication supplies data on human cases.]\n\nUpdate on human cases of Rift Valley Fever in South Africa 2008\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nFrom January 2008 to June 2008, Rift Valley fever (RVF) affecting\ncattle, buffalo, and goats was confirmed in a number of localities in\n4 provinces in South Africa -- Mpumalanga, North West, Gauteng, and\nLimpopo. To date there have been 18 laboratory confirmed human cases\nidentified through serology for IgG and IgM using a recombinant ELISA\n[enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay] technique performed on all\nhigh-risk persons and/or RT-PCR [reverse transcriptase polymerase\nchain reaction] on those with acute symptoms suggestive of RVF. All\n18 persons had close and significant contact with infected animals or\ntheir tissues. These included a veterinary surgeon exposed during a\nnecropsy, 4 veterinary students and 2 technicians exposed during\nnecropsies, a veterinary student who examined an ill calf and 10 farm\nworkers who either handled infected animals or were involved in\nslaughtering livestock. All patients developed fever and myalgia,\nencephalitis was noted in 2 of the patients, and 5 of 6 patients\ntested demonstrated minor liver dysfunction. One patient remains ill\ndue to an underlying illness while all the others have recovered with\nno sequelae.\n\n--\nLucille Blumberg, Janusz Paweska, Jackie Weyer\nField Epidemiology Training Programs (FELTP) residents\nRobert Swanepoel\nSpecial Pathogens and Epidemiology Units\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases,\nNo 1 Modderfontein Rd\nSandringham, Johannesburg\nSouth Africa\n<lucilleb@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[Rift Valley fever virus was first identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in\nsub-Saharan and North Africa. In 1997-98, a major outbreak occurred in\nKenya, Somalia, and Tanzania, and in September 2000, RVF cases were\nconfirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the 1st reported\noccurrence of the disease outside the African continent [see ProMED\narchives below].\n\nAccording to the WHO\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>) the vast\nmajority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact\nwith the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be\ntransmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers, and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nThe virus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound\nfrom an infected knife or through contact with broken skin, or\nthrough inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter of\ninfected animals. The aerosol mode of transmission has also led to\ninfection in laboratory workers. There is some evidence that humans\nmay also become infected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or\nuncooked milk of infected animals.\n\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly _Aedes_ spp. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by haematophagous flies is also possible.\n\nTo date, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented,\nand no transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported\nwhen standard infection control precautions have been put in place.\nThere has been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.\n\nA map of the provinces of South Africa can be accessed at\n<http://www.sa-venues.com/maps/south-africa-provinces.htm>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\n--\nLucille Blumberg, Janusz Paweska, Jackie Weyer\nField Epidemiology Training Programs (FELTP) residents\nRobert Swanepoel\nSpecial Pathogens and Epidemiology Units\nNational Institute for Communicable Diseases,\nNo 1 Modderfontein Rd\nSandringham, Johannesburg\nSouth Africa\n<lucilleb@nicd.ac.za>\n\n[Rift Valley fever virus was first identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift\nValley of Kenya. According to the WHO\n(<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>) the vast\nmajority of human infections result from direct or indirect contact\nwith the blood or organs of infected animals. And now experts are warning that the disease may\nhit Kenya again and other neighbouring countries.\n\nThe new warning by the US National Aeronautics and Space\nAdministration (NASA) and World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE)\nfollows an acute outbreak of the viral disease on the Island of\nMadagascar, off the coastline of East Africa.\n\nThe latest outbreak of RVF in Madagascar was 1st reported by\nAgriculture Ministry on 9 Apr 2008, [following positive results of]\ntests on 2 of 9 animals that were taken ill with symptoms associated\nwith the disease around Avaradrano, Antananarivo, 2 months earlier.\n\n'The situation of RVF in Madagascar is very serious because the\n2-month delay in disease reporting may have facilitated the spread of\nthe disease and the consequent confirmation of several human cases\nand deaths. This could indicate that the infection is well\nestablished in animals in this new epidemic,' the experts warned in\nthe latest issue of the emergency prevention system (EMPRES) report\nby the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) [see further in the\ncommentary.- Mod.AS].\n\nAnalysts said the alarm by NASA and OIE would come handy for Kenya;\n[from Dec 2006 to May 2007] the country [was] hit hard by an outbreak\nof the disease that left more than 155 people killed and more than\n700 infected. North Eastern province bore the brunt of the attack\nwith 333 cases of infections reported, closely followed by Rift\nValley province with 141 cases while Coast and Central provinces\nrecorded 14 and 13 incidents respectively.\n\nHuge damage was also afflicted on the livestock industry where about\n4000 animals were lost prompting the State to slap a ban on livestock\nmovements. Most consumers stopped eating livestock products, pushing\nthousands of dealers and suppliers out of business.\n\nAccording to EMPRES, the Health Ministry in Madagascar had already\nreported 17 human deaths and 418 suspected infections as at mid April\n[2008] in areas around Alaotra, Mangoro, Analamanga, Itasy,\nVakinakaratra and Anosy. The WHO has so far confirmed 59 cases of RVF\n[in humans] through laboratory tests.\n\nExperts are now warning that the situation in Madagascar poses a\ndirect threat to neighbouring nations such as Kenya, especially\nbecause surrounding regions in Central Africa are anticipated to\nwitness an increase in precipitation above normal rains in the next\nfew months -- a condition that suits the spread of the disease.\n\n'Considering that RVF outbreaks were reported in Kenya, Tanzania and\nSudan in 2007, and South Africa is currently experiencing an outbreak\nof RVF, disease surveillance should be heightened and preparedness\nplans put in place throughout the Eastern part of the African\ncontinent. RVF surveillance efforts should be pursued in non-affected\nareas since the disease can still spread,' the report said.\n\nA veterinary expert, Joseph Musaa, said unpredictable weather\npatterns in the country offered a room for the re-emergence of the\ndisease and urged surveillance in main risk areas. 'It is not that we\nwere only hit the other day so we are safe, the dangers of another\nattack are alive because the effects of climate change are alive and\nplaying out,' he told Business Daily.\n\nAnalysts said RVF is an arthropod-borne viral disease of ruminants,\ncamels and humans and may present itself [in humans] in an\nuncomplicated influenza-like illness to a hemorrhagic disease\nattacking the liver and showing in ocular or neurological lesions. In\nanimals, the disease may be unclear in non-pregnant adults, but\noutbreaks are characterised by a large number of abortions and high\nneonatal mortality.\n\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the Aedes mosquito whose infected eggs can\nsurvive through desiccation for months or years and restart\ntransmission after flooding.\n\nRecommended preventive measures include, awareness campaigns,\nincreased disease surveillance and controlled animal movement to\nprevent spread. Animal vaccination is also another strategy besides\nuse of mosquito\nrepellents and mosquito nets.\n\n[Byline: Allan Odhiambo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Subscribers are referred to FAO's recent 'EMPRES WATCH' document\n'Rift Valley fever outbreaks in Madagascar and potential risks to\nneighbouring countries,' available online at\n<http://www.fao.org/docs/eims/upload//242253/EW_rvf_apr08_red.pdf>.\nThe 4-page overview includes the following paragraphs:\n1. Introduction\n2. Disease ecology and climatic drivers in East Africa\n3. Situation of RVF outbreak in Madagascar\n4. Risk Assessment for Rift Valley fever outbreaks\n5. Recommendations\n6. FAO in action\n7. RVF Resources\n8. Bibliography.\n\nIt also includes maps of Africa demonstrating vegetation index\nanomalies and Rift Valley Fever Risk, as well as a map of Madagascar\nwith locations of the RVF infected areas/outbreaks and bovine\ndensity. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "\n\nExperts are now warning that the situation in Madagascar poses a\ndirect threat to neighbouring nations such as Kenya, especially\nbecause surrounding regions in Central Africa are anticipated to\nwitness an increase in precipitation above normal rains in the next\nfew months -- a condition that suits the spread of the disease.
