Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=73523", "date": "2008-04-19 23:00:24", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, HUMAN, BOVINE - MADAGASCAR\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 18 Apr 2008\nSource: World Health Organisation (WHO), EPR, Outbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_04_18a/en/index.html>\n\n\nRift Valley fever in Madagascar\n-------------------------------\nAs of Thu 17 Apr 2008, the Ministry of Health, Madagascar, has\nreported a total of 418 suspected cases including 17 deaths (CFR 4\npercent) of Rift Valley fever from Alaotra Mangoro, Analamanga,\nItasy, Vakinakaratra and Anosy Regions.\n\nInfection with Rift Valley Fever virus (RVFV) has been laboratory\nconfirmed in 59 human cases by the Institut Pasteur de Madagascar, a\nWHO Collaborating Centre for Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers and partner in\nthe Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network.\n\nThe Ministry of Health, Madagascar, has established an\ninter-ministerial committee to oversee the response to the outbreak.\nControl measures implemented have included case management,\nsurveillance, social mobilization, provision of medicines, prevention\nand strengthening of hospital infection control.\n\nThe Ministry of Agriculture (MoA) has reported the RVF in animals to\nthe OIE on 9 Apr 2008.\n\nThe MoH and MoA have requested the support of a joint WHO, FAO, OIE\nmission to support outbreak response efforts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The following information is taken from the WHO 'Overview of Rift\nValley fever' which is available in full at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>.\n\n'Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can\ncause severe disease in both animals and humans, leading to high\nrates of disease and death. The disease also results in significant\neconomic losses due to death and abortion among RVF-infected\nlivestock.'\n\n(Human disease is preceded by animal disease and the cases of human\ndisease described in the preceding report are indicative of the\nexistence of extensive disease in livestock. Rift Valley fever virus\nhas circulated in livestock in Madagascar for several years -- see\nthe ProMED-mail references listed below. - Mod.CP)\n\n'RVF virus is a member of the genus _Phlebovirus_, one of the 5\ngenera in the family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in\n1931 during an investigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm\nin the Rift Valley of Kenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported\nin sub-Saharan and North Africa. In 1997-98, a major outbreak\noccurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania and in September 2000, RVF\ncases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the 1st\nreported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent and\nraising concerns that it could extend to other parts of Asia and\nEurope.\n\n'The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\n\n'Certain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nThe virus infects humans through inoculation; for example, via a\nwound from an infected knife or through contact with broken skin, or\nthrough inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter of\ninfected animals. The aerosol mode of transmission has also led to\ninfection in laboratory workers.\n\n'There is some evidence that humans may also become infected with RVF\nby ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes, most commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF\nvirus by hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible.\n\n'To date, no human-to-human transmission of RVF has been documented,\nand no transmission of RVF to health care workers has been reported\nwhen standard infection control precautions have been put in place.\nThere has been no evidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas. In\nmild form of RVF in humans the incubation period (interval from\ninfection to onset of symptoms) for RVF varies from 2 to 6 days.\nThose infected either experience no detectable symptoms or develop a\nmild form of the disease characterized by a feverish syndrome with\nsudden onset of flu-like fever, muscle pain, joint pain and\nheadache.Some patients develop neck stiffness, sensitivity to light,\nloss of appetite and vomiting; in these patients the disease, in its\nearly stages, may be mistaken for meningitis. The symptoms of RVF\nusually last from 4 to 7 days, after which time the immune response\nbecomes detectable with the appearance of antibodies and the virus\ngradually disappears from the blood.\n\n'While most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of\npatients develop a much more severe form of the disease. This usually\nappears as one or more of 3 distinct syndromes: ocular (eye) disease\n(0.5-2 percent of patients), meningoencephalitis (less than 1\npercent) or haemorrhagic fever (less than 1 percent).\n\n'The total case fatality rate has varied widely between different\nepidemics but, overall, has been less than 1 percent in those\ndocumented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form. An inactivated vaccine has been developed\nfor human use. However, this vaccine is not licensed and is not\ncommercially available. It has been used experimentally to protect\nveterinary and laboratory personnel at high risk of exposure to RVF.\nOther candidate vaccines are under investigation.\n\n'Forecasting can predict climatic conditions that are frequently\nassociated with an increased risk of outbreaks, and may improve\ndisease control. In Africa, Saudi Arabia and Yemen RVF outbreaks are\nclosely associated with periods of above-average rainfall. The\nresponse of vegetation to increased levels of rainfall can be easily\nmeasured and monitored by Remote Sensing Satellite Imagery. In\naddition RVF outbreaks in East Africa are closely associated with the\nheavy rainfall that occurs during the warm phase of the El Nino/\nSouthern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon. These findings have enabled\nthe successful development of forecasting models and early warning\nsystems for RVF using satellite images and weather/climate\nforecasting data. Early warning systems, such as these, could be used\nto detect animal cases at an early stage of an outbreak enabling\nauthorities to implement measures to avert impending epidemics.'\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Madagascar can be accessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-19.4,46.7,5>. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Madagascar submitted to the OIE an 'immediate notification' on this\noutbreak on 9 Apr 2008; see, including map, at\n<http://www.oie.int/wahid-prod/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=6952>.\nAccording to the report, there were 2 cases (out of 9 susceptible\nbovines); no mortality and no destruction or slaughter of any animal.\nThe diagnostic methods, applied by the National laboratory, were\nantibody detection ELISA, IgM-capture ELISA and nested RT-PCR. The\ndiagnosis was confirmed by OIE's Reference Laboratory in the\nVeterinary Institute, Onderstepoort, South Africa. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "In 1997-98, a major outbreak\noccurred in Kenya, Somalia and Tanzania and in September 2000, RVF\ncases were confirmed in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, marking the 1st\nreported occurrence of the disease outside the African continent and\nraising concerns that it could extend to other parts of Asia and\nEurope. As of 15 Jan 2008, a cumulative total of 698 cases,\nincluding 222 deaths, has been reported from 6 states (Gazeera, Kassala,\nKhartoum, River Nile, Sinnar, and White Nile), yielding an overall CFR\n[case fatality rate] of 32.4 per cent.\n\nWhile active surveillance continues in all affected states, no new cases\nhave been reported since 5 Jan 2008. Only Gazeera state has reported cases\nwith date of onset in 2008, while several additional cases have been\nreported retrospectively with date of onset in November or December 2007.\nSeveral of the newly added cases evidence ocular presentation, which is\ntypically a late-occurring feature of RVF infection.\n\nCase management related interventions and health education and vector\ncontrol efforts are continuing. WHO continues to support the Sudan Ministry\nof Health in preparedness for viral haemorrhagic fever and other seasonal\noutbreaks and in the procurement of essential supplies, enhancing\nsurveillance and training activities.\n\nFor more information, see the WHO RVF Fact Sheet at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/index.html>, parts of\nwhich are appended below.\n\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n['Rift Valley Fever (RVF) is a viral zoonosis that primarily affects\nanimals but also has the capacity to infect humans. Infection can cause\nsevere disease in both animals and humans, leading to high rates of disease\nand death. The disease also results in significant economic losses due to\ndeath and abortion among RVF-infected livestock.\n\n'RVF virus is a member of the _Phlebovirus_ genus, one of the 5 genera in\nthe family _Bunyaviridae_. The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of\nKenya. The total case fatality rate has varied widely\nbetween different epidemics but, overall, has been less than 1 per cent in\nthose documented. Most fatalities occur in patients who develop the\nhaemorrhagic icterus form.\n\n'During an outbreak of RVF, close contact with animals, particularly with\ntheir body fluids, either directly or via aerosols, has been identified as\nthe most significant risk factor for RVF virus infection. In the absence of\nspecific treatment and an effective human vaccine, raising awareness of the\nrisk factors of RVF infection as well as the protective measures\nindividuals can take to prevent mosquito bites, is the only way to reduce\nhuman infection and deaths.'\n\nA map of the states of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://www.emro.who.int/sudan/Media/PDF/Sud-states-2006.pdf>. The Health Ministry said\nthat as of 16 Dec 2007 there were 565 cases of haemorrhagic fever reported\nin humans. 'The fatality rate is 29 per cent (with) haemorrhagic fever.\n(And) we have about 5 or 6 cases of eye manifestation [an infrequent\nconsequence of Rift Valley fever - Mod.CP],' said spokesman Magdi Saleh.\nBut the government denied there were any confirmed cases in cattle, a main\nsource of income for many Sudanese in the agricultural economy, or in\nsheep. Rumours of the virus caused panic among Sudanese Muslims as they\ncelebrated Eid al-Adha which began on Wednesday with the slaughtering of\nsheep to remember Abraham who was prepared to sacrifice his son for God. 'I\nam still not sure whether to slaughter or not,' said trader Mohamed Omer.\nHe said he did not trust the government's directive to go ahead and\nslaughter sheep for the holiday.\nRumours of dead animals in Khartoum with blood streaming from their mouths\nare rife. Some of the poor who go to people's houses during the holiday to\nget food refused to take raw meat this year. The price of powdered milk\nrose in the market as people became too scared to drink fresh milk. The\nministry of animal resources said a batch of samples of animal blood from\nan isolated area in While Nile State came back 25 per cent positive for\nantibodies of the virus.\n'(But) the positive results were as a result of antibodies maybe due to\nvaccinations or due to past infection,' spokesman Abdel Moneim said. He\nsaid the samples sent to a South African laboratory were being tested again\nto see if the antibodies had increased with time, which would confirm an\noutbreak of the disease. Mohamed Abdel Ghazi, a senior official from the\nministry, said they were still waiting for the results.\nRift Valley fever, named after the part of Africa in which it is prevalent,\nis an animal disease which can spread to humans through mosquitoes or\nthrough contact with bodily fluid. There is no commercially available\nvaccine for humans. About 1 per cent of human cases get haemorrhagic fever\nbleeding from the nose and mouth, which can result in a quick death. About\n95 per cent of human cases feel flu-like symptoms and then the virus\ndisappears after a week. Saleh said as of 1 Dec 2007 there were no new\nhuman cases from White Nile State where the animal tests are taking place.\nBut cases had been recorded in 3 other states.\nVets in Khartoum criticised the government for not acting with\ntransparency. 'The government should have been honest with the people and\ntalked with transparency,' said one vet in Khartoum who declined to be\nnamed. 'The people got panicked.' The vet said the government should have\nissued guidelines on how to deal with meat and taken precautions such as\nspraying pesticides given the heavier than usual rains this year.\nWell-cooked meat and boiled milk is safe. 'We have a history of the disease\nsince 1931 and some say even earlier ... this was to be expected,' the vet\nsaid. Sudan has in the past denied outbreaks of diseases. Earlier this year\nKharotum denied an outbreak of cholera in the east announced by the World\nHealth Organization.\n[byline: Opheera McDoom, editing by Janet Lawrence]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n[Since the last statement (by WHO) on 21 Nov 2007 the number of cases has\nrisen from 436 to 565, with a fatality rate estimated at 29 per cent. The\noutbreak is far from contained and the above report implies that the\nSudanese government may not be responding with appropriate urgency. It\nsuggests that the general population is more aware of the hazards than\ntheir central government.\nIn outbreaks of Rift Valley fever, the vast majority of human infections\nresult from direct or indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected\nanimals. The virus can be transmitted to humans through the handling of\nanimal tissue during slaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal\nbirths, conducting veterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses\nor fetuses. Human infections also result from the bites of infected\nmosquitoes. Humans may also become infected with Rift Valley fever by\ningesting unpasteurized milk or uncooked milk or meat of infected animals.\nKey public health measures include social mobilization, to help people who\ncome into contact with cattle, sheep, and other animals to adopt safe\nhandling and slaughtering practices; epidemiological measures such as\nactive case finding; supportive clinical measures; vector control to stop\nthe spread of disease, primarily between animals but also from animals to\nhumans; and laboratory diagnosis capacity (see: Rift Valley fever - Sudan\n20071103.3570).\nIt was reported previously (see: Rift Valley fever - Sudan (07):\n20071118.3735 ) that clerics have given Sudanese Muslims the all-clear to\nsacrifice animals infected by a Rift Valley fever outbreak in coming\nfestivities. Religious scholars have ruled that animals suspected of having\nthe disease will still be acceptable sacrifices for the major Muslim\nfestival of Eid ul-Adha, daily newspaper Akhir Lahzah reported. The Board\nof Sudanese Religious Scholars ruled that Muslims were only banned from\nsacrificing animals with a disease mentioned in the Hadith, a collection of\nthe sayings of the Prophet, the paper said.\nWisdom will be needed to achieve a balance between exercising health care\nresponsibilities and offending religious susceptibilities. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\nKey public health measures include social mobilization, to help people who\ncome into contact with cattle, sheep, and other animals to adopt safe\nhandling and slaughtering practices; epidemiological measures such as\nactive case finding; supportive clinical measures; vector control to stop\nthe spread of disease, primarily between animals but also from animals to\nhumans; and laboratory diagnosis capacity (see: A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [byline: Opheera McDoom, editing by Janet Lawrence]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n It was reported previously (see: Rift Valley fever - Sudan (07):\n20071118.3735 ) that clerics have given Sudanese Muslims the all-clear to\nsacrifice animals infected by a Rift Valley fever outbreak in coming\nfestivities. Genus: _Phlebovirus_. Family:\n_Bunyaviridae_\nNature of diagnosis Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced), Necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks\nOutbreak 1 Ngwenya, Ehlanzeni, MPUMALANGA\nDate of start of the outbreak 14 Jan 2008\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\n\nSpecies Buffaloes\nSusceptible 371\nCases 5\nDeaths 5\nDestroyed 0\nSlaughtered 0\nAffected population buffaloes kept in an enclosure on a game farm.\n\nSummary of outbreaks Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak statistics\nSpecies Buffaloes\nApparent morbidity rate 1.35 percent\nApparent mortality rate 1.35 percent\nApparent case fatality rate 100.00 percent\nProportion susceptible animals lost* 1.35 percent\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction\nand/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology: Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection. Vectors\n\nControl measures:\nMeasures applied - Quarantine; No vaccination; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied - Screening; Vaccination in response to the outbreak(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\n\nSpecies Buffaloes\nTest virus isolation\nTest date 8 Feb 2008\nResult Pending\n\nLaboratory name and type: Agricultural Research Council -\nOnderstepoort Veterinary Institute (OIE's Reference Laboratory)\n\nSpecies Buffaloes\nTest immunohistochemical test\nTest date 6 Feb 2008\nResult Positive\n\nSpecies Buffaloes\nTest real-time PCR\nTest date 8 Feb 2008\nResult Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although Kenya, Sudan and countries in East Africa have been the\nmost frequent reporters of this disease, it has occurred from time to\ntime from South Africa to Egypt. In 2000, the disease was seen\noutside of Africa for the 1st time in Saudi Arabia and Yemen. It has\nalso been seen in countries in West Africa, including Mauritania and\nSenegal. Rift Valley fever (RVF) was last seen in South Africa in\n1999 and, prior to that outbreak, in 1991. The last OIE disease RVF\nreport from Zimbabwe was in 2001; Zambia in 1997; Malawi in 2002;\nNamibia in 1985; Mozambique in 1963, Madagascar in 1991; Botswana,\nLesotho and Swaziland have never reported RVF. This outbreak in\nMpumalunga is, however, quite close to Zwaziland and a little further\naway from the southwestern border of Kruger National Park. See\n<http://www.traveljournals.net/explore/south_africa/map/m1842803/ngwenya_hills.html>\nor the OIE reference above.\n\nThe current RVF outbreak in Sudan has resulted in 698 human cases and\n222 deaths. Human disease is usually preceded by a significant animal\ndisease event, which is not the case in this outbreak in South\nAfrica. Vaccination is the best way to control a disease outbreak in\nanimals and helps to control the subsequent transmission of RVF to\nhumans. Outbreaks are preceded by excessive rainfall, which promotes\nlarge populations of the mosquito vectors which transmit the disease\namong animals.\n\nAccording to the WHO RVF website\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en>,\ntransmission occurs in the following manner:\n\n'The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can\nbe transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection.\nThe virus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound\nfrom an infected knife or through contact with broken skin, or\nthrough inhalation of aerosols produced during the slaughter of\ninfected animals. The aerosol mode of transmission has also led to\ninfection in laboratory workers. There is some evidence that humans\nmay also become infected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or\nuncooked milk of infected animals. Human infections have also\nresulted from the bites of infected mosquitoes, most commonly the\n_Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of RVF virus by hematophagous\n(blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To date, no human-to-human\ntransmission of RVF has been documented, and no transmission of RVF\nto health care workers has been reported when standard infection\ncontrol precautions have been put in place. There has been no\nevidence of outbreaks of RVF in urban areas.'\n\nOf note, the laboratory providing the diagnosis, OVI, is celebrating\nits 100th anniversary this year (2008) and is one of the world's\ngreat animal diagnostic laboratories, founded by Sir Arnold Theiler.\nTheiler, a veterinarian by training, first made his mark preparing\nvaccines used in an outbreak of smallpox in Witswatersrand in 1893.\nHe subsequently was the first to characterize East Coast fever and\nmade significant progress in combating piroplasmosis, anaplasmosis,\nrhinderpest and African horse sickness. His son Max, a virologist who\nhad worked at OVI and moved to the Rockefeller Institute, won the\n1951 Nobel prize in medicine or physiology for his vaccine work on\nyellow fever. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Feb 2008\n Measures applied - Quarantine; No vaccination; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied - Screening; Vaccination in response to the outbreak(s)\n\nDiagnostic test results\n\nSpecies Buffaloes\nTest virus isolation\n According to the WHO RVF website\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en>,\ntransmission occurs in the following manner:\n\n'The vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. As of\nWed 19 Dec 2007, a total of 601 human RVF cases, including 211 deaths, have\nbeen reported from White Nile, Sennar, Gazeera, and River Nile States. In\naddition, 31 cases including 7 deaths were reported in Khartoum State, but\nthey are believed to have acquired the infection in the other affected\nareas. The virus\ncan be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. As of Wed 21 Nov 2007,\n436 human RVF cases, including 161 deaths have been reported from White\nNile, Sennar, and Gazeera States. In addition 15 cases including 3 deaths\nwere reported in Khartoum State, but they were probably infected in the\nother affected areas. Gazeera State continues to report the most human\ncases, and now accounts for 271 cases and 100 deaths.\n\nIn RVF outbreaks, the vast majority of human infections result from direct\nor indirect contact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus\ncan be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. Human\ninfections have also resulted from the bites of infected mosquitoes. Humans\nmay also become infected with RVF by ingesting the unpasteurized or\nuncooked milk or meat of infected animals.\n\nKey public health measures include social mobilization, to help people who\ncome into contact with cattle, sheep, and other animals to adopt safe\nhandling and slaughtering practices; epidemiological measures such as\nactive case finding; supportive clinical measures; vector control to stop\nthe spread of disease, primarily between animals but also from animals to\nhumans; and laboratory diagnosis capacity.\n\nThe national response to the outbreak is being managed by an\ninter-ministerial task force, with the participation, inter alia, of the\nFederal Ministry of Health and the Federal Ministry of Animal Resources and\nFisheries. This task force is responsible for managing integrated action to\ncontrol the spread of the disease and to decrease the impact on human and\nanimal health. In support of the task force, state and federal ministers of\nhealth met on Tue 20 Nov 2007 to discuss the response activities and called\nfor systematic measures to control the spread of disease in animal\npopulations, including controls on animal movement.\n\nThe WHO Eastern Mediterranean Regional Office and WHO headquarters continue\nto support the Sudan Federal Ministry of Health in its role as part of the\nnational Task Force, through the provision of technical support.\n\nContinued, integrated intensive social mobilization efforts are urgently\nneeded, using all locally available media, including television and radio\nchannels, as well as community and religious leaders, to ensure that\nat-risk communities are fully aware of the measures that need to be taken\nto reduce the risk of human infection.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of human cases of Rift Valley fever in the White Nile, Sennar,\nand Gazeera States of Sudan is 74 more than given by the Sudanese Ministry\nof Health on 20 Nov 2007, and the number of fatalities has increased by 67.\nThese figures do not include the 15 cases and 3 deaths in Khartoum State,\nthought to have originated outwith the state. The centre of the outbreak\nappears to be Gazeera State, but there is still a lack of clarity regarding\nthe extent of the disease in livestock, the presumed source of the\noutbreak, and the measures being taken to reduce the exposure of the human\npopulation to the disease.\n\nThe location of the White Nile, Sennar, and Gazeera States can be viewed by\naccessing the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Sudan at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=13.8,30,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nKey public health measures include social mobilization, to help people who\ncome into contact with cattle, sheep, and other animals to adopt safe\nhandling and slaughtering practices; epidemiological measures such as\nactive case finding; supportive clinical measures; vector control to stop\nthe spread of disease, primarily between animals but also from animals to\nhumans; and laboratory diagnosis capacity. The virus\ncan be transmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses. Victims usually experience fever, general weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, vomiting of blood, and extreme weight loss at the onset of the\nillness. Many patients recover within a week but others can die, including\nthose with weakened immune systems, experts say.\n\nThe fever was 1st isolated in Kenya's Rift Valley region in 1930s but has\nsince been recorded elsewhere on the continent and overseas.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to this report the number of cases has increased by 33 since the\nstatement issued by WHO on 14 Nov 2007. RFV is a viral\ndisease currently wreaking havoc in East Africa, especially in Sudan.\nHealth authorities fear an epidemic in the Comoros. Pending\nconfirmation of the presence of the disease in the livestock\npopulation of the Comoros, surveillance is being reinforced\nthroughout the islands.\n\nLast August [2007], a boy, 12 years old, living in Moroni (Grande\nComore Island) was transferred to a hospital in Mayotte. He had\ndeveloped symptoms 3 months previously, and it was confirmed in\nSeptember 2007 by the National Reference Center (NRC) in Lyon that\nthe boy was a case of RVF.\n\nAt present, the boy is hospitalized in Mayotte in critical condition.\n'He has [severe] neurological symptoms,' says Pierre Vincent,\nCoordinator of the Epidemiology Centre (Wax) in Mayotte. The boy, a\nresident of Moroni, has apparently contracted infection from a sick\nindigenous animal. Since neither the child nor a relative had visited\nEast Africa, an outbreak of RVF among livestock in Grande Comore is\nsuspected.\n\nThe Health Authorities are anxious to assess the risk of a spread of\ninfection in livestock. Two weeks ago, the veterinary services of\nMayotte dispatched 100 test samples to the Ministry of Health of the\nComoros so that the extent of any infection of the animal population\ncould be estimated. These samples have been sent to the Centre for\nInternational Cooperation in Agronomic Research (CIRAD) in\nMontpellier. The results are not yet known, but, already, Dr. Pierre\nVincent 'feared an outbreak in the Comoros.'\n\n'However, the situation has not alarmed our authorities. We cannot\nconsider that the risk is significant,' stated Dr Vincent. According\nto Dr Nicolas Krieger, deputy director of the Directorate of\nVeterinary Services (DSV), no ruminants or their products have been\nexported to Europe from countries where this disease is endemic. All\nlivestock (cattle, sheep and goats) and animal products imported into\nthe Comoros have originated from France and other countries of the\nEuropean Union. Furthermore, even if the virus can be transmitted via\nthe _Aedes albopictus_ mosquito, the disease could not be transmitted\n[to humans and from human to human by mosquitoes] without the\nexistence of infected livestock to amplify the virus. The WAX\nCoordinator stated that: 'Man does not participate in the development\ncycle of the disease, because the virus does not multiply\nsufficiently in the blood. Mosquitoes, therefore, can only acquire an\ninfectious dose by feeding on domestic livestock.\n\nThe Health Authorities nonetheless remain on their guard. 'We also\nknow that RVF is endemic in Madagascar,' said Dr. Vincent.\n'Consequently, we have continued the surveillance measures which were\nput in place following the outbreak of cholera in the Comoros. There\nis always strict control of goods and materials imported into the\nComoros.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Comoro Islands are an archipelago lying between Madagascar and\nthe African continent. The main islands are Grande Comore, Anjouan,\nMoheli and Mayotte. The islands are volcanic in origin. Politically,\nthe islands are divided into 2 entities: Comoros, a sovereign state,\nand Mayotte, an overseas collectivity of France. A map of the Comoros\nIslands can be accessed at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comoro_Islands>.\n\nRVF virus can cause several different disease syndromes. People with\nRVF typically have either no symptoms or a mild illness associated\nwith fever and liver abnormalities. However, in some patients, the\nillness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases\naffecting the eye). Patients who become ill usually experience fever,\ngeneralized weakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss\nat the onset of the illness. Typically, patients recover within 2\ndays to one week after onset of illness. The most common complication\nassociated with RVF is inflammation of the retina (a structure\nconnecting the nerves of the eye to the brain). As a result,\napproximately 1-10 percent of affected patients may have some\npermanent vision loss. Approximately one percent of humans that\nbecome infected with RVF die of the disease. Case-fatality\nproportions are significantly higher for infected animals. The most\nsevere impact is observed in pregnant livestock infected with RVF,\nwhich results in abortion of virtually 100 percent of fetuses.\n\nThis rather confused report indicates that a single human case of RVF\nhas been confirmed in the Comoros, although this requires independent\nconfirmation, as the symptoms and severity of the disease are\nunusual. The patient has no known link with RVF endemic regions in\nEast Africa, therefore it has been inferred, but not yet established,\nthat the infection occurred by transmission from an infected animal\non the Comoros. Further information is awaited that would confirm\nthis extension of RVF beyond its presently known range. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Identification of RVF in the Comoros should not come as a surprise;\nit is in the Indian Ocean between the RVF-endemic territories of\nTanzania/Mozambique and northern Madagascar (map at\n<http://content.answers.com/main/content/wp/en/d/d9/Comoros_in_relation_to_Afrika_map.jpg>).\nTanzania suffered an RVF outbreak earlier in 2007; Madagascar is also\nknown to be endemically infected. In 1982, the Zinga virus,\nprevailing in Madagascar, was identified by the WHO Reference\nlaboratory for Arboviruses in Yale as RVF virus.\n\nAccording to unofficial assessments, the livestock population of the\nFederal Islamic Republic of Comores is as follows: cattle - 51 000;\ngoats - 115 000 - 170 000; sheep - 20 000. Imports of cattle from\nTanzania have been reported during recent years.\n\nReferences:\n\n1. WHO Weekly Epidemiological Record, 21 Jan 1983.\n\n2. Morvan J, Saluzzo JF, Fontenille D, Rollin PE, Coulanges P.\n(1991). Rift Valley fever on the east coast of Madagascar. Res Virol.\n142(6):475-482.\n\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Nov 2007\n However, in some patients, the\nillness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular disease (diseases\naffecting the eye). Cases reported in Khartoum state are not\nindigenous cases but were imported from one of the other affected\nstates. The most rapid increase in human cases has been seen in\nGazeera state, which now accounts for more than half of the human\ncases. The cases being reported in Gazeera state are in an area close\nto irrigation canals and are linked to naturally occurring cycles\ninvolving livestock and mosquitoes which are abundant in the\nirrigation zone.\n\nOn Sun 11 Nov 2007, the Sudanese Federal Ministry of Animal Resources\nand Fisheries reported to the Office International des Epizooties\n(OIE) that Rift Valley fever had been found on 29 Oct 2007 in samples\ntaken from animals in White Nile State. It is anticipated that\nfollowing this declaration, a well-integrated control program for\nlimiting the disease in both human and animal populations will now be\nimplemented.\n\nThe Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations has\ndeployed a senior animal health expert to the country to assist\nveterinary services with prevention and control measures in animals.\nThe Ministry of Health and the WHO Country Office have presented a\nplan for the prevention and control of the disease in humans to\ninternational donors in Khartoum. The WHO Eastern Mediterranean\nRegional Office and WHO headquarters are supporting the national\nresponse, mobilizing epidemiologists and working with partners to\nenhance national laboratory capacity for RVF.\n\nSocial mobilization activities are now underway to alert the local\npopulation to the human health risks associated with this disease in\nanimals. However, more intensive efforts are urgently needed using\nall locally available media -- including television and radio\nchannels -- as well as community and religious leaders to ensure that\nat-risk communities are fully aware of the measures that need to be\ntaken to reduce the risk of human infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Since the last WHO report on Thu 8 Nov 2007, the number of human\ncases has risen by 101 and the number of fatalities by 12. The WHO Eastern Mediterranean\nRegional Office and WHO headquarters are supporting the national\nresponse, mobilizing epidemiologists and working with partners to\nenhance national laboratory capacity for RVF.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sennar", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}, {"location": "Khartoum", "country": "Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36206", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Sudan (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36206", "date": "2007-11-10 18:00:12", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SUDAN (04)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 9 Nov 2007\nSource: FAO-EMPRES Web site [edited]\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/home.asp>\n\n\nFAO Statement on Rift Valley fever in Sudan\n--------------------------------------------\nRift Valley fever (RVF) outbreaks have been reported by WHO in humans\nin Sudan in White Nile, Sinnar, and Gezira states on 5 Nov 2007. RVF\nis a dangerous mosquito-borne zoonotic disease affecting ruminants\nand humans. People contract infection through mosquito bites or\ndirect contact with infected biological material and liquids such as\nblood during slaughtering or when handling animal abortions.\n\nWhile sometimes difficult to identify, usually RVF is already well\nestablished in animal populations by the time the 1st human cases are observed.\n\n'The source of RVF in animals needs to be identified and veterinary\ncontrol measures put in place in order to reduce the public health\nrisk, to limit the impact on livelihoods and to avoid further\nspread,' said J. Domenech, Chief Veterinary Officer of FAO. This is\nof particular importance during this time of the year given that\nmajor trade movements of ruminants are expected because of the\nupcoming Muslim religious events, the Hajj and Eid Al-Adha. [The Hajj\nbegins 18 Dec 2007; Eid Al-Adha is on 20 Dec 2007. - Mod.AS] He\nemphasized the importance of informing population groups at risk on\nmeasures that may be applied to protect people from becoming\ninfected. FAO closely monitors the developments and has offered\ntechnical assistance to Sudan to support animal disease investigation\nand animal management aspects.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unfortunately -- similarly to numerous past cases -- RVF has been\nagain detected by human rather than animal sentinels. And contrary to\nthe previous outbreak in Somalia, Kenya and Tanzania which began at\nthe end of 2006, the current outbreak has not been preceded by a\nwarning based upon climatic-ecological analyses.\n\nUp to now, no information (official or otherwise) from Sudan is\navailable on suspected clinical cases in animals (predominantly\nmass-abortions and offspring mortality). In addition to the grave\npublic health aspects, the disease may have devastating impact upon\nthe livestock industry and the livelihood of animal owners.\n\nRVF was initially recorded in Sudan in 1936 (antibodies in humans).\nAn extensive epizootic was described in 1973, accompanied by virus\nisolations from affected animals. 1973 is the year officially\nreported by Sudan's veterinary authorities as the last year of RVF\noccurrence. However, a limited epizootic was reported in 1976 (Ref.\nEisa et al., 1980. An outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the Sudan\n--1976. Trans.R. Soc. Trop. Med. Hyg. 74, 417-419). This epizootic\nwas later suspected to be a possible source of the major 1977-78 RVF\nepizootic/epidemic in Egypt (Ref. Gad et al., 1986. A possible route\nfor the introduction of Rift Valley fever virus into Egypt during\n1977. J Trop Med Hyg. 89(5):233-236). The authors concluded:\n'Reintroduction of RVF or other diseases from Sudan into Egypt will\nbe facilitated by the construction of new roads linking the two countries.'\n\nAn epizootic of RVF which occurred in Egypt between April and August\n1997 was also attributed to introduction from the Sudan (Ref. Abd\nel-Rahim et al., 1999. An epizootic of Rift Valley fever in Egypt in\n1997. Rev. Sci. Tech. OIE 18(3):741-748). The authors concluded:\n'Importation of infected ruminants, especially camels from the Sudan,\nis the principal source of infection. Aswan, the nearest Egyptian\nprovince to the Sudan, is the focus of RVF virus infection in Egypt.'\n\nThe epidemiology of RVF, including the possible role of animal\nmovements in its spread, has been subject to past discussions.\nSubscribers are referred to the commentaries of Peter Roeder in\n20070112.0164 and of Glyn Davies in 20070324.1024.\n\nFAO's Animal Health Manual No. 17 'Recognizing Rift Valley Fever'\n(2003) is available online at\n<ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/006/y4611E/y4611E00.pdf>. - Mod.AS]\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Sudan can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=13.8,30,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 9 Nov 2007\n This is\nof particular importance during this time of the year given that\nmajor trade movements of ruminants are expected because of the\nupcoming Muslim religious events, the Hajj and Eid Al-Adha. veterinary\ncontrol measures put in place in order to reduce the public health\nrisk, to limit the impact on livelihoods and to avoid further\nspread And contrary to\nthe previous outbreak in Somalia, Kenya and Tanzania which began at\nthe end of 2006, the current outbreak has not been preceded by a\nwarning based upon climatic-ecological analyses. But Sudan's minister\nfor animal resources said there were no clinical signs of the virus.\n\n'An investigation team conducted an epidemiological investigation and\nsurveillance and did not come across any clinical symptoms to\nindicate an epidemic of RVF disease,' minister Gutluak Deng told reporters.\n\nClinical signs usually show a high rate of abortions or deaths of\nyoung lambs. In animals other than sheep, however, the disease often\nshows no symptoms, according to the World Organisation for Animal\nHealth [OIE; see item 2 further, and commentary].\n\nThe minister said 329 samples had been taken from the suspected\ninfected area in White Nile state and had been sent to South Africa\nfor final tests. Results were expected in the next week.\n\nIn humans, at least 84 have died from almost 250 cases showing\nhaemorrhagic fevers in the White Nile, Sennar and Jazeera states.\n\nThe death rates in haemorrhagic cases, where patients bleed from the\nnose and ears and have bloody faeces and urine, can be as high as 50\npercent, the World Health Organisation [WHO] says.\n\nJournalists chided the ministers of health and animal resources for\nwaiting too long to confirm that the outbreak was Rift Valley Fever.\n\nWHO had said in mid-October 2007 it was investigating an epidemic of\nhaemorrhagic fever which had killed 30 people in Sudan and had\nconfirmed it as Rift Valley Fever on 2 Nov 2007.\n\nThe virus is transmitted by animals or mosquitoes to humans. There is\nno human to human transmission.\n\n[Byline: Opheera McDoom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 5 Nov 2007\nSource: OIE press release [edited]\n<http://oie.int/eng/press/en_071105.htm>\n\n\nThe World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) monitors the situation\ncaused by Rift Valley Fever outbreaks, which occurred over the last\nfew weeks in Africa, particularly in Sudan.\n\nThe OIE recalls the importance of the use of vaccination of\nsusceptible animals as a control measure. This recommendation of the\nOIE has been recently re-endorsed by the OIE national Delegates of\nAfrica and Middle East during the workshop on RVF held in Cairo\n(Egypt) on 13-15 Jun 2007.\n\nAnimal vaccination and, when possible, vector control need to be\napplied well in advance of expected risk periods for vector activity\nand occurrence of the disease.\n\nOutbreaks of RVF have a significant impact on the trade of ruminants,\nespecially from the Horn of Africa to the Middle East, with a\nconsequent significant loss of income for livestock owners in the\naffected areas and countries. By recommending the correct\nimplementation of standards and guidelines, the OIE stands for safe\ntrade and against unjustified sanitary barriers.\n\nShould countries at risk make the request, the OIE would be in favour\nof an appropriate animal vaccination campaign to be carried out in\nareas at risk with the support of the international community.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The media-derived statement that 'the disease often shows no\nsymptoms, according to the OIE' is unfounded; see the following from\nOIE's disease card on RVF:\n\nClinical diagnosis\n------------------\n1. Cattle\nCalves: fever (40-41 C), depression. Mortality rate: 10-70 percent\nAdults: fever (40-41 C), excessive salivation, anorexia, weakness,\nfetid diarrhoea, fall in milk yield. Abortion may reach 85 percent in\nthe herd. Mortality rate is usually less than 10 percent\n\n2. Sheep, goats and pigs\nLambs: fever (40-42 C), anorexia, weakness, death within 36 hours\nafter inoculation. Mortality rate: for animals under one week of age\n- up to 90 percent; for animals over one week of age - up to 20 percent.\n\nAdults: fever (40-41 C), mucopurulent nasal discharge, vomiting; in\npregnant ewes, abortion may reach 100 percent and mortality may reach\n20-30 percent.\n\nIn-apparent infections are quite frequent in other species than sheep.\n\nLesions\n-------\n-Focal or generalised hepatic necrosis (white necrotic foci of about\none mm in diameter)\n\n-Congestion, enlargement, and discoloration of liver with subcapsular\nhaemorrhages\n\n-Brown-yellowish colour of liver in aborted fetuses\n\n-Widespread cutaneous haemorrhages, petechial to ecchymotic\nhaemorrhages on parietal and visceral serosal membranes\n\n-Enlargement, oedema, haemorrhages and necrosis of lymph nodes\n\n-Congestion and cortical haemorrhages of kidneys and gallbladder\n\n-Haemorrhagic enteritis\n\n-Icterus (low percentage)\n\nDifferential diagnosis\n----------------------\nBluetongue\nWesselsbron disease\nEnterotoxemia of sheep\nEphemeral fever\nBrucellosis\nVibriosis\nTrichomonosis\nNairobi sheep disease\nHeartwater\nOvine enzootic abortion\nToxic plants\nBacterial septicaemias\nRinderpest and Peste des petits ruminants\n\nIntensified clinical surveillance and sampling in Sudan may expose\nthe missing link: disease in animals. Enhanced alertness in Sudan's\nneighbour countries, including Egypt, should be undertaken\nimmediately. The need is further underlined by the approaching\nregional ritual events, which include mass slaughter of domestic\nruminants, predominantly sheep, namely the Eid el Adha. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "-Focal or generalised hepatic necrosis (white necrotic foci of about\none mm in diameter)\n\n-Congestion, enlargement, and discoloration of liver with subcapsular\nhaemorrhages\n\n-Brown-yellowish colour of liver in aborted fetuses\n\n-Widespread cutaneous haemorrhages, petechial to ecchymotic\nhaemorrhages on parietal and visceral serosal membranes\n\n-Enlargement, oedema, haemorrhages and necrosis of lymph nodes\n\n-Congestion and cortical haemorrhages of kidneys and gallbladder\n\n-Haemorrhagic enteritis\n\n-Icterus (low percentage)\n\nDifferential diagnosis\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The media-derived statement that 'the disease often shows no\nsymptoms, according to the OIE' is unfounded; The toll was up from 60 deaths among\n125 people a week ago, according to the United Nations agency which\nhas been working with Sudan's health ministry since it sought help in\nOctober [2007].\n\nA total of 15 sites in White Nile, Sennar and Jazeera provinces in\ncentral and eastern Sudan are now affected by the disease, which is\ntransmitted by contact with the blood or organs of infected animals,\nthe WHO said in a statement. The Rift Valley fever virus can also be\ncarried by mosquitos. Herders, farmers, veterinarians and\nslaughterhouse workers are deemed at higher risk of infection from\nthe disease, which can devastate livestock.\n\nThere is no specific treatment or effective human vaccine, so it is\nimportant to raise awareness of risk factors and ensure people take\nprotective measures to prevent exposure, the WHO said. Gloves and\nother protective clothing should be worn when handling sick animals\nor their tissues or when slaughtering.\n\nAnimal products including blood, meat and milk should be thoroughly\ncooked before eating, it said. Humans should also sleep under\nmosquito nets and wear long-sleeved shirts and trousers to protect\nagainst bites. While most human cases are relatively mild, a small\npercentage of patients develop a much more severe haemorrhagic form\nwhich can cause them to vomit blood or pass it in their faeces.\nBleeding from the nose or gums can also occur. [Ocular disease has\nalso been a risk factor in some outbreaks of Rift Valley fever. - Mod.CP]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The death toll in the Rift Valley fever outbreak along the Nile\nvalley in central Sudan is now 84, having increased by 24 since the\nprevious WHO report. The United Nations health agency said 2 weeks ago that it was\ninvestigating a deadly outbreak in Sudan suspected to be yellow fever [see:\nProMED-mail post 'Yellow fever - Sudan: susp., RFI 20071020.3419'], but\nlaboratory tests have shown it was Rift Valley fever, WHO spokesman John\nRainford said.\n\n'There are 125 human cases and 60 deaths,' he told Reuters. More\ninvestigation was needed into the outbreak, which had erupted in White\nNile, Sennar, and Jazeera provinces in central and eastern Sudan, including\nthe exact timing of the first cases, Rainford said. 'Right now we don't\nhave a clear picture.' [A map of Sudan and its constituent provinces can be\naccessed at <http://www.rightsmaps.com/html/sudmap1.html>. - Mod.CP]\n\nRift Valley fever virus, transmitted by contact with the blood or organs of\ninfected animals, can also be carried by mosquitoes, according to the WHO.\nHerders, farmers, veterinarians and slaughterhouse workers are deemed at\nhigher risk of infection from the disease, which can devastate livestock.\n\nWhile most human cases are relatively mild, a small percentage of patients\ndevelop a much more severe haemorrhagic form which can cause them to vomit\nblood or pass it in their faeces. Bleeding from the nose or gums can also\noccur.\n\nThe nearly 50 per cent fatality rate was 'very high' compared to the usual\nexpectations for Rift Valley fever, but it was likely that many more mild\ncases have not been detected in Sudan, according to Rainford. 'The Sudanese\ngovernment has been highly cooperative and transparent in sharing\ninformation,' Rainford said. WHO officials were in the area of the outbreak\nand the United States Naval Medical Research Unit NAMRU-3 laboratory in\nCairo had helped with the laboratory analysis, he added.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rift Valley fever virus is a member of the genus _Phlebovirus_ (family\n_Bunyaviridae_). The virus was 1st identified in 1931 during an\ninvestigation into an epidemic among sheep on a farm in the Rift Valley of\nKenya. Since then, outbreaks have been reported in sub-Saharan and North\nAfrica. In 1997-98, a major outbreak occurred in Kenya, Somalia, and\nTanzania and again in September 2000, and more recently mainly affecting\nlivestock in 2006/2007, Rift Valley fever cases have been confirmed also in\nSaudi Arabia and Yemen (see references below), being the first reported\noccurrence of the disease outside the African continent. A map of the\ndistribution of endemic and sporadic Rift valley fever can be accessed at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf/rvfmap.htm>.\n\nThe vast majority of human infections result from direct or indirect\ncontact with the blood or organs of infected animals. The virus can be\ntransmitted to humans through the handling of animal tissue during\nslaughtering or butchering, assisting with animal births, conducting\nveterinary procedures, or from the disposal of carcasses or fetuses.\nCertain occupational groups such as herders, farmers, slaughterhouse\nworkers and veterinarians are therefore at higher risk of infection. The\nvirus infects humans through inoculation, for example via a wound from an\ninfected knife or through contact with broken skin, or through inhalation\nof aerosols produced during the slaughter of infected animals. The aerosol\nmode of transmission has also led to infection in laboratory workers. There\nis some evidence that humans may also become infected with Rift Valley\nfever by ingesting the unpasteurized or uncooked milk of infected animals.\n\nHuman infections have also resulted from the bites of infected mosquitoes,\nmost commonly the _Aedes_ mosquito. Transmission of Rift Valley fever virus\nby hematophagous (blood-feeding) flies is also possible. To date, no\nhuman-to-human transmission of Rift Valley fever has been documented.\n\nIllness in humans is usually mild. However, in some patients the illness\ncan progress to hemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or hemorrhage),\nencephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead to headaches, coma,\nor seizures), or ocular disease (diseases affecting the eye).\n\nThe interactive HealthNet map of Sudan is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=13.8,30,5>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 2 Nov 2007\n The United Nations health agency said 2 weeks ago that it was\ninvestigating a deadly outbreak in Sudan suspected to be yellow fever [see:\nProMED-mail post 'Yellow fever - Sudan: susp., RFI 20071020.3419'], but\nlaboratory tests have shown it was Rift Valley fever, WHO spokesman John\nRainford said. Transmitted to humans by\nmosquito bites or close contact with contaminated animals, Rift Valley\nfever can cause havoc in Kenya's important meat trade.\nThe movement of livestock was temporarily halted earlier this year [2007]\nwhen the 1st outbreak spread from Kenya to Somalia and Tanzania, killing\nmore than 100 people in each country. In severe cases, the disease triggers\nhaemorrhaging in humans, causing the victim to vomit blood or bleed to\ndeath. Outbreaks of the fever, named after the vast fissure running from\nSyria down to Mozambique, are thought to be cyclical. He said no new\ncases have been reported.\n'There are no new reports of people suffering from similar symptoms as the\ndeceased,' Odondi said. 'We were informed by local farmers\nabout strange symptoms appearing among sheep and cattle near\nNassiriyah,' said Mandhor Rayhan, a spokesman for Dhi Qar provincial\ncouncil. 'A veterinary doctor who examined the animals suggested they\nshould be laboratory tested for Rift valley fever, and the suspected\ndiagnosis was confirmed in at least 4 animals.' [A map of Nassiriyah\ncan be seen at <http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IZ/9/An_Nasiriyah.html>].\nThe Nassiriyah medical laboratory chief, Abdel-Rayy Muhammad, said\nthe samples confirmed as positive were being rechecked at the\nNational Baghdad Laboratory over the next 48 hours. 'A recent phone\ncall from a senior official in the National Laboratory said there was\npossible confirmation of one case, but other samples were waiting to\nbe tested,' he said.\nFayad Sulaiman, a senior official in the Ministry of Agriculture in\nBaghdad, told IRIN a group of specialists were on their way to Dhi\nQar to evaluate the situation. 'We are retesting again, but, as a\nprecaution, we have sent some specialists to Nassiriyah. ... We hope\nit is an isolated case,' Sulaiman said.\n'Some vaccines have been sent to Dhi Qar Governorate this morning,\nand we have contacted companies to get more supplies, which should\narrive within a couple of days,' he added. 'We are seriously\nconcerned about the possibility that the disease might spread,' Dhi\nQar provincial council spokesman Rayhan said, adding that affected\nlivestock farmers have been asked to confine their animals within a 2\nsq km area until more specialised laboratory tests can be carried out\nin Baghdad.\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), RVF affects\nlivestock (including cattle, buffalo, sheep, goats and camels) as\nwell as humans. The disease mostly appears in Africa.\nPeople get RVF mainly from infected mosquitoes, which act as vectors.\nThe disease can also be spread by contact with the blood or body\nfluids of an infected animal. 'Our concern is that with the situation\nas it is in Iraq -- with increased poverty, displacement and pools of\nstagnant water -- people might get infected by mosquito bites,' said Rayhan.\nKhalid Idris, a veterinary specialist in Nassiriyah who has been\ndealing with the problem, told IRIN that livestock in the\ncontaminated farms must be vaccinated as a matter of urgency. 'All\nsheep, cattle and buffalo in herds within the infected area should be\nvaccinated immediately with an inactivated RVF vaccine and\nrevaccinated after 2 to 4 weeks. But these vaccines have not been\navailable in Iraq since before the US-led invasion in 2003,' Idris said.\nThe UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said it had not\nreceived any details of the outbreak but that it was in touch with\nthe Ministry of Agriculture.\nIn July 2001, the FAO said RVF had been detected among livestock in\nYemen and Saudi Arabia and warned of the possibility of the disease\nspreading into Iraq. No case was confirmed then, but, since that\ntime, farmers have been advised to vaccinate their livestock\nperiodically, a procedure that, according to Idris, has not taken\nplace in Dhi Qar since February 2002. 'We are urging international\norganisations and the central government to find quick solutions to\nthe problem,' Idris said.\nThe RVF virus can cause several different syndromes. People who are\ninfected with RVF either show no symptoms or develop a mild fever and\nliver abnormalities. However, in some patients, the illness can\nprogress to haemorrhagic fever (which can lead to shock or\nhaemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the brain, which can lead\nto headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular diseases.\nPatients who become ill usually experience fever, generalised\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset\nof the illness. Normally, RVF patients recover within 2 days to one\nweek after catching the illness.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nOtavio da Silva <otavio_uff104@yahoo.com.br>\n[In the absence of details on the symptoms allegedly observed in the\ncattle and sheep, and of the diagnostic tests applied and their\nspecificity, it is difficult to assess the significance of the above\nsuspicions. In previous RVF cases in the Middle East, cases in humans\npreceded the reporting of animal disease.\nRVF has never been diagnosed in Iraq; the only countries in the Near\nEast which have been affected by RVF in the past are Egypt, Yemen and\nSaudi Arabia. During the late 1970's, RVF was reportedly suspected in\nEgyptian laborers residing in Iraq, but their eventual diagnosis was\nCongo-Crimean Haemorrhagic fever.\nThe clinical signs of RVF in animals vary with the age, species and\nbreed of the animal. In endemic regions, epidemics of Rift Valley\nfever can be recognized by high mortality rates in newborn animals\nand abortions in adults. In lambs, a biphasic fever, anorexia and\nlymphadenopathy may be followed by weakness and death within 36\nhours. Hemorrhagic diarrhea or abdominal pain can also be seen. The\nyoungest animals are most severely affected. In neonates, the\nmortality rate may reach 90 to 100 percent. However, no ovine\nneonates are expected yet in southern Iraq, where lambing is\nanticipated to commence not earlier than the end November 2007.\nSimilar symptoms occur in young calves: fever, anorexia and\ndepression are typical, with mortality rates of 10 to 70 percent.\nAbortions are the most characteristic sign in adult sheep and cattle.\nOther symptoms that may occur in adult sheep include fever, weakness,\na mucopurulent nasal discharge (sometimes bloodstained), melena,\nhemorrhagic or foul-smelling diarrhea, and vomiting. In adult cattle,\nfever, anorexia, weakness, excessive salivation, fetid diarrhea and\ndecreased milk production have been reported. Icterus may also be\nseen, particularly in cattle.\nSimilar but milder infections occur in goats. Adult camels do not\ndevelop symptoms other than abortion, but young animals may have more\nsevere disease.\nFor further details, see\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/rift_valley_fever.pdf>.\nAn extensive epizootic of RVF spread earlier this year [2007] in\neastern Africa and the Horn of Africa.\nFurther details, particularly confirmation (or otherwise) of the\ndiagnosis by a reference laboratory, are soon anticipated. Then OIE\nreference laboratory for RVF is the Onderstepoort Veterinary\nInstitute in South Africa. The NAMRU-3 laboratory in Cairo has been\nhelpful in the early diagnosis of outbreaks in the region. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "We are seriously\nconcerned about the possibility that the disease might spread,' Dhi\nQar provincial council spokesman Rayhan said, adding that affected\nlivestock farmers have been asked to confine their animals within a 2\nsq km area until more specialised laboratory tests can be carried out\nin Baghdad.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: IRIN, Middle East News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=74740>\n\nLocal authorities in Nassiriyah, a town about 300 km south of\nBaghdad, have asked livestock farmers to take all necessary\nprecautions after laboratory tests showed that some livestock had\ndeveloped Rift valley fever (RVF). A report issued yesterday [14 May\n2007] by Dodoma Regional Medical Officer Dr Frida Mokiti showed a\nsteady decline in RVF infections.\nThe death toll caused by RVF reached 55 since the disease erupted in\nthe region in early February this year [2007]. Until yesterday [14\nMay 2007] evening, the Regional Hospital had only 15 RVF patients.\nMirembe hospital, which had 18 patients 2 weeks ago, had only 5\nyesterday. Mvumi Mission Hospital, which had 2 patients last week,\nhad only one yesterday.\nMpwapwa District Hospital is still grappling with the single RVF case\nit had last week. Kondoa District Hospital has no RVF patient at the\nmoment after treating and discharging its 2 cases 2 weeks ago. Kongwa\nstill has its single patient, who was admitted a couple of weeks ago.\nHaneti and Mtitaa dispensaries in Bahi district have successfully\ntreated and discharged their patients. Two weeks ago, Haneti had 3\nRVF cases and Mtitaa had one. So far, a total of 42 patients have\nbeen treated in various hospitals in the region and discharged.\nThe regional RVF report shows that since 1 Feb 2007, medical\nfacilities in the region have handled 120 RVF cases. The Regional\nhospital has handled 70 cases, Mirembe Hospital (25), Kondoa (6),\nMpwapwa (6), Mvumi (5), Kongwa (4), Haneti (3), and Mtitaa (1).\nMedical experts said the decrease was an indication that new\ninfections are fewer now and that the disease is likely to taper off\nand disappear in a month or 2. Out of the 23 who were in hospital\nbeds yesterday [14 May 2007], only 15 have been proved positive for\nthe virus. Ten of them are in the Regional Hospital.\nMeanwhile, the region still faces a shortage of anti-Rift Valley\nfever cattle vaccines following a massive response by livestock\nkeepers who drive their herds to vaccination centers daily only to\nrealize that there are not enough jabs to go around. The response has\nalso posed a challenge to the region, which has only a few veterinary\nofficers in rural areas. The region also faces a crippling shortage\nof transport facilities for officials and veterinary officers.\nVeterinary service tools and materials are also short.\n[Byline: Sosthenes Mwita]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. The PM said\nsome 249 people had contracted the disease since it was 1st reported\nin the country in January this year [2007]. He said 73 patients had\nbeen treated and discharged, while 87 remain in hospital. The PM said\nDodoma was the most affected region, with 55 people still being\nadmitted to hospital.\nHe said 46 600 cows, 56 900 goats and 32 800 sheep had been affected\nby the disease. He said 5580 cows, 6866 goats and 3898 sheep had died\nof the disease.\nThe PM said 1 620 000 doses of vaccine had been received so far and\ndistributed to 37 districts. A total of TZS 1.7 billion [USD 1.3\nmillion] has been spent for the purpose. RFV was reported in 10 out of the 21 regions of Tanzania: 12\ncases were reported in Arusha region, 1 in Dar es Salaam, 156 in Dodoma, 4\nin Iringa, 6 in Manyara, 50 in Morogoro, 5 in Mwanza, 5 in the Pwani, 24 in\nSingida, and 1 in Tanga regions. Only severe cases of RVF were detected\nthrough surveillance and of the 264 cases, 154 (60 per cent) were\nlaboratory confirmed.\nThe surveillance of RVF organized through the Integrated Disease\nSurveillance and Response (IDSR) program has been in place in Tanzania for\nseveral years. To investigate this outbreak a WHO team from the Department\nof Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response and the Regional Office for\nAfrica has been assisting the WHO Country Office in the assessment of the\noutbreak and in refining the health component of the Tanzania Ministry of\nHealth and Social Welfare (TMOHSW) and the Tanzania Ministry of Livestock\nDevelopment (TMOLD) emergency response plan, including the early warning\nsystem, active case detection, case management and social mobilization.\nA national investigation team conducted several field visits in the\naffected region to help with enhancement of surveillance, in-depth case\ninvestigations, and active surveillance activities. The team also provided\ntraining in patient care for clinical staff and in safe sample collection\nand shipment for laboratory staff. The response to the outbreak was jointly\norganized by the Tanzania Ministry of Health and Social Welfare (TMOHSW)\nand the Tanzania Ministry of Livestock Development (TMOLD) in collaboration\nwith the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI), the Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention, WHO, and FAO. The United Nations Emergency\nCoordination Group of UNDP, WHO, FAO, UNICEF and WFP have also outlined\nresponse plans in support of the Government strategy.\nThese programmes include animal and human health interventions as well as\nsensitization and awareness campaigns at community level and among health\ncare professions.\nKenya\n-----\nFrom 30 Nov 2006 to 12 Mar 2007, a total of 684 cases including 155 deaths\n(CFR 23 per cent) of RVF were reported in Kenya. Where all 333 cases were\nreported in North Eastern Province, 183 in Rift Valley Province, 141 in the\nCoast Province, 14 in Central Province, and 13 in the Eastern Province. Of\nthe 684 reported cases, 234 (34 per cent) were laboratory confirmed.\nSomalia\n-------\nFrom 19 Dec 2006 to 20 Feb 2007, a total of 114 cases including 51 deaths\n(CFR 45 per cent) of Rift Valley fever were reported in Somalia. A total of\n73 cases were reported in Lower Juba region, 26 in Gedo region, 7 cases in\nHiran region, 2 cases in Middle Juba region, 4 cases in Middle Shabelle\nregion, and 1 case in Lower Shabelle region. Of the 114 reported cases, 3\n(3 per cent) were laboratory confirmed. During the outbreak response, the\ndifficult security situation has continuously hampered surveillance and\ncontrol activities in the affected areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteurs Marianne Hopp and A-Lan Banks\n[A detailed map of the three East African countries and the\nprovinces/districts affected by Rift Valley fever can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/RVF2007050.jpg>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "To investigate this outbreak a WHO team from the Department\nof Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response and the Regional Office for\nAfrica has been assisting the WHO Country Office in the assessment of the\noutbreak and in refining the health component of the Tanzania Ministry of\nHealth and Social Welfare (TMOHSW) and the Tanzania Ministry of Livestock\nDevelopment (TMOLD) emergency response plan, including the early warning\nsystem, active case detection, case management and social mobilization. "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (26): KENYA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703271150.html>\n\nKenya: 5 More Die of Rift Valley Fever\n-----------------------------------------\n5 people have died of complications associated with Rift Valley fever\n(RVF) in North Eastern Province, a doctor said yesterday [27 Mar\n2007]. Provincial medical officer of health Ahmed Omar told\njournalists in his office that the 5 contracted the highly contagious\nviral disease last December [2006]. They were treated and discharged\nbut died of post-recovery and treatment complications in Garissa and\nIjara districts.\nHe also warned that the fever could reemerge in the region with the\nonset of long rains, which have pounded parts of Ijara in the last 2\nweeks. According to Dr. Omar, the 5 died after developing\nmeningo-encephalitis, a condition linked to post-recovery, a nervous\nsystem and brain disorder that attacks those who had contracted RVF\nbut were discharged after recovery.\nA surveillance medical team that visited parts of Garissa and Ijara\ndistricts last week found 3 of the victims had died in the Liboi and\nFafi areas of Garissa. They had, in December [2006], been admitted to\nthe isolation unit of Garissa Hospital after testing positive for\nRVF; 2 of the victims were women, while the 3rd was an 18-year-old\nherdsman. The other 2 who died in Ijara had previously been admitted\nto Masalani health centre in January 2007. The 2 herdsmen are said to\nhave died on their way to seek medical attention at Masalani district hospital.\nDr. Omar also said the medical team had further found several cases\nof blindness among patients who were discharged from hospital between\nDecember 2006 and January 2007. He asked those who had been\ndischarged from various health centers to report back to hospital\nshould they show post-recovery complications. According to the\ndoctor, 354 people infected at the height of the fever outbreak\nrecovered, while 106 died in Garissa, Ijara and Wajir, which had been\nthe epicenter of the disease before it spread to other parts of the country.\nMost of those affected by the fever, which mainly affects livestock\nbut spreads to humans through mosquito bites, were herdsmen. Their\ninfections were attributed to their close contact with infected animals.\nAccording to Dr. Omar, flooding could fuel a resurgence of the fever\nbecause the _Aedes_ mosquitoes -- which transmit the fever -- get the\nvirus after feeding on infected animals. They then transmit the virus\nto their eggs, and new generations of infected mosquitoes may hatch\nfrom such eggs. The eggs hatch during heavy rains, leading to an\nincrease in the number of mosquitoes.\n[Byline: Hussein Abdullahi]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Kenya showing some of the locations mentioned above is accessible at\n<http://www.masai-mara.com/mmvmk.htm>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Hussein Abdullahi]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n According to Dr. Omar, the 5 died after developing\nmeningo-encephalitis, a condition linked to post-recovery, a nervous\nsystem and brain disorder that attacks those who had contracted RVF\nbut were discharged after recovery. He made the revelation\nin remarks on his recent tour of health facilities across the region\nto assess the magnitude of the epidemic, which has claimed a national\ntotal of 33 lives. The RC was addressing a meeting of guest house and\nhotel owners here on Tuesday [10 Apr 2007], amid reports that the\ndeadly viral disease was digging in.\nDodoma is the region worst hit by the RVF outbreak, and Lukuvi\nappealed to government officials, business people, owners of guest\nhouses and members of the public to step up measures to help prevent\nthe spread of the disease. 'We cannot enjoy ourselves while our\nvoters are suffering. We have to relieve them of the problem,'\nobserved the RC, his appeal coming at a time when the National\nAssembly is ending the 1st half of its ordinary 2-week meeting here.\nGiving what he said were the latest figures, Lukuvi said the region\nhas 56 RVF patients admitted to health facilities, adding: 'The\nsituation is critical. Some patients have been confined to hospital\nbeds for months but still show few signs of getting better.' The RC\nexplained that most patients are unconscious, some having been in bed\nfor over 2 months, noting, 'Medical officers and other staff are\ndoing what best they can do to arrest the situation but things remain\nbad indeed. Those religious leaders endowed with God's healing powers\nshould pray for those (RVF) patients who have lost the ability to\npray for themselves.'\nMeanwhile, Lukuvi used the occasion to order authorities in the\nregion to arrest anyone found eating meat that veterinary experts\nhave not screened and passed as fit for human consumption. There have\nbeen reports of some bars and restaurants here selling roast meat\ndespite a government ban and countrywide public education campaign\nmeant to alert wananchi ['citizen' in Swahili] against such behavior.\nRVF is an acute, fever-causing viral disease that affects both\nlivestock and humans. It hit parts of northern Tanzania in February\n[2007] after filtering in from Kenya, leading to human and animal\ndeaths and threatening the livelihood of pastoralist communities in\nboth countries. The Nairobi (Kenya)-based Centre for Disease Control\nconfirmed the presence of RVF in Tanzania on 1 Feb 2007after testing\nsamples collected by the Livestock Development Ministry in Arusha.\nAbortions feared to be RVF-induced have been reported among livestock\nherds in Kilosa, Tarime, Monduli and Simanjiro districts.\nJoint response and control measures are overseen and coordinated by\nthe Livestock Development and Health and Social Welfare ministries,\nlocal governments and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs). However,\nquarantines and livestock deaths threaten to prevent pastoralists\nfrom benefiting from the ongoing rains and the resultant good pasture\nconditions.\nThe government is planning to spend an estimated 15bn/- [USD 11 888\n250] fighting RVF and 1.7bn/- [USD 1 347 335] has already been spent\non ordering vaccines from abroad, Prime Minister Edward Lowassa and\nLivestock Development minister Anthony Diallo said recently. As of 31\nMar this year [2007], 200 441 head of cattle, 81 945 goats and 37 773\nsheep had showed RVF symptoms around the country. Reports released a\nfew weeks after the outbreak said 568 head of cattle, 1063 goats and\n434 sheep had died after developing symptoms similar to those of RVF.\n(Byline: Privatus Lipili)\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 14 Apr 2007\nFrom: 'Joseph Dudley' <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: Daily News, Dodoma, Sat 14 Apr 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.dailynews-tsn.com/page.php?id=6385>\n\nTanzania: Vice-president commends Rift Valley fever efforts\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nVice-president Dr. Ali Mohammed Shein has commended efforts to\ncontain Rift Valley fever (RVF) in the Dodoma region. Dr. Shein made\nthe remarks yesterday [Fri 13 Apr 2007] when he visited Dodoma\nRegional Hospital where he had gone to see RVF patients who are being\ntreated there.\nThe Dodoma Regional Commissioner, Mr. William Lukuvi, said here\nyesterday that among the measures being taken include sensitising the\npublic about the disease and possible ways of fighting it. Briefing\nthe vice-president, Mr. Lukuvi further said that they have already\nsupplied [livestock] vaccination doses to districts; they are\nsupervising bathing of livestock, destroying mosquito breeding\ngrounds and enhancing efforts to keep the city clean.\nThe measures, he said, have proved successful as the number of\npatients has been declining and until yesterday [13 Apr 2007]only one\nperson is reported to have been taken to the regional hospital. 'The\nnumber of patients that are continuing with treatment in several\nhealth centres stands at 53 out now,' he said. Since the outbreak of\nthe disease in the region, there have been 115 patients out of whom\n37 died and 25 were treated and discharged, he said.\nHe thanked the prime minister's office for extending 300m/- [USD 237\n765] to the region which will assist in the fight against the disease\nand accelerate the implementation of strategies of containing the disease.\nHe also thanked the Tanzania Red Cross Society for sponsoring the\ntraining of 56 villagers who will sensitise their communities and for\nalso handing out 200 mosquito nets and blankets.\n--\nJoseph P.
