We have to relieve them of the problem,'\nobserved the RC, his appeal coming at a time when the National\nAssembly is ending the 1st half of its ordinary 2-week meeting here.\n However,\nquarantines and livestock deaths threaten to prevent pastoralists\nfrom benefiting from the ongoing rains and the resultant good pasture\nconditions. He also thanked the Tanzania Red Cross Society for sponsoring the\ntraining of 56 villagers who will sensitise their communities and for\nalso handing out 200 mosquito nets and blankets.\n Since the outbreak of\nthe disease in the region, there have been 115 patients out of whom\n37 died and 25 were treated and discharged, he said. Giving what he said were the latest figures, Lukuvi said the region\nhas 56 RVF patients admitted to health facilities, adding: 'The\nsituation is critical. By contrast the 2nd report states that of 115\npatients treated, 37 had died, 25 had been discharged and 53 remained\nunder treatment, making the case fatality rate (CFR) The measures, he said, have proved successful as the number of\npatients has been declining and until yesterday [13 Apr 2007]only one\nperson is reported to have been taken to the regional hospital. ' The\nnumber of patients that are continuing with treatment in several\nhealth centres stands at 53 out now,' he said. Many of the Rift Valley fever (RVF) patients admitted to hospitals\nand health centres here are in critical condition, Dodoma Regional\nCommissioner (RC) William Lukuvi has revealed. The Dodoma Regional Commissioner, Mr. William Lukuvi, said here\nyesterday that among the measures being taken include sensitising the\npublic about the disease and possible ways of fighting it. At least 41 people are still\nreceiving treatment in hospitals in Tanzania after showing symptoms of RVF.\n'The disease was first reported in Arusha and has not [now?] spread\nto Dodoma where we are recording many new cases,' Mwakyusa said,\naccording to BBC News.\nVeterinary officials in Kenya said the ongoing domestic animal\nvaccination campaign could be the cause of the rampant spread of RVF.\nThe RVF virus is transferred to humans from livestock through the\n_Aedes_ mosquito, a species originally found in tropical and\nsubtropical zones. A response team from the Tanzanian\nMinistry of Health, WHO (World Health Organisation) Country Office,\nWHO Regional Office for Africa, and the U.S. Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention (CDC) carried out an initial investigation,\nincluding active case finding and specimen collection. The\nWHO-accredited Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) laboratory\nconfirmed 2 cases from Arusha and Tanga. By mid-February 2007, 8\ncases were reported: 4 fatal cases were confirmed by KEMRI, while the\nremaining 4 cases from Arusha, Mangara, and Tanga were hospitalized.\nThe United Nations Emergency Coordination Group of WHO, FAO (United\nNations Food and Agriculture Organisation), UNICEF (United Nations\nChildren Fund), and WFP (United Nations World Food Programme) has\nbeen providing support to the Tanzanian Ministry of Health and the\nMinistry of Livestock. In addition to continued technical and\nfinancial support, WHO has also provided training in patient care for\nclinical staff and in diagnostic techniques for laboratory staff.\nWith UNICEF, WHO has also trained journalists and other media staff\nto increase public awareness about the disease and how to prevent it.\nIn mid-March [2007], new clusters of RVF cases occurred. Fifty-eight\nsuspected cases, including 14 deaths, with 8 specimens confirmed\npositive were reported from Dodoma region. In addition, 60 new\nsuspected cases were reported from Morogoro region.\nWHO is concerned about the recent increase in human cases. It is\nparticularly important to increase community awareness as well as to\nimprove the coordination with veterinary services to contain the\noutbreak. A WHO outbreak response team from the Department of\nEpidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) and the Regional\nOffice for Africa will be assisting the WHO Country Office in the\nassessment of the outbreak, including the cases in Dodoma and\nMorogoro, and refining the health component of the emergency response\nplan, including the early warning system, active case detection, case\nmanagement, and social mobilization.\nFor more information see the WHO fact sheet on Rift Valley fever at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs207/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Tanzania showing the location of the Dodoma and Morogoro\nregions, in the centre of the country, can be viewed at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>. - Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 23 Mar 2007\nFrom: F. Glyn Davies <fgdvirus@compuserve.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (23): Tanzania\n(Dodoma) 20070320.0983, included the following information:\n'Veterinary officials in Kenya said the ongoing domestic animal\nvaccination campaign could be the cause of the rampant spread of RVF'.\nSubsequently, we approached Prof Glyn Davies, a world authority on\nRVF, for advise regarding the above concerns and about the evolvement\nof the outbreak in Tanzania; we are very grateful for Glyn's\nfollowing authoritative commentary. - Mod.AS]\nRVF virus has not spread to Dodoma and Morogoro regions from Kenya.\nIt has been known to be enzootic there for many years, and the data\nis recorded in the Tanzanian Veterinary Department annual reports and\nvarious publications. It would have emerged and virus activity would\nhave been occurring following the excessive rainfall and flooding in\nthe region late in 2006.\nThere appears to be a lack of awareness of the basic natural history\nof the RVF virus. It is transovarially transmitted in floodwater\nbreeding _Aedes_ mosquitoes. The virus emerges and amplification will\noccur with successive cycles of transmission. Factors affecting this\nare the persistence of the flooding and the generation of huge\npopulations of mosquito species breeding in the floodwater, which are\ncapable of secondary transmission of the virus. Many _Aedes_,\n_Culex_, and other mosquito species can do this. The amplification\ncycles will involve the indigenous ruminant populations as feeding\nhosts, most of which would be unlikely to manifest any clinical signs\nof disease. The length of the acute epidemic curve will depend on the\npersistence of the floodwater but is usually of only 3-4 months\nduration(*), with some cases lasting for 2-4 more months.\nIndigenous sheep, goats, and zebu-type [_Bos indicus_] cattle are\nrelatively resistant to RVF infection. During this period, clinical\ndisease in man might be the 1st indication of any RVF virus activity.\nRVF disease might also be seen in exotic breeds of cattle and sheep\nor goats and their crosses; they would abort and young animals may\nshow clinical signs of disease. These may not be present in many RVF\nenzootic areas in Africa. Without these indicator disease hosts, the\nRVF virus activity would be cryptic.\nThe current epizootic in eastern Africa appears to be following the\nexpected time scale. There may have been alterations to the curve,\nwhich have followed the effective transmission of virulent RVF virus\ncaused by the widespread vaccination programmes. These may have\ninvolved hundreds of thousands of animals, which would not have been\notherwise affected.\nVaccination with the Smithburn MLVV (modified live virus vaccine)\nstrain (**) or any other vaccine is totally contraindicated at any\ntime when active virus transmission is taking place.\nIt was for this reason that we developed early warning strategies, to\nidentify the pre epizootic conditions for RVF (see my various\nreferences) and allow for pre epizootic vaccination programmes to be\ncarried out before the disease occurs. FAO/EMPRES (Emergency\nPrevention System) division in Rome used the predictive model\ndeveloped in Kenya, and predicted this epizootic long before it\noccurred (August-September 2006, I believe).\nVaccination of animal populations during periods when RVF virus is\nactively being transmitted by vectors, will serve to propagate the\nvirus very effectively by needle passage. The virus is readily\ntransmitted by infected needles from animal to animal. The apparent\nincrease in cases in the Dodoma region is likely to be due to this.\nThe information from our Predictive Models to provide Early Warning\nof Epizootic RVF virus activity and to drive Emergency Preparedness\nhas been our objective.\n(*) This is the time period in the flood plains of North-Eastern\nKenya and Somalia. It may recur, sporadically, for around 18 months-2\nyears after the rains in the highlands and coastal areas of eastern Africa.\n(**) The vaccine is cheap and easy to produce but causes problems in\nsusceptible sheep breeds (abortions and foetal abnormalities in\naround 10 percent). It is safe in cattle and non-pregnant animals.\n--\nF. Glyn Davies MA. PhD (Cantab) MB Vet. MRCVS\n<fgdvirus@compuserve.com>\n[Besides the specific hazards related to the use of the Smithburn\nvaccine, special attention should be paid to Dr Davies' warning\nagainst any mass application of injection needles in ruminants during\nRVF epizootics. His remarks about the possible negative impact of the\n(belated) vaccinations upon animal health, with subsequent enhanced\ndissemination of the RVF virus, fall in line with the timeline of\nevents as recorded. According to official information, the RVF\noutbreak in Tanzania started on 18 Jan 2007, while the 1st batch of\nvaccines arrived (from South Africa) on 2 Mar 2007, followed by mass\nvaccinations (see ProMED-mail posting Rift Valley fever - Eastern\nAfrica (20): wildlife, not 20070305.0777).\nAdditional background information can be found in an earlier\ncommentary by Peter Roeder, FAO (see ProMED-mail posting Rift valley\nfever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya 20070112.0164).\nA detailed, useful review of RVF in humans and animals, including\naccumulated data on its epidemiology, is available at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/AGAinfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/rvf.html>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A WHO outbreak response team from the Department of\nEpidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) and the Regional\nOffice for Africa will be assisting the WHO Country Office in the\nassessment of the outbreak, including the cases in Dodoma and\nMorogoro, and refining the health component of the emergency response\nplan, including the early warning system, active case detection, case\nmanagement, and social mobilization. These deaths and suspected cases\nare scattered in the country's Arusha, Dodoma, Manyara, and Tanga\nregions, 3 of them being in the north and one in the middle. The\nArusha region was the 1st in Tanzania to have reported RVF-caused\ndeaths in early February [2007], after 2 people were found dead on 31\nJan 2007 in the region.\nIn 1998, [there was an outbreak of] Rift Valley fever in Arusha\nfollowing a similar outbreak in Kenya and the disease killed at least\n10 people in Tanzania between January and March that year.\nRift Valley fever, most common during years of heavy rainfalls, is a\nviral disease that affects mainly animals such as cattle, buffalo,\nsheep, and goats. But it can also affect humans. People contract RVF\nmainly from bites of infected mosquitoes and the disease can also be\nspread through direct contact with the blood or body fluids of an\ninfected animal. RVF can cause serious eye infection, inflammation of\nthe brain, severe bleeding (hemorrhage) and death.\n--\nJoseph P. According to Zawadiel Mchome, the Dodoma Regional\nAdministrative Secretary, Tanzanian authorities had already put the\nBahi and Chamwino districts under livestock quarantine. The 10\n[deaths occurred] in the past month, he said [as he opened] a 2-day\nworkshop for stakeholders in the war against HIV/Aids in the Dodoma\nregion.\nMr Mchome has been the 1st regional official to confirm the existence\nof the fatal disease (RVF) after efforts by journalists to [obtain\ninformation about it] from other regional authorities failed. 'We\nhave lost a number of people without knowing exactly what was behind\ntheir deaths, until recently when we [established that] it was the\ndeadly RVF,' he said. However, he could not reveal the names of the\ndeceased or their places of origin.\nOn the other hand, the Dodoma regional veterinary officer, Dr Samson\nMwanuko, said Bahi and Chamwino have been confirmed to have the\ndisease. Without releasing statistics, Dr Mwanuko said the 2\ndistricts have been under quarantine since last Monday [12 Mar 2007].\n[Byline: Lucas Lukumbo]\n--\nJoseph P. ' Source: allAfrica.com, The Nation (Nairobi) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200703141208.html>\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF) has struck the Dodoma region of Tanzania\nkilling 10 people. \nRift Valley fever - Tanzania (04): correction 19980412.0675\n Without releasing statistics, Dr Mwanuko said the 2\ndistricts have been under quarantine since last Monday [12 Mar 2007].\n On the other hand, the Dodoma regional veterinary officer, Dr Samson\nMwanuko, said Bahi and Chamwino have been confirmed to have the\ndisease. According to Zawadiel Mchome, the Dodoma Regional\nAdministrative Secretary, Tanzanian authorities had already put the\nBahi and Chamwino districts under livestock quarantine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hiv/aids", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tanzania", "country": "Tanzania"}, {"location": "Eastern Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10083", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa (30): Kenya & Tanzania", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10083", "date": "2007-05-02 20:00:02", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER, EASTERN AFRICA (30): KENYA & TANZANIA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue 1 May 2007\nSource: International Federation of Red Cross And Red Crescent\nSocieties (IFRC), Reliefweb [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWB.NSF/db900SID/SHES-72SQRV?OpenDocument>\n\nRift Valley fever (RVF), a rare zoonotic viral disease, has claimed\n155 lives in Kenya and caused huge losses of income in Kenya's\npastoralist communities. The outbreak of the disease has exacerbated\nan already precarious food insecurity and livelihoods situation,\nfollowing the massive floods in Kenya and neighboring countries at\nthe end of 2006. A large number of animals were lost to the disease.\nWhile Rift Valley fever is unfortunately familiar to farmers in\nKenya, Tanzania and other countries in the region, not much is known\nabout the virus causing the disease. It is transmitted primarily to\nhumans through contact with infected animal matter such as blood or\nother fluids, as well as animal organs. Consumption of raw milk from\nan infected animal, an important element in the diet of many nomadic\npastoralists in Kenya, is also thought to lead to infection. RVF is\nalso spread by livestock through mosquito bites. The infected\nmosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can stay dormant\nfor years until they get submerged. The eggs then hatch to mosquitoes\nthat spread the virus.\nIn Kenya, RVF has been well known for over 60 years. As early as\n1913, a disease fitting the description of RVF was blamed for the\nloss of sheep in the Rift Valley in Kenya. So far, there is no cure,\nand doctors are only able to treat the symptoms. About one per cent\nof people contracting RVF develop the disease in a severe form;\napproximately half of those die. The last large outbreak was in 1997,\nfollowing heavy rains blamed on El Nino, when some 27 500 people were\ninfected, and 170 died in Garissa District.\nThis time around, the 1st case of RVF was reported in Gurufa, Garissa\non 7 Dec 2006. Almost simultaneously, outbreaks were reported in a\nnumber of other districts, including Ijara, Wajir, Tana River and\nIsiolo, all of which had suffered from the extensive flooding in\nKenya's North Eastern Province.\nNearly 700 suspected cases of RVF were recorded in Kenya, according\nto the Ministry of Health, with 155 deaths. The worst affected\ndistricts were Garissa, Ijara and Wajir districts in North Eastern\nProvince, Tana River and Kilifi districts in Coast Province, and\nKirinyaga and Maragwa districts in Central Province.\nThe outbreak lead to a government-imposed ban on the slaughter of\nlivestock in the affected areas, which led to the closure of key\nlivestock markets, as well as a ban on movement and slaughter of\nanimals. This accentuated the precarious situation of pastoralists'\nwelfare, particularly in North Eastern Province. The ban on the\nslaughter of animals has now been lifted in Garissa, Ijara, Mandera\nand Wajir districts in North Eastern Province. However, the animal\nquarantine is in force awaiting review through a veterinary\ndepartment investigation.\nAt the peak of the RVF outbreak, the Kenya Red Cross Society was\nengaged in social mobilization activities targeting health workers\nand the affected communities. Access to affected areas in Garissa\nposed the greatest challenge due to flooding in the area. With the\nassistance of Emergency Response Units (ERUs) from sister societies\naround the world and other partners, the Kenya Red Cross assisted in\nthe establishment of Special Wards in Garissa Provincial Hospital and\nNgao Sub-District Hospital in Garsen.\nThe ward in Ngao Sub-District Hospital was established with support\nfrom the Japanese and Australian Red Cross and MSF-Spain. The Kenya\nRed Cross also worked with the MoH to institute timely and effective\ncare to suspected and/or confirmed RVF cases. The Medical ERUs helped\nto train medical personnel working in local health facilities on\nuniversal precautions, early case detection and referral.\nSignificant government vaccination campaigns targeting 1.5 million\nlivestock (cattle, sheep and goats), as well as other preventive\nactivity is ongoing in 33 districts where RVF cases have been\nreported. Other interventions include supportive case management;\nenhanced surveillance; community mobilization/public health education\nand veterinary intervention, like the ban on slaughtering of animals\ncurrently in force in the Marigat and Makutano parts of Baringo.\nVector control is also ongoing through the spraying of high risk\nanimals with synthetic pyrethroid.\nAccording to the World Health Organization, RVF can be prevented by a\nsustained program of animal vaccination. Live, attenuated and killed\nvaccines have been developed for veterinary use. The live vaccine\nrequires only one dose and produces long-lived immunity, but the\npresently-available vaccine may cause abortion if given to pregnant\nanimals. The killed vaccines do not cause these unwanted effects, but\nmultiple doses must be given to produce protective immunity. This may\nprove problematic in endemic areas.\nThe available vaccine is only for use with livestock. In humans, an\ninactivated vaccine has been developed. This vaccine is not licensed\nand is not commercially available, but has been used experimentally\nto protect veterinary and laboratory personnel at high risk of\nexposure to RVF. Other candidate vaccines are under investigation.\nIn neighboring Tanzania, the National Society has organized a one-day\nseminar on RVF in the capital city of Dodoma with participation of\nlocal authorities, Tanzanian Red Cross volunteers and representatives\nof local townships and villages. Following the seminar, the\nvolunteers went back into villages to educate local communities on\nthis epidemic.\nA total of 90 people in Dodoma were infected, and 19 of those lost\ntheir lives. The total number of RVF deaths in Tanzania now stands at\n33. The majority of Dodoma residents are livestock keepers, and the\ndeaths of large numbers of livestock simply mean a dwindling of\npeople's economic resources, Mr. Yunus Rugaiyamu, the Regional\nAdministrative Secretary, lamented and added that 'we must cooperate\nand work together in order to get rid of this killer disease in our region.'\nThe number of Tanzanian regions with suspected cases of RVF has\ncontinued to rise, now standing at 8: Arusha, Manyara, Tanga,\nKilimanjaro, Dodoma, Morogoro, Singida and Iringa. In Dar es Salaam,\nRegional Commissioner Mr. A Kandoro has announced a tentative ban on\nthe sale of meat grilled at roadside stalls (kebabs) and urged the\ncommunity to watch their eating manners as a precautionary measure,\nwhile leading authorities asked everyone to raise their level of\nalertness against the disease's entry into the city.\nResponding to the outbreaks, the Tanzanian Red Cross has distributed\n100 mosquito nets, 200 blankets and 2 tents through the Regional\nMedical Officer in Dodoma to be used at established treatment camps,\nwhile another 100 mosquito nets will be distributed by Dodoma Red\nCross to RVF-affected families. The Society also provided 4000\nleaflets to give health education to the local communities.\n[Byline: Everlyn Kemunto & Anthony Mwangi, Kenya Red Cross, and\nStella Marealle, Tanzania Red Cross]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Wed 2 May 2007\nSource: Daily News, Dar es Salaam [edited]\n<http://www.dailynews-tsn.com/page.php?id=6601>\n\nRift Valley Fever (RVF) patients admitted to health facilities in\nDodoma region have dropped to 35 from 137 last month [April 2007],\nindicating significant gains in controlling the killer disease, which\nhas wreaked havoc on the meat industry here, the Regional\nCommissioner (RC), Mr William Lukuvi, has said.\nAddressing a May Day rally at the Jamhuri Stadium here yesterday [1\nMay 2007], Mr Lukuvi said by yesterday morning the Dodoma Regional\nHospital had 20 RVF patients, Mirembe Hospital 11, Mvumi Mission\nHospital had 2 and Kongwa and Mpwapwa district hospitals had one\neach. The disease has killed more than 50 people in the region.\nHowever, the RC cautioned against eating meat from sick or dead cows,\nwarning traders to sell only meat certified by health and veterinary\nofficers. Some patients have been in coma since last February [2007],\nhe warned.\nThe RC also said that business at the Dodoma abattoir was picking up\n'slowly.' He said the abattoir, with capacity to slaughter 200 cows a\nday, handled only 6 yesterday [1 May 2007]. Business at the facility\nhad virtually stopped.\n[Byline: Sosthenes Mwita]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\n[According to these reports, the number of recorded human cases of\nRVF in Kenya now totals 700, including 155 fatalities, and 90,\nincluding 19 fatalities, in the Dodoma region of Tanzania. Overall,\nthere have been 33 RVF deaths in Tanzania. The most recent data from\nthe Dodoma region of Tanzania suggests that the outbreak is abating.\nA map of Tanzania showing the location of Dodoma can be viewed at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/tanzania.pdf>.\n- Mod.CP]\n[Dr Glyn Davies wrote in ProMED, Rift Valley fever, Eastern Africa\n(25): Tanzania (Dodoma), WHO 20070324.1024: 'There may have been\nalterations to the [epizootic] curve, which have followed the\neffective transmission of virulent RVF virus caused by the widespread\nvaccination programs. These may have involved hundreds of thousands\nof animals, which would not have been otherwise affected...\nVaccination with the Smithburn MLVV (modified live virus vaccine)\nstrain or any other vaccine is totally contraindicated at any time\nwhen active virus transmission is taking place... Vaccination of\nanimal populations during periods when RVF virus is actively being\ntransmitted by vectors will serve to propagate the virus very\neffectively by needle passage. The virus is readily transmitted by\ninfected needles from animal to animal.'\nAnd the more animals that are infected, the greater the chances of\nmosquito-borne transmission to humans. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "In Dar es Salaam,\nRegional Commissioner Mr. A Kandoro has announced a tentative ban on\nthe sale of meat grilled at roadside stalls (kebabs) and urged the\ncommunity to watch their eating manners as a precautionary measure,\nwhile leading authorities asked everyone to raise their level of\nalertness against the disease's entry into the city.\n Source: Daily News, Dar es Salaam [edited]\n<http://www.dailynews-tsn.com/page.php?id=6601>\n\nRift Valley Fever (RVF) patients admitted to health facilities in\nDodoma region have dropped to 35 from 137 last month [April 2007],\nindicating significant gains in controlling the killer disease, which\nhas wreaked havoc on the meat industry here, the Regional\nCommissioner (RC), Mr William Lukuvi, has said. Eastern Africa (21): Kenya, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8700", "date": "2007-03-07 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (21): KENYA, VACCINATION\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 6 Mar 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: IRIN via Reuters [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/a62d994e043a2365ea7b06698793d799.htm>\n\nKENYA: Livestock vaccination stems spread of RVF\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn ongoing livestock vaccination campaign against an outbreak of Rift\nValley Fever (RVF) has stemmed the spread of the disease in Kenya,\nwhere the mosquito-borne illness, which affects both animals and\nhumans, has killed 154 people since December 2006, officials said on\nTuesday [6 Mar 2007].\n'We have not received any new (livestock) cases, although our\nextension officers are still carrying out surveillance in the\naffected districts,' said William Maritim, senior veterinary officer\nwith the disease control unit of the Ministry of Livestock and\nFisheries.\nAt least 1.5 million livestock (cattle, sheep, and goats) are\ntargeted for vaccination in the ongoing campaign in 33 districts\nwhere RVF cases have been reported. The worst affected districts were\nGarissa, Ijara and Wajir in Northeastern Province, Tana River and\nKilifi districts in Coast Province, and Kirinyaga and Maragwa\ndistricts in Central Province.\n'We are also in the process of procuring an additional 750 000 doses\nof vaccine to sustain the exercise,' Maritim said.\nThe vaccination project, which began in Garissa on 8 Jan 2007, is\nmoving towards the Rift Valley Province, where the disease was 1st\nreported in 1931. RVF causes spontaneous abortions and death in\nanimals.\nMost of the vaccines have been imported from South Africa, at\napproximately USD 0.37 a dose.\nThe RVF virus is spread to humans from livestock via the aedes\nmosquito, which breeds rapidly during floods [and by direct contact\nof humans with infected animal tissues - Mod.AS]. The Northeastern\nProvince, inhabited by nomadic pastoralists, was hit by devastating\nfloods in the last 3 months of 2006 after heavier than normal\nrainfall.\nIt can be transmitted through contact with infected animal material,\nsuch as blood or other body fluids, or organs. Consumption of milk, a\nstaple for many pastoral people, is also thought to lead to\ninfection. Symptoms in humans include bleeding through the nose and\nmouth and liver failure.\nThe government imposed a ban on the slaughter of livestock in the\naffected areas when RVF was 1st reported, leading to the closure of\nlivestock markets in a region where people depend on animals for\nincome and food. The ban has since been lifted, but a restriction on\nlivestock movement is still in force.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n An ongoing livestock vaccination campaign against an outbreak of Rift\nValley Fever (RVF) has stemmed the spread of the disease in Kenya,\nwhere the mosquito-borne illness, which affects both animals and\nhumans, has killed 154 people since December 2006, officials said on\nTuesday We have not received any new (livestock) cases, although our\nextension officers are still carrying out surveillance in the\naffected districts,' said William Maritim, senior veterinary officer\nwith the disease control unit of the Ministry of Livestock and\nFisheries. The government imposed a ban on the slaughter of livestock in the\naffected areas when RVF was 1st reported, leading to the closure of\nlivestock markets in a region where people depend on animals for\nincome and food. The worst affected districts were\nGarissa, Ijara and Wajir in Northeastern Province, Tana River and\nKilifi districts in Coast Province, and Kirinyaga and Maragwa\ndistricts in Central Province. The Northeastern\nProvince, inhabited by nomadic pastoralists, was hit by devastating\nfloods in the last 3 months of 2006 after heavier than normal\nrainfall. The RVF virus is spread to humans from livestock via the aedes\nmosquito, which breeds rapidly during floods [and by direct contact\nof humans with infected animal tissues - Mod. At least 1.5 million livestock (cattle, sheep, and goats) are\ntargeted for vaccination in the ongoing campaign in 33 districts\nwhere RVF cases have been reported. The vaccination project, which began in Garissa on 8 Jan 2007, is\nmoving towards the Rift Valley Province, where the disease was 1st\nreported in 1931. The officer-in-charge at the\npark, Ms Lydia Kisoyan, confirmed the deaths.\n[byline: Karanja Njoroge]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Results from the laboratory are awaited with interest.\nAn earlier query from Dr Joe Dudley, the sender of the posting above,\nenclosed a comment from Dr Michael Woodford (founder of IUCN (World\nConservation Union) Veterinary Specialist Group; Regional contact person\nfor Middle East, Western, and Central Asia, OIE Wildlife disease working\ngroup) on the absence of current information regarding RVF in wildlife.\nThis, and additional raised queries, have been forwarded to Prof Glyn\nDavies, a world authority on RVF. We are very grateful for his response,\nwhich constitutes the following report. - Mod.AS]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 24 Feb 2007\nFrom: Glyn Davies <fgdvirus@compuserve.com>\n\nWildlife and RVFV\n-----------------\n1. Field observations\nI spent a great deal of time during RVFV (Rift Valley fever virus)\nepizootic periods in Kenya observing the wild ruminants on properties\naffected by RVFV in domestic animals and also communicating with cattle and\nsheep farmers on RVF affected farms. At no time, did I nor anyone else, see\nwild animals grazing RVFV infected areas with affected cattle, show any\nclinical disease, which might have been due to RVFV. Abortions may have\noccurred, however, but it is unlikely that these would have been detected,\ndue to the presence of wild carnivores that would scavenge fetal material.\nSurveys were carried out in sera collected from wild ruminants and there\nwas evidence that cryptic RVFV infection had occurred in some species\n(Davies 1975 & unpublished data). My conclusions were that infection by\nRVFV did occur in these situations, but that this was subclinical, with the\nreservation that abortion may have occurred in pregnant females, which was\ndifficult to observe or confirm.\nThere was a report from South Africa that springbok and blesbok were\naborting during a RVF epizootic, but this was not confirmed to be due to\nRVF (Joubert, et al. 1951).\n2. Experimental inoculations\nFive adult female buffalo (_Syncercus caffer_) were inoculated with RVF\nvirus and viraemia was detected for cc 48 h in 4 of them. Two animals,\nwhich were pregnant, aborted. Some RVF antibody was detected in wild\npopulation samples from buffalo, but the samples were from ecological zones\nwhere RVFV activity was unlikely to have occurred for some considerable\ntime: there had been no recent periods of epizootic RVFV activity before\nthe sampling (Davies & Karstad, 1981).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "Some RVF antibody was detected in wild\npopulation samples from buffalo, but the samples were from ecological zones\nwhere RVFV activity was unlikely to have occurred for some considerable\ntime: there had been no recent periods of epizootic RVFV activity before\nthe sampling (Davies & Karstad, 1981).\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [byline: Karanja Njoroge]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 The deaths of over 10 buffaloes in Hells Gate National Park have sparked\nfears among local conservationists that Rift Valley fever (RVF) may have\nspread to wild animals, especially since 2 of the animals died in a farm\nwhere the 1st local case of the fever was reported. The vaccine is administered to livestock.\nAbout 500 000 doses, were ordered by the government 2 weeks ago and were\nimmediately dispatched for distribution in affected areas -- Arusha,\nManyara, Kilimanjaro, Morogoro, and Tanga regions. 'The distribution of the\nvaccines has already started and we want to see it speeded up,' Mr Diallo\ntold reporters.\nOfficials and experts have urged inhabitants of Arusha to handle and\nprepare carefully meat and other animal products before eating them. Meat\nand milk should not be consumed raw or half done. Signs and symptoms of RVF\n[in humans] include flue-like illness with fever, weakness, back pain,\ndizziness, and weight loss. This vaccine\nwill confer protecting antibody levels within a relatively short period but\nis known to be abortogenic. [This sensible precautionary measure seems to\nreflect the possibility that vaccination might be applied in\nincubating animals or animals that could get infected shortly after\nvaccination, before immunity is established. - Mod.AS]\nMeanwhile, there are suspicions that a 17-year-old girl died of RVF\nin Msabaha, a sub location of the Malindi district [north of\nMombasa], after family members refused to take her to hospital due to\nreligious beliefs.\nMalindi district officer, Herman Shambi, said that the girl's\nrelatives are members of the Miracle Revival Fellowship Pentecostal\nchurch, which considers medication and hospitalization as sinful as\nit amounts to doubting God.\nHe said the girl died at home as family members were dangerously\nhandling her, oblivious of the danger they were exposing themselves\nto since they had not taken her anywhere for medical examination.\nThe girl could be the 5th victim to succumb to the viral disease in\nMalindi district though it has been difficult to establish the number\nof deaths due to reluctance by the locals to seek medical attention.\nMalindi district medical officer, Dr. Anisa Omar, said he would\ncomment on the issue at a later date.\n[Byline: Mark Kemoli]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[According to WHO's most recent available update on the RVF situation\nin Kenya and Somalia (31 Jan 2007), the Kajiado district is included\nin the regions where numerous human cases have been reported; see map at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/AFRO_RVF_20070130.png>.\nKenya's notification to the OIE of clinical RVF cases in animals\n(sheep, goats, cattle, and camels) was submitted to the OIE on 9 Jan\n2007, referring to an outbreak in Galmagara, Garissa, the southern\npart of the North-Eastern province, which reportedly had started on 4\nDec 2006 and confirmed on 22 Dec 2006. This is\nnot a new phenomenon. A forgotten piece of history: RVF was\nidentified for the 1st time in South Africa, in 1950, only when\nseveral veterinarians got infected, exhibiting influenza-like\nsymptoms, after performing PM [postmortem] in an affected bull in the\nBloemfontein Artificial insemination (AI) centre. This led to the\ndiscovery that the virus had already been circulating, causing heavy\nlosses, for about 6 months in rural areas, infecting hundreds of\nthousands animals and thousands of humans without being suspected nor\nidentified. Similar situations have occurred since in several other countries.\nIn view of the reports on the occurrence of RVF in humans and animals\nin Kenya and Tanzania, and in humans in Somalia (wherefrom\ninformation on animal disease is still anticipated), it will not\nsurprise if the disease occurs in other receptive countries, such as\nUganda, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Sudan, Egypt, and Yemen. The 5\ndied as the Ministry of Health warned Kenyans against handling\nanimals suspected to be infected with the disease.\nDr. Jack Nyamongo of the National Public Health Laboratory\nServices/National Blood Transfusion Services said it was important\nnot to handle material from infected animals. He said veterinary\nofficers at Kabete were testing samples from a cow confiscated in\nRuai at the weekend to establish if the animal was infected with the\ndeadly virus.\nLast evening [11 Feb 2007], the Director of Veterinary Services, Dr.\nJoseph Musaa, said initial results indicated that the cow was\nsuffering from Lumpy Skin disease. [Lumpy skin disease is caused by a\npoxvirus classified in the genus _Capripoxvirus_, which affects\ncertain breeds and crossbreeds of cattle in Africa. - Mod.CP].\nThe 4 family members succumbed to the killer fever after attending a\ntraditional wedding in the Tana River on Mon 12 Feb 2007. The victims\ndeveloped symptoms of the disease before bleeding to death barely 2\ndays after feasting on camel meat at a wedding ceremony in Anole\nvillage, Madogo division. Three of the victims died in manyattas\n[fenced settlements of several huts characteristic of Masai\ncommunities. - Mod.CP], while the 4th was pronounced dead on arrival\nat Garissa Provincial General Hospital, where 21 other villagers were\nhospitalised.\nNorth Eastern Provincial Medical Officer of Health, Dr. Omar Ahmed,\nsaid more than 20 other villagers who attended the weekend function\nhad been put under observation after developing symptoms of the\ndisease. He said most of the affected villagers were treated [and]\nsubjected to periodic check-ups. Three of them were admitted to an\nisolation unit in the facility. Omar regretted that most of the fresh\ncases reported over the last 2 weeks followed disregard of the\nslaughter ban. Madogo DO [District Officer], Mr. George Omolo, said\nvillagers reported the matter after 3 of the women who prepared the\ncamel meat collapsed and bled to death.\nPreliminary reports indicated that the camel had been bought, Omolo\nsaid. He said the pastoralist who sold the animal was among those\nretained for specialised treatment at the hospital. Panicky\nvillagers, including those who ate cooked meat thronged local health\ncentres to establish their RVF status.\nThis brings to 114 the number of deaths reported in northern Kenya\nsince the outbreak of the disease, 2 months ago. In Baringo District\nan 18-year-old man died bringing the death toll in the area to 16.\nMedical Officer of Health, Dr. George Otieno, said the man who had\nbeen receiving treatment at Kimalel Health Centre died on Saturday\n[10 Feb 2007]. Nationally, 150 people have died of the disease in the\npast 2 months.\nOtieno said a team of health workers had been dispatched to the\naffected villages in the Marigat and Kiserian divisions to fight the\ndisease. He identified the most affected villages where the fever has\ntaken its toll as Ngambo location, Sindan, Sandai, Logumgum, and\nSalabani all in the Marigat division, and some parts of the Mukutani\ndivision.\nHe said the government has supplied the district with 500 mosquito\nnets and insecticides. But Otieno said the chemicals were still lying\nat chemical stores in Kabarnet town, as the Government has not\nreleased money to hire casual workers to spray houses in the affected\nareas.\nBaringo Central MP, Mr. Gideon Moi, visited patients in the Kimalel\nand Marigat sub-district hospitals and distributed more than 2000\nmosquito nets.\nAt the same time, farmers in Nakuru have asked the Government to\ndeclare the fever a national disaster. Farmers meeting in Nakuru\nyesterday [11 Feb 2007] criticised the Livestock Development ministry\n[for the way it] handled the matter.\nMeanwhile, fear of the disease spreading in Meru Central have led to\nan order of closure of all abattoirs and butcheries in the area.\nDistrict veterinary officer, Dr. Daniel Karugu, said samples from\nseveral suspected cows are being analysed. Neighbouring districts of\nIsiolo, Meru North, and Meru South have reported cases of the disease.\n--\nJoseph P. Of course,\nruminants suffer significant loses, act as amplifiers of the virus\nbut also should serve as a warning to people in the area, because the\ndisease is often transmitted by mosquitoes to humans or people are\nexposed to infected ruminants directly.\nThe location of these outbreaks is indeed unfortunate as they have\nprogressed through the new year 2007. The local English newspaper Daily News\nquoted Arusha Regional Medical Officer Naftari King'ori as confirming\nthat the 4 people had been admitted into the Mount Meru Hospital,\nwhere the country's 1st 2 victims of the disease died on 31 Jan 2007.\nTanzanian Prime Minister Edward Lowassa called on local government\nofficials to coordinate efforts to contain the spread of the disease.\nHe told lawmakers on Friday [9 Feb 2007] in Dodoma that the\ngovernment had already ordered vaccines and would soon start\nvaccinating livestock in the country, which has a cattle population\nof 18.5 million. Rift Valley fever is a viral disease\nthat affects mainly animals such as cattle, buffalo, sheep and goats.\nBut it can also affect humans. The disease is most common during\nyears of heavy rainfalls.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[If confirmed positive, these cases will represent a significant\nincursion of Rift Valley fever into the human population of Tanzania.\nSo far, little information has been released regarding the extent of\npenetration of the disease into livestock in the Arusha region, which\nis adjacent to the outbreak in eastern Kenya.\nA map of Tanzania can be viewed at\n<http://www.uhuru7.com/images/tanzania_rel_2003.jpg>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Tanzania has already banned livestock movement to\nand from neighboring Kenya and started scrutinizing all livestock\nmeant for human consumption after the disease had killed 2 local\nresidents and a Kenyan visiting northern Tanzania. The deaths\nwere reported in the northern Arusha region last week, raising fears\nof an outbreak, the area's regional commissioner Evans Balama told\nAFP. The fever has killed at least 162 people\nand infected hundreds in Kenya since it was first diagnosed in\nmid-December [2006].\n\nVictims of Rift Valley fever usually experience fever, generalized\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, vomiting of blood and extreme weight\nloss at the onset of the illness. Many patients recover within up to\na week but others die, experts say.\n\nThe fever was 1st [reported] in Kenya's Rift Valley region in the\n1930s but has since been recorded elsewhere in Africa.\n\n--\nJoseph P. Villagers said 11 people had died even as\nveterinary officers insisted it was 6.\nAn estimated 300 goats and sheep have died of a mysterious disease linked\nto the spread of [Rift Valley fever] in the past week.\nThe clinical officer in charge of Marigat Sub-district Hospital, Rahab\nRandall, said 4 people have died in the last week. Two other\npeople are fighting for their lives at Taveta District Hospital. Those who\ndied included a Maasai herdsman and a woman at Salaita village in Taveta\ndivision. Last month a Somali herdsman died at Kuranze Ranch in Voi\ndivision. He said the Government is educating the\npublic on the disease.\nThe District veterinary officer, Dr Julius Nkanata, said several animals\nhave died of an unidentified disease in the area. WHO Update 3\n-----------------------------------------------\nKenya\n-------\nAs of Tue 30 Jan 2007, 411 suspected cases, including 121 deaths\n(case-fatality rate, 29 percent) have been reported in North Eastern\nProvince, Coast Province, Eastern Province and Central Province (see the\nWHO map at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/AFRO_RVF_20070130.png>).\n131 cases have been laboratory confirmed.\nThe North Eastern Province has been the most affected, with Garissa\ndistrict (175 suspected cases, 58 confirmed cases, including 57 deaths) and\nIjara district (125 suspected cases and 22 confirmed cases, including 23\ndeaths) reporting the most cases and deaths. Sporadic cases have also been\nreported from districts in Eastern Province (Isiolo - 8 suspected cases, 3\nconfirmed cases) and from districts in Central Province (Kirinyanga - 4\nsuspected cases, 4 confirmed cases, including one death; Kajiado - 3\nsuspected cases, one confirmed case, including 3 deaths; Maragua - one\nsuspected case, one confirmed case); Thika - 2 suspected cases, one\nconfirmed case). Some of the cases from Central Province were diagnosed in\nNairobi.\nThe outbreak appears to be in decline, although the Ministry of Health\ncontinues to coordinate activities to contain the outbreak, including\nactive surveillance. The team from the Global Outbreak Alert and Response\nNetwork (see previous report) has returned from the affected areas, having\nprovided a mobile laboratory for initial diagnosis of the disease, training\nin case management/infection control to provincial health officials and\nassistance with health education and informing affected communities about\nthe disease. WHO, the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Livestock and\nFisheries Development developed key public health messages which have been\ndisseminated in the local community, and meetings were held with community\nreligious leaders.\nSomalia\n---------\nAs of Tue 30 Jan 2007, WHO has reported 100 suspected cases, including 48\ndeaths, in Somalia (see WHO map), with one case laboratory confirmed by the\nKenyan Institute of Medical Research (KEMRI) and the Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention/ International Emerging Infectious Program (CDC/EIP)\nin Kenya.\nMedecins sans Frontieres is facilitating transport of samples, and the WHO\ncountry office has held training sessions with Somali medical officers on\nhow to detect and contain the disease. However, the deteriorating security\nsituation continues to hamper control measures in the affected area.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n{The total number of suspected cases of Rift Valley fever in Kenya and\nSomalia combined is now at least 511 with 169 deaths (case fatality rate 33\npercent).\nA WHO-generated map of the distribution of suspected cases of Rift Valley\nfever in Kenya and Somalia can be accessed from the WHO website or via\n<http://www.who.int/csr/AFRO_RVF_20070130.png>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "Sporadic cases have also been\nreported from districts in Eastern Province (Isiolo - 8 suspected cases, 3\nconfirmed cases) and from districts in Central Province (Kirinyanga - 4\nsuspected cases, 4 confirmed cases, including one death; Kajiado - 3\nsuspected cases, one confirmed case, including 3 deaths; Maragua - one\nsuspected case, one confirmed case); Thika - 2 suspected cases, one\nconfirmed case). The contagious\ndisease hit remote areas of Kenya's North East and Coastal provinces in\nmid-December 2006 and has since spread to neighboring Somalia. The country\nhas recorded nearly 60 new human infections since the end of last week.\n'The government has already spent 100 million shillings [USD 1.43 million]\nto provide medical care for affected areas, and 2 million heads of cattle\nhave already been vaccinated,' Alfred Mutua, the government's spokesman\ntold a news conference. Health officials at the Kenyan Dadaab refugee camp,\na densely populated camp near the border with Somalia, said 29 cases,\nincluding 5 deaths, had been reported by Thu [18 Jan 2007].\nThe disease is transmitted to humans through mosquito bites or frequent\ncontact with contaminated animals. Although transmission from animals to\nhumans is rare, the disease develops into a much more severe illness once\nit crosses over, causing victims to abort, vomit blood or bleed to death.\nThe government asked people to avoid contact with animals, especially cows,\nto use mosquito nets and to take extra care with their personal hygiene. Rift Valley fever patients usually\nexperience fever, generalized weakness, back pain, dizziness,\nvomiting of blood and extreme weight loss at the onset of the\nillness. Eastern Africa (08): Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7016", "date": "2007-01-26 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (08): KENYA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Wed 24 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation Alertnet, IRIN News [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/4531a279e89daa64773728f5c6c9e0d0.htm>\n\nKenya: Rift Valley fever reported in Nairobi\n-----------------------------------------------\nTwo cases of Rift Valley fever (RVF), a deadly viral disease that\nbroke out in northeastern Kenya in December 2006, have been reported\nin the capital, Nairobi, despite assurances by health officials on\nWed 25 Jan 2007 that the disease had been contained.\nKariuki Njenga, a virologist and Laboratory Director for the United\nStates Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Kenya and the Kenya\nMedical Research Institute (KEMRI), described the 2 as 'spot cases'\ntransferred from other parts of the country and said they did not\nrepresent an escalation. 'One was a journalist returning on Sunday\n[21 Jan 2007] from an assignment in the Northeastern Province, while\nthe other was that of a man who had traveled to the city from\nKirinyaga [where the outbreak has also been reported],' he added.\nSince the disease broke out, at least 220 cases, including 82 deaths,\nhave been reported in Northeastern and Coast provinces; a UN agency\nsaid KEMRI had confirmed 56 of the cases, including 12 deaths.\nThe epicenters of the outbreak were the northeastern districts of\nGarissa and Ijara, where the disease has also killed hundreds of\nlivestock, mostly goats, sheep and cattle. Coast Province, Wajir and\nTana River districts have also been affected, and local media reports\non Wed 25 Jan 2007 said the disease had spread to Kirinyaga and\nMaragwa districts, which are close to Nairobi.\nA Kenyan government ban on the sale and slaughter of livestock in\nNortheastern Province, imposed in December 2006, has not been lifted.\n'There is no pressure, and the Kenyan government is going to cope\nshould the disease spread beyond expectations,' he said. 'What I can\nconfirm now is that RVF is under control in Kenya.'\nThe RVF virus is spread to humans from livestock via the _Aedes_\nmosquito, which breeds rapidly during floods. Northeastern Province,\ninhabited by nomadic herdsmen, was hit by devastating floods between\nOctober and December 2006. The disease can also be transmitted\nthrough contact with infected animal material such as blood or other\nbody fluids or organs. Consumption of milk, a staple for many\nshepherds, is also a possible risk. Symptoms include bleeding through\nthe nose and mouth and liver failure.\nThe Ministry of Health has been working together with KEMRI and the\nCDC to curb the spread of the disease. Njenga said Ministry officials\nhad managed to keep the RVF virus from spreading to other parts of\nKenya and to other countries in the region. He said health officials\nwere working around the clock to inform the public on how best to\nkeep the virus at bay. 'We are working together and have increased\nsurveillance throughout the country, especially in livestock areas,'\nNjenga said. He added that KEMRI and the CDC were analyzing samples\nreceived from various parts of the country. No cases have been\nconfirmed in Ethiopia, although one spot [sporadic] case was reported\nin Somalia,' he said. 'Spot cases are not uncommon in areas where RVF\nis endemic, and the positive case in Somalia is one such example; it\ndoes not represent an escalation of new cases.\nContinued public education is the best tool available in the fight\nagainst RVF,' Njenga said. 'We must teach the people how to handle\nanimal products, especially raw meat, carefully; to avoid consuming\nuncooked meat; and use treated mosquito nets.'\nNortheastern Province was previously hit by an outbreak of RVF in\n1997 after heavy flooding caused by the El Nino weather pattern. The\ndisease was 1st identified in Kenya in 1931. A 1st sign of it is\nspontaneous abortions in sheep, goats and cattle.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An interactive map showing the location of Nairobi in relation to\nthe Garissa and Ijara districts, the epicenters of the outbreak, can be seen at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO&pcodero/js/mw>.\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 25 Jan 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation Alertnet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L25916601.htm>\n\nKenya: Rift Valley fever death toll rises to 148\n-----------------------------------------------\n53 more people have died in Kenya in the last week after an outbreak\nof Rift Valley fever, bringing the death toll to 148, a government\nspokesman said on Thu 25 Jan 2007. The contagious disease, which 1st\nhit parts of Kenya's Northeastern and Coast provinces in mid-December\n[2006], has now spread to the east African country's Central, Eastern\nand Rift Valley provinces. Kenya has recorded 108 new human\ninfections since last week.\nThe disease, which is transmitted to humans through mosquito bites or\nfrequent contact with contaminated animals, causes victims to abort,\nvomit blood or bleed to death. 'We have spent over 100 million Kenya\nshillings (USD 1.42 million) so far to provide the necessary\nmedicine. We have vaccinated 2 million cows and quarantined them. We\nare also distributing mosquito nets,' Kenya government spokesman\nAlfred Mutua told a news conference.\nHe denied media reports that one case had been detected in Kenya's\ncapital, saying an infected person from one of the affected areas had\nbeen admitted at Kenyatta National Hospital. 'There are new cases in\nKitui central constituency, Kajiado and Kirinyaga,' Mutua said.\nHealth officials at the Kenyan Dadaab refugee camp, a densely\npopulated camp near the border with Somalia, said last week 29 cases,\nincluding 5 deaths, had been reported.\nThe Kenya government said last week it had spent 100 million Kenya\nshillings (USD 1.42 million) to provide medical care and asked\nKenyans to avoid contact with animals, use mosquito nets and exercise\nbasic hygiene. The World Health Organization has said a dilapidated\ninfrastructure in the worst-hit areas would make treatment difficult\nand feared the disease would spread quickly. A similar outbreak in\n1997-1998 killed hundreds of people in Kenya.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive\nSuite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[The preceding report from Kenya reported 2 cases of Rift Valley\nfever in Nairobi, both considered to have originated elsewhere.\nClarification is awaited. - Mod.CP]\n[Vectors: Rift Valley fever virus can be spread by at least 31\nmosquito species, and moreover has been isolated from 2 tick species,\nincluding _Rhipicephalus appendiculatus_ in Kenya, but mosquitoes\nremain the most important arthropod vectors.\nIn Kenya isolations of the virus have been made from _Aedes\ndalzieli_, _Ae. durbanensis_, _-Ae. mcintoshi_ (formerly called_ Ae.\nlineatopennis_), _Culex antennatus_, _Cx. theileri_, _Cx.\nzombaensis_, _Cx. rubinotus_, _Anopheles christyi_ and _An.\npharoensis_. At a guess the most important vectors in Kenya could\n_Ae. mcintoshi_ and _Cx. antennatus_, both being common mosquitoes\nthat bite humans and which breed in pools and marshy areas\nespecially those having grassy vegetation. Adults of _Ae. mcintoshi_\nbite mainly during the daytime, while those of _Cx. antennatus_ bite\nmainly in the evenings and at night and therefore insecticide treated\nbednets could offer considerable protection, although if biting was\nexperienced early in the evenings before people had gone to bed they\nwould be exposed to transmission. But what is needed is the\nidentification of the species transmitting Rift Valley fever so that\nmost appropriate actions can be taken to reduce transmission.\nAlso _Ae. circumluteolus_ a common mosquito in Kenya is a known\nvector of Rift Valley fever virus in both Uganda and South Africa,\nbut I am unsure whether it is a proven vector in Kenya. Eastern Africa (04): Kenya, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6679", "date": "2007-01-16 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (04): KENYA, WHO\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: World Health Organisation (WHO), CSR, Disease Outbreak News,\nMon 15 Jan 3007 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2007_01_15a/en/index.html>\n\nKenya: Rift Valley fever situation - WHO Update 2\n-------------------------------------------------\nAs of Fri 12 Jan 2007, 220 suspected cases, including 82 deaths, of\nRift Valley Fever virus [infection] (case-fatality ratio 37.2\npercent) have been reported in North Eastern Province and Coast\nProvince, Kenya. Fifty-six cases, including 12 deaths have been\nlaboratory-confirmed by the Kenya Medical Research Institute.\nGarissa district in North Eastern Province remains the main affected\narea with 132 suspected cases and 54 deaths. Fifty-eight cases\nincluding 10 deaths have also been reported from Ijara district in\nNorth Eastern Province. In neighbouring Coast Province, 15 cases and\n12 deaths have been reported in Wajir district and 15 cases and 6\ndeaths in Tana River district.\nThe Kenyan Ministry of Health is coordinating a mulitsectoral\nresponse in collaboration with the Ministry of Livestock and\nFisheries Development and with United Nations partners including FAO,\nUNICEF and WFP, as well as with other non-governmental partners. The\nInternational Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies\n(IFRC) and national societies from Finland, Germany and Japan are\nalso working with the Kenyan Red Cross to contain the disease.\nThe Kenyan Ministry of Health is carrying out clinical case\nmanagement, and Rift Valley Fever wards have been established in\nGarissa Provincial Hospital as well as in Ijara district. Over 8000\nanimals have been vaccinated under the supervision of the Kenyan\nMinistry of Livestock and Fisheries Development and FAO. Vector\ncontrol spraying, human and animal surveillance and social\nmobilization activities are continuing.\nAdditional technical assistance is also being provided by an\ninternational team from the Global Outbreak Alert and Response\nNetwork (GOARN). An 11-member team from GOARN partner institutions,\nand WHO (Country Office, Regional Office for Africa, and\nHeadquarters) is supporting the Ministry of Health, provincial and\ndistrict health authorities in implementing public health measures to\ncontrol the outbreak. GOARN partners include: a mobile laboratory\nteam and 2 epidemiologists from the Public Health Agency of Canada\n(National Microbiology Laboratory, Canadian Science Centre for Human\nand Animal Health, and Canadian Field Epidemiology Programme ), a\ntechnical expert on Rift Valley Fever and a case management/infection\ncontrol expert from the National Institute of Communicable Diseases\n(NICD) and Department of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases, National Health Laboratory Service (NHLS) and the School of\nPathology of the University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South\nAfrica, and a 2-3 member social mobilization team from the US Centers\nfor Disease Prevention and Control (CDC) and WHO Centre for\nVulnerability Reduction, (WMC), Tunisia. WHO has also received offers\nof further technical assistance from GOARN institutions.\nCDC-Kenya is coordinating bilateral assistance from the US\nDepartments of Agriculture, Defense and Health and Human Services (HHS).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "(National Microbiology Laboratory, Canadian Science Centre for Human\nand Animal Health, and Canadian Field Epidemiology Programme ), a\ntechnical expert on Rift Valley Fever and a case management/infection\ncontrol expert from the National Institute of Communicable Diseases\n(NICD) and Department of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases, National Health Laboratory Service (NHLS) and the School of\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n An 11-member team from GOARN partner institutions,\nand WHO (Country Office, Regional Office for Africa, and\nHeadquarters) is supporting the Ministry of Health, provincial and\ndistrict health authorities in implementing public health measures to\ncontrol the outbreak. Eastern Africa (03): Kenya, planning", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6653", "date": "2007-01-15 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (03): KENYA, PLANNING\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Kenya - updated situation\n[2] Ethiopia - preparedness\n[3] Kenya - control measures\n[4] Tanzania - preparedness\n[5] Kenya - response to disease forecasts\n[6] Kenya - background\n******\n[1] Kenya - updated situation\nDate: Mon 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Kenya Broadcasting Corporation [edited]\n<http://www.kbc.co.ke/story.asp?ID=40372>\n\nGovernment says it has taken measures to contain Rift Valley fever\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe government has verified that so far 95 people have died of the deadly\nRift Valley fever, which broke out late last year [2006].\nIt has at the same time said that it has spent 350 million shillings [USD 5\n029 000] in its efforts to contain the disease, which has already spread to\n7 districts in the country.\nAccording to the ministry of health, another 21 districts are at risk, but\nmeasures have been put in place to contain the disease.\nDirector of medical services Dr James Nyikal says the majority of those\naffected by the disease are men aged between 20 and 40 years and that there\nis a decline in reported cases.\n[byline: Carol Gakii]\n******\n[2] Ethiopia - preparedness\nDate: Mon 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ReliefWeb (OCHA - UN Office for Coordination Humanitarian Affairs)\n[edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWB.NSF/db900SID/JBRN-6XGKB2?OpenDocument>\n\nRift Valley fever threatens Ethiopia\n------------------------------------\nFollowing reports of suspected Rift Valley fever (RVF) cases from Kenya,\npreventive measures have been established in Ethiopia. A committee\ncomprised of the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MoARD),\nFederal Ministry of Health (FMoH), Veterinary Laboratory Department, FAO,\nUSAID and WHO established on 27 Dec 2006 is preparing appropriate\nprevention and response. The committee is led by MoARD.\nIn late December 2006, MoARD conducted a rapid assessment in regions\nbordering Kenya, and the report is being finalized. Preliminary results,\nhowever, indicate no cases to date in Ethiopia, even from high risk areas\nsuch as the Moyale zone. WHO and FAO, in collaboration with the government\nand international partners, are closely monitoring the situation.\nMeanwhile, an assessment mission comprised of FMoH, the Water Resource\nMinistry, UNICEF and WHO, has been deployed to the Somali Region from 15 to\n21 Jan 2007. RVF, an acute fever-causing viral disease that affects\ndomestic animals and humans, is most commonly associated with mosquitoborne\nepidemics during years of unusually heavy rainfall.\n******\n[3] Kenya - control measures\nDate: Mon 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Voice of America News [edited]\n<http://www.voanews.com/english/Africa/2007-01-15-voa22.cfm>\n\nFAO increases surveillance for Rift Valley fever in Kenya\n-----------------------------------------------\nIn Kenya, local media report the death toll from Rift Valley fever in north\neastern Kenya has reached 90, with nearly 250 cases in all. Mosquitoes\nspread the disease, which primarily affects animals. The worst hit areas\nare reported to be the Garissa, Wajir, Ijara, and Tana River Districts.\nDr Vincent Martin, veterinarian for the UN Food and Agriculture\nOrganization, has just returned to Rome from Kenya. From FAO headquarters,\nhe spoke to VOA English/Africa Service reporter Joe De Capua about the Rift\nValley fever outbreak. 'In Kenya, the situation has been quite worrying,\nbecause we are facing a Rift Valley fever epidemic, which is quite similar\nto the one that broke out in Kenya 9 years ago. So when I was there, I met\nthe different key stakeholders and partners who are trying to control the\noutbreak situation,' he said.\nIt's unclear how many livestock have been infected. Martin said: 'It's very\ndifficult to get figures on the number of animals affected, basically,\nbecause of the situation on the ground. The fact that all the areas, which\nwere affected, were flooded, it was very difficult to access these places.\nAnd therefore, the reports on suspected animals or abortions or deaths had\ndifficulty getting back to the provincial level or the headquarters. And\ntherefore, that's the main reason why we don't have precise figures.'\nThe FAO is trying to strengthen surveillance by mobilizing teams to\ninvestigate reports of Rift Valley fever in various areas. It's also\noffering technical advice and training on how to identify the disease in\nits early stages.\nMartin said while he didn't see any animals being vaccinated, he believes\nthousands of doses from South Africa and the United States have arrived in\nrural areas.\n[byline: Joe De Capua]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The vaccine obtained from South Africa is probably commercial\nlive-attenuated (Smithburn) vaccine. This vaccine will confer protecting\nantibody levels within a relatively short period but is known to be\nabortogenic. Should pregnant animals be vaccinated, subsequent abortions\nmight cause reluctance to vaccinate or to cooperate with the vaccinators\namong herders. The safer, inactivated vaccine requires booster vaccinations\nand is more laborious and expensive. This is the vaccine of choice in\nnon-endemic situations (RVF-free countries/regions) and prior to the\ncommencement of outbreaks in endemic regions.\nIt will be interesting to note which vaccine has been supplied from the US.\nIs it the MV P12 vaccine, produced from a mutagen-derived strain of (human)\nRVF virus? Details would be appreciated. - Mod.AS]\n******\n[4] Tanzania - preparedness\nDate: Mon 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IPP Media - Guardian, United Republic of Tanzania [edited]\n<http://www.ippmedia.com/ipp/guardian/2007/01/15/82346.html>\n\nOfficials: we are alert over Rift Valley fever [Tanzania]\n-----------------------------------------------\nHealth and livestock authorities in northern Tanzania are keeping close\nwatch at the Tanzania-Kenya border following a fresh outbreak of the deadly\nRift Valley fever in Kenya's North-Eastern Province after a lull of almost\n9 years.\nOfficials at the Northern Zone Veterinary Investigation Centre (VIC) have\nenhanced their monitoring efforts and are maintaining tight restrictions\naround the northern border.\nThe VIC acting chief, Dr Adam Mbise, confirmed in a telephone interview\nthat round-the-clock surveillance was on as directed by the director of\nveterinary services in the Livestock Development ministry.\nWe are maintaining tight surveillance on our northern border and are\nclosely monitoring developments linked to a new outbreak of the deadly RVF\nin Kenya, said another senior expert with VIC, Dr Adam Pima.\nNo case of RVF has been reported in Tanzania, but experts have warned\npeople around the border against eating any kind of meat that has not been\npassed by a certified veterinary officer. Dr Pima has further recommended\nthat people desist from drinking raw milk that he said could be behind the\noutbreak. People are also supposed to sleep under nets at night, because it\nis possible for the fever to be transmitted from livestock to humans by\nmosquitoes, he added.\nExperts fear that if the disease spreads to Tanzania, it could put the\nlives of a staggering 35 million people and a cattle population of 18.5\nmillion at serious risk. The new outbreak of RVF has killed nearly 80\npeople in Kenya over the past 4 weeks, according to health officials in\nNairobi early last week. The vaccination of at least a million livestock in\nthe regions hit by the fever is said to be going on.\nSome 200 people have contracted the disease since the 1st case was reported\nlate last month [December 2006], and it has continued to spread across\nseveral districts in Kenya.\nOmar Ahmed, the medical services chief in the worst-hit North Eastern\nProvince, was quoted as saying a death toll of 70 has been registered in\nGarissa, Ijara, Tana River, and Wajir districts. Another 5 deaths have been\nreported in Kilifi District along the Indian Ocean coast.\nMore people were understood to have been admitted to hospitals with the\nviral disease, which is usually transmitted from livestock to humans by\nmosquitoes, mainly during and after flooding. However, preliminary\nepidemiological reports suggest that the drinking of raw milk from infected\nanimals could be the main route of infection in this outbreak.\nRVF, which was 1st detected way back in the 1930s in South Africa, affects\nboth livestock and humans. Experts believe that the mosquitoborne pathogen\nhad crossed the Sahara into Egypt by 1977, and by 1999, it had traversed\nthe Red Sea into Yemen and Saudi Arabia.\nPatients who contract the virus usually experience fever, weakness, joint\npain, dizziness and extreme weight loss. One of the earliest reported\noutbreaks occurred in 1950-1951 in Kenya.\n[byline: Adam Ihucha]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5] Kenya - response to disease forecasts\nDate: Mon 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: Peter Roeder <Peter.Roeder@fao.org>\n\nre: Rift Valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya\n-----------------------------------------------\nIn my message [see 20070112.0164], I lamented the lack of national and\ninternational preparedness for the RVF emergency.\nThat is still the case, but to be fair, I must mention the fact that the\ncoordinated actions taken by the veterinary and medical authorities of the\nKenyan Ministries of Health and Livestock and Fisheries Development are\nimpressive and might well have served to reduce the incidence of human\ncases. With very limited funding available and an inadequate resource base,\nit is laudable that they have managed to put a coherent response in place.\nIt seems that at least some lessons were learned from the last RVF pandemic.\n--\nDr Peter Roeder, BVetMed, MSc, PhD, MRCVS\nAnimal Health Officer (Virology) and GREP Secretary\nAnimal Health Service\nAnimal Production and Health Division\nFood and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations\nRome, Italy\n<peter.roeder@fao.org>\n******\n[6] Kenya - background\nDate: Mon 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: Susan Baekland <grolleyog@wanadoo.fr>\n\n[The following information has been received from Dr Susan Baekland, a\nveterinarian who formerly worked in Kenya. Her firsthand observations might\nhelp in assessing the difficulties the authorities encounter in controlling\nRVF in the affected regions. - Mod.AS]\nThe problem with that area, which I used to know very well indeed, is that\nthe Tana river has overflowed, and there have been massive rains. The\nSomali and some Rendille tribesmen herd cattle, fat tailed sheep, and\ngoats. These animals are enclosed in a circular enclosure made of thorn\ntree branches at night. They are not inside, and the herdsmen, unless they\nare in one place for quite a while, will sleep in the open alongside a\nfire. The Rendille make a shelter of semicircular branches covered with\nhides. These residences are taken down and carried on camels when they\nmove. These people are going to drink the milk of their stock and probably\nkill and eat a sick animal before it dies. It is a real problem.\nThe herds and herdsmen are scattered over huge areas looking for grazing,\noften a long way off any sort of vehicular access. They can be spotted from\nthe air. But it all costs money, and if one is going to vaccinate\nlivestock, then somehow these herdsmen who are largely illiterate and very\nscattered have to be informed. The only real way to contact these people is\nby radio or word of mouth by a fellow tribesman, well informed and on a\ncamel. You can use vehicles, but they get held up all the time by the bush\nand rocks, etc. But then they will suspect it is a government tax trap. It\nall takes time; whether the nomads will bring their stock in for\nvaccination is another matter.\n--\nSusan Baekland\n<grolleyog@wanadoo.fr>\n[The preparedness steps in Eastern Africa, particularly in the Horn of\nAfrica, might be of an academic nature if susceptible animals in the\nRVF-prone areas remain unvaccinated. In spite of the immense difficulties\ndescribed by Susan Baekland and others, timely mass vaccinations are\ncrucial for the prevention of disease in animals and exposure of humans.\nFor description of the areas where vaccinations should be performed, see\nFAO's document 'Possible RVF activity in the Horn of Africa,' November\n2006, which includes maps; available online at\n<http://www.fao.org/docs/eims/upload//217874/EW_hornafrica_nov06_rvf.pdf>.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n -----------------------------------------------\nHealth and livestock authorities in northern Tanzania are keeping close\nwatch at the Tanzania-Kenya border following a fresh outbreak of the deadly\nRift Valley fever in Kenya's North-Eastern Province after a lull of almost\n9 years.
