VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA (02): KENYA\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 13 Jan 2007\nFrom: Pablo Nart <pablo.nart@terra.es>\nSource: News 24 [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2054459,00.html>\n\nThe death toll from an outbreak of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in Kenya\nhas hit 88, said officials on Saturday [13 Jan 2007], as health\nauthorities fanned out across affected regions in a bid to contain the disease.\nThe viral disease has infected about 250 people since it was 1st\nreported in mid-December 2006 and has continued to spread across\nseveral, mostly arid, districts in the country.\n'In northeastern regions, so far we have recorded 82 deaths,' said\nOmar Ahmed, the medical services chief in the country's worst-hit\nNortheastern Province.\nHealth authorities have also reported the death of at least 6 people\nin the coastal province, bringing the overall toll to 88.\n'We are moving across the affected region to ensure that we contain\nthe disease, which is spread by either mosquitoes or by direct\ncontact with infected animals,' Ahmed told AFP by telephone.\nOfficials said vaccinations targeting 2 million animals, which began\non Monday [8 Jan 2007], have intensified in the region, most of which\nwas recently hit by flooding triggered by unusually heavy rains [see\ncommentary].\nThe exact number of people infected is unknown, but experts believe\nit is much higher than officially recorded, because most of those\naffected come from communities of nomadic farmers in remote areas.\nThe government has banned the slaughter of animals in affected\nregions, advised farmers to reduce contact between humans and\nlivestock, boil milk before drinking it and sleep under mosquito nets.\nPatients have fever, general weakness, back pain, dizziness, vomit\nblood and lose weight at the onset of the illness.\nThe United States Centers for Disease Control and aid agencies\nMedecins Sans Frontieres, the World Health Organization and the\nUnited Nations children's fund are assisting the government in\ncontaining the outbreak.\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n[Mass animal vaccinations are vital in preventing RVF in animals and\nreducing exposure of humans to this zoonotic disease agent. There are\n2 commercially available animal vaccines: live-attenuated and\ninactivated (dead) vaccines. The live vaccine, prepared from\nSmithburn's attenuated strain of RVF virus, is recommended for use in\nnon-pregnant animals (cattle, sheep, goats, camels) since it may\ncause abortions. The inactivated vaccine may be used in pregnant\nanimals as well; it requires a booster vaccination, and its price is higher.\nHere, too, timing is everything. If applied prior to the outbreak,\nboth vaccine types may be used with good results. When vaccination is\nresorted to during the course of an outbreak, its effect will be less\nsignificant.\nDetails on the vaccine used currently in Kenya and the animal species\nvaccinated will be useful. Can one assume that -- in view of time\nconstraints and the need for immediate effect -- mainly or only live\nvaccine will be applied? - Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: News 24 [edited]\n<http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,,2-11-1447_2054459,00.html>\n\nThe death toll from an outbreak of Rift Valley fever [RVF] in Kenya\nhas hit 88, said officials on Saturday [13 Jan 2007], as health\nauthorities fanned out across affected regions in a bid to contain the disease. Officials said vaccinations targeting 2 million animals, which began\non Monday [8 Jan 2007], have intensified in the region, most of which\nwas recently hit by flooding triggered by unusually heavy rains [see\ncommentary]. The live vaccine, prepared from\nSmithburn's attenuated strain of RVF virus, is recommended for use in\nnon-pregnant animals (cattle, sheep, goats, camels) since it may\ncause abortions. Medecins Sans Frontieres, the World Health Organization and the\nUnited Nations children's fund are assisting the government in\ncontaining the outbreak.\n --\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n The government has banned the slaughter of animals in affected\nregions, advised farmers to reduce contact between humans and\nlivestock, boil milk before drinking it and sleep under mosquito nets. We are moving across the affected region to ensure that we contain\nthe disease, which is spread by either mosquitoes or by direct\ncontact with infected animals,' Ahmed told AFP by telephone. The exact number of people infected is unknown, but experts believe\nit is much higher than officially recorded, because most of those\naffected come from communities of nomadic farmers in remote areas. Can one assume that -- in view of time\nconstraints and the need for immediate effect -- mainly or only live\nvaccine will be applied? - Mod. The viral disease has infected about 250 people since it was 1st\nreported in mid-December 2006 and has continued to spread across\nseveral, mostly arid, districts in the country.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-01-13 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2007-01-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Northeastern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States Centers", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6564", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift valley fever - Eastern Africa: Somalia, Kenya", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6564", "date": "2007-01-12 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - EASTERN AFRICA: SOMALIA, KENYA\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org >\n[1]\nDate: Fri 12 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, Fri 12 Jan 2007 [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L12869448.htm>\n\nRift Valley fever virus, a virus that has killed nearly 80 people in\nKenya, has spread to the Somali border town of Doble, where thousands\nof refugees fleeing conflict are assembled, officials said on Friday\n12 Jan 2007. The disease had been largely confined to remote parts of\nKenya's North Eastern and Coast provinces. However, the disease which\nis spread through the movement of infected livestock, has crossed\nover to neighbouring Somalia.\n'In Doble, there were reports of people falling sick and animals\ndying,' Kariuki Njenga, a virologist with the Centre for Disease\nControl, told Reuters. 'There are also reports of animals aborting\nfor the last 2 weeks. These are some of the symptoms of the Rift Valley Fever.'\nAlthough transmission from animals to humans is rare, the disease\ndevelops into a much more severe illness once it crosses over causing\nvictims to abort, vomit blood or bleed to death. The disease is\ntransmitted to humans through mosquito bites or frequent contact with\ncontaminated animals.\n'Four more people have died of Rift Valley Fever in the region today.\nThis brings the total death toll to 78. There are now 214 confirmed\ncases since 14 Dec 2006,' said Ahmed Omar, medical officer for North\nEast province.\nThe World Health Organisation (WHO) has said its teams were having\ndifficulties getting help to affected people as heavy rains over\nKenya had made roads impassable, meaning the disease could spread to\nother areas. The WHO, Medecins Sans Frontieres and other agencies\nhave deployed teams of experts to reinforce local hospitals and\nclinics and stop the epidemic spreading any further\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The human death toll from Rift Valley fever in the region has\nincreased fro 68 on Fri 5 Jan 2007 to the current total of 78. The\nnumber of known cases is now 214 in Kenya plus an unknown number in\nthe town of Doble across the border in Somalia. - Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 12 Jan 2007\nFrom: Peter Roeder <Peter.Roeder@fao.org>\n\nRE: PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Somalia: susp, RFI\n-----------------------------------------------------\nIt is interesting, if rather disheartening, to watch another RVF\nepizootic emerge and evolve in eastern Africa and to note that it is\nsuch a close recapitulation of events that occurred in 1997/8 and\ndecades before. It is a recapitulation not only with respect to\ndisease evolution but also in terms of national and international\npreparedness -- or lack of it.\nThose who followed ProMED in those days will be aware that the\nepizootic attracted intense international attention and was closely\nreported in postings, which contain much useful information. Despite\nseminal work on developing early warning systems based on remote\nsensing, led by Vincent Martin, Glyn Davies and Kenneth Linthicum\ninter alia, it seems that the capacity to respond has not improved\ngreatly in the high-risk countries in Africa.\nAs warned by FAO EMPRES, in the face of an established El Nino event,\nif continuing rainfall maintains inundation, we are likely to see in\nthe next weeks the progressive emergence of foci of RVF and other\ndiseases across a broad swathe of country from southern Ethiopia and\nSomalia to northern Tanzania with devastating effects on the health\nof communities and livelihoods based on livestock production and\ntrade. [See further, in section 3 of this posting, data from the\nFAO/EMPRES analysis and outlook, published ahead of the current RVF\noutbreak -- namely in November 2006. - Mod.AS]\nIn addition, re-emergence of disease in West Africa is a real\npossibility. Are the national authorities themselves taking action to\nlimit impact? Should major epizootics develop, this time will it\nbring about investment in establishing systematic early warning and\nresponse systems for the future, or will there be a flurry of\nexuberant activity followed by _Aedes_ eggs settling into the dried\nmud of dambos and heads re-buried in the sands of Africa like the\nproverbial ostrich?\nOne other issue I would like to raise is that whenever there are\nreports of RVF outbreaks, the possibility of the disease spreading to\nother areas is described, as it is in your posting of 11 Jan 2006\n[20070111.0112]. I wish to suggest that this is an incorrect concept,\nand I would be grateful if others more knowledgeable than me could\ncomment. Certainly as an RVF epizootic evolves, one sees first the\nemergence of RVF in a small number of sites and then asynchronous\nappearance of additional foci of disease over an extended time.\nSuperficially this can give an appearance of the disease spreading\nlike a contagious disease, and of course there might be some local\nspread by movement of vectors and viraemic livestock, yet, in fact,\ninfection is primarily emerging from dormancy at different times in\ndifferent sites as conditions there become suitable for the emergence\nand build-up of primary and secondary vector populations, possibly\nalso reflecting density of susceptible hosts available to amplify\ninfection. Lateral spread seems to play only a minor role in\nepizootic development.\nThis is not a trivial, pedantic issue. Undoubtedly area-wide\nvaccination has a place in RVF control to suppress emergence and\ndevelopment of epizootics but the concept of disease spreading out\nfrom a focus tends to mislead people into conceiving that vaccination\nbuffer zones can contain infection. That is unlikely given that the\nvirus has already been seeded into and established long ago in\nsuitable habitats across a broad area.\n--\nDr Peter Roeder, BVetMed, MSc, PhD, MRCVS\nAnimal Health Officer (Virology) and GREP Secretary\nAnimal Health Service\nAnimal Production and Health Division\nFood and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations\nRome, Italy\n<Peter.Roeder@fao.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Fri, 12 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: FAO, Animal Production and Health Division, Emergency\nPrevention System for the Transboundary Animal Diseases (EMPRES) [edited]\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/home.asp>\n\nThe above web-site includes the section 'EMPRES WATCH' as well as a\npdf document titled 'Possible RVF activity in the Horn of Africa' (7\npages), dated November 2006; recommended reading. It is available\non-line at\n<http://www.fao.org/docs/eims/upload//217874/EW_hornafrica_nov06_rvf.pdf>.\nThe following 2 last sections of the said document are herewith copied.\n5. Recommendations\n------------------\nThe Risk maps presented in this review were obtained from the\nanalysis of environmental data alerts and depict specific areas of\nAfrica that could face new outbreaks of vector-borne diseases and\nmore specifically Rift Valley fever. Countries located in high risk\nareas of RVF and those which recently experienced RVF should activate\nand increase disease surveillance according to OIE standards in\nparticular those countries located in areas associated with the\nprevious occurrence of RVF. If there are no reports of clinical signs\ncompatible with RVF, disease surveillance should focus on mosquitoes\nand serology of susceptible ruminants only.\nFAO encourages these countries to activate their early warning,\nprevention and contingency plans.\nImporting countries of meat or animals from RVF risk areas should not\napply trade restrictions if disease surveillance is in place in\ncountries/zones at risk with negative results. The OIE standards\nclearly separate 'RVF infection free country or zone' from 'RVF\ninfected countries/zones without disease'.\nIn the 1st case the country is out of the historical distribution\narea, a surveillance programme is in place and 4 years have elapsed\nsince the last epidemic.\nIn the 2nd, the country is considered free but disease has not\noccurred in humans and animals in the past 6 months and climatic\nchanges predisposing to outbreaks of RVF have not occurred during this time.\nA 3rd classification is 'RVF infected country/zone with disease,'\nmeaning clinical disease in humans and animals has occurred within\nthe past 6 months. Even in presence of disease or infection, the OIE\nTerrestrial Animal Health Code accepts trade of ruminants and meat\nfrom infected countries if certain specific conditions of quarantine\nor vaccination are met. This is based on timely and prompt\nnotification of infection\n6. FAO in action\n----------------\n1. The EMPRES (Emergency Prevention System for the Transboundary\nAnimal Diseases) programme provides, at an international level, an\noverall initiative for coordination of the RVF-Early Warning System,\nwhere data integration and analysis are performed before being\ndisseminated to recipient countries, international organizations and\nkey stakeholders in the form of RVF bulletins and risk assessments.\nEMPRES promotes the use of remote sensing for forecasting RVF and\nother arboviruses occurrence and field validation studies on a\ncountry and regional basis, and its use may allow for preventive\nmeasures to be taken such as the vaccination of susceptible livestock\nand mosquito larval control methods.\n2. The regional task forces in Kenya have been alerted. FAO office in\nKenya is currently monitoring the situation and is promoting field\nassessment mission in flooded areas. Results are expected in the near future.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Dr Roeder's observations, based upon his expertise and experience in\nthe East African arena, are highly valued. One wonders if the timely\nEMPRES warnings could have helped to set in motion better\npreparedness for the evolving outbreak. Certainly, the unstable\npolitical situation in the Horn of Africa has played its role in\ndelaying adequate response. - Mod.AS]", "summary": "Superficially this can give an appearance of the disease spreading\nlike a contagious disease, and of course there might be some local\nspread by movement of vectors and viraemic livestock, yet, in fact,\ninfection is primarily emerging from dormancy at different times in\ndifferent sites as conditions there become suitable for the emergence\nand build-up of primary and secondary vector populations, possibly\nalso reflecting density of susceptible hosts available to amplify\ninfection. [edited]\n<http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/newsarticle.asp?newsid=1759&newscategoryid1>\n\nThree cases of the highly contagious Rift Valley fever (RFV) have been\nreported in Nairobi's Kariobangi and Eastleigh estates. Two people died\nlast week while a 3rd died early this week at the Kenyatta National\nHospital. But the government insists that the 3 contracted the disease\nwhile in the North Eastern province.\nAddressing a press conference on Wed [31 Jan 2007], Senior Deputy Director\nof Medical Services Dr. Shahnaaz Sharif said meat in Nairobi, and other\nareas that have no reported cases, is still safe to eat. He said: 'We wish\nto reassure Kenyans that it is safe to eat meat, but you must ensure that\nthe meat is cooked properly until there are no bloody parts. So far no\nconfirmed cases of RVF have been infected following eating of meat.'\nDr. Sharif stressed that there is an ongoing public awareness campaign\ntargeting different audiences to inform Kenyans on the fever and steps that\nshould be taken to prevent infection in both animals and people. 'You can\nonly get RVF by touching the blood or body fluids of an infected animal,\nslaughtering, skinning and cutting meat of an infected animal, touching and\nhandling raw meat of an infected animal, drinking un-boiled milk from an\ninfected animal and the bite of an infected mosquito,' he said.\n[RFV] is [transmitted] by _Aedes_ mosquitoes and has spread in 14 districts\nof the country namely; Garissa, Ijiara, Lamu, Thika, Maragua, Wajir, Tana\nRiver, Kilifi, Malindi, Taita Taveta, Isiolo, Kirinyaga, Kajiado and\nNairobi. Out of the 414 suspected cases, 135 have been confirmed as Rift\nValley fever. It is however unclear what the precise death toll is. On\nMonday the [death] toll was 121. Since then, however, 2 deaths were\nreported in Kajiado yesterday bringing the toll to 123. However the\ngovernment says the toll is one less at 122 deaths.\n[Byline: Catherine Karong'o]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 1 Feb 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: allAfrica.com, The Nation (Nairobi), Thu 1 Feb 2007 [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200701311034.html>\n\nTwo more people have died of Rift Valley fever in Nairobi, sparking fears\nthat the virus could spread in the city. The 2 -- a man and a woman -- were\nadmitted to Kenyatta National Hospital from Nairobi's Kariobangi and\nEastleigh estates last week and died on Mon 29 Jan 2007, senior ministry of\nHealth official Patrick Nguku said yesterday.\nMedics had established that the 2 had travelled to Garissa District, the\nepicentre of the deadly disease. 'They are likely to have contracted the\nvirus there,' Dr Nguku said. This brings to 3 the number of people who have\ndied at Kenyatta hospital in the past 2 weeks. The 1st death occurred on\nSunday after a patient admitted 2 weeks ago from Kerugoya in Kirinyaga\nDistrict succumbed. This prompted the hospital to issue an alert to doctors\nand nurses to be on the lookout for the killer disease.\nAt the same time, KNH director Jotham Micheni has announced that the\nhospital has set up an isolation ward where patients manifesting symptoms\nof the disease would be confined and treated. Dr Nguku said 2 more victims\nof the fever were still at the hospital.\nThe officials were answering journalists' questions during a joint press\nconference by Livestock and Health ministry officials at Afya House. Dr\nShanaaz Shariff, the senior deputy director of medical services, urged\nNairobi residents not to panic, saying the disease was unlikely to spread\nin the city.\n'A surveillance team comprising Livestock and Health ministry officials has\nbeen set up in Nairobi to ensure that no infected animals from the\nneighbouring Maragua, Kirinyaga and Thika districts are allowed into the\ncity. One can only be infected by handling blood or body fluids,\nslaughtering, skinning, cutting or drinking unboiled milk from an infected\nanimal or from the bite of an infected mosquito,' he said.\nHe appealed to Nairobi residents not to stop eating roasted or boiled meat.\n'However, people should ensure they only eat meat that has been\nrubber-stamped and inspected by veterinary officials,' Dr Shariff added.\nSince the outbreak 2 months ago, the death toll has reached 122.\n[Byline: Mike Mwaniki]\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed 31 Jan 2007\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: SomaliNet, Wed 31 Jan 2007 [edited]\n<http://somalinet.com/news/world/East%20Africa/7120>\n\nKenya's capital Nairobi is among the 9 high-risk districts where a million\ndoses of Rift Valley fever (RVF) vaccine will be distributed. Kenya's\nLivestock and Fisheries Development Minister Joseph Munyao said Tue 30 Jan\n2007 that the vaccine would also be distributed in Nakuru, Koibatek, Uasin\nGishu, Trans Nzoia, Trans Mara, Narok,\nKajiado, Machakos and Nyeri districts,\nMeanwhile, Rift Valley Fever has killed up to 124 people. 'On average, each\ndistrict will receive 100 000 doses, which will be distributed according to\nlivestock population and RVF risk. 'At the same time, the ongoing control\nactivities in North Eastern and Coast provinces will be stepped up,' Munyao\nsaid.\nWhen the Rift Valley fever broke out 2 months ago, more than 400 000 head\nof livestock, out of the targeted 2 million, had been vaccinated in various\nparts [of the country]. On Tuesday, the lives stock minister distributed 10\n000 litres of synthetic insecticide which would be distributed at no cost\nto farmers and herders to assist in fighting mosquitoes.\nIn the same light, the United States (U.S) Government announced it would\ndonate a 2nd shipment of 800 000 doses of livestock vaccine worth Sh 21\nmillion [USD 299 000]. 'This contribution follows the initial one where 450\n000 doses, worth Sh 12.5 million [USD 178 000], were donated on 7 Jan\n2007,' a statement added. The Kenyan Government last week released Sh 100\nmillion [USD 1.4 million] to assist in the fight against Rift Valley fever.\nRift Valley fever which was first identified in the Rift Valley Province in\nthe 1930s is a viral disease which primarily affects animals, but\noccasionally attacks humans.\n[Byline: Bonny Apunyu]\n--\nJoe Dudley\nEAI Corporation\nSAIC\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n******\n[4]\nDate: Fri 2 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR Weekly, Fri 2 Feb 2007 / 56(04);73-76 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5604a3.htm?s_cid=mm5604a3_e>\n\nRift Valley Fever Outbreak -- Kenya: Nov 2006 to Jan 2007\n--------------------------------------------------------\nIn mid-December 2006, several unexplained fatalities associated with fever\nand generalized bleeding were reported to the Kenya Ministry of Health\n(KMOH) from Garissa District in North Eastern Province (NEP). By 20 Dec\n2006, a total of 11 deaths had been reported. Of serum samples collected\nfrom the first 19 patients, Rift Valley fever (RVF) virus RNA or\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies against RVF virus were found in samples\nfrom 10 patients; all serum specimens were negative for yellow fever,\nEbola, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and dengue viruses. The outbreak\nwas confirmed by isolation of RVF virus from 6 of the specimens. Humans can\nbe infected with RVF virus from bites of mosquitoes or other arthropod\nvectors that have fed on animals infected with RVF virus, or through\ncontact with viremic animals, particularly livestock. Reports of livestock\ndeaths and unexplained animal abortions in NEP provided further evidence of\nan RVF outbreak.\nOn 20 Dec 2006, an investigation was launched by KMOH, the Kenya Field\nEpidemiology and Laboratory Training Program (FELTP), the Kenya Medical\nResearch Institute (KEMRI), the Walter Reed Project of the U.S. Army\nMedical Research Unit, CDC-Kenya's Global Disease Detection Center, and\nother partners, including the World Health Organization (WHO) and Medecins\nSans Frontieres (MSF). This report describes the findings from that initial\ninvestigation and the control measures taken in response to the RVF\noutbreak, which spread to multiple additional provinces and districts,\nresulting in 404 cases with 118 deaths as of Thu 25 Jan 2007.\nTeams of investigators conducted patient interviews and reviewed medical\nrecords from 1 Dec 2006 forward in major health-care facilities in the\ndistricts from which cases were first reported. The teams detected\nadditional cases by meeting with elders, other leaders, and health-care\nproviders in villages where cases had been reported and in adjacent\nvillages. Blood samples from patients with suspected RVF were collected and\nmaintained at 39.2 F (4.0 C). Samples from NEP and surrounding areas were\ntransported to a field laboratory established at Garissa Provincial\nHospital by CDC, KEMRI, and KMOH; samples from other areas were sent to\nKEMRI laboratories in Nairobi and to a laboratory in Malindi that was\nsupported by a team from Health Canada.\nA suspected case was defined as acute onset of fever (>99.5F [>37.5C]) with\nheadache or muscle and joint pain since 1 Dec 2006 in a person who had no\nother known cause of acute febrile illness (e.g., malaria). A probable case\nwas defined as acute onset of fever in a person with unexplained bleeding\n(i.e., in stool, vomit, or sputum or from gums, nose, vagina, skin, or\neyes), vision deterioration, or altered consciousness. A confirmed case was\ndefined as a suspected or probable case with laboratory confirmation of the\npresence in serum of anti-RVF virus IgM by enzyme-linked immunosorbent\nassay (ELISA) or RVF virus RNA by reverse transcription polymerase chain\nreaction (RT-PCR).\nThe index case was reported in Garissa District in a patient who had\nsymptom onset on 30 Nov 2006. Retrospective analysis of sera collected\nduring July to November 2006 at Garissa Provincial Hospital revealed no\nevidence of earlier acute RVF infections. As of 25 Jan 2007, a total of 404\ncases of RVF had been reported in Kenya with 118 deaths, a case-fatality\nrate of 29 percent. Of the reported cases, 115 (29 percent) were laboratory\nconfirmed by anti-RVF virus IgM by ELISA (64 cases, 56 percent) or RT-PCR\n(79, 69 percent), including 28 cases (24 percent) confirmed by both. Of the\nremaining 289 cases, 109 were classified as probable.\nOf the 230 patients with available demographic information, 140 (61\npercent) were male [illustrated by a histogram in the original text].\nPatients ranged in age from 4 to 85 years, with a median age of 27 years\n(30 years for females and 25 years for males). RVF cases were reported from\n3 districts in NEP (Garissa [175 cases], Ijara [125], and Wajir [26]); 5\ndistricts in Coast Province (Kilifi [38], Tana River [16], Malindi [8],\nIsiolo [8], and Taita Taveta [one]); 2 districts in Central Province\n(Kirinyanga [2] and Maragua [one]); one district in Rift Valley Province\n(Kajiado [3]); and one from Nairobi Area [These districts are located in a\nmap in the original text]. The patient from Nairobi had traveled to NEP\nduring the week before illness onset but was hospitalized in Nairobi. Ijara\n(population 79 932) and Garissa (population 420 918) districts had the\nhighest RVF incidence rates: 156 and 42 per 100 000 population, respectively.\nAmong the first 97 reported cases from Garissa and Wajir districts with\ndetailed epidemiologic information available, 71 (73 percent) met the\nprobable case definition; 38 of the 62 patients who provided blood samples\ntested positive by IgM ELISA, RT-PCR, or both. The most frequently reported\nsymptoms among the 97 patients were fever (100 percent), headache (90\npercent), bleeding (76 percent), malaise (70 percent), muscle pain (62\npercent), back pain (60 percent), vomiting (56 percent), and joint pain (51\npercent).\nTwo thirds of the 66 patients who provided information on potential risk\nfactors reported having an animal that was recently ill. The most\nfrequently reported RVF risk factors during the 2 weeks preceding illness\nonset were drinking unboiled (raw) milk (72 percent); living within 100\nmeters of a swamp (70 percent); having an ill animal (67 percent); drinking\nmilk from an ill animal (59 percent); working as a herdsman (50 percent);\nhaving a dead animal (50 percent); and slaughtering an animal (42 percent).\nApproximately 9 percent of patients reported contact with another ill human.\nThe outbreak peaked on 24 Dec 2006, and the number of daily cases has been\ndeclining since 27 Dec 2006 [illustrated by a figure in the original text].\nA ban on livestock slaughtering in Garissa District went into effect on 27\nDec 2006 and was expanded as RVF was detected in additional districts.\nVaccination of animals with live, attenuated RVF vaccine began on 8 Jan\n2007. Prevention messages were developed in 3 languages (English, Kiswhali,\nand Somali), and public meetings (known as barazas) were held to spread\ninformation rapidly to the community. Messages also were disseminated via\nradio, a widely used communication medium in NEP. Village elders, chiefs,\nand religious leaders were consulted throughout Garissa District, leading\nto a district ban on the slaughter of livestock and closure of the\nlivestock market. Health-care workers were trained to care for persons\nsuspected to be infected with RVF virus.\nReported by: P Nguku, S Sharif, A Omar, C Nzioka, P Muthoka, J Njau, A\nDahiye, T Galgalo, J Mwihia, J Njoroge, H Limo, J Mutiso, R Kalani, A\nSheikh, J Nyikal, Kenya Ministry of Health; D Mutonga, J Omollo, A Guracha,\nJ Muindi, S Amwayi, D Langat, D Owiti, A Mohammed, Kenya Field Epidemiology\nand Laboratory Training Program, Kenya Ministry of Health/CDC. J Musaa,\nKenya Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries Development. R Sang, Kenya\nMedical Research Institute. R Breiman, K Njenga, D Feikin, M Katz, H Burke,\nP Nyaga, M Ackers, S Gikundi, V Omballa, L Nderitu, N Wamola, R Wanjala, S\nOmulo, International Emerging Infections Program, Global Disease Detection\nCenter, CDC Kenya. J Richardson, D Schnabel, S Martin, US Army Medical\nResearch Unit-Kenya. D Hoel, H Hanafi, M Weiner, US Naval Medical Research\nUnit No. 3, Cairo, Egypt. J Onsongo, T Kojo, M Duale, A Hassan, M Dabaar, C\nNjuguna, Kenya Country Office; M Yao, African Regional Office; T Grein, P\nFormenty, World Health Organization, Geneva, Switzerland. B Telfer,\nMedecins Sans Frontieres Belgium; R Lepec, Medecins Sans Frontieres\nEpicentre, Paris, France. H Feldmann, A Grolla, Health Canada, Winnipeg,\nManitoba. S Wainwright, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Svc, US Dept of\nAgriculture. Global Disease Detection Program, Coordinating Office for\nGlobal Health; Div of Global Migration and Quarantine, Div of Emerging\nInfections and Surveillance Services, National Center for Preparedness,\nDetection, and Control of Infectious Diseases (proposed); Special Pathogens\nBr, Div of Viral and Rickettisial Diseases, Div of Vector-Borne Infectious\nDiseases, National Center for Zoonotic, Vector-Borne and Enteric Diseases\n(proposed); E Lederman, E Farnon, C Rao, BK Kapella, H Gould, EIS officers,\nCDC.\nMMWR Editorial Note\n-------------------\nRVF is an acute, febrile zoonotic disease caused by Rift Valley fever\nvirus, which belongs to the family _Bunyaviridae_ and genus _Phlebovirus_.\nThe virus is primarily a vector-borne zoonotic pathogen. Humans acquire RVF\nthrough bites from infected mosquitoes or, more frequently, through\nexposure to the blood, body fluids, or tissues of animals that have been\nbitten by infected mosquitoes.\nDirect exposure to infected animals can occur during slaughter or through\nveterinary and obstetric procedures. RVF was first described in sheep in\nthe early 20th century, and the virus was first isolated in humans in Kenya\nin 1930 (1,2). In livestock, RVF causes abortion and death. Livestock\nepizootics can occur after heavy rainfall and flooding that result in\nhatching of _Aedes_ mosquitoes (thought to be the initial vector and\ninter-epizootic reservoir of RVF) and other vectors that feed on nearby\nmammals (3). Eastern Kenya experienced unusually heavy rainfall during the\nperiod October to December 2006, three times the average for that period\nduring the preceding 8 years and 13 times the rainfall in 2005 (Kenya\nMeteorological Department, unpublished data, 2007).\nPatients with RVF usually have initial signs and symptoms of influenza-like\nillness; less than 8 percent of patients subsequently have severe disease,\nincluding generalized hemorrhagic syndrome, encephalitis, or retinitis (2).\nThe overall human mortality rate from RVF has been estimated at 0.5 percent\nto 1.0 percent of those infected, but the rate is much higher among those\nwith severe disease. The largest reported human outbreak occurred in Kenya\nduring the period 1997 to 1998, in which an estimated 89 000 persons (based\non a systematic serosurvey) were infected and 478 died; this outbreak also\nwas centered in NEP (3, 4, 5). Previous RVF outbreaks among humans were not\nreported outside sub-Saharan Africa until 1977 to 1978, when approximately\n18 000 persons became ill with 1000 in Yemen had severe illness (6, 7, 8).\nLike the 1997-1998 outbreak, the current outbreak was associated with heavy\nrainfall, which produced massive flooding in much of Kenya, and\nparticularly in NEP. Climatic forecasting in conjunction with satellite\nimaging of flooded areas has been suggested as a method for predicting\nwhere and when RVF outbreaks might occur, potentially enabling earlier\ninterventions (9).\nMost of the cases before 20 Dec 2006 occurred in young men who herded\nlivestock, perhaps because herdsmen are the first to identify and slaughter\nill animals. Later in the outbreak, the distribution of cases broadened by\nage and sex. Young women also were over-represented, perhaps because they\nhandle uncooked animal products at home as they prepare meals for the\nfamily. Cases among children aged <5 years and the elderly have been rare,\nprobably because they rarely interact with animals or handle raw animal\nproducts.\nMost patients reported to KMOH had severe illness with bleeding, which\nlikely accounts for the 29 percent case-fatality rate. Judging from\nprevious studies, many mild, undetected RVF virus infections likely\noccurred during this outbreak (5). Additional cases of severe disease also\nmight have occurred in NEP but were not detected because of the\ninaccessibility of many areas of the province resulting from flooding. Many\nareas of NEP, including an entire division of Garissa District, were\nunreachable by road from early December to mid-January.\nSince mid-January, RVF in livestock has been detected in districts\nsurrounding Nairobi, signaling occurrence of the outbreak in new areas.\nReports also have been received of livestock and humans with illness\nconsistent with RVF across the border in Somalia, where disease assessment\nhas been hampered by ongoing security concerns. Several international\norganizations are collaborating to control the spread of the outbreak\nwithin Kenya and to other countries. Travelers should take precautions when\nvisiting RVF-affected areas.\nGenerally, the risk for RVF infection among travelers to Kenya is low,\nunless they visit areas where an outbreak is occurring and are bitten by\ninfected mosquitoes or come in contact with body fluids, uncooked tissue,\nor aerosols from infected livestock. No preventive RVF medications or\nlicensed vaccines for humans exist. Travelers to affected areas should\nreduce their risk for infection by protecting themselves from mosquito\nbites and by avoiding direct contact with livestock. Specific\nrecommendations for U.S. travelers are available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/travel/other/2006/rift_valley_fever_kenya.htm>.\nTo control the outbreak, KMOH launched several interventions, some of which\nmight have limited the public health impact of the outbreak. A ban on the\nslaughter of animals (including during Eid-ul-azha, a religious holiday)\nwas imposed in NEP and strictly enforced. The Ministry of Livestock and\nFisheries Development initiated a policy of vaccinating apparently\nunaffected herds of livestock in districts in which human or livestock RVF\ndisease had been confirmed and also in adjacent districts; however, as of\n25 Jan 2007, only a small proportion of livestock had been immunized. Other\ninterventions included heightened disease surveillance among humans and\nanimals, community mobilization, animal quarantines and restricted\ntransport of livestock, and an integrated vector-control strategy,\nincluding indoor residual spraying and larviciding. RVF wards were\nestablished in which appropriate infection-control measures were encouraged.\nTimely detection of this outbreak was aided by implementation of Integrated\nDisease Surveillance and Response [A strategy of the African Regional\nOffice of WHO that aims to improve availability and use of surveillance and\nlaboratory data to control infectious diseases that are the leading causes\nof death, disability, and illness in the region] within most of the\naffected districts. A 2nd factor contributing to timely detection was\ninitiation of RVF laboratory-supported field surveillance of febrile\npatients at outpatient clinics in Garissa. Ongoing epidemiologic,\nentomologic, and veterinary studies related to this outbreak continue to 1)\nidentify factors associated with severe forms of RVF illness and poor\noutcomes; 2) characterize the role of specific species of mosquitoes in\ntransmitting, maintaining, and spreading RVF virus; 3) assess the economic\nimpact of the outbreak; and 4) define the impact of livestock immunization\nwith live, attenuated RVF veterinary vaccine on minimizing the spread of\nanimal and human disease. Taking measures to decrease contact with\nmosquitoes through use of repellents and bednets and avoiding exposure to\nblood or tissues of animals that might be infected are important protective\nmeasures for preventing RVF.\nLivestock vaccination also can be an effective means of preventing cases of\nhuman RVF if adequate vaccination coverage and herd immunity are achieved.\nAcknowledgments\nThis report is based, in part, on contributions by S Konongoi, V Ofula, J\nLutomiah, C Ochieng, M Warigia, Kenya Medical Research Institute, and R\nLindsay, Health Canada, Winnipeg, Manitoba.\nReferences\n----------\n[1] Daubney R, Hudson JR, Garnham PC. Enzootic hepatitis or Rift Valley\nfever: an undescribed virus disease of sheep cattle and man from East\nAfrica. J Pathol Bacteriol 1931;34:545--79.\n[2] Meegan JM, Bailey CL. Rift Valley fever. INFORMATION\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Tue 9\nJan 2007 [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200701090378.html>\n\nFighting in southern Somalia has hampered efforts to confirm a\npossible spread of Rift Valley fever (RVF) from neighbouring Kenya to\nthe Lower Juba Region where 7 people have died after showing symptoms\nof the rare, contagious haemorrhagic disease, Somali health officials\nsaid. The deaths were reported in Dobley, 18 km north of the Kenyan\nborder, in the last 5 days. 'The dead are mainly nomadic herders,'\nsaid Hassan Mursal, a clinical officer in nearby Afmadow hospital.\n'The number could be higher but because of the current insecurity in\nthe area there is no way of getting the full picture.'\nMahamud Haji Hassan Jabra, an epidemiologist with the European\nUnion-funded Somali Animal Health Service Project, said numerous\nreports of animal abortions -- a key indicator of the disease -- had\nbeen received from the area. But plans to send 2 teams to verify the\noutbreak would only go ahead once the security situation allowed.\n'Our focal point in the area has reported the clinical signs of the\ndisease but we need to confirm this by testing the samples\ncollected,' he said. 'If it turns out to be RVF it will have a\ndevastating impact on the livelihoods of the pastoralists, who have\nsuffered 2 years of drought followed by heavy flooding.'\nDobley is close to the Kenyan border where fighting continues between\nUnion of Islamic Courts (UIC) remnants and Ethiopian-backed Somali\ngovernment soldiers, who have been chasing them since the UIC were\nforced out of Mogadishu and much of southern Somalia. A humanitarian\nsource in the area told IRIN on Tuesday [9 Jan 2007] that casualties\nhad been reported when planes carried out air strikes in villages\nclose to Dobley. 'We have reports of 22 people killed by the\nbombing,' he said. International media reported that the planes were\nAmerican, targeting suspected al-Qaeda operatives.\n'Most of those killed were in a convoy of donkeys carrying sugar to\nthe outlying villages,' which have been rendered inaccessible due to\nrecent heavy rains, said the source, who requested anonymity. Another\nsource told IRIN there were reports of a number of armed militia in\nthe area. 'We don't know whether they belonged to the Islamic courts\nor not but some people are saying that they were there.'\nThe bombardment took place in an area known as Jiiro, a 'very good\npastureland, with the highest concentration of cattle in the Juba\nvalley', said the humanitarian source, adding that whether there were\nmilitants in the area or not, 'civilians had been hit'. The fighting,\nhe added, was making 'it impossible to access the area and help the\npastoralists'.\nAn epidemic of RVF is first manifested in unexplained abortions among\nlivestock. However, Jabra cautioned that 'some of the symptoms of\nRVF, such as fever, headache and muscle pain are also common in flu\nand malaria.'\nAccording to the World Health Organization, the disease is endemic in\nAfrica, naturally occurring in livestock but occasionally affecting\nhumans. Animals are infected with the RVF virus by the\n_Aedes_ mosquito. Characterised by bleeding from all orifices, it is\nspread to humans via infected mosquitoes; through contact with blood\nor other body fluids; or from the organs of infected animals. The\ndisease mainly occurs after heavy rainfall -- southern Somalia has\nbeen experiencing El Nino-type rains, which flooded many parts of the\ncountry. 'The conditions in Lower Juba region are conducive to an\noutbreak,' said Jabra.\nAt least 60 people in Kenya's North East Province have died from the\ndisease and last week, health experts warned it may have begun to\nspread. 'All evidence suggests that the disease is still spreading,'\nsaid Kariuki Njenga, a virologist and laboratory director for the\nUnited States Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Kenya. The worst\naffected districts are Garissa, where 100 cases, including 40 deaths,\nhave been reported; and Ijara, where 20 out of 42 people infected\nwith RVF have died. The CDC has set up a field laboratory to test\nsuspected cases and is helping the Kenyan government to develop a\nvaccination strategy.\nA team from the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation is also working\nwith Kenya, Somalia and Ethiopia to address the outbreak. 'Together\nwith officials from the WHO and various international aid agencies\npresent in the area, the FAO team is helping to draw up preparedness,\ncommunication, surveillance and response activities,' according to a\nFAO statement. Kenya: early warning system", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6478", "date": "2007-01-11 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA: EARLY WARNING SYSTEM\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 8 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: All Africa [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200701080142.html>\n\nKenya: NASA Gave Warning Over Deadly Fever\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe deaths from Rift Valley fever (RVF) could have been avoided if\nKenya had heeded a warning by an American body that changing climatic\nconditions posed a risk.\nThe UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) says the US-based\nNational Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Goddard Space\nFlight center sounded the alarm way back in September [2006], 2\nmonths before the 1st case was reported in Garissa.\nHowever, it is not clear whether the country received the warning or\nsimply ignored it.\nSince November [2006], more than 47 human deaths have been reported\nin North Eastern Province.\nThe center had warned that rising temperatures accompanied by heavy\nrains in the Central and Eastern Pacific Ocean and Western Indian\nOcean could spark an outbreak of the disease.\nThe warning was contained in FAO's September [2006] edition of the\nEmergency Prevention Systems Magazine, Empress Watch. The center had\nbeen monitoring climate in East Africa for several years.\n'The heavy rains being experienced were similar to what was observed\nin 1997/1998, when a major outbreak occurred in Tanzania, Somalia and\nKenya,' read the warning.\n'The outbreak of Rift Valley Fever is another example that requires a\nquick and coordinated response,' said FAO's New Crisis Management\nCentre manager, Karin Schwabenbauer.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The above newswire was circulated internally at ProMED-mail with the\nfollowing question posed by Mod.MPP: 'What would/could they have done\nto prevent the outbreak?' The response of our moderators definitely\nwarrants sharing with the general ProMED-mail community. - Mod.MPP]\n[What, indeed could they have done? There is no commercial human RVF\nvaccine available. The virus is in _Aedes_ eggs deposited in 'dambos'\n(periodically flooded wet areas), and when they hatch and adults\nemerge, they come equipped with virus ready for transmission. _Aedes_\nvector control in this large an area seems impractical and expensive.\nMoving people and their small ruminant animal RFV hosts out of areas\nof potential or active transmission also seems impractical,\nespecially along the Kenya-Somalia border given what has been going\non there over the past several days. The only feasible alternatives\nthat occur to me are: (1) vaccinating livestock as WHO proposes, (2)\neducating people not to handle or butcher infected animals, to\nminimize animal-to-human (non-vector) transmission, and even that\nwould be daunting with people spread over a large area of difficult\naccess, and (3) giving health care providers time to get ready to\nattend the human cases that would result from an outbreak. - Mod.TY]\n[A comment on some aspects of RVF in Kenya as posted in ProMED\narchive 20070106.0058 and our internal discussions:\nAs regards vector transmission, at least 30 species of mosquitoes\nhave been found naturally infected with the virus of RVF. Although it\nis stated that _Aedes_ species are the main vectors, considerable\ntransmission can be due to _Culex_ and _Mansonia_ species. In Kenya,\nspecies found naturally infected include _Aedes dalzei_, _Ae.\ndurbanensis_, _Ae. lineatopennis_, _Culex antennatus_, _Cx.\nsimpsoni_, _Cx. vansomereni_, _Cx. zombaensis_, _Cx rubinotus_ and\n_Anopheles christyi_ and _An. pharoensis_. Note the large numbers of\n_Culex_ species.\nIn addition, the tick _Rhipicephalus appendiculatus_ was reported as\na vector in Kenya in 1933. In Nigeria (1967) _Culicoides_ species\nwere reported positive for the virus as were _Simulium_ species in\nSouth Africa in 1953. However, whether these non-mosquito vectors are\nimportant epidemiologically is questionable. I would guess not.\nWhereas the eggs of _Aedes_ mosquitoes can tolerate desiccation for\nmonths and even years, species of _Culex_ and other genera cannot.\nTransovarial transmission was shown in _Ae. lineatopennis_ in Kenya\nand in _Ae. vexans_ in Senegal, but most likely occurs in other\naedine species. It has been suggested that such transmission\nmaintains the virus in nature during inter-epidemic periods.\nRecent epidemics in Kenya have shown the importance not only of\nrainfall but also of crop irrigation practices.\nIf logistics and finances allow, then ultra-low-volume (ULV) aerial\napplications of insecticides are the most appropriate method for\ncurtailing epidemics; or on a smaller scale, ground-based spraying\ncan be used. Commonly used insecticides include organophosphates,\nsuch as malathion and pirimiphos-methyl, or pyrethroids, like\npermethrin and deltamethrin, to kill the adults.\nInsecticide-impregnated nets, which can remain effective for many\nmonths or even years depending on the method of treating the nets\nwith pyrethroid insecticides, will only be effective at night, when\npeople are sleeping under them. Many of the potential RVF vectors\n(e.g. most _Aedes_ species) bite during the daytime, not at night,\nalthough in general, _Culex_, _Mansonia_ and _Anopheles_ species bite at night.\nIndoor residual spraying, whether in human or animal quarters, will\nonly be effective if the vectors enter such quarters to feed and or\nrest, and most potential vectors do not. By the way, one hopes that\nKenya will soon reintroduce DDT spraying of houses for malaria\ncontrol, as have at least 8 other African countries.\nWhat is meant by larviciding stagnant pools? Many, if not most, RVF\nvectors will not breed in stagnant waters but in relatively clean\naquatic habitats. Moreover, larviciding needs precise identification\nof the aquatic habitats colonized by vector mosquitoes, which,\ncombined with the often extensive nature of such habitats, means that\nlarviciding is not likely to be very effective. Moreover, when\ndesiccated eggs are flooded, not all will hatch; it may take several\nrepeated flooding and drying periods to stimulate hatching.\nLarviciding will kill only the larvae, not any un-hatched eggs. - Mod.MS]\n[A live vaccine prepared from Smithburn's attenuated strain of RVF\nvirus has been used for the control of RVF in non-pregnant cattle and\nsheep in endemic areas and during outbreaks, while inactivated\nvaccines for use in pregnant animals and in RVF-free countries are\nprepared from virulent field strains. RVF vaccines have been\nextensively applied in RVF-infected countries, such as South Africa\n(where both live and inactivated vaccines are commercially produced),\nZimbabwe, Kenya, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. For example, Egypt's annual\nmass vaccination during 2004 included more than 7 million\nvaccinations, of which 1 986 825 were in cattle, 1 259 195 in\nbuffaloes, 3 170 183 in sheep, 935 128 in goats and 95 308 in camels.\nBoth attenuated and killed vaccines are applied. Egypt's last RVF\noutbreak was reported in July 2003.\nIsrael, an RVF-free country, carried out preventive vaccination\nagainst RVF during the years 1979 -1981 in the face of the RVF\npanzootic in neighboring Egypt. The entire country's ruminant\npopulation and camels were vaccinated with a commercial inactivated\nvaccine and earmarked; the country remained free of disease. No\nvaccinations have been carried out since.\nAccording to OIE's manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for\nTerrestrial Animals, an inactivated experimental RVF vaccine has been\nused for 25 years in humans with considerable success to protect\npersons at risk. This vaccine is currently produced on diploid cells.\nHowever, the limited availability of the vaccine precludes its use in\nthe general population.\nTwo new vaccine candidates produced from human RVF virus isolates are\nundergoing extensive testing with a view to replacing existing animal\nvaccines. The 1st, MV P12, is a mutagen-derived strain of virus found\nprotective in young lambs and in cattle, but its safety for pregnant\nanimals is still under investigation. Kenya (Garissa) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6211", "date": "2006-12-28 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (GARISSA) (04)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mailis a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 28 Dec 2006\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: IRIN News org East Africa, Thu 28 Dec 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=56866>\n\n\nThe Rift Valley Fever (RVF) outbreak that has killed dozens of people\nin northeastern Kenya could threaten the livelihoods of pastoralists\nliving in the semi-arid province, after the government imposed\nquarantine on local livestock. At least 28 people have died from the\ndisease since it was reported 2 weeks ago. Hundreds of animals,\nmostly goats, in Fafi, Jarajila and Shanta Abak -- considered the\nepicentre of the outbreak -- have also died. Other areas affected are\nKorakora, Shanta Abak, Shell Gulliet and Shimbirey, all near Garissa.\n\nThe ban on movement of livestock -- aimed at containing the spread of\nthe disease -- comes just days before celebrations to mark the New\nYear and Eid-Ul-Adha, a religious occasion marking the end of the\nHajj, in which Muslims are expected to slaughter animals.\n\nOn Wednesday, local leaders in the provincial capital, Garissa,\nappealed to the government to declare the RVF outbreak and recent\nfloods in the region a national disaster, saying the disease had\nnegatively affected the welfare of the province's residents. They\nsaid the quarantine would affect their revenue because they could not\ncollect on livestock sales.\n\nCalling for emergency medical and food aid, Garissa Mayor, Siyat\nOsman, said pastoralists in the affected areas were starving after\nheeding the government's advice not to consume products from infected\nanimals. But the chief medical officer in Garissa, Shahnaaz Sharif,\nsaid health officials had held a meeting with religious leaders to\nadvise residents on the dangers of slaughtering livestock at home.\n'We expect that more than 20 000 goats will be slaughtered in the\nprovince at the end of the month to mark religious festivities,' he\nsaid. 'It is important that this is not done at home to reduce the\nrisk of humans contracting the disease.'\n\nThe disease was first identified in Kenya in 1931. The World Health\nOrganisation (WHO) says it occurs in epidemics in animals in Africa\nand is associated with spontaneous abortions in sheep, goats, cattle,\ncamels, and deaths in young animals. It can be transmitted to humans\nvia mosquitoes or through contact with infected animal material, such\nas blood or other body fluids, or organs. Consumption of milk, a\nstaple for many pastoral people, is also thought to lead to infection.\n\nFollowing the latest outbreak, Kenya's health ministry is carrying\nout clinical case management, surveillance and social mobilisation\nactivities, as well as mosquito net distribution. The aim is to\nreduce the risk of animal-to-human transmission via unprotected\nanimal husbandry and slaughter practices. The government also has 100\n000 doses of animal vaccine.\n\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n\n[The death toll in the Rift Valley fever outbreak in the North East\nProvince of Kenya has increased from 24 to 28 in the last few hours\nand seems likely to increase.\n\nA detailed account of the epidemiology of Rift Valley fever can be\nfound at the CDC web-site\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf.htm>), and\na map of the North Eastern Province of Kenya can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/kenya.pdf>.\n\nThe material contained on <http://www.IRINnews.org> comes via IRIN, a\nUN humanitarian news and information service, but may not necessarily\nreflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. - Mod.CP]\n\n[The temporary closure of abattoirs might indeed help in protecting\ntheir workers from exposure to RVFV infection. However, animals --\nparticularly sheep -- intended for commercial, veterinary-controlled\nslaughter, might join the numerous animals finding their way to\nuncontrolled ritual home slaughter during the coming Eid-ul Adha (31\nDec 2006 - 2 Jan 2007) celebrations. It will be extremely difficult\nto convince devout Muslims not to perform the traditional sacrifice\n('Qurban') which commemorates Abraham's sacrifice of Ismael. A rather\nefficient step in controlling RVF in animals and subsequently\nreducing human exposure would be mass vaccination of domestic\nruminants. Unfortunately, the results of such an operation might only\nbe seen several weeks following vaccination. - Mod. The World Health\nOrganisation (WHO) says it occurs in epidemics in animals in Africa\nand is associated with spontaneous abortions in sheep, goats, cattle,\ncamels, and deaths in young animals. A rather\nefficient step in controlling RVF in animals and subsequently\nreducing human exposure would be mass vaccination of domestic\nruminants. Hundreds of animals,\nmostly goats, in Fafi, Jarajila and Shanta Abak -- considered the\nepicentre of the outbreak -- have also died. \n\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n\n But the chief medical officer in Garissa, Shahnaaz Sharif,\nsaid health officials had held a meeting with religious leaders to\nadvise residents on the dangers of slaughtering livestock at home.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1931-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Fafi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "Namibia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6378", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya (multi-province)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6378", "date": "2007-01-06 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (MULTI-PROVINCE)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 5 Jan 2007\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n\nUpdate: Preliminary epidemiological data\n----------------------------------------\nThe outbreak of Rift Valley Fever in humans was first confirmed from cases\npresenting with fever, headache, myalgia and hemetemis in patients admitted\nto Provincial General Hospital, Garissa on 23 Dec 2006. The diagnosis was\nconfirmed as Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection by specific IgM\n[assay] and PCR [amplification]. After the first cases were confirmed the\nMinistry of Health (MOH), Centre for Disease Control (CDC) and the World\nHealth Organization sent a team to investigate and put in place control\nmeasures to stop the spread of the disease.\nPreliminary data show that 71 percent of all cases admitted with RVF were\nmales and 29 percent were females. Patients less then 20 years comprised\nless then 3 percent. The age of male patients was 28 years while the mean\nage of female patients was 33 years. The attack rate for Garissa district\nwas 19 per 100 000 people and the highest attack rate was in Shanta Abak at\n129 cases per 100 000. The first cases were reported from Shanta Abak.\nThe commonest presenting features were fever, headache, muscle pains and\njoint pains. The patients with severe disease had a bleeding tendency such\nas hemetemesis, bleeding from the nose and gums. A total of 86 percent of\nthe patients interviewed said that they drank raw milk and 71 percent said\nthat they had drunk milk from a sick animal 2 weeks before onset of\nsymptoms. Most patients lived near a swampy area. In all, 71 percent of\npatients had sick animals in their herds and 60 percent had lost an animal\ndue to disease 2 weeks prior to onset of symptoms; 53 percent had\nslaughtered a sick animal while 53 percent reported they had eaten meat\nfrom either a sick or a dead animal. Fifty-one percent of patients were\nusing a [mosquito] net.\nCases have now been reported from other parts of North Eastern Province\nsuch as Ijara, Garissa and also in 2 districts of Coast Province (Tana\nRiver and Kilifi District). Cumulative figures as of 5 Jan 2007 are 188\ncases with 68 deaths.\nThe Government has imposed a quarantine for animals in North Eastern\nProvince and also imposed a ban on slaughtering animals at home. The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. It has started distributing insecticide treated nets and\nindoor residual spraying and larviciding stagnant pools of water.\n--\nDr. S. K. Sharif\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 6 Jan 2007\nFrom: Mary Marshall <tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\nSource: Reuters Foundation AlertNet, ex MSF Belgium [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/msfbelgium/116801382768.htm>\n\nOn [Thu] 4 Jan 2007, 8 new suspected cases of Rift Valley fever were\ndiscovered by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) teams in the Ijara District in\nthe North-Eastern Province of Kenya. One of the patients died, taking the\ndeath toll to at least 67 since the outbreak began on 7 Dec 2006. MSF\nstarted battling the outbreak on 22 Dec 2006 when teams began work in the\ntown of Garissa, setting up facilities to care for patients in the hospital\nin which 23 people had been treated for their Rift Valley fever infection.\nToday, MSF teams are working in Garissa, Ijara and Tano River providing\ninformation, trying to locate infected people and treating patients.\nRift Valley fever is a rare viral disease of which very little is known.\nTransmitted primarily to humans through contact with infected animal\nmatter, such as blood or other fluids, or organs, it is also spread from\nlivestock via _Aedes_ mosquitoes. Consumption of raw milk, an important\nelement in the diet of many nomadic pastoralists of the area, is also\nthought to lead to infection.\nThe epidemic has been triggered by extensive flooding in the region. [A map\nof the flooded areas of Kenya, where conditions may be favorable for the\nspread of Rift Valley fever, is available at:\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fullMaps_Af.nsf/luFullMap/C1A04D85AE229930852572290055544F/$File/ocha_FL_hoa061116.pdf?OpenElement>.\n- Mod.CP]\nThe infected mosquito eggs are often laid around river banks and can lay\ndormant for years until they get submerged. Once covered with water, the\neggs become infected mosquitoes which spread the virus. The last large\noutbreak in the same region was in 1997, also following heavy rains. During\nthat time in Garissa District, around 27 500 were infected and 170 died.\nOnly about one percent of people contracting Rift Valley fever develop the\ndisease in a severe form. But of those who do, around half will die.\n'The great majority of people infected just suffer from headaches and\ninfluenza-like symptoms reminiscent of malaria,' explains MSF emergency\ncoordinator Dr Ian Vanenglegem, 'but the severe form, like other\nhaemorrhagic diseases, attacks the liver and can cause the patient to bleed\nfrom every orifice. There is no cure, so we are only able to treat the\nsymptoms.'\nOne of the biggest challenges of dealing with this outbreak is logistical.\n'Much of Kenya's North-Eastern Province is not accessible by road because\nof the floods, so the only way we can find patients is to travel by\nhelicopter,' continues Dr Vanenglegem. [An interactive map is available at\n<http://www.alertnet.org/map/index.htm?ct=2&style=2&ex_iso=ET,KE,SO,SD,TZ,UG&pcode>\n- Mod.CP]\n'Just to reach the Masalani hospital in Ijara can take up to 3 days by\nroad. It is estimated that up to 500 000 people are at risk from infection\nand this population is scattered over a vast area. We are sure that the\nnumber of cases discovered is only the tip of the iceberg.'\nAnother difficulty is the fear of the outbreak among the population. With\nsuch a high death rate among those contracting the severe form of the\ndisease, many people will see no benefit in making the often long journey\nto a health centre. To counter this, MSF teams are undertaking\nawareness-raising activities to increase understanding of what Rift Valley\nfever is and what measures people should take themselves. 'This is an\nimportant concern because it is likely that, with the flood waters being a\nperfect breeding ground for mosquitoes, this outbreak will be followed to\nby high numbers of malaria infections. The initial symptoms may be similar\nto those of Rift Valley fever. If people are too scared to come to health\ncentres, or simply don't see the point, then there may be even more\nunnecessary deaths,' concludes Dr Vanenglegem.\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n[ProMED-mail acknowledges contribution of the same report by Pablo Nart. -\nMod.CP]\n[The outbreak of Rift Valley fever in the North Eastern Province of Kenya\ncontinues to develop. The number of confirmed deaths has risen from the 54\nreported on Wed 3 Jan 2007, to 67 reported by MSF on Thu 4 Jan 2007, and\nnow to the 68 reported by Dr. Sharif in the above report. This\ncircumstance may enable the local authorities to control the outbreak in\nthe human population by vector control measures. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The\nMinistry of Health with CDC, WHO, UNICEF and the Red Cross have mounted an\nintensive health education program using electronic media, religious\nleaders and health workers to tell people to avoid contact with sick\nanimals, to stop drinking raw milk and to stop eating meat from sick or\ndead animals. Hundreds of animals,\nmostly goats, in Fafi, Jarajila and Shanta Abak -- considered the\nepicentre of the outbreak -- have also died. Other areas affected are\nKorakora, Shanta Abak, Shell Gulliet and Shimbirey, all near Garissa.\n\nThe ban on movement of livestock -- aimed at containing the spread of\nthe disease -- comes just days before celebrations to mark the New\nYear and Eid-Ul-Adha, a religious occasion marking the end of the\nHajj, in which Muslims are expected to slaughter animals.\n\nOn Wednesday, local leaders in the provincial capital, Garissa,\nappealed to the government to declare the RVF outbreak and recent\nfloods in the region a national disaster, saying the disease had\nnegatively affected the welfare of the province's residents. They\nsaid the quarantine would affect their revenue because they could not\ncollect on livestock sales.\n\nCalling for emergency medical and food aid, Garissa Mayor, Siyat\nOsman, said pastoralists in the affected areas were starving after\nheeding the government's advice not to consume products from infected\nanimals. But the chief medical officer in Garissa, Shahnaaz Sharif,\nsaid health officials had held a meeting with religious leaders to\nadvise residents on the dangers of slaughtering livestock at home.\n'We expect that more than 20 000 goats will be slaughtered in the\nprovince at the end of the month to mark religious festivities,' he\nsaid. 'It is important that this is not done at home to reduce the\nrisk of humans contracting the disease.'\n\nThe disease was first identified in Kenya in 1931. The World Health\nOrganisation (WHO) says it occurs in epidemics in animals in Africa\nand is associated with spontaneous abortions in sheep, goats, cattle,\ncamels, and deaths in young animals. It can be transmitted to humans\nvia mosquitoes or through contact with infected animal material, such\nas blood or other body fluids, or organs. Consumption of milk, a\nstaple for many pastoral people, is also thought to lead to infection.\n\nFollowing the latest outbreak, Kenya's health ministry is carrying\nout clinical case management, surveillance and social mobilisation\nactivities, as well as mosquito net distribution. The aim is to\nreduce the risk of animal-to-human transmission via unprotected\nanimal husbandry and slaughter practices. The government also has 100\n000 doses of animal vaccine.\n\n--\nMary Marshall\n<tropical.forestry@btinternet.com>\n\n[The death toll in the Rift Valley fever outbreak in the North East\nProvince of Kenya has increased from 24 to 28 in the last few hours\nand seems likely to increase.\n\nA detailed account of the epidemiology of Rift Valley fever can be\nfound at the CDC web-site\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf.htm>), and\na map of the North Eastern Province of Kenya can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/kenya.pdf>.\n\nThe material contained on <http://www.IRINnews.org> comes via IRIN, a\nUN humanitarian news and information service, but may not necessarily\nreflect the views of the United Nations or its agencies. - Mod.CP]\n\n[The temporary closure of abattoirs might indeed help in protecting\ntheir workers from exposure to RVFV infection. However, animals --\nparticularly sheep -- intended for commercial, veterinary-controlled\nslaughter, might join the numerous animals finding their way to\nuncontrolled ritual home slaughter during the coming Eid-ul Adha (31\nDec 2006 - 2 Jan 2007) celebrations. It will be extremely difficult\nto convince devout Muslims not to perform the traditional sacrifice\n('Qurban') which commemorates Abraham's sacrifice of Ismael. A rather\nefficient step in controlling RVF in animals and subsequently\nreducing human exposure would be mass vaccination of domestic\nruminants. Unfortunately, the results of such an operation might only\nbe seen several weeks following vaccination. - Mod. RVF is most commonly associated with\nmosquito-borne epidemics during years of unusually heavy rainfall.\nThe disease is caused by the RVF virus, a member of the genus\n_Phlebovirus_ in the family _Bunyaviridae_. The disease was first\nreported among livestock by veterinary officers in Kenya in the early\n1900s. and has since been recorded throughout East Africa and the\nMiddle East.\nA detailed account of the epidemiology of Rift Valley fever can be\nfound at the CDC web-site\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/spb/mnpages/dispages/rvf.htm>), and\na map of the North Eastern Province of Kenya can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/kenya.pdf>. -\nMod.CP]\n[Unfortunately, once again, humans play sentinels for a (severe)\nzoonotic disease, which is also a transboundary disease. She\nwas honored with the 1998 ProMED-mail Award for Excellence in\n --\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-08-07 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "Kenya"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6125", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Kenya (Garissa)(02): conf.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6125", "date": "2006-12-23 00:00:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - KENYA (GARISSA)(02): CONFIRMED\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 23 Dec 2006\nFrom: Dr. S. K. Sharif <sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\nSource: Ministry of Health, Kenya, Sat 23 Dec 2006 [edited]\n\nThe Ministry of Health in Kenya has confirmed that the suspected\noutbreak of a viral haemorrhagic fever in Garissa in the North\nEastern Province is due to Rift Valley Fever virus (RVFV). Results\nfrom KEMRI (The Kenya Medical Research Institute) laboratories have\nconfirmed that the samples sent from the Provincial General Hospital\n(PGH) in Garissa were positive. The RVFV specific IgM titers were\npositive as well as [results obtained] using PCR. There have been 11\ndeaths in Garissa District and at least 6 patients have been admitted\nto the PGH in Garissa. Two of the deaths occurred in the hospital.\nThe area has been affected by floods due to heavy rains since the end\nof November and many parts of the district are inaccessible by road.\nAll cases were in herdsman aged between 20 and 30 years. The symptoms\nincluded headache, fever, myalgia and bleeding tendencies.\nThere have been no deaths reported in abattoir workers or butchers.\nResults from sentinel surveillance sites at PGH Garissa also show\nevidence of past infection as evidenced by presence of RVFV specific\nIgG; this may indicate exposure to the virus during the 1997-1998\noutbreak. Entomological studies indicate increased densities of both\nanopheles and aedes mosquitoes in Garissa District and the\nneighbouring Ijara District.\nThere are reports of deaths occurring in areas of Southern Somalia\nbordering Kenya with patients presenting with similar symptoms,\nhowever it has not been possible to obtain blood samples from\npatients in Somalia. It is difficult to estimate the number of deaths\nin livestock in the area because of the inaccessible roads. Air\ntransport has been used to evacuate people stranded in floods and to\nevacuate patients in inaccessible areas. The Ministry of Livestock\nhas banned movement of livestock from the province and is starting a\ncampaign to vaccinate all cattle in the area.\nThe Ministry of Health with UNICEF and WHO have sent\ninsecticide-treated nets (ITNs) for distribution for all the people\nand chemicals for indoor residual spraying (IRS). Distribution of ITN\nhas been difficult because most of the areas are inaccessible due to\nheavy rains and it may be difficult to conduct IRS in all areas\nbecause of the nomadic life style of the population and the fact that\nmost of the areas are inaccessible.\n--\nDr.S.K.Sharif OGW,MBChB,MMed,DLSHTM, MSc\nChief Medical Specialist\nMinistry of Health\nKenya\n<sksharif@africaonline.co.ke>\n<pphs@health.go.ke>\n[Dr Sharif's statement reports the results of laboratory tests\n(serology and PCR) confirming the involvement of Rift Valley fever\nvirus in the outbreak of hemorrhagic fever in the North Eastern\nProvince of Kenya. There are unconfirmed reports also of human cases\nof Rift Valley fever to the east of Garissa in the southern region of\nSomalia.\nEpizootics of Rift Valley fever are generally observed during years\nin which unusually heavy rainfall and localized flooding occur. The\nexcessive rainfall allows mosquito eggs, usually of the genus\n_Aedes_, to hatch. The mosquito eggs are naturally infected with the\nRift Valley fever virus, and the resulting mosquitoes transfer the\nvirus to the livestock on which they feed. Once livestock (cattle,\nsheep and goats) are infected, other species of mosquitoes can become\ninfected from these animals and can spread the disease. In addition,\nit is possible that the virus can be transmitted by other biting\ninsects. Humans can become infected as a result of bites from\nmosquitoes and possibly other bloodsucking insects that serve as\nvectors.\nHumans can also get the disease if they are exposed to either the\nblood or other body fluids of infected animals. This exposure can\nresult from the slaughtering or handling of infected animals or by\ntouching contaminated meat during the preparation of food. In the\nGarissa outbreak, the detection of IgG antibody in abattoir workers\nand butchers, in the absence of disease, may indicate that the virus\nhas been present in insect vectors in this region undetected for some\ntime. In general humans are less susceptible to severe disease than\ndomestic animals. Humans typically have either no symptoms or a mild\nillness associated with fever and liver abnormalities. However, in\nsome patients the illness can progress to hemorrhagic fever (which\ncan lead to shock or hemorrhage), encephalitis (inflammation of the\nbrain, which can lead to headaches, coma, or seizures), or ocular\ndisease (diseases affecting the eye).\nPatients who become ill usually experience fever, generalized\nweakness, back pain, dizziness, and extreme weight loss at the onset\nof the illness. Typically, patients recover within 2 days to one week\nafter onset of illness. The most common complication associated with\nRVF is inflammation of the retina. As a result, 1-10 percent of\naffected patients may have some permanent vision loss. - Mod.CP]\n[Circulating RVF virus, anywhere, is bad news; its current timing and\nlocation in Somali is particularly of concern. This, in view of the\napproaching Eid ul-Adha (Eyd-e Qorban, the islamic Festival of\nSacrifice), which marks the end of the pilgrimage or Hajj for the\nmilions of Muslims who make the trip to Mecca. Eid ul-Adha is 4 days\nlong. Muslims who can afford to do so may sacrifice domestic animals,\nusually sheep, as a symbol of Ibrahim's sacrifice; this sacrifice is\ncalled 'Qurban.' This occurs throughout the Muslim world; the numbers\nof ritually slaughtered animals takes on huge dimensions in Mecca.\nThis year's Eid is due between 31 Dec 2006 to 2 Jan 2007. The animal\nhealth and public health authorities in the relevant countries have\nto exercise enhanced alertness to prevent the inclusion of infected\nruminants among the animals transported for slaughter. This relates\nparticularly to Saudi Arabia, where the virus has been circulating\nsince the late 90s, probably introduced from the Horn of Africa, and\nwhere millions (!) of sheep and goats, as well as large numbers of\ncattle, are to be slaughtered during the Eid. Human infections,\nfollowing their exposure to infected blood droplets produced during\nhome slaughtering, were recorded during the RVF outbreak in Egypt in\n1977-78. - Mod.
