Four new cases of the fever have been recorded in Ijara and\nGarissa Districts in the province, to bring the total number of cumulative\ncases in the region to 105.\nAddressing the press on Monday [1 Jan 2007], North Eastern Provincial\nMedical Officer of Health Ahmed Omar said that one death has occurred at\nSangailu dispensary, while patients from Bilbil in Tana River District in\nCoast Province succumbed to the disease at the Garissa Provincial General\nHospital last night [31 Dec 2006].\nHe said teams of 10 doctors were dispatched Monday [1 Jan 2007] morning to\nsupport other doctors on the ground to prevent the killer disease from\nspreading further. Three of the 4 new cases are recorded in Ijara, while\nthe other is from Garissa District. Omar said that due to the vastness of\nthe province, it was difficult to tell whether the disease was under\ncontrol, adding that he was waiting for reports from doctors on the ground\ntomorrow [2 Jan 2007]. He decried the impassability of roads in the region\nand the nomadic lifestyle of the local community, adding that the twin\nproblems have hampered government efforts to control disease once and for all.\nRift Valley Fever is endemic in Africa, naturally occurring in livestock\nbut occasionally affecting humans. Animals are infected with the virus by\nthe _Aedes_ mosquito. The disease, characterized by bleeding from all\norifices, is spread to humans in a number of ways: from infected\nmosquitoes; through contact with blood or other body fluids; or from the\norgans of infected animals. Symptoms of the disease include fever, general\nweakness and malaise, cough and diarrhea, with severe cases progressing to\nshow facial swelling and bleeding from the orifices. The incubation period\n(interval from infection to onset of symptoms) of Rift Valley Fever varies\nfrom 2 to 6 days.\nThe fever mainly occurs following periods of heavy rainfall. In 1998, an\noutbreak claimed at least 200 lives in the North Eastern Province following\nthe El Nino rains. Kenya's North Eastern and Coast provinces also\nexperienced heavy rainfall in November and December this year [2006], which\nled to massive flooding affecting hundreds of thousands of people.\n--\nJoseph P. We apologize in advance for an\ninconvenience this may cause our subscribers. - Mod.MPP]\nDate: Sun 26 Sep 2004\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\nOne million doses of expired vaccine found\n---------------------------------------\nVeterinary doctors in Jizan have discovered a million doses of vaccine\nagainst Rift Valley Fever (RVF) that expired a year ago [2003], according\nto the Arabic daily Okaz.\nThese sources said that the vaccines had been stored in a warehouse of the\nagricultural ministry branch of the region since last year [2003]. The\nbranch sent a report of the situation to the ministry but has received no\nresponse so far. The veterinary doctors have stopped supplying these\nvaccinations to cattle owners.\nRVF -- which usually affects livestock -- can strike human beings, leading\nto the victims suffering swollen brains and burst arteries. In 2000, RVF\nappeared for the 1st time outside Africa, with an outbreak in Saudi Arabia\nand Yemen. A total of 124 people, out of 884 infected, died in that\nepidemic in Jizan, which took months to subdue. Peters <cjpeters@UTMB.EDU>\n\nConcerning Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan)(03), it might be\nuseful to clarify a couple of things for ProMED-mail readers:\n1. In the newspaper article, it is said that RVF 'occasionally'\ninfects humans but has a high mortality when it does. In fact, human\ninfections are quite frequent. Humans are usually symptomatic but\ninfrequently severely ill. When hemorrhagic fever occurs, it does\nhave a high case fatality. The overall mortality from RVF is not\nknown with precision, but may be around one percent.\n2. Human infection does occur after 'close contact with contaminated\nanimal tissue,' but, it is worth emphasizing that freshly shed blood,\nand freshly dead animals, are the risk. It is generally believed that\nmeat from carcasses inactivates RVFV through post-mortem\nacidification.\nThese are not major issues, but, for the average reader, it would be\ngood to keep things clear. We are all looking forward to knowing\nwhether these are IgM antibodies and whether there are virus\nisolations. Recognition of transmission of RVF depends strongly on\ngood surveillance and laboratory testing.\n--\nClarence J. Peters\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch\nGalvesto, Texas\n<cjpeters@utmb.edu>\n[Dr. Peters's authoritative comments are highly valued. We did not find any\nsuspected RVF cases among them,' said Dr. Tariq ibn Ahmed Madani, an\ninternist and adviser to Health Minister Dr. Hamad Al-Manie.\nMadani was a member of the ministry's team who recently visited the\nregion on the instructions of Al-Manie following reports that 5\nanimals in the region tested positive for the deadly virus.\nDr. Yaaqub Al-Mazroue, assistant deputy health minister for\npreventive medicine, also visited Jizan soon after reports of fresh\nRVF outbreak in the region.\nMazroue inspected the arrangements made by the Health Ministry to\nprevent the spread of the disease as well as the progress of work at\ndisease combat centers. He said the numbers of\nmosquitoes had been brought down as a result of continuous spraying\nof insecticides. 'We have also intensified health awareness campaign\namong the people of Jizan,' the official said, adding that the\nauthorities had taken precautions to prevent the spread of the\ndisease.\nAgriculture Minister Dr. Fahd Balghaneim reported on Monday that 5\nanimals in Jizan (4 in Abu Areesh and one in Aaridah) tested positive\nfor RVF during periodic examinations. 'These positive results from the\ntests do not mean that the situation in the region has reached\nepidemic proportions,' Balghaneim said.\nThe minister urged the authorities to be cautious about the RVF\nvirus, which is capable of surviving in the eggs of mosquitoes for a\nlong time and can surface whenever it finds a hospitable environment.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has set up an early warning unit to monitor\nand contain infectious diseases affecting agricultural and animal\nresources in certain regions before they spread to other parts of the\nKingdom.\nRVF primarily affects animals but occasionally causes illness in\nhumans, in whom it leads to high morbidity and mortality.\n[Byline: P.K. Abdul Ghafour]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For many years it was thought that RVF infected only people who came\ninto close contact with contaminated animal tissue, while animals\nwere primarily infected by arthropod vectors. Most of the people\ninvolved were farmers, farm laborers, and abattoir personnel. Similar\nobservations were made during the 1977/78 major outbreak in Egypt,\nthough vector transmission there became more significant than before.\nExposure of humans to infected animal tissues may specifically occur\nwhen exposed to blood aerosols during the slaughter of viraemic\nanimals. This was one of the concerns of the Saudi authorities in\n2000, in view of the massive slaughtering of ruminants during the\nMoslem holidays. Such a situation might recur during the coming Eid\nal-Fitr holiday, also called Eid al Zeghir (minor festival). Eid\nal-Fitr marks the end of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month of fasting,\nand is celebrated during the first 3 days of Shawwal, the 10th month\nof the Islamic calendar. During these days, house slaughtering of\nruminants, mainly sheep and goats, is widely practiced, especially in\nrural areas. Eid al-Fitr is due this year on 14-15 November -- a\nseason characterised by intense vector activity in the Near East.\nVector control activities might help, but timely mass vaccination of\nsusceptible ruminants is essential in order to prevent the\nestablishment of RVF in animals and the subsequent public health\nhazard. - Mod.AS]\n[It is not at all clear that this is an outbreak, yet. The lack of reports of sick or dead animals or abortions in livestock does\nnot suggest that there is a current epizootic, but the Saudi authorities are\nquite right to take preventive action, to protect both their livestock &\nhuman population from the threat. These positive results from the\ntests do not mean that the situation in the region has reached\nepidemic proportions,' Balghaneim said. Exposure of humans to infected animal tissues may specifically occur\nwhen exposed to blood aerosols during the slaughter of viraemic\nanimals. Madani said his team checked all the files\nof patients admitted at Jizan hospitals for the past 3 months to make\nsure whether they were infected with RVF virus or not.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rift valley fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2004-09-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Abu Areesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aaridha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yemen", "country": "Yemen"}, {"location": "Jizan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "Egypt"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206511", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206511", "date": "2004-09-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "RIFT VALLEY FEVER - SAUDI ARABIA (JIZAN) (02)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 8 Sep 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Arab News, 7 Sep 2004 [edited]\n<http://arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=51118&d=7&m=9&y=2004>\n\n\nRVF reported in Jizan; livestock owners warned\n------------------------------------------------------------\nAgriculture Minister Dr. Fahd Balghaneim has called on livestock\nowners and breeders in the southern Jizan region to take\nprecautionary measures against Rift Valley Fever, after reports\nthat 5 animals in the region had tested positive for the deadly virus.\n\nThe minister, however, downplayed the new RVF outbreak, saying\nthat there was only 'a limited activity of the virus' in the region. His\nministry was implementing a comprehensive plan to deal with the\nsituation and prevent the spread of the disease.\n\nThe Agriculture Ministry discovered 5 positive samples of the virus -\n- 4 in Abu Areesh and one in Aaridah -- during periodic\nexaminations, the Saudi Press Agency said, quoting the minister.\n'These positive results from the tests do not mean that the\nsituation in the region has reached epidemic proportions,'\nBalghaneim said. [The correct word to use, when only animals are\ninvolved, is 'epizootic'. - Mod.JW]\n\nThe RVF outbreak in Jizan 3 years ago killed more than 125\npeople. In April of this year [2004], the ministry lifted a 3-year-old\nban on the movement of livestock between regions hit by the virus.\nThe authorities agreed to lift the ban in light of a ministerial\ncommittee report that said that the campaign to contain the disease\nhad been successful. 'The situation is now stable, as no RVF viral\nactivity has been found in humans, animals, or mosquitoes,'\nBalghaneim said, when the ban was lifted.\n\nThe minister urged the authorities to be cautious about the RVF\nvirus, which is capable of surviving in the eggs of mosquitoes for a\nlong time, and, can surface whenever it finds a hospitable\nenvironment.\n\nThe Agriculture Ministry has set up an early warning unit to monitor\nand contain infectious diseases affecting agricultural and animal\nresources in certain regions, before they spread to other parts of\nthe Kingdom. The ministry also established a laboratory in Jizan to\ncarry out medical tests and check the effectiveness of insecticides.\n\nRVF primarily affects animals, but, occasionally, causes illness and\nleads to high morbidity and mortality in humans. According to the\nWorld Health Organization, many different species of mosquitoes\nare vectors for the RVF virus.\n\n[Byline: P.K. Abdul Ghafour]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 8 Sep 2004\nFrom: Shamsudeen Fagbo <oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n\nComment Re. Rift Valley fever - Saudi Arabia (Jizan): suspected\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe [Saudi] Ministry of Agriculture must be commended for\ndetecting and reporting animal cases before detection in human\nsubjects. This was not the case during the 2000 outbreak. I hope\nthat more details will soon be provided. Helpful details would include\nthe types of tests employed (probably ELISA), the total number of\nanimals tested, the species tested, and mosquitoes spp. tested. No\ndetails could be found on the Ministry's web-site:\n<http://www.agrwat.gov.sa/index.php?newlang=english>.\nThe spread of the virus can be evaluated only if more data are\nprovided.\n\nHowever, the recurrence of RVF in Jizan is not surprising.\nExpectations of new RVF cases, due to floods and altered ecology,\nhave been discussed before (see ProMED posts 20031016.2612\nand 20031016.2606). There have been severe floods in Jizan, and\nother parts of South Western Saudi Arabia, with loss of life,\nlivestock, and infrastructure, in April and August 2004.\n\nAs regards the intended surveillance, this outbreak reinforces the\nfact that surveillance should be more widespread and of a\npermanent nature. The possibility of potentially exposed vacation-\ngoers returning to other parts of the country is present, and these\npeople may not be covered by geographically-restricted\nsurveillance.\n\nAdditionally, surveillance will not be fully effective unless\nawareness of the differential diagnosis of RVF is not practically\napplied. Other zoonoses/diseases such as brucellosis, Q fever,\nand malaria should be factored into a nationwide surveillance. This\nwas not the case during the 2000 outbreak [see Fagbo SF. Rift\nValley fever epidemic in Saudi Arabia: disconcerting\nepidemiological defects and lack of differential diagnoses and\nconcordance in studies. Clin. Infect. Dis. 2004 May\n15;38(10):1503].\n\nSome of the figures and lay statements from the Saudi Gazette\nnews wire definitely do not help to put things in perspective. For\nexample, to date, there has been no scientific proof to justify the\nclaim that the 'virus had reached the Kingdom from Africa through\ninfected sheep and was passed on by mosquitoes.' In the article,\n'livestock breeders' seems to be an inaccurate translation from\nthe Arabic original, a government press release. I think 'livestock\nowners' was intended.\n\nThe recent reports of active dengue transmission in the Jeddah\narea lead to worries about the presence of potential RVF\ntransmitting mosquitoes in this vital area. Monitoring and\nsurveillance in this area should also be enhanced.\n\n--\nShamsudeen Fagbo,DVM\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>\n\n[We are most grateful to Dr. Fagbo for these important comments\nwhich include scientifically-based, first-hand information. - Mod. No human being was detected\nto have RVF. There has not been a single case of RVF detected in humans,\nQahtani said.\nRift Valley fever -- which usually affects livestock -- can strike human\nbeings, leading to the victims suffering swollen brains and burst\narteries. [This terminology might be related to difficulties along the\nArabic-English translation routes; they probably refer to the typical\ncongested and edematous brains and to subcutaneous hemorrhages,\ncharacteristic of RVF in humans. - Mod. AS].\nThe results of these tests indicate existence of limited virus activity,\nsaid the minister. [It will be interesting to learn if this activity has\nbeen detected by sero-conversion in sentinels, viral investigations in\ntrapped vectors, or otherwise. - Mod. AS].\nBalghunaim said his ministry is moving to prevent an epidemic as in 2000,\nwhen RVF appeared for the first time outside Africa with an outbreak in\nSaudi Arabia and Yemen. A total of 124 people out of 884 infected died in\nthat epidemic in Jizan which took months to subdue. Additionally, tens of\nthousands of livestock were slaughtered to prevent the disease from\nspreading. The virus had reached the Kingdom from Africa through infected\nsheep and was passed on by mosquitoes.\nMost people get a flu-like illness when infected by the RVF virus. Some may\ndevelop serious symptoms, including liver or kidney disease. At least 30\nspecies of mosquitoes are capable of carrying it from cattle or sheep to\nhumans. People also can catch it by handling the blood or fluids of an\ninfected animal.\nThe ministry has already prepared a comprehensive plan for tackling such\ncases, Balghunaim said. Preventive measures taken in 2000-2001 had included\nsending teams to Jizan to spray insecticides. Qahtani said the Health\nMinistry has already started a medical survey of the area to define the\nmagnitude of the problem. He described the medical survey as 'active phase\ndetection'. The surveillance will be conducted on all the hospitals in the\nregion. Besides, the Ministry will launch a campaign for the eradication of\nmosquitoes, which are known for spreading the RVF virus, he said.\nHe said the Ministry of Agriculture will also engage in surveillance of\nfarmlands in Jizan to detect the disease if it exists in animals. Awareness\nabout RVF is already high among people in Jizan since they experienced the\noutbreak in 2000.\nScientists say that usually only one percent of infected humans die of Rift\nValley fever. The mortality rate in animals less than a week old is 90\npercent.\nIn late September 2000, before the preventive slaughter of animals had\nbegun, the Saudi Minister of Agriculture and Water said the virus had\nkilled almost 11 000 sheep, cows and camels in the Jizan port area alone.\nAt about the same time, Yemen reported 6000 dead animals. Total livestock\nmortalities in that epidemic, including animals that were destroyed and\naborted fetuses, is estimated in the range of 40 000.\nNoted as a disease in Kenya's Rift Valley as early as the turn of the 20th\ncentury (the causative virus was isolated in 1930), RVF has been seen at\nirregular intervals on the continent, particularly after heavy rains that\nfavor mosquito breeding. The 2000 outbreak in Saudi Arabia and Yemen came\nafter a prolonged drought both in the Horn [of Africa] and in East Africa.\nAnother outbreak -- in Libya in early 1999 -- was also not associated with\nrains. [RVF has never been reported from Libya; might the Gazette be\nreferring to the human cases in the Delta area, Egypt, in 2003? see ProMED\npost 20030827.2158. - Mod. AS].\nBalghunaim said that there is no cause for panic at this stage and that the\npositive results of the samples do not necessarily mean an epidemic has\nbroken out again in Jizan. He appealed to livestock breeders in Jizan to take\nall the required precautionary measures and to cooperate with the authorities\nconcerned in this respect.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The introduction of RVF into Yemen and southern Saudi Arabia (Jizan) in\nSeptember 2000 was the first occurrence of natural RVF infection outside\nthe African continent. The outbreak continued until the first quarter of\n2001, affecting humans and animals (mainly small ruminants) -- see refs.\nbelow.\nArboviral diseases seem to be seasonal in the Middle-East, probably related\nto enhanced vector prevalence and activity during the months August --\nDecember, c.f. bluetongue, Akabane disease, West Nile fever, ephemeral\nfever, and -- in Egypt and the Arab peninsular -- RVF.\nIn April 2004, the Saudi authorities lifted a 3 year old ban on the\nmovement of livestock between regions hit by Rift Valley Fever (RVF). The\nban was imposed on animals in Jizan, the Tihama areas of Asir, Makkah [Mecca -\nMod.JW], as well as Baha regions Qunfudha, Najran, and Tihama Qahtan. The\nAgriculture Ministry set up an early-warning unit 'to monitor and contain\ninfectious diseases that affect agricultural and animal resources in certain\nregions, before those diseases spread to other parts of the Kingdom' and\nestablished a laboratory in Jizan to carry out medical tests and check the\neffectiveness of insecticides (see ProMED post 20040426.1160). It might be\ninstrumental in investigating the possibility that RVF has become established\nin the Arabian peninsular, or in other words -- endemic, with possible\nperiodic outbreaks.\nThe current news seems to reflect results obtained by the said surveillance\nsystems; details on the species/tissues sampled/tested, the lab techniques\napplied and the results obtained will be helpful; in the meantime, the\ndisease remains 'suspected'.- Mod. Agriculture Minister Dr\nFahd Balghaneim, who announced the decision, urged precautionary measures\nto prevent further outbreaks of the disease. The ban was imposed on animals\nin Jizan, the Tihama areas of Asir, Makkah, as well as Baha regions\nQunfudha, Najran, and Tihama Qahtan. The RVF outbreak in Jizan killed more\nthan 125 people 3 years ago.\nThe authorities agreed to lift the ban in light of a ministerial committee\nreport, the Saudi Press Agency quoted Dr Balghaneim as saying. The\ncommittee, chaired by interior minister Prince Naif, included the ministers\nof municipal and rural affairs, health, and agriculture. The report said\nthe campaign to contain the disease had been successful. The situation is\nnow stable, as no RVF viral activity has been found in humans, animals, or\nmosquitoes, he said. The committee also took into account the\nrecommendations of international organizations related to contagious and\nanimal diseases as well as those of a panel studying the ban's economic effect.\nDr Balghaneim urged the authorities to be cautious about the RVF virus,\nwhich is capable of surviving in the eggs of mosquitoes for a long time and\ncan surface whenever its finds a hospitable environment. The minister\nadvised cattle owners intending to transport their animals from\nRVF-affected areas to other parts of the Kingdom to contact the ministry in\nadvance.\nThe Agriculture Ministry has set up an early-warning unit to monitor and\ncontain infectious diseases that affect agricultural and animal resources\nin certain regions, before those diseases spread to other parts of the\nKingdom. The ministry also established a laboratory in Jizan to carry out\nmedical tests and check the effectiveness of insecticides. The situation is\nsafer now, as tests of mosquitoes found that they no longer carry the virus\nthat causes the disease, the minister said.\nRVF primarily affects animals but occasionally causes illness in humans, in\nwhom it leads to high morbidity and mortality. Ecological\ndisasters such as floods can advance the emergence of vector-borne\ndiseases. With the recent floods following exceptionally heavy rainfalls in\nsouthwestern Saudi Arabia, large swathes of human habitation were inundated\nwith floodwater, with many people displaced in Jizan province and related\nareas. Roads were cut and connections with other parts of the country\naffected. The rains were described as the heaviest in decades.\nA geographically expanding arboviral disease, Rift Valley fever (RVF) is\ncaused by a phlebovirus [i.e. a type of virus with a tripartite\nnegative-stranded RNA virus genome classified in the genus _Phlebovirus_ of\nthe family _Bunyaviridae_, which with the exception of Rift Valley fever\nvirus is usually transmitted by phlebotomine sandflies. -\nMod.CP]. RVF-endemic zones are often predisposed to outbreaks following\nunusually high rainfall and flooding. Heavy rainfalls also preceded the\n2000 outbreak of RVF that confirmed the endemic nature of the disease in\nSaudi Arabia.\nThe risk of RVF resurgence within the region and beyond is very high. The\nabundance of potential vectors and the exposure of susceptible domestic\nanimals that are associated closely with displaced persons further\nunderscore the immediate and long-term risks. Mosquito vectors in the\nregion include _Aedes vexans arabiensis_, _Culex pipiens_, and _Culex\ntritaeniorhynchus_. Other epidemic vectors may enter and modify the\ntransmission cycle. _Aedes albopticus_, another competent vector, exists\nin the Makkah-Jeddah axis and may be more widespread than is presently known.\n_Culicoides_ spp, usually abundant after floods, are locally endemic. RVF\nvirus (RVFV) has been isolated from biting midges in Nigeria and Kenya.\nFlood-amplified populations of phlebotomine sandflies (competent RVFV\nvectors) as well as ticks play complementary roles in RVF transmission. In\nmassive numbers, _Phlebotomus_ spp., _Simulium_ spp., _Glossina morsitans_,\nand _Culicoides_ spp. may mechanically spread RVFV. The role of rodents in\nRVF epizootic and inter-epizootic cycles needs to be evaluated.\nSeropositive rodents in endemic areas may indicate enzootic activity.\nIn summary, flood-altered ecology often modifies local transmission\npatterns [and increases] the risk of transmission of RVFV to other regions\nof Saudi Arabia and beyond (especially during Hajj).\n--\nShamsudeen Fagbo, DVM\nP.O.BOX 122656 Jeddah\n21332 Saudi Arabia\n<oloungbo@yahoo.com>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A geographically expanding arboviral disease, Rift Valley fever (RVF) is\ncaused by a phlebovirus [i.e. a type of virus with a tripartite\nnegative-stranded RNA virus genome classified in the genus _Phlebovirus_ of\nthe family _Bunyaviridae_, which with the exception of Rift Valley fever\nvirus is usually transmitted by phlebotomine sandflies. The disease occurs in\nclimatic conditions favouring the breeding of mosquito vectors and is\ncharacterised by liver damage. The disease is most severe in sheep, goats\nand cattle, in which it produces abortions in pregnant animals and a high\nmortality rate in the newborn. Humans are susceptible to infection by\nhandling infected material and through transmission by mosquito vectors.\n\nEgypt was the first country to be affected by RVF outside sub-Saharan\nAfrica, namely in 1977, suffering one of the most devastating outbreaks in\nthe history of the disease. The government had imposed the ban 3 years\nago after cases of Rift Valley Fever [RVF], a deadly livestock disease that\ncan be transmitted to humans, were reported in Kenya. The country's\ndirector of veterinary services, Dr. William Chong, told the African press\nthat his country would immediately resume export of live camels, sheep and\ngoats to the Middle East. 'The government will now go into full-scale\nexportation,' he said.\nThe Kenyan government, he said, had in the past few months been holding\nnegotiations with the Saudi government, and the lifting of the embargo\nmarked a successful end to these efforts. The ban on the African livestock\nwas put in place in September 2000.\n******\nThe following additional information concerning RVF in Saudia has been\nderived from selected news items published recently by Arab News - Mod.AS]\n[2]\nDate: 3 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Arab News 21 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=30631&d=21&m=8&y=2003>\n\nAbdullah Orders Steps to Prevent RVF Outbreak\n--------------------------------------\nCrown Prince Abdullah, deputy premier and commander of the National Guard,\nhas instructed the authorities to take precautionary measures to prevent a\nrenewed outbreak of Rift Valley Fever (RVF) in the southern Jizan region,\nwhich has already been hit by torrential floods.\nThe crown prince's order to take precautionary measures comes after a major\nRVF outbreak [in 2001] killed more than 125 people in Jizan. The killer\nvirus affected more than 900 people in the region.\nSaudi authorities fear that the recent heavy rainfalls in Jizan could\ntrigger a new outbreak of infectious diseases including RVF as the rains\nhave created a large number of swamps, possible breeding grounds for\nvirus-carrying mosquitoes.\nHealth Minister Al-Manie announced plans to dispatch a team of doctors and\nspecialists as well as adequate amounts of medication to Jizan. Special\nvehicles and equipment for spraying insecticides will also be sent to the\nregion.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 3 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Arab News 23 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=30732&d=23&m=8&y=2003>\n\nBan on Livestock Import From Ethiopia Lifted\n------------------------------\nIn a move to cut reliance on a handful of Asian and European countries for\nimport of livestock, Saudi Arabia has lifted a ban on Ethiopian livestock\nand meat products. Ethiopia, an African state rich in cattle population, is\nthe only African country besides Sudan now allowed to export its livestock\nto the Kingdom.\nAn Ethiopian diplomat said the Kingdom's ban on Ethiopian livestock was\nimposed because of the spread of Rift Valley Fever (RVF) in his country. He\nsaid Saudi nationals own 2 major abattoirs in Ethiopia, which have a total\nof 5 facilities with a capacity to slaughter 1000-2500 sheep and goats and\n100-150 oxen daily.\nHe said the Kingdom, Kuwait, the UAE, and Yemen had been major importers of\nEthiopian live sheep, goats, frozen meat, and meat products in the past.\n******\n[4]\nDate: 3 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Arab News 28 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www4.arabnews.com/?page=1\u00a7ion=0&article=30974&d=28&m=8&y=2003>\n\nMinistry Takes Steps to Prevent RVF Outbreak\n-----------------------------------\nAgriculture Minister Dr. Fahd Balghaneim said his ministry had taken a\nnumber of precautionary measures to prevent a renewed outbreak of Rift\nValley Fever (RVF) in Jizan, where a previous appearance of the disease\nkilled more than 100 people.\n'We have supplied adequate amounts of vaccines for various contagious\ndiseases, especially RVF, and deployed veterinarians and other staff to\ncarry out the vaccinations,' the minister told Al-Watan Arabic daily.\nBalghaneim said insecticide continued to be sprayed at swamps created by\nrecent floods in Jizan. SOUTH AFRICA (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n[see also\nRift Valley fever - South Africa 990208191655]\nDate: Thu, 11 Mar 1999 17:42:46 GMT+0200\nFrom: Robert Swanepoel <bobs@niv.ac.za>\n\n[Paraphrased by Mod.CHC]\nThe potential epidemic zone had an ideal situation for Rift Valley fever\n[RVF] in January: abundant surface water following good rains in the whole\neastern half of the country. On that basis, I ventured to predict that an\noutbreak of RVF would occur. Within days we had reports of buffalo\nabortions in the Kruger National Park and a waterbuck died in an adjoining\npark. On the basis of virus isolations, PCR results and sequencing,\nhistology and immunohistochemistry, and antibody findings, we were able to\nshow that both were due to RVF; a giraffe death could not be to proved to\nbe due to RVF.\nBecause of a severe heat wave and lack of rain since then, the situation\npromptly changed. Predicted bumper crops are now teetering on the brink of\nfailure.\n\nRVF has evaporated.\n--\nProf R Swanepoel\nSpecial Pathogens Unit\nNational Institute for Virology\nPrivate Bag X4\nSandringham 2131\nRSA\nTEL: +27 11 321 4200\nFAX: +27 11 882 0596\ne-mail: bobs@niv.ac.za\n[We are indebted to Bob Swanepoel for bringing this brief story to a close.\nStill, although RVF has disappeared from the area, RVF virus surely has\nnot. This is as fascinating an infectious disease story as occurs\nanywhere. Unless and until we get a grasp of virus dynamics in\ninterepidemic/interepizootic periods, as CDC appears to be doing with\nhantaviruses in the United States, we will not be able to predict outbreaks\nwith certainty. Dr. Swanepoel's willingness to go out on a limb in this\nsituation took courage. - Mod.CHC]\n......................chc/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. (Abdel-Aziz AA, Meegan JM, and\nLaughlin LW (1980) Rift Valley fever as a possible cause of human\nabortions. Trans. Roy. Soc. Trop. Med. Hyg. 74:685).
